DOC.HEAD: Wife of Mail Bomb Suspect Pleads Guilty to Witness Tampering
DOC.TEXT: The estranged wife of a man accused in two fatal mail bombings has pleaded guilty in a related witness-tampering case, an Atlanta newspaper reported in its Wednesday editions. Susan Moody, 28, is cooperating with government prosecutors in their case against Walter Moody Jr., the Atlanta Journal-Constitution said. Moody was charged earlier this month in the mail bombings of federal appeals judge Robert Vance in Alabama and civil rights activist Robert Robinson in Savannah, Ga., last December. Mrs. Moody entered the guilty plea Nov. 10 before U.S. District Judge Anthony Alaimo, the paper quoted people close to the investigation as saying. Alaimo sealed records of the proceeding, and his action prohibits participants from even acknowledging whether a hearing took place. Walter and Susan Moody were indicted in July on 13 counts of obstruction of justice, bribery and witness tampering. They are accused of threatening two women who had been paid to provide a fake alibi for Moody during his efforts to overturn a 1972 bomb-possession conviction. The women were considering changing their story. Both Moody and his wife originally entered innocent pleas in that case, but Mrs. Moody changed her plea to guilty, the Journal-Constitution reported. Moody is being held without bond in the Atlanta Federal Penitentiary. Mrs. Moody, who has filed for divorce, is living with her parents in DeKalb County. As Moody's wife when the alleged crimes occurred, it is Mrs. Moody's choice whether to invoke spousal immunity from testifying, lawyers said. In a related development, a Florida man who had been holding three footlockers for Moody that contained diagrams for a remote control bomb was denied bail Monday. The footlockers found at the home of Ted Banks of Titusville, whom agents described as a close friend of Moody's, also contained five weapons, a book with bomb formulas, three pieces of pipe and several metal rods. Banks, 63, was arrested Friday on charges of receiving weapons while being a convicted felon. U.S. Magistrate Donald Dietrich denied the bond request, saying there was enough evidence that Banks was involved with the ``crimes of violence currently under investigation.''

DOC.HEAD: NY City Ballet Opens Season
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs Planned
DOC.TEXT: The New York City Ballet opened its winter season with a celebration of the 150th anniversary of the birth of Tchaikovsky, performing his music as choreographed by the late George Balanchine. The show Tuesday night at the New York State Theater was followed by a benefit party, with tables for 10 going for up to $10,000. The evening began with ``Serenade,'' which Balanchine choreographed in 1935. His signature was evident right from the start, as small groups of ballerinas with intertwined arms moved in intricate patterns. Balanchine didn't give the men, in this case Lindsay Fischer and Leonid Kozlov, much to do in ``Serenade.'' Maria Calegari, Melinda Roy and Heather Watts were superb in the leading parts. Merrill Ashley was an audience favorite dancing the 1960 creation, ``Tchaikovsky Pas de Deux,'' with Jock Soto. This isn't a romantic duet. It's a dance for dance's sake. Soto, an exciting young dancer, displayed impressive classical technique. The performance ended with the 1967 ``Diamonds,'' which Balanchine originally made the last part of an evening that included ``Rubies'' and ``Emeralds.'' Kyra Nichols and Adam Luders danced the parts created for Suzanne Farrell and Jacques d'Amboise, to music from Tchaikovsky's ``Third Symphony.'' Ballerinas wore real diamonds, on loan for the evening. Hugo Fiorato conducted.

DOC.NOTE: EDs: Members who used PM-Gulf-Reserves-Army, the list of Army Reserve and National Guard units called up Monday and transmitted as a0422 for PMs Tuesday, are asked to use the following. FYI, an accompanying story, a0516, PM-Gulf-Reserves 1st Ld-Writethru, was correct.
DOC.TEXT: An Associated Press list of Army National Guard and Army Reserve units called to active duty on Monday erroneously reported that three National Guard combat brigades from Georgia, Mississippi and Louisiana had been called to active duty. Pentagon spokesman Major Doug Hart said Monday the combat units were called up as part of a broad activation of reserves. On Tuesday, he said he had misunderstood the makeup of units called up and the three brigades were not among them. The brigades are the 48th Infantry Brigade (Mechanized) of Georgia, the 155th Armored Brigade of Mississippi and the 256th Infantry Brigade (Mechanized) of Louisiana. The Pentagon had said previously they would be activated, but no specific date has been announced.

DOC.HEAD: Store Firebombed in Incident Linked to Newspaper Strike
DOC.TEXT: A small store was firebombed and two employees were hurt Tuesday hours after a man allegedly demanded that the owners stop selling the Daily News, police said. The bodega in the Bronx section was heavily damaged in the early-morning attack, police said. Two employees who suffered slight injuries refused medical attention, police said. Officer Janice Swinney said police believe the incident was linked the nearly month-long strike at the newspaper because a man came into the store Monday evening and told employees not to sell the News. Violence has punctuated the strike since it began on Oct. 25. Many vendors, saying they have been intimidated, are refusing to sell the News, which before the strike was the nation's third-largest metropolitan daily newspaper. The Daily News, using management, replacement workers and returning Newspaper Guild members, has published every day since the strike began. But circulation has lagged. The News said last week that it was printing 600,000 papers a day and selling about 400,000, down from 1.09 million before the strike. It said 2,000 of its usual 12,000 outlets were selling the paper. The News has hired hawkers, including homeless and other unemployed people, in an attempt to fill the void.

DOC.HEAD: Typhoon Death Toll Reaches 335
DOC.TEXT: The toll from Typhoon Mike's two-day rampage through the central Philippines has risen to 335 dead and 205 missing, the Office of Civil Defense said today. The Nov. 13-14 typhoon injured nearly 500 people and caused about $275 million in damage to property and crops, the office said. The storm forced 3.2 million Filipinos to seek temporary shelter in schoolhouses and evacuation centers. It destroyed 116,512 houses and damaged 294,131 others, the civil defense office said. Most of the damage was in the Visayas islands of central Philippines.

DOC.HEAD: British Rail To Be Prosecuted Over Disaster That Killed 35
DOC.TEXT: The government plans to prosecute British Rail on criminal charges for a train wreck in south London that killed 35 people two years ago, officials said. Allan Green, director of public prosecutions, decided in May that there was insufficient evidence to bring criminal charges against the state-owned rail line or any of its employees. But Tuesday, the Department of Transport said the board that runs the network was being served summonses under the Health and Safety Act that allege it criminally failed to take all practical steps to ensure safety. On Dec. 12, 1988, an express train on its way to central London from southern England crashed into the back of a stationary train at Clapham in south London. The driver of the stationary train had stopped to report a faulty signal. In addition to those killed, about 500 people were injured. One summons alleged that by failing to provide effective signaling, British Rail did not ensure the safety of its employees. A second summons alleged British Rail failed to ensure passengers were not exposed to safety risks. The Battersea Magistrates Court in southwest London will meet Jan. 7 to decide if there is enough evidence to warrant trial. ``It is far too early to say how the board will plead,'' a rail board spokesman said. ``We will have to examine the prosecution case in detail and speak to witnesses as well before commenting further.'' Lawyer Sir Anthony Hidden found during a public inquiry last year that while rewiring signals in the area, a technician had failed to cut back a small piece of old wire. This interfered with new wiring, causing the signal to flick from green to red and back again. In September, an inquest jury ruled the 35 were unlawfully killed. British Rail has admitted civil responsibility and paid out nearly $2 million in compensation in 300 cases so far.

DOC.HEAD: Mother Wonderful Tells How to Bake Them Better
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Come on, says Mother Wonderful. Have some cheesecake. It won't kill you. ``No one ever got cardiovascular disease from a sliver of cheesecake now and then,'' says Mother Wonderful, alias Myra Chanin. ``Don't eat cheesecake three times a day, but when you do have it, enjoy it to the max.'' Chanin's book, ``Mother Wonderful's Cheesecakes and Other Goodies,'' first came out in 1982 and went out of print. The second edition now is in its second printing. Chanin, whose cheesecakes come in flavors like ginger pear, mocha blanca and honey fig, isn't surprised. She sees good food as essential for marital bliss. ``Soft lights, sweet music and diaphanous gowns may create an evening's diversion, but comes the dawn and even Casanova must eat,'' she says in the book's introduction. Professional bakers agree that cheesecakes haven't lost their attraction. ``We're selling more than ever,'' said Janet Rosing, owner of Cheesecakes by J.R. in Chicago. Ms. Rosing estimates she sells more than five tons of cheesecake a week. ``It's fun to visualize, isn't it?'' she said. Nancy Bier, owner of Miss Grimble Associates in New York, says people think of cheesecake as something special. ``When people want dessert and want to splurge, they say, `Let's have a piece of cheesecake.' Everyone likes the flavor and the fact that it's so rich.'' Miss Grimble's has been in business for about 20 years and turns out about 50 different cakes and pies, but Mrs. Bier said cheesecake still is the No.1 item. ``The classic vanilla with a sour cream topping is the best seller,'' she said. Several qualities come together to make a good cheesecake, Ms. Rosing said. ``It's a combination of creamy texture, which is very satisfying, and the flavors of the cream and the sweetness,'' she said. ``People feel they're really getting value in cheesecake. There's really something substantial there. It's not some light, fluffy thing.'' Even a doctor from the American Heart Association went along - somewhat - with Mother Wonderful's idea that a sliver of cheesecake once in a while isn't all that bad. ``I would certainly agree with a sliver now and then, but what does one call a sliver?'' said Dr. Alan Chait, chairman of the AHA's Nutrition Committee. ``And if you bake a whole cheesecake, who's going to eat just a sliver?'' Chait, a professor of medicine at the University of Washington, said the AHA doesn't preach the idea of good or bad food. ``The important thing is a person's total diet - a diet that is low in saturated fat and cholesterol - rather than the individual food,'' he said. Both the AHA's cookbook and Mother Wonderful offer low-fat cheesecake suggestions. Chanin also offers encouragement to the nervous cook. ``Cheesecake is the easiest dessert to make! How did it get such an awesome reputation? Bakers lie. When you find out how easy it is to make cheesecake, you'll stop paying $25 for theirs and start baking your own.'' She thinks the problem is the old-fashioned ways of baking. ``People are still using recipes that were created in 1850. Ovens then had no thermostats, so they'd tell you to bake the cake in the oven for half an hour and leave them in the oven with the door ajar. You couldn't leave the house! ``Then there are those recipes that tell you to put your cheesecake pan in a pan filled with boiling water! I think that one was invented by Johnson & Johnson, to sell more Band-Aids. There's no better way in the world to scald yourself.'' There's none of that in this cookbook. What Chanin does offer is advice such as how to get that creamy, custardlike texture. ``Since I never want to unwrap another package of cream cheese, I pass on all my secrets to you,'' she confides before introducing her ``Ten Commandments for Making Perfectly Baked Cheesecakes Every Time.'' Actually, there are 17 commandments, which Chanin admits tends to prove her husband's contention that she is ``bossier than God.'' Among them: - Thou Shalt Not Chintz on Ingredients. - Thou Shalt Never Defile Thy Crusts with Graham Cracker Crumbs. - Thou Shalt Never Even Think About Using Those Gunky Cornstarch Toppings. - Thou Shalt Measure Out Ingredients before Beginning to Bake. - Thou Shalt Always Add Eggs to Thy Batter with Thy Mixer on the Lowest Speed. She really means it about using the best ingredients. ``The cost differential between a sublime cheesecake and a third-rate one is less than $3. If money is a problem, make an 8-inch version and serve petite wedges, but always make sure anyone who tastes it will rave about your skill and beg for more.'' --- Here, for Thanksgiving, is a recipe for Pumpkin-Ginger Cheesecake, from ``Thanksgiving Dinner: Recipes, Techniques and Tips for America's Favorite Celebration,'' by Anthony Dias and Kathryn K. Blue (Harper & Row, 1990). Serves 10 to 12.
DOC.HEAD: Crust:
DOC.TEXT: 1{ cups graham cracker crumbs 1 teaspoon ground cinnamon 1 teaspoon ground ginger 1 tablespoon sugar 1 stick unsalted butter, melted
DOC.HEAD: Filling
DOC.TEXT: Three 8-ounce packages cream cheese, at room temperature 1{ cups sugar 5 eggs One 16-ounce can pumpkin puree, or 2 cups fresh puree 1 tablespoon vanilla extract 2 tablespoons dark rum 2 tablespoons minced crystallized ginger 2 teaspoons ground cinnamon { teaspoon grated nutmeg
DOC.HEAD: Topping
DOC.TEXT:
1{ cups sour cream { cup sugar { teaspoon ground cinnamon 2 tablespoons dark rum
In the bowl of a food processor fitted with the metal blade, combine graham cracker crumbs, cinnamon, ginger, sugar and melted butter, pulsing two or three times to blend evenly. Pour into a buttered, 10-inch springform pan and press the mixture onto the bottom and one-third up the sides of the pan. Chill for 30 minutes. Preheat oven to 325 degrees. In the bowl of an electric mixer, beat the cheese and sugar until smooth. Continiung to beat at medium speed, add eggs one by one, beating well after each addition. In a mixing bowl combine pumpkin, vanilla, rum, ginger, cinnamon and nutmeg. Mix until smooth. Add pumpkin mixture to the cream cheese and beat to combine. Pour the filling into the crust and bake for 1{ hours, or until set. Whisk the sour cream, sugar, cinnamon and rum together and spread over the cake. Allow to cool and then chill for at least five hours before serving. Can be made up to two days ahead. Cover and refrigerate.

DOC.HEAD: Australian Weather Too Hot for Crocodile Mating
DOC.TEXT: Queensland's dry hot weather is doing nothing, absolutely nothing for the love life of the state's crocodiles. Crocodile farmer John Lever says the crocs mate once a year and depend on monsoon rains - due around now. ``But with the dry, dry weather we've been having, there's no stimulus at all ... The crocs are all sort of lying about in anticipatory glory, they've gone off their food and they're listless, some of the males are a bit tetchy and we're all getting a bit anxious.'' He said the farm's ``passion'' indicator, a frolicksome female nicknamed ``the old tart,'' was stirred only faintly by a recent thunderstorm. ``She's always the first one to be switched on ... but even she has hardly batted an eyelid,'' Lever said. He said the croc exhibited some signs of arousal after the thunder and lightning, stretching her neck and blowing bubbles in the water, but she failed to draw any sign of interest from the males. A heavy rain was needed, he said. Otherwise, males could miss out on the female's peak once-a-year fertility period and the eggs would be sterile. Like all farmers, he said, ``we're really dependent on the weather.''

DOC.HEAD: Myriad Problems Nag Post-Communist Czechoslovakia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Gloom has replaced the euphoria that enveloped Czechoslovakia's peaceful revolution a year ago. Economic worries abound and Slovak nationalism threatens to split the country. Ordinary people are fearful without the economic security the old communist system provided. Economists forecast that unemployment and inflation will rise rapidly as the nation converts to capitalism. President Vaclav Havel, the former dissident playwright who personified the ``velvet revolution,'' has acknowledged the national malaise. ``A question is looming over this state: whether it is dying due to its own faults,'' he said in a television speech Oct. 28, the 72nd anniversary of Czechoslovakia's birth. ``We do not have too many reasons to be satisfied.'' Such national uncertainty has seldom been matched since the Czechs and Slovaks joined in 1918, after centuries of domination by the Austro-Hungarian Empire, to create Czechoslovakia. The two nations were separated by the Nazis during World War II, and afterward, Czechoslovakia spent 40 years as part of the Soviet bloc. Now, with the disintegration of the communist empire, Slovak separatism is resurgent and the threat of another separation has become real. Slovaks make up about one-third of the 15.5 million people and occupy the more rural eastern part of Czechoslovakia. Under the centralized communist government, nearly all Slovak affairs were decided in Prague, the federal capital. Discord between Czechs and Slovaks seemed non-existent a year ago; they filled the streets together to bring down the old regime. Czechoslovaia's revolution began Nov. 17. 1989, when police brutally beat thousands of students demonstrating for more rapid democratic change of the kind that was transforming Poland, Hungary and East Germany. The police brutality inspired street protests that toppled the Communist Party Politburo seven days later. Before the end of the year, Havel and fellow dissidents were in power. Havel visited several countries in the ensuing months. Back home, the mood remained euphoric, with rising crime and increasing nationalism seen as relatively minor problems accompanying the revolution. Because about 5 million Czechoslovaks were at least indirectly beholden to the communists, the interim government's campaign against the party was not entirely successful. In elections June 8, Havel's Civic Forum and Public Against Violence, its Slovak sister organization, won 57 percent of the vote. The turnout was 97 percent. The first economic shocks came after the elections. Food prices were raised, gasoline prices went up 50 percent and train fares doubled. Disillusionment spread and many people had a sense of betrayal. ``We disregard our everyday worries for the sake of discussing privatization ... leaving the spiritual values aside,'' Daniela Kolarova, an actress and member of Parliament, said earlier this year. ``We keep hearing the argument that, once the economy starts functioning, there will be time for the soul.'' Slovak nationalists have held mass demonstrations for months. In mid-November, thousands of Slovaks marched in Bratislava, capital of Slovakia, demanding secession. They were angered by their regional government's efforts to reach agreement on power sharing with the Czech and fed administrations. Some members of the Slovak parliament also have demanded a separate nation. The resurgent Slovak separatism cast a cloud over the 72nd anniversary ceremonies and led Havel to appeal for cooperation. ``I believe our reason, our sense of togetherness, our responsibility, culture as well as the instinct for self-preservation will prevail,'' he said in the televised address. Some people old enough to remember the two separate nations seem to be preparing for the memory to become reality again. ``It just may be that the end of the communist excursion into history could bring the end of the Czechoslovak experiment, too,'' a 78-year old Czech told a reporter who asked his opinion.

DOC.HEAD: Former `Gladiators' Tell of Secrecy, U.S. Contacts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: By MARY BETH SHERIDAN
DOC.TEXT: Every once in a while, Umberto Bilisco used to disappear for a few hours into the attic. His parents thought he was looking for a book. But Bilisco was on a secret mission. Working alone, the young state employee would carefully set up sophisticated radio equipment. As his parents placidly watched TV downstairs in their home in the northern city of Trieste, Bilisco would practice calling the contacts he would need during a Soviet bloc invasion. Bilisco was one of 622 Italians who belonged to an anti-Communist network recently exposed in Europe. Set up by secret services in the 1950s, in some cases with CIA help, it was coordinated through NATO. Throughout Western Europe, men and women like Bilisco secretly trained for years in how to blow up bridges, conduct secret radio conversations and organize a resistance movement in the event of invasion. The organization, in many cases, is only being dismantled now. ``I entered this organization with enthusiasm,'' said Bilisco, now 64. ``Here in Trieste, we had terrible moments after the war.'' Bilisco and a few dozen other members of the Italian organization have been exposed by the press since Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti last month disclosed the existence of the group, known as ``Operation Gladio.'' Those who agreed to interviews have described years of secrecy in which they were spirited off to military bases for training or contacted by strangers using code names. Several say they met U.S. military officials during their training in the 1960s. Their reports contradict statements by some U.S. officials that Washington helped organize the units but had nothing to do with them after the 1950s. Like Bilisco, most say they joined Gladio out of patriotism and fear of an invasion during the Cold War. ``Today, with things the way they are and the way Gorbachev has changed Europe, there's no more need for a service of this kind,'' said Mattia Passudetti, 70, a former ``gladiator'' from Udine. ``But if conditions were the same as back then, there would be.'' Operation Gladio has caused an uproar in Italy because of speculation by politicians and newspapers that it might be linked to a series of unsolved terrorist attacks in the 1960s and 1970s attributed to the right wing. But the members of Gladio - named for the swords carried by Roman gladiators - deny such assertions. ``All the things we learned were things that would help in a guerrilla movement, in the case of war,'' Bilisco said in a telephone interview. ``They never said anything about politics.'' The Italian ``gladiators'' received training at a base on the island of Sardinia and at a military installation near Rome, according to the accounts. Periodically, exercises were held in northern Italy. It was during such an exercise that Gianmario Pierantoni, 60, worked with American soldiers, he said. ``I only know that it was a group coming from Vietnam, the Airborne Cavalry,'' Pierantoni said in a telephone interview from Verona. ``We did a training exercise ... a Viet-Cong type thing among the hills,'' he said. Pierantoni practiced escorting people out through enemy lines during the 1965 exercise, which involved four to five Italians and a squad of Americans, he said. Passudetti said two American military men as well as some French- and German-speaking officers observed his training exercise in September 1962. Unlike the others, Bilisco said he worked only with Italians. The state land-surveyor entered Gladio in 1960 at the invitation of an old school friend, he said. ``I joined on condition it was an organization recognized by the state,'' he said. ``He assured me it was.'' Bilisco took a four-month night course at a local school to learn how to communicate by radio. Then, during a two-year period, a mysterious instructor who seemed to be a police officer came to Trieste frequently to train him further. The lifelong bachelor went to a military base near Rome three times for instruction with others, whom he knew only by their first names. The last session was in 1980. The group also held a practice exercise in the mountains near Bergamo in northern Italy, he said. ``My job was to receive messages and transmit the organizational plans,'' he said. ``We simulated a guerrilla situation. When a plane passed over, we had to hide.'' Bilisco has no regrets about his years in the secret organization. ``If by chance, during the training, I learned that there was something fishy, I would have resigned immediately,'' he said. ``I saw it was legal - secret, but of the state.''

DOC.HEAD: Fresh Turkey For 230,000 Americans in Persian Gulf
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.BYLINE: With PM-Bush, Bjt ^By EDITH M. LEDERER
DOC.TEXT: It looks like virtually all 230,000 Americans deployed in the Persian Gulf will be eating fresh turkey with all the trimmings on Thanksgiving Day. But just in case, the U.S. military has 600,000 prepackaged turkey dinners stashed in a warehouse. Since mid-August, Chief Warrant Officer Wes Wolf has been preoccupied with trying to provide American servicemen a holiday meal that will remind them of Mom's home cooking. For the 42-year-old major domo of military cuisine, that means fresh food rather than prepackaged, TV-style tray rations known as T-rats in militaryspeak. ``I've only got one unit that's going to eat T-rats, and I think I'm going to be able to get them fresh rations,'' he said. ``About 230,000 soldiers are going to be eating fresh rations.'' For five days now, Wolf has been overseeing the distribution of Thanksgiving dinner courses from three huge warehouses staffed by the 123rd Supply and Service Company from Alabama National Guard. Supply officers from 139 different military units, from 15 people to 35,000 in size, have been arriving to pick up ingredients ranging from shrimp cocktail to after-dinner nuts and ``Happy Thanksgiving'' banners. Tuesday was the day for salad fixings, vegetables, half a dozen varieties of fruit, 45,000 pies in five flavors, whipped cream and bread. Thanksgiving may be American but the ingredients for dinner are as international as the multinational force deployed here following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. The 60,000 pounds of rolled, boneless turkey from the United States and 2,000 whole turkeys from Saudi Arabia, each weighing 15 to 20 pounds, have already been picked up by units scattered around the country and are being prepared for the roasting pans. Because Saudi Arabia is a Moslem country, which forbids the eating of pork, the U.S. military has cut pork products from its menus. But Wolf said he decided to make an exception for Thanksgiving and include ham shipped from the United States. There will be plenty of other American contributions: shrimps, mashed potatoes, stuffing, cranberry sauce, fruit cake and pumpkin, pecan and mince meat pies. But the roast beef is from Saudi Arabia, the cherry and apple pies from Germany, the grapes from Lebanon, the oranges from Brazil, and the tomatoes and vegetables from Lebanon, Turkey and Syria. Ehad Kamal, general manager of Sanad Trading Cold Storage where the produce is kept, said he ordered 25,000 cartons of bananas from the Philippines and Honduras, each with 90 bananas, which means every man and woman in the military here will be getting five bananas. ``Too many bananas,'' he said with a laugh. The military also printed 230,000 souvenir menus, featuring a turkey on the cover and President Bush's Thanksgiving message inside. Bush will be dining on the same food as the troops when he flies in for Thanksgiving dinner, Wolf said. There is no front-line combat version of Thanksgiving dinner, known as an MRE or Meal-Ready-To-Eat that comes in a bag and is usually eaten cold. But Wolf ordered holiday T-rats so units without kitchens could still have a hot meal. ``We've got units coming in every night and I just wanted to make sure that on Thanksgiving, if a soldier showed up in Saudi Arabia, I'd be able to give him some turkey, some cranberry sauce, some mashed potatoes,'' he said. Two people helped Wolf plan dinner and 160 others worked on it. ``I've fed up to 30,000 soldiers at one time, but never this many. So, it's been really tough,'' he said. ``But we're in good shape with everything.'' With all troops expected to eat fresh food, known in militaryspeak as A-rations, Wolf will have plenty of holiday T-rats for Christmas and holidays next year, if need be. After Thanksgiving dinner with troops in the desert, Wolf said, he plans to get a good night's sleep and then get back to work on Christmas dinner. The rangy warrant officer from Monterey, Calif., nicknamed ``Santa Claus'' by Maj. Gen. William ``Gus'' Pagonis, the U.S. Army's logistics chief, said he started on Christmas two weeks after he began Thanksgiving preparations. ``I've just had to double my figures for Christmas because we're bringing some more troops in,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Prepares for Columbia's Long-Overdue Astronomy Mission
With PM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: After being grounded half a year, Columbia appeared headed for an early December liftoff with an observatory despite scientists' pleas that NASA wait another week for better viewing. The space agency turned its attention to Columbia after Atlantis ended a secret military mission Tuesday with the first shuttle landing at Kennedy Space Center in five years. Columbia is expected to blast off around Dec. 2 with the $150 million Astro observatory on a mission that has been on hold since May because of hydrogen leaks. Scientists, however, are pushing for a launch on Dec. 10 or so. ``The science will be much better if it's a few days later,'' said mission scientist Ted Gull. Certain objects of extreme interest, like the brightest visible quasar, won't be as close to the sun in mid-December and will thus be more distinguishable. Also, there will be a full moon Dec. 2, and an astronomy mission should take place under a dark sky, Gull said. Because of the delays in getting Columbia off the ground, ``We've always jokingly said it's going to be a full moon'' when the shuttle finally goes up, Gull said. NASA officials are expected to set a launch date after a review on Tuesday. It will be the fifth countdown since May for the mission, originally scheduled for 1986 but delayed until this year by the Challenger accident. Columbia's seven astronauts, four of them astronomers, are eager to get going. They will work around the clock in shifts during the 10-day flight, the first shuttle mission in five years devoted entirely to scientific research. ``We're going to be the best trained crew you've flown,'' mission commander Vance Brand jokingly told shuttle directors recently. Bascom Murrah, in charge of Columbia's prelaunch operations, said that when the shuttle finally lifts off, ``I don't know if I'm going to cry or dance or feel relieved.'' Columbia's leaks were much more extensive than those plaguing Atlantis. Workers replaced Columbia's hydrogen lines and installed new seals. Both shuttles were found to be free of dangerous leaks during a fueling test last month. Scientists have been working seven days a week since Columbia's latest launch delay in mid-September to revise the observing schedule. Astro's three ultraviolet telescopes and one X-ray telescope will probe about 240 high-energy objects, including galaxies and a supernova. One observation is planned of Comet Levy, which is on its way out of the solar system and less visible than it was in September. Halley's Comet was among Astro's targets when the mission was scheduled for 1986. Astronomers planned to study Comet Austin if Columbia had gone up in May. ``Every time we try to plan a mission with a comet, that mission has been postponed. We're beginning to wonder if it's our nemesis,'' Gull said. He joked, ``There's not a bright one coming (in December), so we can go.''

DOC.HEAD: School Isolates 8-Year-Old Because He Refuses To Cut Poneytail
DOC.NOTE: Eds: September in 9th graf cq.
Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto sent Nov. 20.
DOC.TEXT: Zachariah Toungate is a typical 8-year-old, hunting for rocks and playing with Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, and his grades are excellent. But his school says Zach is a disciplinary problem because he refuses to cut his 7-inch ponytail, and confines him to a 10-by-13-foot isolation room all day. His parents are backing him up. For more than six weeks, Zach has been parting with his third-grade classmates when they get off the bus at Mina Elementary School and stepping into what school officials call an ``alternative education setting.'' The room has two windows facing into a bigger classroom, but they are covered. To Zach, it is a prison that has given him nightmares about being trapped in a room that shrinks until it crushes him. ``They put me in jail, so why shouldn't we put them in jail,'' he says of school officials. Zach is taught alone. His mother, grandmother and aunt take turns going to school and eating with him because he is not allowed in the lunchroom. His parents, September and Stanley Toungate, were told the ponytail did not comply with the school's dress code. ``I like the way my hair is. I think the rule stinks because girls can have long hair and boys can't,'' Zach said Monday. Mrs. Toungate said she offered to pin the ponytail up, or even have Zach wear a short-haired wig. Aside from the ponytail, Zach has a crew cut. ``I've tried to compromise with them in every way,'' she said. ``All I want for my children is to go to a school in a place that doesn't discriminate.'' The Toungates appealed to the school board, and it refused to budge. They took their case to state district court, claiming sexual discrimination. The judge denied a temporary injunction that would have returned Zach to the classroom and back into the choir and art classes he misses. The Toungates' attorney, Charles Beall, said they will appeal to the 3rd Court of Appeals. ``I told Zach that if this is ever too much of a problem, we will drop it,'' Beall said. ``He says, `No, I don't want to cut it.''' Zach is taught by substitute teachers. He makes excellent grades, but would rather be with his classmates. Occasionally another student is sent to the room for detention, but they eventually leave. Zach remains. School superintendent Paul Fleming said Zach's case has gained more attention then it deserves. ``It's a matter that has a rather simple solution. The mother has a right to try and get a policy changed. The logical solution would be to get the youngster in compliance with the dress code and then pursue her battle,'' Fleming said. ``One of the things that students have to learn is that there are rules and regulations in life that you may not necessarily agree with but you have to live with,'' he said. Mrs. Toungate, who grew up in a military family, says she understands some rules are tough to abide by, but adds that she has learned ``you are an American first, and the rest of it doesn't matter.'' Ironically, Mrs. Toungate, who is studying to be nurse, and her auto mechanic husband moved 30 miles from Austin to this town of 5,700 people so that Zach and his 5-year-old sister, Linzi, could benefit from the country lifestyle. Now, they have become the focus of attention. Mrs. Toungate said some parents side with her, saying the school's dress code is ridiculous. But she said others accuse her of trying to usurp school rules. ``I want rules. Children need rules. My children have rules at my home. I want rules that apply to all students,'' Ms. Toungate said.

DOC.HEAD: After Just a Week, Couple Wins Race to Conceive
DOC.TEXT: The fun was over practically before it started when a couple who had entered a three-way contest to see who could be the first to conceive was declared the winner after just one week. James and Lisa Machamer of Des Moines will get a $1,000 savings bond, a crib and six months of diaper service as winners of the Breeders Cup promotion sponsored by radio station KRNQ. Another prize will arrive in nine months. Positive results from a home pregnancy test taken on Friday were confirmed by a doctor Monday, said KRNQ sales manager Scott Schubert. ``I don't think the contest made any difference - we didn't do anything different,'' said Mrs. Machamer, 22. ``That's the first question everybody wants to know.'' The Machamers and two other couples were among about 20 who responded to the station's invitation to participate in the Breeder's Cup, which was open to married couples without children. The three couples were chosen by lot. The contestants agreed to talk about their experiences on the radio each Friday. Schubert said the promotion was one of the hottest ever at the station. Schubert said the station didn't receive any complaints about making public the usually private ``trying'' part of conceiving. ``If it's done with taste, you can do it,'' he said. Mrs. Machamer said the publicity far exceeded her expectations, ``and I don't know if we would have done it if we had known ahead of time.'' She said she didn't do much talking on the radio. ``It was a little embarrassing,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Marines Practice Everything, Even Getting Wounded in Battle
DOC.TEXT: When the U.S. Marines practice war, they also practice treating and transporting the wounded. A mock invasion wouldn't be real without mock casualties. ``It does bring back the reality of the whole thing,'' said Capt. Robert Chaney, who is responsible for all of the Marines' medical assets in Saudi Arabia. ``People get hurt. Occasionally, they die. We have to learn to handle both. ``The Marines hav a saying. We fight the way we train. Well, we treat patients the way we practice,'' Chaney said. Even though the amphibious portion of Imminent Thunder was called off Monday because of 14-foot seas, the Marines held mass casualty drills involving about 80 simulated wounded at five field hospitals. Twenty patients were flown by helicopter to Foxtrot Co. Surgical Support, the northernmost of the field hospitals. Stretcher bearers scrambled into action after a siren wailed. They carried the incoming through clouds of powdery sand kicked up by helicopter blades, practicing skills the way an infantryman practices with a rifle. ``Practice dying,'' said Lance Cpl. Jimmy O. Hall of Atlanta, one of the mock casualties brought to the emergency room. It took just 20 minutes for the first Marine to pass from triage to pre-op to one of five operating rooms. ``There's probably not an emergency room in the states that can beat that time,'' Chaney said. No matter how much surgeons work on being prepared, nothing can ready them for the carnage they'll see if real war breaks out, according to Lt. Cmdr. Chris Kain of Bremerton, Wash. Kain, one of four orthopedic surgeons at Foxtrot, said even the knifings and the shootings he treated from the drug wars in U.S. emergency rooms can't compare with the killing tools assembled in war. ``We're going to be overwhelmed,'' Kain said. ``We're used to seeing those kinds of wounds, but not at such huge, huge volumes. None of us has encountered this tremendous volume.'' He described surgery under such conditions this way: ``It's fast and dirty. We used to call it slash and dash. Are we scared? Absolutely. Can we handle it? Yes.'' For the Marines brought here as part of their training, the experience of make-believe wounds was unsettling. ``War could start tomorrow. I always have that in the back of my mind,'' said Lance Cpl. Richard Flores, 20, of Anaheim, Calif. He had a simulated broken arm, and he said from his stretcher: ``I hope if we do go to combat I don't see this place again.'' Doctors take the drills very seriously, according to Lt. Cmdr. Steve Meister of San Diego, who runs the triage operation. ``We don't want anybody to die because of something we didn't do,'' he said. The field hospital, which has fewer than 100 beds but can be expanded, is lacking in amenities. The triage floor is desert sand. Operating rooms and intensive care units are under green canvas tents covered with camouflage netting. The dust kicked up in the desert sometimes settles on medical equipment. ``You don't have to have tile walls and beautiful furniture to make a hospital,'' Chaney said. But there is a sobering reminder of what can happen. One tent at the hospital is designated as the morgue. Two corpsmen have volunteered to work there. ``Yes, we have a morgue. That bottom line is that's a reality of war,'' Chaney said. ``Hopefully, we'll have very few of those. War is still war.''

DOC.HEAD: Construction Site Collapse in Downtown Washington
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 6-8: ``The Fire,'' with evacuation of building containing UPI headquarters; INSERTS penultimate graf; subway vibration feared. Adds byline
DOC.TEXT: A building construction site in downtown Washington caved in Monday night and firefighters tried to determine if anyone was trapped in the hole. Three construction trailers and a van, parked on the sidewalk on in the street adjacent to the site, tumbled into the cavity at 14th and H Streets Northwest, two blocks north of the National Press Club and four blocks from the White House, fire officials said. Fire Chief Ray Alfred told reporters, ``We think we may have seen some movement in the hole'' with a device designed to detect body heat. But it was not certain that anyone was trapped. Alfred said an employee of the contractor told firefighters he was the last person to leave the site. Special teams were readied to descend into the hole on ropes as officials sought to determine whether the site was vulnerable to further collapse. The Fire Department ordered the evacuation of an office building next to the excavation containing the headquarters of United Press International, said department spokesman Ted Holmes. ``There is still some movement'' of soil, Holmes said, pointing to a fire hydrant next to the eacuated building. The subsurface pipe feeding the hydrant was bare. But until 11:20 p.m., nearly three hours after the cave-in, the pipe had been surrounded with earth. The square excavation appeared to be about 30 yards on a side and workers said it was four stories deep. Darkness and the distance spectators were kept from the site prevented detailed observation of the rubble inside. Fire officials said the 8:30 p.m. cave-in apparently was set off by the vibrations of a faulty transformer, whose spectacular arcing could be seen for blocks. ``It lit up the whole sky,'' said one construction worker, who would not give his name. Service was suspended on a subway line running past the area, with trains turning back at nearby stations on either side. Buses were called to carry passengers between the Metro Center and Farragut West stations. The subway line was in no danger, officials. Rather they feared the effect of vibrations from passing trains. One man was killed in another cave-in at the site earlier this year.

DOC.HEAD: Inflow of Foreign Capital Seen Dropping
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. economy will no longer get $10 billion a month in investments from Japan, Germany and other nations because they now need the money at home, specialists say. But the money will be less needed here because the federal budget deficit is going down and fewer U.S. bonds will need to be sold to foreigners, the specialists said Monday at a meeting of the Institute for International Economics, a private study group. Americans are earning more foreign money by selling goods abroad because the dollar has declined in value and made the U.S. goods attractive for foreigners to buy. Some of the foreign money has gone into such projects as the Japanese purchase of Rockefeller Center in New York and made for bad feeling between the two countries. The Japanese had to buy the dollars needed for that purchase and many others by selling yen. Americans needed the yen to pay for goods they bought in Japan. As Americans sell more goods, they will have more yen at their disposal. The need for foreign funds could rise if war starts in the Persian Gulf at a cost estimated as high as $30 billion a month, said Rudolph G. Penner, a former director of the Congressional Budget Office. Otherwise, Penner saw the current slowdown in business as a short one, although the recovery sluggish if major companies have trouble finding the new capital they will need. Robert D. Hormats, a former assistant secretary of state, said Japan and Germany will be using more of their money at home. Japanese banks are having problems because the prices of stocks and real estate have gone down, he explained. Japan is also under international pressure to spend less abroad and more on increasing its own people's living standards. ``The estimated cost of German unification has now gone up to 140 billion marks (about $95 billion),'' Hormats said. ``Probably it'll go up again.'' He agreed with Penner that war in the gulf would bring economic and well as human and political problems. ``War has a voracious appetite for capital,'' said Hormats, who is vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International, a leading investment bank. William R. Cline, a senior fellow at the economics institute, said the U.S. need for foreign money has declined because the drop in the value of the dollar has made U.S. exports more attractive and brought in more cash. Slower growth for the United States as a whole slows down imports and the outflow of money to pay for them, he noted.

DOC.HEAD: Postal Unions' Demand Would Increase Stamp Prices, Management Says
DOC.TEXT: Postal unions' pay raise demands would cost $50 billion over the next three years and raise the price of stamps to 43 cents, according to a top Postal Service negotiator. ``We don't take it as a very serious proposal. ... They're in a fantasy land,'' Assistant Postmaster General David Charters said Monday, noting that the service's annual budget is $40 billion. The Postal Service and its four largest unions, which together represent 660,000 workers, were working against a deadline of midnight tonight to reach a compromise for a new contract. Moe Biller, president of the American Postal Workers Union, said Postal Service officials are ``the ones who are not in the real world.'' He said management always predicts huge stamp increases during contract bargaining to win the public's support. ``They predicted a 50-cent stamp in 1981 - it never happened,'' Biller said. Stamps now cost 25 cents. If no agreement is reached by midnight tonight, the two sides could agree to continue talks or allow the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service to appoint a neutral arbitrator. Under federal law, it is illegal for postal workers to strike. The Postal Service is offering a two-year contract that provides cash bonuses of $450 the first year and $500 the second year. In addition, the Postal Service would implement a pay incentive plan in which workers could receive bonuses of up to $1,100 a year if their divisions met certain customer satisfaction and budget goals. Management's plan would provide cost of living increases only if inflation rose more than 4 percent. For instance, if inflation rose 6 percent, workers would get a 2 percent raise. So far this year, the government's inflation gauge has risen 6.7 percent. Biller, whose union has 334,000 members, has called management's offer of cash bonuses but no hourly wage increases ``a piece of garbage designed to pit worker against worker.'' Biller said the union would reject the Postal Service's offer of no cost of living increase before a 4 percent inflation rate. Letter carriers and clerks receive a starting salary of about $24,000 and can earn up to about $31,500. Employees receive an additional $8,560 in benefits and premium pay. The service, no longer subsidized by taxpayers, must break even over time. Its board of governors has proposed raising the cost of mailing a letter from 25 cents to 30 cents next spring. Despite the huge gap in the two sides' positions, Charters and Biller said they were optimistic a deal could be struck by tonight. The other unions negotiating are the National Letter Carriers Union, with 234,000 members; the National Postal Mail Handlers Union, which represents 50,000 mail handlers; and the National Rural Letter Carriers Association, with about 42,000 members.

DOC.HEAD: Weathercasting Past and Future Goes on Display
DOC.TEXT: The National Weather Service is offering the public a look at weather at least 100 years into the past and at least a few years into the future at its new Science and History Center. Weather Service Director Elbert W. Friday Jr., said the agency is passing through an ``absolutely fantastic'' time, with new technology involving computers, radar, satellites and better communications leading to major changes in the agency. All the changes can be observed at the new museum, which opened Monday in this Washington suburb. One display looks back at weather work a century ago, recreating the Agriculture Department's 1891 weather observation office from Cairo, Ill. ``Some of those instruments look very familiar to me,'' John A. Knauss, head of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, quipped of the antique thermometer, barometer and rain gauge on display. At the other end of the scale are operating satellite and radar displays, showing national weather patterns and specific events in the Washington area. Dramatic photos of storm scenes line one wall of the new museum on the ground floor of the Weather Service's new headquarters building. Another wall is glass, affording a view of whatever weather is happening at the moment. Video monitors provide the satellite and radar displays along with current forecasts for the area. Other displays include: -A model of a NOAA hurricane hunter airplane. -A transportable tornado research instrument designed to be placed in the path of tornadoes to measure the wind and pressure within the twisters. These Transportable Tornado Observatories are known as ``Toto,'' after the little dog caught up in the tornado in ``The Wizard of Oz.'' -A scale model of one of NOAA's weather satellites, constructed by students at the Unionville, Pa., high school. -A bank of telephones hooked to NOAA weather radio, providing current forecasts for the Washington area.

DOC.HEAD: Teamsters in Turmoil Over Aide's Firing
DOC.TEXT: A top aide to retiring Teamsters' President William McCarthy says he was fired because he decided to run for the presidency himself rather than back McCarthy's choice for a successor. Walter Shea, a 34-year Teamsters' veteran, said Monday that McCarthy fired him on Friday after he told McCarthy he would seek the union's top post in next year's government-supervised elections. The firing has brought new turmoil to the union, prompting complaints that McCarthy is trying to manipulate the election, which was ordered by the Justice Department as part of the settlement of its massive civil racketeering suit against the union. Next year's election will be the first in the Teamsters' 87-year history in which rank-and-file members vote for union leaders. McCarthy is ``on a vendetta. ... He is on a seek-and-destroy mission. He would destroy the entire international union just to get his way,'' said Jack Cox, a Teamsters' vice president from Los Angeles who has been at odds with McCarthy. Phone calls to McCarthy's spokesman were not returned. Cox said he believes that McCarthy, who decided to retire for health reasons, fired Shea because Shea refused to back McCarthy's ``hand-anointed'' candidate, R.V. Durham of North Carolina. Shea, a Teamsters' vice president who has served every union president since Jimmy Hoffa, said that after he told McCarthy he was running for president, McCarthy ``advised me to clean out my desk `because you're not loyal to me.''' The job from which McCarthy was fired paid about $75,000 a year; he will continue to receive his vice presidential salary of about $75,000. At a Teamsters' board meeting last month, McCarthy announced he would retire, citing personal reasons. That prompted a majority of the board, with McCarthy's approval, to endorse Durham, a union vice president, as the candidate to replace McCarthy. The December 1991 elections were agreed to by the union board last year as part of the settlement of a massive civil racketeering suit brought by the Justice Department. Over the last several months, court-appointed officers have moved to oust local union leaders still accused of organized crime ties. The elections will be secret ballot voting by the 1.6 million union members. In previous elections, only union leaders got to vote. Shea said he decided to run for the union's top post because he thought the troubled union needed new leadership. ``The way people perceive this union today is rather dim. I think it's attributable in part to our leadership. I think I could change that around,'' he said. ``I'm not coming in from a truck or a local or the left field or the right field. With the right leadership, I think we can turn this union around.'' Besides Durham and Shea, Ron Carey, a local president from New York, is mounting an independent campaign for the Teamsters' presidency.

DOC.HEAD: New Prime Ministers of India, Pakistan To Meet
DOC.TEXT: Barely two weeks in office, the prime ministers of India and Pakistan meet on Wednesday in the first top-level contact in two years between their antagonistic, neighboring nations. The timing of their meeting at a summit conference of the South Asia Association of Regional Cooperation so soon after each took office is a coincidence. No one expects them to start tackling the problems which last spring brought their countries to the brink of their fourth war in 43 years. Chandra Shekhar was installed as prime minister in New Delhi on Nov. 10 after the government of V.P. Singh collapsed. Nawaz Sharif took office in Pakistan three days earlier following the ouster of the Benazir Bhutto government and a general election. The three-day summit brings together two men with no experience in foreign affairs who are preoccupied with domestic politics and with their still unsettled governments. Under the rules of the association, it does not deal with bilateral issues. Officials of both countries also say corridor diplomacy will be minimal, with neither side ready to get into tough questions. But the encounter could lead to a resumption of talks on reducing tensions along the frontier, which saw the two armies mobilized for war last April. ``It can happen that we will be authorized to meet again,'' said India's senior diplomat, Muchkund Dubey. The talks, initiated through U.S. diplomacy, were interrupted by the political upheavals in Islamabad and New Delhi. Two previous sessions in July and August produced no visible gains. ``The differences between us are fundamental and substantive. We are dealing with big, big issues,'' said a Pakistani diplomat, speaking on condition he not be identified. The latest flare-up was over the province of Kashmir. Moslem militants there are seeking to splinter off from Hindu-dominated India, either to join Islamic Pakistan or to become independent. The long-simmering insurgency exploded into a guerrilla war in January. Since then, more than 1,550 people have been killed and economic activity has halted in what was once a highly popular tourist spot. India accuses Pakistan of supplying arms and training to the insurgents, and helping them slip across the mountainous frontier. Pakistan denies actively aiding the guerrillas, but supports their cause diplomatically. It also suspects India of stirring up troubles in its own Sind province. Previous talks failed because India limited them to practical steps toward confidence-building, and Pakistan wanted to discuss the underlying issue of the political future of Jammu and Kashmir state. The two armies frequently traded artillery fire during the summer. Both sides dismissed the incidents as minor. The South Asian association was formed six years ago, ostensibly to promote regional projects and economic cooperation. It was also a forum for the small countries to band together against what they saw as Indian domination. Its concrete achievements are meager - an anti-terrorism convention, a draft agreement on harmonizing narcotics laws, and the lifting of visa requirements for Supreme Court justices and members of parliaments. The conference comes at an unsettled time for all members except the Maldives, a string of 1,190 idyllic coral islands south of India with 200,000 people. The other six nations represent one-fifth of the world's population, and are among the poorest countries. Each is in transition. President R. Premadasa of Sri Lanka declined to attend the summit, saying he could not leave as long as the ethnic war continues between the dominant Sinhalese and the minority Tamils, who want their own homeland. The war has claimed 14,000 lives in the last seven years. Bangladesh's president, former army Gen. Mohamed Hussain Ershad, is facing a renewed challenge from opposition groups demanding his resignation. Ershad seized power in 1982. His foes say the three elections that kept him in office were rigged. They want him out before the presidential vote due next year. King Birendra of Nepal yielded this spring to a popular uprising for democracy, which killed at least 300 people. This month, he promulgated a new constitution relinquishing his absolute power. Bhutan's King Jigme Singye Wangchuk is trying to preserve his country's culture in the face of pressures from Nepalese immigrants, who dislike laws demanding that they adopt Bhutanese dress and language. Reports from the Himalayan kingdom speak of dozens killed in clashes with police and of kidnapping by Nepalese dissidents. Indian political analyst Bhabani Sen Gupta wrote in New Delhi that stability in each country is a prerequisite for raising the region from the economic and social basement. If the summit can ``cool down ... narrow nationalist and sectarian passions,'' he said, ``it will have made its name in the history of South Asia.''

DOC.HEAD: Survey Finds Bankers Tightening on Loans
DOC.TEXT: Bankers are getting increasingly cautious about making loans, particularly to commercial real estate developers but also to other corporate borrowers and home buyers, a Federal Reserve Board survey finds. Compared with a similar poll three months earlier, the latest survey ``generally painted a picture of increased credit restraint, with agencies and branches of foreign banks reporting more tightening than domestic banks,'' the central bank said Monday. ``The pullback was least evident in consumer and home mortgage lending and was clearest in commercial real estate lending, a category for which a large majority of respondents continued to raise their credit standards,'' it said. The October survey of senior loan officers at 60 large banks comes as Bush administration officials are showing growing concern that a shortage of credit is deepening the economic downturn. Financial institutions and some borrowers have complained for months that bank and savings and loan examiners have overreacted to the thrift crisis by discouraging even sound loans. The regulators, however, say they are only urging prudence in response to the weaker economy. President Bush met with top administration officials on the situation last week. Chief of staff John Sununu, Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher and budget director Richard Darman reportedly said the examiners should ease up, while Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady and Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan argued that the closer scrutiny of lending is appropriate. ``There perhaps have been some regulators that have been overzealous at times,'' said Michael Boskin, Bush's chief economic adviser. ``We need to make sure they are prudent and do enforce the safety requirements ... but I think it is likely the case that some, seeing the S&L situaion, have perhaps inadvertently overreacted,'' Boskin said when asked about Monday's survey at a National Press Club lunch. He added that some banks have been forced to make fewer loans in response to stricter capital standards taking effect Jan. 1 under an international accord. Banks that cannot raise additional capital have little choice but to restrict the number of new loans they make while they build their capital gradually by retaining earnings. Nearly two-thirds of the respondents in the Fed poll reported tightening lending standards for commercial real estate loans, while almost half of the respondents had tightened lending standards for non-real estate commercial and industrial loans to large corporations. They most often cited ``a deterioration in the economic outlook'' and ``problems specific to individual industries'' for the greater restraint, the report said. About one-fifth of the banks surveyed said their capital position restricted new lending, while two-thirds said it had no effect. ``Home mortgage lending remained relatively favored,'' the Federal Reserve said. But it noted that more U.S. banks, particularly in the Northeast, are reporting tighter standards even for those loans. About one in four of the banks said they were either requiring a higher down payment on home mortgages or had raised the household income needed to qualify for a loan. ``In sum, the results of this lending practices survey suggest that a deterioration in the general economic outlook since summer has prompted a sizable share of domestic respondents to tighten credit standards more,'' the central bank said. In addition to scrutinizing borrowers more closely, about half the banks said they had raised their loan fees and charged a bigger spread over base interest rates. Between one-third and one-half are requiring better collateral.

DOC.HEAD: Officials: Joint Operation Practically Wipes Out Hawaii Marijuana Crop
DOC.TEXT: Hawaii's billion-dollar marijuana industry has been dealt a potentially fatal blow by a federal, state and county crackdown that used space-age surveillance and pinpoint aerial spraying of herbicide, authorities say. About 90 percent of Hawaii's summer marijuana crop has been destroyed in Operation Wipeout, the biggest joint agency crackdown in Hawaii history and one of the largest in the nation, state Attorney General Warren Price said Monday. ``Law enforcement intelligence sources report that the industry is now in shambles, with growers leaving the state or turning to legitimate businesses,'' Price said. In three months, the statewide operation that had the blessing of just-resigned drug policy chief William Bennett destroyed 785,000 plants worth $1.1 billion on the street, officials said. Price said the sweep was made possible by ``space-age intelligence gathering and photo identification methods.'' He declined to say whether that meant military satellites were used to pinpoint the marijuana crops, saying only that information on the Pentagon's involvement was classified. Marijuana, or ``pakalolo,'' is the state's No. 1 cash crop and is grown year-round, mostly on the island of Hawaii. The state is among the biggest pot producers in the nation. Price said the entire state was photograhed in grids. Once marijuana-growing areas were identified, herbicide was sprayed from helicopters or officers uprooted the plants. Price said the areas would be checked periodically to ensure more pot is not planted. Checks over the past few weeks turned up only one replanted plot, he said. ``The marijuana industry in Hawaii is not yet dead, but it is severely wounded,'' Price said. ``Over the next several months we feel we can destroy the remnants of the industry and eliminate it in its entirety once and for all.'' William Paty, director of the state Department of Land and Natural Resources, said herbicide nozzles developed by the department were a key weapon. The nozzle, attached to a hose suspended from the belly of a helicopter, allows pinpoint eradication of marijuana plants in remote areas without harming nearby foliage, he said. Joseph Parra, head of the Drug Enforcement Administration in Hawaii, said Operation Wipeout has driven the street price of Hawaii marijuana from between $1,600 and $2,200 a pound to between $4,600 and $6,000 a pound. Hawaii officials have previously been criticized as being too easy on marijuana growers. Besides serving as an example for other states, Operation Wipeout ``could be used to show foreign governments that we're trying to resolve our drug problems at home, and not just asking them to spray their plants,'' Parra said.

DOC.HEAD: Summit Shows Paradoxes of Peace and War
With PM-Summit Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The leaders have come to make peace in Europe. For all but the privileged thousands who have security or press reasons to penetrate security barriers, it's a short television spectacle. On Monday afternoon, a few dozen people wanted actually to see the leaders step from their limousines at the congress center at Avenue Kleber, a few hundred yards from the Arc de Triomphe in Paris. They couldn't even get close. One of the 10,000 or so policemen deployed around Paris in uniform or disguised as street sweepers and vendors even had the grace to smile. ``I know it's madness,'' he said. ``But I can do nothing.'' --- Gorbachev warned in his speech Monday that ethnic conflicts could have ``a destructive snowball effect,'' especially if separatists achieve changes in the borders adopted after World War II in Europe. The Helsinki Final Act of 1975, the basis of the process celebrated by 34 participating nations at their current summit, aimed to make those borders final, regardless of the many border changes of the past and still raging rival ethnic claims. But what of borders inside countries? They apparently are not included. And so, on Monday, the foreign ministers of the three Baltic republics were rejected as summit observers, because the Soviet Union - of which they are nominally part - rejected their claim to any kind of independent voice. --- The Baltics and isolationist Albania, already an observer but lacking full membership, craved a place at the summit table. So, apparently, did an uninvited guest - Saddam Hussein. The Iraqi leader, probably aware that President Bush would use Paris as a forum to muster yet more international support for his policy in the Persian Gulf, used Sunday and Monday to announce what appeared to be major moves. Questions about Iraq's decision to start releasing foreign hostages before Christmas and its move to deploy up to 250,000 more troops in Kuwait peppered every news conference, overshadowing peace rhetoric and the historic accord to slash conventional arms. ``Saddam Hussein invites himself to Paris,'' the Paris daily Liberation commented Monday. --- And, indeed, Saddam's shadow cast a pall not seen from the sunny sky in Paris on Monday. It is the shadow of war. The leaders want to preserve the peace they came to celebrate. From Gorbachev to German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and even Bush and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who are more forthright than others about the need to use force in the Persian Gulf if necessary, they advocated peaceful solution. But the Paris summit in the name of peace and prosperity also had to examine the paradoxical proposition that force may be needed to preserve both. Gorbachev summed up the quandary facing the leaders in Paris. ``We all need patience,'' he said at a picture session before dinner with Bush, ``but that does not mean that we are going to weaken or retreat.''

DOC.HEAD: Story of Boy Left Home Alone Knocks Out `Rocky V'
DOC.TEXT: Rocky took a strong hook to the box-office jaw from the little boy starring in ``Home Alone.'' ``Home Alone,'' about a savvy kid left by himself when burglars strike, took in $17 million over the weekend, dropping Sylvester Stallone's ``Rocky V'' into second place with $14 million, Exhibitor Relations Co. reported Monday. The return of Chuckie the killer doll in ``Child's Play 2'' finished third with $5 million, down from first place the previous week. The animated feature ``The Rescuers Down Under'' opened in fourth with $3.49 million. The other-worldly romance ``Ghost'' refused to disappear, finishing fifth with $3 million for a total box office take of $190.3 million. Kevin Costner's directorial debut in ``Dances With Wolves'' continued to be a howling success, grossing $565,00 on just 14 screens for a two-week total of $1.53 million. It is scheduled for national release Wednesday. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Sunday as tallied by Exhibitor Relations, with distributor, weekend gross, number of theater screens, average per screen, total gross and number of weeks in release. Figures are based on a combination of actual box-office receipts and studio projections where actual figures are not immediately available. 1. ``Home Alone,'' Fox, $17.08 million, 1,202 screens, $14,211 per screen average, one week. 2. ``Rocky V,'' MGM-UA, $14.07 million, 2,053 screens, $6,855 per screen average, one week. 3. ``Child's Play 2,'' Universal, $5 million, 2,017 screens, $2,480 per screen, $18.11 million, second week. 4. ``The Rescuers Down Under,'' Buena Vista, $3.49 million, 1,230 screens, $2,845 per screen, one week. 5. ``Ghost,'' Paramount, $3 million, 1,013 screens, $2,963 per screen, $190.31 million, 19 weeks. 6. ``Jacob's Ladder,'' Tri-Star, $2.82 million, 1,264 screens, $2,235 per screen, $19.25 million, three weeks. 7. ``Reversal of Fortune,'' Warner Bros., $1.72 million, 649 screens, $2,660 per screen, $7.07 million, five weeks. 8. ``Sibling Rivalry,'' Columbia, $1.57 million, 1,361 screens, $1,161 per screen, $14.89 million, four weeks. 9 ``White Palace,'' Universal, $1.44 million, 863 sceens, $1,680 per screen, $14.34 million, five weeks. 10.``Quigley Down Under,'' MGM-UA, $1.34 million, 1,051 screens, $1,275 per screen, $15.83 million, five weeks.

DOC.HEAD: American and Canadian Refugees Arrive from Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi occupiers of Kuwait ``can kill you for any reason,'' says one of the 84 American and Canadian refugees newly evacuated from the Persian Gulf country. The 75 Americans and nine Canadians arrived Monday night at Dulles International Airport outside Washington. Three of the passengers were taken to a hospital but officials said there were no serious medical problems. Authorities took the rest of the exhausted refugees to a hotel near the airport. The passengers were not hostages but had been living in Kuwait since before the Aug. 2 invasion by Iraq. A Kuwaiti accompanying his four American-born children said, ``There are random arrests, killings sometimes. They can kill you for any reason. They may arrest anybody. Maybe they don't like his car. They may inflict harm on his body, torture.'' ``The Iraqi government is implementing many internal policies to force the people out of their country,'' said the man, who would not give his name. ``By driving or walking, you are putting yourself in a position where you could be arrested, beaten or killed.'' One 35-year-old woman said she had been hoping for American troops to come to her rescue. ``For the past three and a half months, I have gotten up hoping and praying they would come,'' she said. But a 36-year-old Palestinian accompanied by his two American daughters expressed doubts about the wisdom of using force. ``I don't know, force will kill a lot of people,'' he said. ``It will mean mass destruction.'' The two asked that their names not be used. Health and Human Services Department spokesman Steve Siegel said 75 Americans and their dependents were aboard - 16 men, 16 women and 43 children. He said there were nine Canadians - two men, four women and three children. The refugees were among 136 on a flight from Iraq that landed earlier Monday at London's Gatwick Airport. The Loudoun County disaster services director, Tom Berezoski, said two children had minor infections and one adult was in a wheelchair, but otherwise everyone seemed healthy. Children who arrived on the flight were ``sitting in a semi-circle watching TV. It's like they haven't watched in years,'' said Berezoski. ``Most of the passengers on this flight have been qualified to depart for some time but have only recently decided to leave,'' State Department spokesman Richard Boucher told reporters at the airport. He said the flight brought to about 2,250 the number of American citizens and their relatives evacuated since the crisis began. Passengers of nine other nationalities had been aboard the flight that arrived in London from Baghdad. A number of the passengers on that flight told reporters they could not stand conditions in the emirate since the takeover by Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Leading Reformer Appeals to West for Emergency Food Supplies
DOC.TEXT: The mayor of Leningrad, one of the Soviet Union's leading reformers, has appealed to the West for emergency aid to avoid famine and prevent public opinion from turning against democratic reforms. ``Already, a lot of people are saying, `Let's go back to the way things were under Brezhnev - at least then there was food in the stores,''' said the leader of the country's second largest city, Anatoly A. Sobchak. In recent days, Sobchak, 53, has been mentioned as a possible candidate for the new post of vice president in President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reorganized government. In an interview with The Associated Press on Monday, he said he had not been approached about the job. He skirted the issue of whether he would accept if Gorbachev offered it, saying he did not expect to be chosen and had no desire for a permanent career in politics. Sobchak, a member of the Supreme Soviet legislature and former law professor, is the first high-level Soviet official to appeal publicly for food donations from the West. He said some people in Leningrad had accused him of being too proud to ask for help, but that for the good of the city, he would be willing to ``get down on my knees'' if necessary. Germany promised Gorbachev during his visit last week that it would provide emergency food aid to help the Soviet Union through the winter, and Chancellor Helmut Kohl said Monday that rail shipments could begin as early as next week. Sobchak said a private U.S. organization, AmeriCares, was also preparing shipments. The mayor visited the United States in October and met with President Bush at the White House. He said he regretted that he did not ask for emergency aid at that time. ``A month ago, I thought we could avoid foreign aid. Today, I think we can't,'' he said. ``The food situation has worsened, and by the time we take steps to increase stockpiles and improve distribution, we could already have placed our major cities ... in danger of famine.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III said on Monday that the U.S. government had not received a formal request for help. But Bush, meeting other leaders at a summit conference in Paris, indicated he would favor humanitarian aid. ``If there are food shortages, for example, and the United States was in a position to help, clearly I would want to try to help,'' he said. ``And that's the right and humane thing to do as a country moves towards us and relations are greatly improved.'' At Sobchak's urging, Leningrad's City Council voted last week to begin rationing meat, poultry, eggs, flour, butter and other staples starting Dec. 1 in the city of about 5 million people. Many other cities throughout Russia and the Ukraine already ration food, vodka, matches, soap and other necessities. Sitting under a portrait of Lenin in his Moscow legislative office, Sobchak said Communist Party officials are deliberately preventing food from being distributed efficiently. ``We are facing opposition - possibly the last gasp of opposition - from the old Communist, totalitarian, administrative system against the new democratic system that is being born,'' he said. He added that if there is widespread hunger this winter, popular sentiment could turn against the reforms that Gorbachev has introduced since coming to power in 1985. ``People are asking ... `What good is this democracy to me, when I've got nothing to eat?''' he said. Sobchak spoke enthusiastically about the government reorganization proposed by Gorbachev on Saturday. He said eliminating the Council of Ministers, headed by Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov, would give the president a clear line of administrative authority independent of the Communist Party, allowing Gorbachev to take ``more decisive action'' to improve the economy. At the same time, Sobchak called for a radical reduction in the role of the central government, saying its function should be only as a ``coordinator and arbiter'' between autonomous Soviet republics that voluntarily remain within the union.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Commission Seeking Labeling Of Toys With Small Parts
DOC.TEXT: The Consumer Products Safety Commission, issuing its annual holiday warning about dangerous toys, says it may go for regulations requiring labeling of playthings with small parts that could choke children if swallowed. ``Think big in buying toys for children under 3,'' Jacqueline Jones-Smith, chairman of the commission, said Monday at a news conference. The commission said it received reports of 33 deaths related to toys between January 1989 and September 1990. In 20 of these cases, the children choked on balloons, marbles, small balls or parts of toys. ``The buyer has to beware and parents have to be careful,'' Ms. Jones-Smith said. She said the commission has taken the first steps toward developing mandatory requirements for labeling on balloons, balls and marbles. In addition, she said, the commission has begun action that may result in a requirement that toys having small pieces, intended for children aged 3 to 6, be labeled to warn of the choking hazards to younger children. The commission's staff hopes to have these regulations before the commission for consideration early next year, she said. Ms. Jones-Smith demonstrated two toys with small parts for reporters and announced that the manufacturers have agreed to voluntarily recall them from the market. During the past year, she said, about 198 kinds of toy have been recalled or stopped from sale. In a statement distributed at the news conference, the commission also said it has seized about 3 million toys at ports of entry since it began a cooperative program with the Customs Service in 1987. ``The industry itself is policing itself much better in recent years, partly because of its own sensitivity and party because of our work with Customs,'' said David Schmeltzer, director of compliance for the commission. Ms. Jones-Smith said most of the toys the commission deals with are imported.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa: `I Was Born For Victory'
LaserPhoto NY19 of Nov. 19
DOC.TEXT: Having mounted a pugnacious campaign against a government he largely created, Lech Walesa is presenting himself as a man vindicated by events and predicts victory in Sunday's presidential elections. ``I was born only for victory. So I have to win,'' Walesa declared in an interview with The Associated Press at his headquarters Monday. Polls show Walesa ahead of his chief rival and former ally, Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki. But with four others in the field, it was unclear if anyone would get a first-round majority and avoid a runoff Dec. 9.
