The 47-year-old Solidarity chairman accused his opponents of talking only about his personality and ambitions, not substantive issues. ``I am waiting for a political discussion while my partners are saying that I have dirty fingernails and so try to discourage people from voting for me,'' Walesa said. Walesa, who picked Mazowiecki for prime minister in August 1989 after the long-ruling Communists suffered a humiliating electoral defeat, said he was laughed at early this year when he urged the government to pick up the speed of reforms. He said he saw that dramatic stes were needed, including purging government and industry of Communists. ``My colleagues - dangerous politicians - were carrying out a dangerous policy which was on the edge of civil war. I made an attempt to save us ... to save reform,'' Walesa said. The Mazowiecki camp argues that Poland's delicate transition to full democracy could be thwarted if the government engages in a large-scale ``witch hunt'' for ex-Communists. Virtually all of Walesa's former advisers have sided with Mazowiecki, leaving Walesa to assemble a new team of unionists and lesser-known politicians. ``I have been struggling for nine months to regain Solidarity's position and to regain my position. I do not know to what extent it worked, but from what I see, it did,'' Walesa said. A peasant's son with a trade-school education, Walesa said he differs from his former colleagues, most of them intellectuals, because he is not frightened by ordinary people. ``If you fear the masses, then of course the masses will defeat you,'' he said. ``I am not afraid of the masses. I want to find work for them, and I want to show them what's possible or impossible, and then go on with what's possible and probable.'' His former allies may quarrel with him now, Walesa said, but they will see he was right. ``I am playing like a chess player, five or six moves ahead, and my colleagues can see only one move. That is why they are scared.'' Once he is elected, Walesa said, he will move to patch up the splintered Solidarity movement. While he has called for faster reforms, he said that as president he would avoid abrupt changes until a freely elected parliament is seated, which could take two or three months, he said. ``Until the elections, as few changes as possible, only the necessary changes. Because to the outside world, it always (looks like) change upon change, from one change to another.'' Walesa has recently been full of praise for Finance Minister Leszek Balcerowicz, but he sidestepped a question on whether he would ask Balcerowicz to stay. Walesa said he would offer part of the Cabinet the option to remain, but wouldn't appeal to them with hat in hand. ``The point is reform of the country, patriotism and full devotion, and not to me but to Poland,'' Walesa said. ``If someone needs to be asked, it means he's useless,'' he said. Asked why he had not done more to rebuke anti-Semitism during his rallies, Walesa said he had reminded Poles in recent interviews that anti-Semitism is contradictory to their Catholicism. Mazowiecki, who contends Poland's future depends on maintaining his course of cautious reforms, says he'll join the opposition if Walesa wins.

DOC.HEAD: Army Kid-Naps Wrong Goat From Navy
DOC.TEXT: Army failed to get Navy's goat. Early Sunday, cadets from the U.S. Military Academy abducted a goat they thought was Bill XXVI, the U.S. Naval Academy mascot. But the midshipmen had been anticipating the prank and proved to be great kidders. The real Bill had been hidden by midshipmen. The Naval Academy said Monday the kid-napped goat was one of several that had auditioned to succeed Bill XXV, who was retired in 1988. Faux goat, as the Navy is calling the kidnapped one, had been rejected because it was ornery and had poor bathroom habits. ``We sort of hope they keep Faux goat,'' said Rear Adm. Virgil L. Hill Jr., Naval Academy superintendent. ``He would do well at West Point. His personality will fit right in there.'' Kid-nappings are tradition before the annual Army-Navy football game. The 100th anniversary of the first Army-Navy game will be celebrated when the teams meet on Dec. 8 in Philadelphia. The kidnappers left a ransom note that said Bill would be ``cared for at a farm ... and will be warm, well-fed and dry.'' ``We take this as a win,'' said Naval Academy spokeswoman Carol Feldman. Bill's whereabouts remain a military secret.

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Company Recalls Hot Dogs Suspected Of Contamination
DOC.TEXT:
A Chicago company is recalling more than five tons of hot dogs suspected of being contaminated by food poisoning. Agriculture Department officials said on Monday that David Berg & Co. is recalling 10,000 pounds of bulk-packed ``David Berg Beef Frankfurters'' distributed in California, Illinois, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania and Texas. Also being recalled are about 1,400 pounds of retail-packaged ``David Berg Deli Beef Franks'' distributed in the Chicago metropolitan area. The franks may be contaminated with listeria monocytogenes, an organism that can cause listeriosis, which was described as ``a rare but potentially serious disease.'' The bulk-packed hot dogs are sold in 10-pound boxes and are distributed to hot dog vendors, delicatessens and restaurants. ``EST. 1'' appears inside the USDA inspection seal on the box label. All bulk franks with the code 60250 on the bottom of the box are being recalled. The 12-ounce retail packages were distributed to grocery stores and supermarkets in Chicago. ``EST. 1'' appears in the inspection seal on the package label. All retail packages with ``Sell by Dec. 10'' stamped on the side of the package are being recalled. None of the company's other products are involved in the recall, said Ronald J. Prucha, associate administrator of the department's Food Safety and Inspection Service.
---
DOC.HEAD: Corcoran Gallery Appoints New York Art Historian As New Leader
DOC.TEXT:
The Corcoran Gallery of Art, in turmoil since the cancellation of a Robert Mapplethorpe exhibit, has named a New York art historian and education administrator as its new leader. David C. Levy, chancellor of he New School for Social Research, was elected by the Corcoran board of trustees Monday to become director and president of the gallery and the art school affiliated with it starting Jan. 1. Levy, 52, joined the Parsons School of Design in 1961. He initiated the merger of Parsons and the New School in 1970 and continued as Parsons' chief administrative officer until last year. Levy's appointment was announced in conjunction with a policy statement in which the board reaffirmed the Corcoran's commitment to freedom of expression. The Corcoran, 120 years old and two blocks from the White House, attracted nationwide criticism when its former director, Christina Orr-Cahall, canceled an exhibit containing sexually explicit photographs by the late Robert Mapplethorpe. She said she canceled the show to avoid getting embroiled in the emotional debate over federal arts grant policies. But the cancellation ignited an equally intense debate in the artistic community, and Orr-Cahall resigned last February.
---
DOC.HEAD: Researchers Accuse FDA Of Imperiling Supply Of French Abortion
DOC.TEXT: Drug

Medical researchers say the Food and Drug Administration is threatening access to a French abortion drug that shows promise in treating cancer and other diseases. Dr. George P. Chrousos of the National Institute of Child Health and Development told a House hearing Monday that scientists are being ``whiplashed by the FDA decision'' to issue an import alert on the French drug RU-486. ``I won't be able to initiate a new study'' because of the uncertain supply of RU-486, Chrousos said. He said the reluctance by the French company, Roussel-Uclaf, to supply it for research in this country was ``unethical.'' The drug has shown promise in treating breast and brain cancer, Cushing's Syndrome and other diseases. Cushing's Syndrome is a disorder of the pituitary gland. The FDA got ``carried away'' under pressure from the right-to-life movement and ``may have made a political decision,'' Chrousos added. The FDA issued an import alert in June 1989 barring the abortion drug for personal use after getting inquiries from right-to-life groups and a dozen members of Congress who oppose abortion, including Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., and Rep. Robert Dornan, R-Calif. Since then, some U.S. researchers have had difficulty getting the drug from its French manufacturer, which fears its business could suffer if it becomes embroiled in an abortion controversy. The regulatory agency's import alert was not a politically motivated decision, the FDA's Ronald G. Chesemore told the House subcommittee on regulation, business opportunities and energy. The FDA didn't consult leading U.S. researchers before issuing the import alert, testified Dr. Kathryn Horwitz, a professor of medicine at the University of Colorado. The FDA announced the alert 19 days after demands for it from members of Congress. ``This certainly must be a new land-speed record for an agency response to congressional inquiries,'' observed subcommittee chairman Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore. He called FDA's action ``very irresponsible.'' Wyden suggested that Health and Human Services Department Secretary Louis Sullivan urge the French company to ensure adequate supplies of the drug for U.S. research.

DOC.HEAD: Soccer Headers Can Result in Brain Damage, Study Shows
DOC.TEXT: An Oslo University medical student says he's determined that soccer players who use their heads to strike at balls are risking brain damage. Thirty percent of retired Norwegian soccer players were found to have signs of minor brain damage from ``heading'' balls, according to the survey medical student Alf Thorvald Tysvaer conducted for his doctoral thesis. Tysvaer said in an interview with the news agency NPK that 3 percent of the active Norwegian soccer players he studied also showed symptoms of brain damage. Soccer balls can travel at more than 60 mph. But Willy Simonssen, assistant head of Norway's Soccer Federation, said such widespread damage appeared unlikely. ``I have not noticed it in my meetings with players,'' he said. In the study, former players complained of headache, dizziness and irritability and some had problems with pain in the neck, Tysvaer was quoted as saying. He said those were symptoms of chronic, or permanent, brain damage. But the brain changes he recorded were not as severe as those suffered by boxers, Tysvaer said. NPK said in the report Monday that Tysvaer's study included 69 active Norwegian division players and 43 former national team members.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Dips, Stocks Also Fall
DOC.TEXT: The dollar edged down against the yen Tuesday, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell moderately. The dollar closed at 128.93 yen, down 0.02 yen from Monday's close of 128.95 yen. After opening at 129.23 yen, the currency ranged between 128.90 yen and 129.28 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues shed 312.68 points, or 1.33 percent, closing at 23,518.16. The market's main barometer had gained 346.53 points the previous day. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds slipped to 85.10, down from Monday's close of 85.37. Their yield rose to 7.690 percent from 7.640 percent. Currency dealers said the dollar was bought during early trading, then drifted because of dollar-selling in small amounts by life insurance firms and other institutions. They said the dollar's initial strength followed Iraq's announcement that it will increase its forces in Kuwait by 250,000 troops. The dollar tends to rise in times of unrest because it is seen as a safe investment. On the stock market, the Iraqi announcement caused the Nikkei index to drop more than 200 points in early trading, said Tsukasa Wakihata, an analyst with Yamaichi Securities. ``The index recovered some of its early losses following a news report that Saudi Arabia will increase its oil production,'' Wakihata said.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Florence Henderson says she regrets arriving in Hollywood about the time the studios stopped making musicals. ``I loved those old film musicials,'' said Henderson, best known as the matriarch of ``The Brady Bunch.'' ``I grew up in this tiny town in southern Indiana where going to the movies was the biggest excitement of the week. I wanted to be Jane Powell.'' She even tried to break into show business as a singer, at a talent show staged by bandleader Horace Heidt, but the results were less than successful, she recalled in a recent interview. ``I was such a kid. I didn't know you had to bring your own piano player. I showed up with a Jane Powell record. On one side, she was singing `It's A Most Unusual Day' and on the other was a French song,'' she said. ```What are you going to sing?' Mr. Heidt asked. `These two songs,' I said. `Where's your piano player?' he wanted to know. `Oh, I don't have one,' I said. That's what I did, too. Of course, I didn't win.'' --- NEW YORK (AP) - Paul Newman is donating $10,000 from his Newman's Own line of food products to help keep a Ms. magazine educational program cooking. The program, ``Ms.: the World of Women,'' provides copies of the magazine for use in women's, sociology and psychology classes at about 2,000 U.S. colleges. The magazine initially provided the copies for free. After Ms. ran into financial troubles last year, people such as Newman began underwriting the program, said publisher Ruth Bower. Newman's company donates its earnings from such products as salad dressing to charity. --- BOSTON (AP) - Rep. Barney Frank, noting there is no good time to have a heart attack, says he's happy that at least his occurred while Congress was out of session. The Massachusetts Democrat checked himself into Beth Israel Hospital on Saturday after experiencing chest pains while working out at a health club. Doctors unblocked a clogged artery on Sunday. ``There's no good time for something like this to happen, but at least Congress is out now,'' Frank said in a statement issued from the hospital Monday. ``That means I'll be back at work when Congress is back in session.'' Congress goes back into session in January. ``If progress continues at this rate, I anticipate a complete return to normal activity,'' said Dr. William Grossman, a Beth Israel cardiologist. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Veteran rocker David Crosby, who broke his left leg, ankle and shoulder in a motorcycle accident, is in good spirits and confident of making a full recovery, a hospital spokesman says. ``David seems to be on the road to recovery from some very serious fractures,'' Cedars-Sinai Medical center spokesman Ron Wise said Monday. ``He seems real clear and upbeat and confident that he'll get through this in good shape.'' Crosby was listed in fair condition Monday. Rocker Billy Idol was treated at the hospital in February after breaking his leg and arm in a motorcycle crash. Crosby, 49, was driving his motorcycle along a winding road Saturday when he lost control and skidded about 40 feet, said police Officer Leona Thomas. ``He says his throttle got stuck,'' Ms. Thomas said. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Dan Quayle, who has made it to the big leagues of politics, is about to be inducted into the Little League Hall of Excellence. ``He's the first Little League graduate to be vice president,'' Little League spokesman Steve Keener said Monday. Induction ceremonies will be held Dec. 6 in Washington. Quayle plans to donate his old glove to the Little League Museum in Williamsport, Pa. ``Vice President Quayle was selected for this prestigious distinction on his qualifications as a leader, role model for children and his commitment to excellence,'' Little League President Creighton J. Hale said. Quayle played baseball for the Herald-Press newspaper team in the Hoosier Little League of Huntington, Ind., in the mid-1950s. Little League officials still have the vice president's eligibility affidavit and original team roster, but his hitting and fielding statistics are not available, Keener said.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrators Charge Front is Behind New Communist Party
DOC.TEXT: Government critics have taken to the streets with charges that a new Communist party was created with secret support from the governing National Salvation Front. More than 3,000 people marched two miles down Bucharest's main boulevard on Monday, shouting anti-Communist slogans and railing against the government. The new Communist party, called the Socialist Labor Party, was formed last weekend through the merger of the tiny Democratic Labor and Socialist parties, both created after the December revolution that ousted and executed longtime dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. The party, led by former Communist Premier Ilie Verdet, describes itself as ``a reorganization, on a new basis, of the former Romanian Communist Party.'' In a statement Monday, the new party deplored ``intolerant movements to discourage our constructive efforts'' and pledged to ``reject all Stalinist and Ceausescu-ist practices.'' But critics were skeptical. ``The Communists have infiltrated all the structures of power and quite naturally will try to return us to where we were before,'' said Constantin Ticu Dumitrescu, president of the Former Political Prisoners Association. Many in the opposition have charged that the National Salvation Front, which took power after the December revolution that ousted Ceausescu, and its leader, President Ion Iliescu, are secret Communists. The demonstrators Monday shouted ``Down with Iliescu!'' and ``The blood was spilled for nought!'' Some carried a large banner that equated the government with communism. It read: ``Romanian Communist Party - National Salvation Front - Socialist Labor Party - Romanian Communist Party.'' Iliescu and other front leaders, bowing to popular pressure that sprung from hatred of Ceausescu, announced in January that communism would be banned in Romania. Later, they backed away from that position. A statement issued by the political prisoners' group charged that ``almost all the top (Communist Party) members were freed despite their crimes against humanity.'' It alleged that Ceausescu's feared secret police, the Securitate, ``is intact and on duty.'' More than 100,000 Romanians demonstrated against the front on Thursday to mark the third anniversary of anti-Ceausescu riots in Brasov, 60 miles north of Bucharest, which were brutally suppressed. Dissatisfaction with the front has grown since Nov. 1, when price reforms introduced by Premier Petre Roman led to the doubling and tripling of prices. The front on Sunday criticized Roman's reform package as not doing enough to protect the social welfare of citizens. It was time the front had openly attacked Roman, whose relationship to the government party is unclear. Roman said he was resigning in July, but he has since presided over several meetings of a front organization.

DOC.HEAD: Funeral for Medal of Freedom Winner Who Helped Save U.S. Fliers in WWII
DOC.TEXT: Two of the American fliers she helped save attended the funeral of Charline Chable Rotondo, a member of the French underground awarded the Medal of Freedom for her World War II exploits. Rotondo, who moved to the United States in 1974, died of lung cancer Thursday at age 78. Her funeral was Monday. World War II fliers John Swenson of Newton, Mass., and Alvin Little of Burlington, Vt., were among the 32 Americans Rotondo sheltered from the Nazis. ``Without people like her, we would have been dead,'' Swenson said. ``We would have starved to death, or turned ourselves in to the Germans.'' ``She went through as much hell as us,'' Little said. Rotondo received America's highest civilian honor in Paris in 1945 after she escaped from the Nazis, who had imprisoned and tortured her. She was the first foreign-born woman to receive the medal. Also attending her funeral were members of the 8th Air Force Historical Society in Massachusetts and the Air Forces Escape and Evasion Society, which reunited Rotondo, Swenson and Little in 1985. Swenson was the radio operator and Little a gunner on a bomber that was shot down over France in 1943. After being rescued by two Frenchmen, they were secretly moved from house to house, village to village, across France. Little spent 12 weeks at Rotondo's home in Esbly outside Paris. Swenson stayed there a week. One evening when Germans knocked on Rotondo's door, ``she kept them occupied until I and her niece could slip out another door,'' Little said. Rotondo, a banker's daughter who was then 31, eventually was captured herself. She was beaten, hung from rafters and burned with cigarettes, but she told her captors nothing about the French resistance. She escaped when a train carrying her to a concentration camp was bombed by the Allies. After the war, the multilingual Sorbonne graduate became a fashion designer and lived in Southeast Asia before moving to the United States and settling in Salem. She sought in vain for 10 years to find any of the fliers she helped, until the Escape and Evasion Society found her. Her medal was displayed in her coffin. She is survived by her husband, Alfred Rotondo.

DOC.HEAD: Leukemia Victim Whose Father Fought for Bone Marrow Transplant Dies
DOC.TEXT: A 13-year-old leukemia victim who was denied the possibility of a bone marrow transplant from his 3-year-old half siblings died without a fair chance against the disease or the courts, his father says. Jean-Pierre Bosze died Monday at his suburban Hoffman Estates home, ending his father's six-month legal battle to have the teen-ager's twin half-siblings, a boy and a girl, tested as donors for a bone marrow transplant that doctors said might have saved his life. ``He was a very, very brave boy,'' said his father, Tamas Bosze. ``It's very unfortunate the way the law is now. I don't think he had a fair chance.'' Bosze had sought a court order to force Nancy Curran - his former girlfriend and the mother of the twins - to have the toddlers tested. Curran had claimed the tests would be too painful and risky. In September, the state Supreme Court affirmed a lower court's ruling in her favor. A request to reconsider its decision was before the high court when Jean-Pierre died. The boy was released from Lutheran General Hospital in Park Ridge last week, and both his mother and father were at his bedside when he died, said Edward Jordan, Bosze's lawyer. ``He was at peace,'' Jordan said. ``He was as calm as he could be. He didn't want to die. But he knew it was coming.'' Jordan said Bosze feels no bitterness toward Curran, of suburban Elk Grove. ``It's not anything like `You killed my kid,' nothing like that,'' Jordan said. ``It's just that they'll never know'' if the twins could have been donors. Blood relatives are more likely to be biologically compatible donors. ``When he started out he was a good candidate to receive bone marrow from anyone,'' the boy's father said. ``His condition got worse, the twins were the only hope.'' Curran's attorney, Beverly Pekala, issued a one-sentence extending her client's sympathy. Healthy bone marrow must come from donors whose tissue types closely match the patient's. Bosze approached Curran after tests showed that he and three other family members were incompatible. Bosze, a tavern owner, fathered the twins with Curran when he was separated from Jean-Pierre's mother, to whom he remains married. Curran has sole custody of the twins. He initially petitioned the courts in June, insisting the twins would agree to the tests if they were old enough to decide. Circuit Judge Monica Reynolds ruled Sept. 6 that the tests would violate the twins' right to privacy. Bone marrow is extracted from the hipbone or breastbone. Risks include pain, complications from anesthesia, infection and the possible need for a blood transfusion.

DOC.HEAD: Blockbuster Swallows Erol's in Video Merger
DOC.TEXT: America's No. 1 video chain is swallowing No. 3 in a $40 million deal that gives Blockbuster Entertainment Corp. a total of more than 1,700 stores. Blockbuster agreed to acquire Erol's Inc. of Springfield, Va., a chain of 208 outlets that pioneered the video rental business in 1980 but has struggled amid management shuffles and stiff competition. The deal ``provides an outstanding opportunity for Blockbuster and its franchise owners to broaden the base of ourstores,'' Blockbuster chairman and chief executive officer H. Wayne Huizenga said Monday. Erol's, the nation's third-largest chain behind West Coast-National of Philadelphia, has stores in Philadelphia, Baltimore, Cleveland and Chicago as well as 112 stores in the Washington, D.C., area, where Blockbuster has only 48 outlets and was looking to expand. Blockbuster, based in Fort Lauderdale, opened its 1,500th store Monday, in Vancouver, British Columbia. In all, the chain has stores in 44 states, the District of Columbia, Guam, Puerto Rico, Canada and England. Erol's founder and principal stockholder, Erol Onaran, said the buyout was in the best interest of his 2,600 employees. ``It was going to be a fight,'' said analyst Drew Beja at Advest Securities. ``And Blockbuster had the resources to win the fight.'' Onaron founded Erol's as a stereo repair shop in Washington in 1963. It was an early pioneer in the video industry, opening stores exclusively devoted to rentals in 1980, and led all other video chains in revenue until Blockbuster surpassed it in 1988. But Erol's has been stagnating since then, and didn't begin to sell franchises until last August, said Frank Molstad, editor of Video Store magazine. In contrast, Blockbuster has been expanding by 400 to 500 stores a year since Huizenga bought the company in 1987 for $19 million, and Huizenga has said sales this year could top $1 billion. Erol's had revenue of $100 million last year, said Jerry Falkner, an analyst at Southwest Research Partners in Boca Raton. While more than 1,700 stores by the end of the year, Blockbuster will still have only about 10 percent of the home video market, said Fran Blechman Bernstein, an analyst with Merrill Lynch.

DOC.HEAD: Government, University Scientists Develop Superconducting Transistor
DOC.TEXT: Scientists say they see exciting potential for the world's first high-temperature superconducting transistor in the development more advanced supercomputers, microwave components and other electronics. The new transistor was developed at the University of Wisconsin and Sandia National Laboratories in Albuquerque, N.M., and operates at a relatively high temperature of minus 340 degrees Fahrenheit, the scientists said Monday. While superconductive compounds that function at similarly high temperatures have been known for years, the transistor marks the first successful attempt to use such materials to create a transistor. The Department of Energy also backed the project, which now has advanced to the installation of the transistor into a functioning electronic circuit. Transistors, often the size of pinheads, function in supercomputers and other electronic devices as the switches that control current. They also are used to amplify signals from devices ranging from stereos to satellites. Superconductivity, the loss of all resistance to electrical current, occurs in dozens of materials when they are chilled to minus 452 degrees Fahrenheit, or close to absolute zero. Devices that become superconductive at higher, more easily achievable temperatures would allow more practical applications and could open the way to faster supercomputers, microwave components and other electronics products. The new transistor is etched in a thin film of thalium and superconducting copper oxide and is chilled to the temperature of liquid nitrogen. While you still ``can't keep it in your shirt pocket,'' it gives scientists more flexibility because it operates at a higher temperature, said electrical engineering Professor James B. Beyer, who directed the project along with Professor James E. Nordman and university graduate Jon Martens. The new transistor intrigues scientists partly because it functions far differently from conventional transistors. Conventional transistors use alteration in the voltage to control current. The new transistor uses changes in the current to control voltage. Ken Frazier, a Sandia spokeesman, said the new transistor may serve as a bridge between circuitry that functions at room temperature and circuitry being developed using superconductivity close to absolute zero. But Nordman cautioned that scientists are still studying the new transistor and are far fro determining its applications. ``The transistor was invented in 1948, and we've been learning about it ever since,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnam Repatriates 11 Sets Of Possible American Remains
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. military team flew to Hanoi today to receive 11 sets of remains that the Vietnamese say may be those of missing American soldiers, a U.S. official said. After a repatriation ceremony at Hanoi's airport, the remains were to be flown to the Army's Central Identification Laboratory in Hawaii for analysis, said James Williams, spokesman for the U.S. Embassy in Bangkok. He said Vietnam last returned remains on Sept. 13, when 20 sets were handed over. None of those have yet been identified. The Pentagon lists 2,294 Americans as missing in action, or MIA, from the Vietnam War, which ended in the Communist defeat of the U.S.-backed South Vietnam government in April 1975. Of these, 1,676 are missing in Vietnam, 529 in Laos, 83 in Cambodia and six in Chinese coastal waters. In August 1987, U.S. presidential envoy John W. Vessey and Vietnamese Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach agreed to new forms of cooperation. Since then, Vietnam has returned a total of 101 remains in 15 repatriations. Williams said that since 1974, more than 400 sets of remains have been returned from Vietnam, but only 245 Americans have been accounted for as a result. Most of the remains, he said, were determined to be those of Southeast Asian Mongoloids although a few sets are still under analysis. U.S. and Vietnamese experts held talks on accelerating cooperation on the MIA issue on Nov. 7-9 in Hanoi. The Vietnam News Agency said they discussed plans to conduct their 12th and 13th joint searches in coming months. In these searches, investigators inspect plane crash sites, interview villagers who witnessed crashes and collect other evidence of missing soldiers. Late last month, Thach said he welcomed the idea of the United States stationing an official in Hanoi to coordinate efforts to account for missing Americans. The two countries do not have diplomatic relations and the United States has not posted an official in Vietnam since the war. U.S. officials in Bangkok said, however, that it did not appear an official would be posted there anytime soon.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Executive Escapes Kidnapper; Gunman at Large
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of Minnesota's second-largest bank was abducted at gunpoint and forced to make a ransom demand from his car phone but escaped uninjured after being left alone in the woods, authorities said. The search continued today for the lone gunman and the banker's Mercedes. First Bank System Chairman John Grundhofer was kidnapped Monday when he arrived at his office building. He escaped two hours later and called for help from a dairy farm in Wisconsin, just over the Minnesota line, authorities said. Jeff Jamar, chief of the FBI's Minneapolis office, said the gunman approached Grundhofer in the bank's parking garage, forced him back into the car and told him to drive out of the city. Authorities said Grundhofer called in a ransom demand to the bank about an hour later. The amount was not disclosed. The ransom was not paid. The kidnapper ``was prepared, well-planned. I believe he stalked him, knew who he was after,'' Jamar said. Police Chief John Laux said a witness in the garage reported the kidnapping. Authorities gave few details on the sequence of events but said Grundhofer was left alone in the woods, freed himself and walked to a farm. ``He wasn't released, he escaped,'' Jamar said. ``The person left him (and) told him he'd be back.'' KSTP-TV of St. Paul reported that Grundhofer was bound, placed in a sleeping bag and left at the bottom of a wooded embankment in Houlton, Wis. Bruce Dahlke, the farmer who let Grundhofer use the phone, told the TV station he overhead the banker tell police the kidnapper claimed to have attached explosives to Grundhofer's wrists. Police would not confirm the account. ``I'm OK,'' Grundhofer said at a news conference Monday. ``I have no idea why this took place this morning. ... We're very grateful to the good Lord for me being here.'' The abductor, described as between 50 and 60 years old, carried a handgun and a knife and wore an overcoat, dark business suit, tie and brown tweed hat, authorities said. He carried a black leather satchel, investigators said. Grundhofer, 51, has been chairman, president and chief executive officer since January of First Bank System Inc. With total assets of $19.2 billion, it is the second-largest bank holding company in Minnesota and the 36th largest in the nation. Previously he was vice chairman and senior executive officer for Southern California at San Francisco-based Wells Fargo Bank. He and his wife live in a western Minneapolis suburb, according to a bank spokeswoman. They have two grown daughters who live in California. Thirty years ago, while working at Union Bank in Los Angeles, Grundhofer dodged a bullet while trying to repossess a debtor's car, the Star Tribune reported today. In September, a gunman fired into a crowd at a bar in Berkeley, Calif., killing one person and seriously wounding Grundhofer's 22-year-old daughter, Karen. Grundhofer said recently that his daughter is recovering.

DOC.HEAD: Ambassador Writes Open Letter To Pakistanis On U.S. Aid
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. ambassador has written an open letter to Pakistanis, explaining that $573 million in U.S. aid has been suspended because Pakistan has not made adequate assurances about its nuclear capability. The letter appeared in Monday's editions of the English-language newspaper The Nation and several Urdu-language publications. Washington suspended military and economic assistance Oct. 1, demanding greater assurances that Pakistan neither possesses nor wants to possess nuclear weapons. Pakistan, the third-largest recepient of U.S. aid behind Egypt and Israel, insists its nuclear program is for peaceful purposes. The 2-week-old government of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif has pledged to go ahead with its nuclear program - even if it means losing American aid. Many Pakistanis believe their country's nuclear program acts as a deterrent against possible attack by India, its traditionally hostile neighbor to the east. India exploded a nuclear device in 1974. The two uneasy neighbors went to war in 1948, 1965 and again in 1971. Fears of a fourth - and possibly nuclear - war escalated last spring over the disputed territory of Kashmir, which is claimed by both. In his letter, ambassador Robert Oakley tried to explain that U.S. law prohibits economic and military aid to any country that even possesses the components of a nuclear device. ``The definition of possession ... applies to components of a nuclear device, not only to an assembled device,'' the letter says. Unless the U.S. president provides certification to Congress, assistance is suspended on Oct. 1, the start of the new fiscal year, Oakley said. ``There is no authority for any action by the president to extend this date, which only Congress can do if the president fails to certify,'' he said. The ambassador said President Bush had proposed that Congress delay the suspension so that U.S. aid would not be an issue in the Oct. 24 parliamentary election. The right-wing political parties blamed ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto for the suspension and used the issue not only to defeat her at the polls but to fuel anti-American sentiment. ``I know there is a widespread tendency in Pakistan to see the United States as a huge spider spinning its web and determining what happens in all corners of the world, but you should not fall into this trap,'' Oakley said. ``Nor should you assume that better relations between Pakistan and India, or a mutual reduction in armaments, would necessarily be at Pakistani exepense,'' he said. ``A lowering of both the threat level between Pakistan and India and the amount of money they spend for defense would seem to be a good thing for the peoples of both country. ``Why not explore it seriously rather than suspect that Pakistan's favorite arch-villain, the United States, is plotting to weaken and undermine you with such a subversive, insidious suggestion?'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Teen-agers Arraigned in Wilding Attack That Left Woman Dead
DOC.TEXT: Eight teen-agers have been charged with raping and murdering a young mother in a ``wilding'' attack that police said rivals New York's Central Park jogger case in savagery. The eight were arraigned Monday in the slaying of Kimberly Rae Harbour, 26, who was beaten with a branch and a broken bottle, repeatedly raped, stabbed and kicked. Her body was found in a field near the housing project where she lived. ``One person jumped on top of her repeatedly,'' Detective Peter J. O'Malley said during the arraignment. Police said the Boston youths went out as a group on Halloween night looking for women to rob. They bragged about the crime the next day, news reports said. Harbour's father, Russell, said he was at a loss to understand the attack on his daughter, who had a 7-year-old daughter of her own and had recently worked for the Census Bureau. The girl now lives with relatives in Virginia. ``An animal wouldn't do this,'' he said. ``I'm not a vengeful person, but I would like to push the button, pull the rope, cut them up myself.'' Lt. Detective Edward McNelley, head of the homicide squad, said the case shares similarities with the New York case, in which a gang of youths jumped, raped and beat a 28-year-old investment banker jogging in Central Park. The jogger survived despite losing much of her blood. Three people were convicted, two are on trial and one awaits trial. The case gave wide exposure to the term ``wilding'' for gang attacks carried out for fun against passersby. Carlos Garcia and Corey James, both 18, and Che Barnes, 17, all of Boston's Dorchester section, were jailed without bail on charges of aggravated rape, murder and armed robbery. Five juveniles ages 14 to 16 were arraigned in the attack as well and placed in juvenile custody. Their names were withheld. ``I haven't seen anything this bad in 15 years,'' said court probation officer Billy Stewart. ``You're talking major-league wilding here. You're talking animal here, pure vicious.''

DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed against key currencies in European trading this morning. Gold prices steadied. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 128.93 yen, down 0.02 yen from Monday's close of 128.95 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 128.65 yen. DOC.HEAD: Americans Increasingly Worried Bush May Wage War
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An increasing number of Americans believe President Bush is moving too fast toward military action in the Persian Gulf, according to a New York Times-CBS poll. Forty-seven percent of those polled said the Bush administration has been too quick to get U.S. forces involved and has not been diligent enough about seeking diplomatic solutions, according to the poll in today's Times. Only 38 percent felt that way back in August. Just over half - 51 percent - of those polled expect the United States to fight Iraq. Less than a third ofthose polled - 31 percent - felt that protecting the oil supply was a good enough reason to go to war. Slightly more - 35 percent - felt U.S. military action against Iraq would be justified to defend Saudi Arabia and restore the Kuwaiti government. More than half - 54 percent - said that stopping Saddam Hussein from developing nuclear weapons was a good enough reason to wage war. Shortly after Iraq invaded Kuwait in August, 75 percent of Americans approved of Bush's decision to send American soldiers to the Middle East and gather international support for an embargo against Iraq. Only 50 percent now approve of Bush's approach, while 41 percent disapprove. Sixty-one percent of those surveyed said the United States was right to send troops to Saudi Arabia initially. Only 41 percent support sending more than 150,000 additional troops. The poll of 1,370 adults was done by telephone Nov. 13-15. It has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Snow and Rain in West, Dry Weather Elsewhere
DOC.TEXT: Snow covered higher elevations in the West today, while mild, dry weather prevailed over much of the rest of the nation. Lower elevations in the Northwest and in Northern California got scattered rain, and the mountains of Maine had clouds and flurries. A storm over the Bering Strait brought snow and high winds to western Alaska. Dry weather prevailed over most of the nation, with fair skies in the south-central and southeastern United States and mostly mild weather in the Midwest. The forecast called for continued heavy snow in the mountains of Oregon, Washington, Idaho, Montana, Wyoming, Colorado, Nevada and Arizona. Sattered showers were expected tonight in Kansas, Missouri, Iowa, Nebraska and the Dakotas. The high temperature for the nation Monday was 88 degrees at McCallen, Texas. Elsewhere in Texas, Amarillo and El Paso reached 79 degrees, tying records in those cities for the date. DOC.HEAD: Saddam Says German Hostages to Go Free
DOC.TEXT: President Saddam Hussein said today that he would ask the National Assembly to meet later in the day and grant all German hostages freedom, state-run Baghdad radio reported. Iraqi officials said passage was certain. Saddam said the Germans should go free because of what he called the history of excellent ties between Germany and the Arab world. There was no indication of when the releases would take place. German Chancellor Helmut Kohl has expressed a reluctance to exercise the military option against Iraq. On Sunday, he urged President Bush to exhaust all other possible options before resorting to military force to try to drive Iraqi forces from Kuwait. Earlier this week, Iraq said all foreigners would be set free between Christmas and March 25, but Information Minister Latif Nassiyif Jassim indicated Monday that some might be allowed to leave earlier. However, he also indicated that passage of a U.N. resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq might hinder the releases. There are about 280 Germans left in Iraq and Kuwait, with some held at strategic sites in an effort to ward off an attack by the U.S.-led multinational forces seeking to force Iraq out of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: 35 Injured in Clashes, Capital Shuts During General Strike
LaserPhoto DHA2
DOC.TEXT: Riot police swinging steel-tipped batons today dispersed about 200 rock-hurling protesters who were enforcing a general strike to demand the ouster of President Hussain Muhammad Ershad. The 24-hour nationwide strike apparently was successful in the capital, where businesses shut and streets were deserted. Buses and bicycle rickshaws also stayed off the roads. At least 20 people were injured in the clash with the police in downtown Dhaka. Some of the victims were hit on the head with rifle butts. In another part of the city, 15 studets were injured when they were attacked by supporters of Ershad with sticks and knives, United News of Bangladesh said. The news agency said the students were opposition activists and were forcing shops and offices to close in central Dhaka. Government offices were open but few people attended. Most workers walked to work and ministers drove to their offices before the strike began at 6 a.m. Opposition parties led by the Awami League and the Bangladesh Nationalist Party intensified their anti-Ershad campaign Oct. 10, calling a series of strikes and demonstrations that often turned violent. At least eight protesters have been fatally shot by police since. Today's shutdown was the seventh in a month called by the opposition, which wants Ershad to resign before the national elections scheduled next year. Ershad has refused. On Monday, at least 200 people were injured in 13 towns across the country during clashes between police and supporters and opponents of Ershad. About 100 people were injured when pro- and anti-Ershad groups fought with crude bombs and rocks in Rajshahi, 120 miles north of Dhaka, United News Of Bangladesh said. In the southern port city of Chittagong, police fired bullets and tear gas to quell anti-government demonstrators, leaving at least 40 people injured. Bengali-language newspaper Sangbad said another 60 people were injured in clashes in 11 other towns. The 60-year-old president seized power in a bloodless coup in 1982. He quit the army after winning presidential elections in 1986 that observers said were heavily rigged. Ershad has promised to hold another presidential election in 1991, but the opposition has vowed to boycott it, saying the polls are certain to be rigged again. They demand that Ershad resign and hand over power to a caretaker government until the elections decide the new leadership. Opposition leaders also have rejected Ershad's assurance that the 1991 elections will not be rigged and that he will invite foreign observers, including former President Jimmy Carter, to monitor the polls.

DOC.HEAD: Police Blame Guns, Drugs For Oakland's Homicide Record
DOC.TEXT: Police blame guns and drugs for a deadly onslaught they say has brought more homicides to Oakland this year than ever before. The fatal shootings of two late Sunday in an area known for drug activity brought the number of killings for the first 10{ months of 1990 to 149, police said. During all of last year, a record 148 people were killed. Police Lt. Mike Sims said drugs were involved in about 30 percent of the city's slayings and guns were used in about 75 percent. He said he doesn't see the city of 350,000 reducing its homicide rate until ``the overall cause of drugs and violence are surpressed.'' Three of the weekend's five killings appeared drug-related, police said, and one involved a 15-year-old who was killed when two other teen-agers fired into a crowd with shotguns.

DOC.HEAD: Burma Sentences Opposition Leaders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with background, details. Adds byline. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Burma's military rulers have sentenced two opposition leaders to 10-year jail terms in the toughest move yet against the party that won national elections in May, a political source said today. A military tribunal sentenced Kyi Maung and Chit Khaing of the National League for Democracy on Monday, said the source, who was contacted in Rangoon from Bangkok and spoke on condition of anonymity. At the time of his arrest, Kyi Maung, 72, was acting leader of the league, which won the May 27 elections by a landslide but has been barred from taking office by the military government. Most of the rest of the party's leadership also is behind bars. Both men were arrested on Sept. 6. It appeared they were sentenced under the terms of Burma's Official Secrets Act, the source said. Violation of the act carries a maximum prison term of 14 years, the source said. Western diplomats said at the time of the arrests that the men apparently were accused of passing to other league members a confidential document given to them by the chief of military intelligence, Maj. Gen. Khin Nyunt. Kyi Maung and Chit Khaing were among the 392 members of the National League for Democracy who won parliamentary seats in the election. Both were members of the central executive committee. Political sources in Rangoon report that authorities have arrested at least 50 other members of the party, including about 15 elected members of parliament, since the end of October. Only four of the league's 10-person central executive committee remain free. On Nov. 9, a leading organizer of the party, Maung Ko, died in military custody, and political sources said relatives believed he was tortured to death. The head of the military government, Gen. Saw Maung, said Maung Ko had committed suicide. The general secretary of the party, Aung San Suu Kyi, has been under house arrest since July 1989. Its chairman, Tin Oo, was sentenced in December to three years in prison, with hard labor. Saw Maung's government came to power in September 1988, when troops killed thousands of people to crush a nationwide pro-democracy uprising. His latest clampdown has included raids on Buddhist monasteries and the arrest of at least 200 dissident monks, political sources have said. Kyi Maung, a retired army colonel, was considered a moderate with the potential to mediate between the military and more radical elements of his own party. Chit Khaing, 69, headed the league's publications wing. Saw Maung indicated in a speech on Nov. 13 that Kyi Maung's arrest may have been related to an interview he gave to the Hong Kong-based magazine Asiaweek following the election. In the interview, Kyi Maung expressed his views on whether military officers would be tried by a future opposition-led government for ordering the killings of demonstrators. Kyi Maung said there would be no witch hunt, but added that Khin Nyunt might reasonably feel insecure about the possibility. On July 13, Khin Nyunt called the statement insulting and said he could sue Kyi Maung.

DOC.HEAD: AmeriCares Relief Group Sending Food, Medicine to Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: A relief group has a special Christmas gift for the Soviet Union - 220,000 pounds of food and medicine. AmeriCares, which normally sends such supplies to countries that have just been stricken by natural disasters, is making this shipment in the hope of avoiding a disastrous food shortage next year. ``Our people (in the Soviet Union) said ... this was going to be a bleak winter,'' AmeriCares spokesman Steve Norman said Monday. ``Our whole idea is, hopefully, to avert any severe shortages.'' The Soviet Union is facing a shortage of potatoes and other crops that rotted before they could be delivered to market. In Leningrad, officials voted last week to begin wide-scale food rationing Dec. 1. The first of three AmeriCares airlifts is scheduled to arrive in Moscow on Dec. 13 carrying supplies destined for 24 orphanges. The other shipments are to arrive around Christmas and will go to hospitals and social service agencies. Volunteer doctors will also arrive in Moscow at that time. The Christmas shipments continue a relationship AmeriCares began with the Soviet Union following the country's devastating Armenian earthquake of 1988. ``We're hoping that this might be an encouragement for other groups to do the same thing,'' Norman said.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Summit Rdp Bjt
Hungarian Hopes For Dissolution of Warsaw Pact by '92
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS lede to reflect that Hungarian prime minister urged dissolution of the alliance by 1992, sted any formal agreement to that end.
DOC.TEXT: Hungarian Prime Minister Jozsef Antall said today he hopes the Warsaw Pact can be dissolved by 1992. ``New democracies in middle and eastern Europe are now standing before the task of a new formulation of their relations and of their security policies,'' Antall told the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. ``We hope that the conditions for the complete dissolution of the Warsaw Pact within the European security process will be created by early 1992,'' he said. ``We are happy that the participating states of the (Warsaw Pact) have shown agreement over the dissolution of the military organization.'' The Warsaw Pact was founded in 1955. Antall is the first Warsaw Pact country leader to talk about the complete demise of the pact and to propose a deadline. In the past, the leaders have spoken only of ending the Warsaw Pact's military function. However, the future of the pact has been one of major subjects of the three-day meeting on the post-Cold War restructuring of Europe. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev said Monday that the six remaining members of the Warsaw Pact ``are likely to take important decisions before the end of the year on transforming the organization and changing its character.'' He did not provide details. Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel called the Warsaw Pact ``a remnant of the past.'' ``It came into being as a typical product of Stalinist expansionism,'' Havel said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Sues TV Station Alleging Sex Discrimination
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `EEOC Chairman ...,' to RESTORE dropped word `anchorwoman.'
DOC.TEXT: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has filed a sex discrimination lawsuit against a Baltimore TV station accused of firing an anchorwoman because she demanded the same pay as her male counterparts. Officials said the lawsuit Monday against WBAL and parent company Hearst Corp. is the first such action by the federal agency against a TV station. EEOC Chairman Evan Kemp Jr. said the agency found that former anchorwoman Ruth Ann ``Rudy'' Miller was paid less than her male counterparts for similar duties and fired in 1989 because she demanded equal pay. Miller earned $141,000 a year when she was fired, compared to $170,000 and $180,000 for two male anchormen, the EEOC said. The lawsuit, filed in federal court, also claims Miller was given different assignments and faced increased scrutiny of her clothes and hairstyle because she is a woman. The lawsuit seeks back wages and an equal amount in damages. Miller filed her own lawsuit in January alleging similar violations. She demanded $200,000 in damages. ``It is ironic and disturbing that an organization devoted to protecting the public's interest paid so little attention to illegal discriminatory activities within its own ranks,'' Kemp said. The lawsuit should ``send a message throughout the country'' to TV stations, he said. David Barrett, station vice president and general manager, denied the allegations. He said Miller earned less because she refused to anchor the 11 p.m. newscast. She had been anchoring the noon and 5 p.m. newscasts when her contract was not renewed. Miller, 41, is now host of a daily radio talk show in Baltimore and publishes the monthly Maryland Family Magazine. She said if the lawsuit ``helps other women, God, that's great.'' Gerald Kiel, EEOC regional attorney, said the commission sued after negotiations to reach a settlement failed.

DOC.HEAD: A Top Priority on New Germany's Global Agenda: Help the Soviets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 8 grafs new with Kohl speech urging support for Eastern Europe.
DOC.TEXT: German Chancellor Helmut Kohl appealed to the world's affluent nations to help Eastern Europe's transition to democracy so that it doesn't collapse from economic hardships and social unrest. With the end of the Cold War divisions, ``there must now be no borders which perpetuate the prosperity divide,'' Kohl told the 34 leaders of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. The newly united Germany is placing aid to the Soviet Union high on its agenda of shaping the post-Cold War world order. Germany is coordinating emergency international food deliveries to help the Soviets overcome severe shortages and alleviate the winter cold. President Bush said Monday he would be willing to send food, too. Unlike his American, Soviet and British counterparts, Kohl in his speech avoided direct mention of the Persian Gulf crisis. He expressed worry about growing nationalism in parts of Eastern Europe, and the plight of ethnic minorities. ``Outmoded hostile stereotyping from the days of (Cold War) confrontation must not be replaced by backward-looking nationalism,''said Kohl. Kohl also formally pledged that the reunited Germany will only use its global muscle for the pursuit of peace, and won't repeat mistakes of the past. ``Peace alone will emanate from German soil,'' said Kohl. German experts will be sent to the Soviet Union next week to examine needs, Kohl told reporters Monday night. Kohl said he spoke with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev about the proposed aid. President Bush also said Monday that the United States is willing to send emergency food supplies to the Soviet Union, and Kohl said the plan is supported by British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. ``We'll talk about this in the EC (European Community) very soon,'' said Kohl, adding that EC leaders have already told him they are ready to help out. He said some supplies could be shipped by train as early as next week. Kohl and Gorbachev have been steering their countries closer together in the past few months. The chancellor wants to help Gorbachev keep the Soviet Union from collapsing, at least partly because of the economic shock waves it could send into Europe. Kohl said he impressed on Gorbachev the importance of making sure food shipments from the West are not backed up at the border by the Soviet Union's slow-moving bureaucracy. Kohl is making his debut as leader of the united Germany at the summit. Before the Oct. 3 unification, Kohl's West Germany already was Europe's mightiest economic machine, and German economic power is expected to expand even further in the next few years.

DOC.HEAD: Housing Starts Down 6 Percent in October
DOC.TEXT: Housing starts plummeted 6.0 percent in October to their lowest level since the last recession, the government said today. And as a portent of things to come, building permit applications plunged to their lowest level since the 1981-82 downturn. The Commerce Department said starts of new homes and apartments fell to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.04 million units following declines of 2.1 percent in September and 1.9 percent in August. Housing starts through October have declined for nine straight months, the first time that has occurred since the department began keeping records in 1959. And the number of October starts was the lowest since 902,000 units got under way in June 1982. The housing industry has been in a slump for more than a year, with starts during the first 10 months of 1990 down 12.4 percent from the same period of 1989. The department also said applications for building permits, often a barometer of future activity, fell 6.8 percent to 925,000. It was the lowest level since 913,000 applications were filed in June 1982. ``Tighter credit conditions and plummeting demand continue to take their toll on the residential housing industry,'' economists with the Mitsubishi Bank in New York wrote in their Weekly Economic Indicator Report. The weakness resulted in the loss of 80,000 construction jobs in October, the Labor Department reported earlier. Over the past five months, the industry has seen jobs tumble by 185,000. Analysts see no immediate improvement. ``We look for further deterioration through year-end, although the pace of decline could moderate,'' economists with Fuji Securities Inc. in Chicago wrote in their weekly Perspectives. ``No upturn is expected until next spring at the earliest,'' said Michael K. Evans, head of Evans Economics Inc. in Washington. Construction of single-family units dropped 1.0 percent to 854,000 units following a 3.2 percent increase the previous month. Multi-family starts plunged 23.3 percent to 187,000 units after a 17.3 percent drop in September. The Northeast, which has seen some of the slowest housing activity recently, posted the only gain in starts - up 38.5 percent to 144,000 units. Starts were down 16.9 percent to 266,000 units in the West, and 10.4 percent to 395,000 units in the South. Starts were off 2.5 percent to 236,000 in the Midwest.

DOC.HEAD: Execution of Labor Leader Joe Hill Remembered
DOC.TEXT: Some 200 people gathered for a candlelight vigil to commemorate the 75th anniversary of the execution of labor leader Joe Hill. Hill, a songwriter, poet and union organizer whose tunes condemned capitalist bosses and promoted workers' rights and union solidarity, was executed by a firing squad in Utah on Nov. 19, 1915. He was convicted of two slayings, but supporters believed he was a victim of the anti-labor sentiment that flared after bitter strikes in Utah's copper mines. ``Joe Hill was larger than life, even when he was alive, because he reached into the heart, soul and psyche of the people,'' Steve Banick, Amnesty International, said at the ceremony Monday night. ``He promoted workers' rights and human rights.'' Rosalie Sorrels sang several labor-organizing ballads including ``I Dreamed I Saw Joe Hill Last Night'' and ``The Rebel Girl.'' After the program the crowd carried candles to the spot in Sugarhouse Park where the state prison once stood and Hill was put to death.

DOC.HEAD: Socialists Prepare to Settle Scores After Censure Fails
DOC.TEXT: The governing Socialists pledged today to settle scores with their former Communist allies after Prime Minister Michel Rocard squeaked through a no-confidence vote in parliament. The Communists, normally allied with the Socialists in the National Assembly, defected Monday and voted with three opposition conservative parties in favor of the no-confidence motion. But the coalition fell five ballots short of the absolute majority of 289 needed in the 577-seat assembly. Socialist Party First Secretary Pierre Mauroy, in a radio interview today, pledged revenge on the Communists. ``We're going to go to all the city halls controlled by the left to say to the Communists, `We had agreements, you didn't keep them, you mixed your votes with those of the right,'' said Mauroy, a former prime minister. The vote came while France hosted the 34-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. The no-confidence vote was the most serious challenge to Rocard's leadership since the Socialists returned to power in 1988. The main conservative parties - the Rally for the Republic, Union for French Democracy and Union of the Center - filed the no-confidence motion over a social security tax proposed by Rocard. The Socialists normally rely on the Communists to abstain from such votes, allowing the government a comfortable margin of security. But the Communists pledged this time to vote with the right, bringing a combined potential of 286 votes behind the measure. The coalition needed just three independent deputies to win. The Socialists, who have only 272 seats, managed to get support from some independent deputies and some stray conservatives and Communists, leaving the opposition five votes short. Conservative leader Charles Millon predicted that a wave of troubles besieging the government would continue, including demonstrations by high school students demanding better education. Their protests occasionally have turned into riots. Other troubles include a slowing economy, a campaign fund-raising scandal implicating Justice Minister Henri Nallet and rioting by youths in suburban ghettos outside Paris and Lyon. Rocard had no comment after the vote except to thank the parliamentarians for their support. The effort to oust Rocard was prompted by a dispute over his proposal for a 1.1 percent social security tax. It would replace part of the existing social security fund, which is subsidized by employers and employees. The Communists and conservatives opposed the plan, saying it would levy taxes on some previously exempt retired and unemployed people. They also say the tax could be raised in coming years. Rocard says the tax would streamline the social security system and reduce the tax burden on most poor and middle-income people.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Briton Went Missing Six Months Ago
DOC.TEXT: The newspaper Ad-Diyar published a letter today from friends of a British national saying he disappeared in Lebanon seven months ago and they feared he was kidnapped. The Arabic-language letter, signed by ``Friends of British businessman Robin Gregson,'' said his disappearance was reported to the British Embassy three months ago but was ignored. ``Our friend Robin Gregson went missing more than six months ago between the town of Chekka and the port of Jounieh. He was heading for Jounieh to leave via its port on April 21,'' the letter said. Chekka is a coastal town in Syrian-policed north Lebanon and Jounieh is the main port in the Christian enclave. A passenger boat line serves the Christian enclave with daily trips from Jounieh to Larnaca, Cyprus. ``We have inquired about his whereabouts with the Lebanese and Cypriot immigration authorities as well as with a number of political parties in north Lebanon, but to no avail,'' the letter said. ``The British Embassy was informed of the matter three months ago, but unfortunately it did not show any interest in the disappearance of one of its citizens,'' the report added. Police said they have no record on Gregson and telephone calls to the British Embassy in Beirut's northern suburb of Jal el-Deeb were not answered. The letter suggested that Gregson was kidnapped. ``To his kidnappers we say: Release Robin so he could return to his family and friends. More than seven years ago he chose to live in Lebanon because he loved Lebanon despite all that has happened,'' the letter concluded. The letter did not indicate where the friends lived. Because his disappearance remains unconfirmed, Gregson was not listed among the 13 Westerners missing in Lebanon, most believed kidnapped by pro-Iranian underground factions. The hostages include six Americans. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, who was kidnapped on March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor: Lie Shows He's Not Perfect
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with comment from Ms. Dodrill. Picks up 6th graf, `Rinehart said ...' SUBS 23rd graf, `Ms. Dodrill has ...' to DELETE outdated material. Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CO1 of Nov. 19.
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Dana Rinehart launched a citywide honesty campaign last year that drew national attention, but now he's admitted that he lied about having an extramarital affair. ``You find somebody whose life is perfect, and let him lead the campaign. My life is not perfect,'' Rinehart said Monday in an interview with The Associated Press. Until last weekend, Rinehart called reports of his affair with Human Services Director Brenda Dodrill an ``outhouse rumor.'' But in an interview Saturday with a radio station, the 44-year-old mayor acknowledged the affair. ``I flat wasn't telling the truth,'' Rinehart told WTVN-AM. ``I'm not proud of what's happened, but I'm not unhappy about it,'' Ms. Dodrill said in a newspaper interview published today. ``As far as a personal relationship, we'll have to see what happens. We don't have any plans.'' She said her involvement with Rinehart was a private matter, adding, ``I'm not an elected public official.'' Rinehart said Monday he lied to protect innocent people. ``It was not truthful. I'm sorry about that. ... I felt that my willingness to take that risk, knowing full well that someday I would have this conversation with a reporter - I would pay for this. I was trying to protect them,'' he said. Rinehart and his wife, Carol, have two children. Rinehart, a Republican in his second four-year term, announced July 22 that he would not seek another term, saying family, financial and political reasons influenced his decision. The following month, he and his wife announced they had separated. Now he says he will not resign and will decide in December whether to seek re-election in 1991. Rinehart was at the forefront of a 1989 campaign called ``Take an Honest Look.'' He established the Columbus Commission on Ethics and Values after an incident in which the rear doors of an armored car flew open, spilling thousands of dollars onto a downtown highway. Motorists grabbed the cash and most of them kept it. Newspaper advertisements and broadcast commercials urged residents to ``examine honesty as it affects our daily lives.'' A former Watergate conspirator, the Rev. Jeb Stuart Magruder, was chairman of the commission. He has since moved from Columbus to Lexington, Ky., to become minister of the First Presbyterian Church. Like Magruder, many members of the commission, which included City Council members and religious, business and education leaders, declined to comment about the matter. But John S. Christie, who served on the commission during the campaign, said he didn't think the affair would hinder Rinehart's effectiveness as mayor. ``I have always found the mayor, as an administrator on city business, to be a very good mayor,'' said Christie, vice president for corporate development at Battelle Memorial Research Institute. ``Even though there are personal problems, I still think he has the ability and the wherewithal to keep high standards as it relates to running the business of the city of Columbus.'' Rinehart, 44, said he would continue to serve on the commission. Ms. Dodrill, 32, began working at City Hall in 1986 as a $28,205-a-year personnel specialist. She was appointed to her post last year and makes $66,685 a year. Ms. Dodrill's husband, Douglas Matteson, sued for divorce on Oct. 30 and later filed court documents alleging an affair between Rinehart and Ms. Dodrill. He alleged that Rinehart and Ms. Dodrill had been seeing each other since March. They were together ``a couple times a week'' and went out of town together for weekends at least twice, according to the documents. Ms. Dodrill had not reported to work since the relationship was revealed and is on vacation this week. It is not the first sex-related controversy involving Rinehart. In 1978, when Rinehart was Franklin County treasurer, family baby sitter Vicki Rae Pardue accused him of sexually assaulting her. Ms. Pardue alleged that, while napping at Rinehart's home after baby sitting his children, she awoke to find him performing oral sex on her. Rinehart denied the allegations. A county grand jury investigated but did not issue an indictment.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lede to change ``most'' to ``many'' combat reservists, reflecting Pentagon correcting itself on status of three National Guard combat brigades. Subs pvs 6th graf, The Army, with 3 new grafs, also reflecting Pentagon changing information.
DOC.HEAD: Army, Marines Call Up Additional 26,000 Reserves
DOC.TEXT: The Army and Marine Corps are ordering to active duty 26,625 additional reservists, many for combat roles, as the military reaches into hundreds of communities nationwide to bolster its Persian Gulf deployments. The callups announced Monday were the largest on a single day since President Bush authorized the use of citizen-soldiers in the gulf crisis in August. It also was the Army's first call to arms for reserve combat units, which some critics have said may not be adequately prepared for desert warfare against Iraq. Since the start of Operation Desert Shield on Aug. 7, a total of 77,126 reservists have been called up - most in non-combat roles such as transportation and cargo handling. It is the biggest call-up of reservists since the Berlin crisis of 1961. The Army said Monday it ordered 20,129 National Guard and Reserve members from 41 states, Puerto Rico and the District of Columbia to report for active duty Wednesday. The Army had put those units on alert for possible call-up last Friday. The Pentagon initially said the Army units included three National Guard combat brigades totaling about 12,000 troops - the 48th Infantry Brigade (Mechanized) of Georgia, the 155th Armored Brigade of Mississippi and the 256th Infantry Brigade (Mechanized) of Louisiana. But today it said they were not included. Maj. Doug Hart, a Pentagon spokesman, said he had misunderstood the makeup of the Army units being activated, and that while they included some combat reservists - such as the 1st Battalion, 158th Field Artillery of the Oklahoma National Guard - they did not include elements of the Georgia, Mississippi and Louisiana brigades. Elements of those three brigades were alerted last Friday that they would be called up soon, but none has been officially ordered to active duty, Hart said today. Each of those three brigades is a ``roundout'' unit for a regular Army armored or mechanized division, but none was called up in the initial deployment of more than 230,000 forces to the gulf. It's still not certain that the three brigades will be sent to the front lines; they are scheduled to undergo desert warfare training in the United States before a deployment decision is made. Reservists normally train one weekend per month plus one two-week exercise a year. The Marine Corps said it was ordering 6,496 reservists to active duty for Desert Shield. Most are expected to be deployed to the gulf as part of Marine reinforcements totaling about 45,000 men. About 45,000 regular Marines already are in the gulf area. The Marine reserves, from units in 23 states and the District of Columbia, will report for duty starting Saturday with the 2nd Marie Expeditionary Force at Camp Lejeune, N.C. That unit is expected to deploy to the gulf. The missions of the Marine reserves in the latest call-up include air defense, mechanized and infantry operations, close air support, radar and artillery. Bush has authorized a maximum call-up of 125,000 reserves from all services. The reserve forces total more than 1.1 million men and women.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Launch Nationwide Attacks
DOC.TEXT: Leftist guerrillas today attacked military positions in eastern and central El Salvador in what they said was a nationwide campaign. At least 10 people were killed, according to preliminary reports. The victims were mostly rebel or government combatants, the reports said. The rebels, in a communique, said the attacks on a dozen military positions did not constitute a major offensive, but rather ``a nationwide military campaign.'' The guerrilla communique said the campaign was dubbed ``Punishment of the Armed Forces.'' The most concentrated and sustained attacks appeared to be on garrisons and army positions in the eastern cities of San Francisco Gotera and Usulutan. Residents of the those towns said the attacks began about 3 a.m. (4 a.m. EST) and that sporadic fighting continued until after dawn. Local radio stations with correspondents in the provinces, as well as the Armed Forces Press Committee, also reported attacks on army posts in the towns of San Jose Guayabal, Suchitoto, Nejapa, Apopa and Quetzaletpeque. All five towns are in a radius of 15 miles north of San Salvador. Preliminary reports indicated four soldiers killed and 20 wounded in the fighting. Six rebels were killed and four wounded, according to the same reports. The guerrilla high command threatened to escalate the level of fighting if the government and the military refused to negotiate sweeping reforms in the armed forces. It said there could be cease-fire only when the armed forces impunity in human rights cases ends. The campaign comes only days after the anniversary of the army massacre of six Jesuit priests on Nov. 16, 1989. The priests were slain amid a bloody rebel offensive in the capital. Thousands of leftists, suspected leftists, human rights activists, intellectuals, labor activists and government opponents have died at the hands of the military or military-linked death squads during the decade-long civil war. In all, more than 72,000 people, mainly civilians, have been killed.

DOC.HEAD: Serviceman's Son Says `Sadly Insane' Took Daddy Away
DOC.TEXT: An Air Force sergeant's 3{-year-old son has unwittingly come up with a new nickname for Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, a moniker that has the White House laughing. It took Pam Averill a minute to figure out what her son, Kyle, meant when he said, ``Sadly Insane took Daddy away.'' Kyle's father, Sgt. Kenneth Averill, was shipped from Loring Air Force Base in Limestone, Maine, to an island off the coast of Saudi Arabia on Aug. 20, 18 days after Hussein's troops invaded Kuwait. ``He has heard us talking and it's hard for a little kid to say `Saddam Hussein,' '' said Averill, who moved from the air base to live with her parents while her husband is away. ``It's even hard for me to say it.'' Kyle's grandmother, Joyce Austin, wrote President Bush to let him in on the joke. A typed reply from the White House carried the handwritten note at the end: ``Sadly Insane? I love it.'' Apparently, someone in Washington thinks it's funny enough to spread around, Averill said. ``Someone from the White House called to tell us the president might use the phrase in a speech,'' she said. ``They didn't want to get our hopes up, but wanted to let us know it might happen.''

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Imposes Death Penalty for Illegal Grain Trading
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to CLARIFY that law applies to trading. Picks up 5th graf pvs ``Farmers will..
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: The National Assembly has declared a government monopoly on the trading of wheat, barley, rice, corn and other cereals and mandated the death penalty for anyone violating the law, the state press said today. The 250-member parliament passed the law late Monday, saying it was necessary because of shortages caused by the U.N. embargo. The assembly said the law was needed to deter greed. The law bans sales of grains for trading by both private sector middlemen and farmers. The government will have a monopoly on both sales and storage. Farmers will be allowed to keep 1,000 pounds of wheat for their personal use and 400 pounds of rice, but the rest must be turned over to the goverment within two weeks of harvest. The annual rice harvest is just starting; the wheat harvest usually begins in April. Before the invasion, Iraq imported 70 percent of its food. Iraq has two rivers and abundant fertile land, but the government gave agricultural development a much lower priority than industrial growth. The U.N. embargo, imposed as part of efforts to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, cut off most imports. During the debate, some assembly members suggested that the penalty be life in prison, but the majority voted for the death penalty, the report said. The parliament is dominated by members of the ruling Arab Baath Socialist Party and generally viewed as a rubber stamp for policy initiated by the ruling command council under President Saddam Hussein.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor to Investigate Presidential Dark Horse
With PM-Poland-Walesa
DOC.TEXT: Stanislaw Tyminski, a millionaire who returned to his homeland after 21 years abroad to wage a strong campaign for president, today rejected charges that he slandered the government. Tyminski told reporters his statements are ``from the heart'' and he will not apologize. The justice minister on Monday announced a preliminary slander investigation of Tyminski, a Polish-born businessman who recently returned after making a fortune in Peru and Canada. The inquiry stems from his statements to voters Nov. 17 in the southern resort of Zakopane. Polls indicate Tyminski, who is backing his candidacy with his personal wealth, is running a surprisingly strong third behind Lech Walesa and Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki. Tyminski today accused Mazowiecki of ``ignorance of the best interests of the country in the economic sense.'' Earlier, Tyminski accused the prime minister of ``betraying the people.'' On a nationwide television broadcast Monday he tried to back up the charge by showing documents purportedly proving the government plans to sell state assets at greatly undervalued prices.
