However, it turned out that Tyminski was mistaken - the figures on the documents were not the selling prices for enterprises to be privatized but summaries of sales turnover. Nonetheless, he said he did not intend to withdraw his accusation, adding: ``I made the statement because I was right.'' Tyminski says he is a self-made millionaire who left Poland at 21, spent several months in Sweden and then moved to Canada in 1970 to seek his fortune. He says he spent the early 1980s in an Amazon River port in Peru, operating a cable television outfit and a restaurant, before returning to Canada, where he runs Transduction Ltd., a computer automation company outside Toronto. He says he is the leader of the Libertarian Party of Canada. A poll by the state-owned polling service Friday showed Tyminski was supported by 17 percent of those who intend to vote, behind Mazowiecki with 19 percent and Solidarity leader Lech Walesa with 35 percent. A second poll Sunday produced similar results. A fresh face promising to apply his business wizardry to the shattered economy, Tyminski seemed to appeal to disenchanted Poles looking for an alternative to Walesa and Mazowiecki. While Tyminski had been written off by most media in Poland until his latest surge in the polls, he is now the center of attention. ``A Liar or a Fool'' was today's headline about Tyminski in the nation's largest newspaper, Gazeta Wyborcza.

DOC.HEAD: US Military Chief Says Iraqi Reinforcement Plan May Backfire
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's announced plan to send 250,000 more troops to Kuwait is a publicity ploy and may hurt rather than help the Iraqi army's war-fighting ability, Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today. The state-run Iraqi News Agency reported Monday that President Saddam Hussein had decided to form seven additional army divisions and call up more than 150,000 reservists and regulars, ``adding to our forces over a quarter of a million fighters.'' Iraq already has about 430,000 troops in Kuwait and southern Iraq, according to Pentagon estimates, facing off in the gulf area against 230,000 American forces and at least 100,000 forces of U.S. allies and other Arab nations. President Bush two weeks ago announced plans to send U.S. reinforcements to the gulf that are expected to increase the American force to about 430,000 by January. In an interview today with ``CBS This Morning,'' Powell said the announced Iraq reinforcement plan didn't trouble U.S. military planners, who are preparing for a possible order from Bush to launch an offensive to liberate Kuwait. ``It's not clear that large numbers of additional, probably less capable units significantly adds to his combat power in theatre; and in fact, might present him with new vulnerabilities rather than added strength,'' Powell said. The four-star general also said it is possible that Saddam is planning to use the extra troops as replacements to allow weary soldiers to rotate back from the front lines. ``He may be thinking of doing some rotations and some reliefs in place,'' Powell said. ``We'll see. But at the moment, it's just part of his headline-of-the-day program where he tries to divert world opinion from his own aggression. Yesterday was a troop buildup. The day before that, it was a hostage release. I think we always have to keep coming back to the fundamental point that he is trying to divert attention from his aggression, the fact that he invaded a neighboring country, and now he is threatening peace in the region.''

DOC.HEAD: Activation of Guard Unit Shifts Homeless From Armory
DOC.TEXT: About 150 homeless people who sought shelter in a National Guard armory were evicted to make room for 200 guardsmen mobilizing for service in the Middle East. ``It's part of the craziness of these times,'' Philip Mangano, executive director of the Greater Boston Adult Shelter Alliance, said Monday. ``Operation Desert Shield takes precedence over the sort of basic shield for people. It's a bizarre situation.'' The homeless sheltered in the armory in the West Newton section were moved about seven miles to an armory in Cambridge, guard officials said. Mangano said such a move is traumatic for people who must now get used to new surroundings. ``The time to warehouse people has passed, and nothing shows that more than the events of this weekend, when we were forced to deal with human beings as though they were less important than the weapons being brought here,'' Mangano said. A dozen shelter workers spent Monday stacking cots, moving office equipment, dismantling the health clinic and packing kitchen supplies. About 200 members of the 972nd Military Police combat unit of the Army National Guard are to be processed through the armory before being activated.

DOC.HEAD: Explosives Found at City's Main Fuel Storage Depot
DOC.TEXT: More than 130 sticks of dynamite and other explosives were found today in the capital's main oil storage area one day after a bombing attack on the home of the country's justice secretary. The incident was the latest sign of rising political tension in Manila. On Monday, The Manila Times and The Manila Chronicle quoted unidentified military sources as saying they expected right-wing extremists to launch a new coup attempt next month. Police said the amount of explosives placed at the oil depot could have set off a huge fire. The depot is in a densely populated residential district of flimsy, frame houses. ``The ones who planted the bombs knew what they were doing,'' police Cpl. Edilberto Capacete said. Police said they did not know who planted the explosives, which were booby-trapped to go off if disturbed. They said a janitor and a security guard found the explosives near a group of six storage tanks at a Shell Oil Co. facility, about a mile east of President Corazon Aquino's office. Facundo Roco, Shell company spokesman, said the bombs were placed in four pipes leading to six fuel tanks. Each fuel tank had a capacity of 50,000 liters, he said. Shell officials said the depot can store up to 7.9 million gallons of fuel, but a spokesman refused to say how much oil was actually stored there at the time. On Monday, four bombs hurled by unknown assailants exploded at the home of Justice Secretary Franklin Drilon but he, his wife and two children escaped injury. Drilon is responsible for prosecuting left-wing and right-wing extremists opposed to President Corazon Aquino. Also today, the military said Communist rebels killed five civilian militiamen and two soldiers in an ambush in a remote village in the southern Philippines. There were no reports of casualties on the rebel side in Monday's attack. The military said about 70 New People's Army guerrillas ambushed a platoon of army soldiers and militiamen on patrol near the town of Lapuyan, about 85 miles west of Iligan. Iligan is about 500 miles south of Manila. The rebels have been waging a 21-year-old insurgency to establish a Marxist state.

DOC.HEAD: Fire That Triggered Missiles Deliberately Set, Newspaper Says
DOC.TEXT: A fire that triggered the launch of two anti-aircraft missiles in the Soviet Far East was deliberately set, possibly by a discharged officer, a newspaper today quoted investigators as saying. Komsomolskaya Pravda, the Communist youth newspaper, said an investigating committee determined an arsonist set fire to a bucket of gasoline underneath one of the missiles' engines in the Nov. 15 incident, in the Amur region near the Chinese border. The committee is headed by I.M. Tretyak, commander-in-chief of the air defense troops. The fire set off the launching system and the missile struck and destroyed a radar station, the newspaper said. The launch of the first missile triggered a second missile, which hit a barracks where servicemen were sleeping. The official Tass news agency reported last week that the second missile killed one soldier and injured eight soldiers. Tass reported safety devices on the missiles prevented their warheads from exploding. ``A bucket full of gasoline was put under the solid propellant engine of one missile, and set on fire,'' Komsomolskaya Pravda said. ``But another missile was fired, too. There could have been many more casualties.'' The newspaper said investigators believe the fire may have been set by a discharged officer, or may have been an act of revenge, although it did not say by or against whom. ``Finally, the criminal could have been one of the draftees called up last May and not willing to serve in the army,'' it said. Komsomolskaya Pravda said that three months before the incident, a new commanding officer was assigned to the air defense unit, which it said was ``lacking discipline and showing a low degree of combat preparedness.''

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Keating-Senators
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts of testimony Monday from the Senate Ethics Committee hearing on the ``Keating Five.''
DOC.HEAD: Sen. Dennis DeConcini, speaking in his own defense:
DOC.TEXT: ``All of the evidence that has been admitted, as I understand now that lies over there - some 44 volumes. ... This information contains heresay. ... It contains rumors, unfounded allegations about all the senators, I dare say. ... ``Now, Mr. Chairman, I regret that I have to mention and make reference to Mr. Bennett (special counsel Robert S. Bennett) because of the manner in which he presented the case Thursday and Friday. ... He wants a victory. He wants to nail somebody. He wants to get somebody, I'm sorry to say. He wants another trophy on the wall. ... ``But it has been said many times, this is not a trial. This is supposed to be a fact-finding hearing where we get an opportunity to lay our case out for you and the American public. ... ``Constituent service to me is very important. ... And when a constituent, someone from Arizona, walks in to my office, we have no discrimination, whether they are Republican, Democrat, liberal, conservative, rich, poor, even if they are not registered voters. If they've got a complaint, we listen to them. ... ``What is wrong with intervention from someone who sends you a check to your campaign? Nothing - no more different than what is wrong when American Continental or their employees sent checks to our campaigns. They didn't hand the checks to us and talk about it. ``We've handled 75,000 constituent cases in the 14 years that I have been a senator. And we haven't discriminated, and we don't talk money with them. ... ``Now, let me talk about the case of American Continental and Lincoln. They came to me, as they did to other people, argued their problem and their case, saying they were being mistreated. And I said to them, `Give me some evidence.' ... So what did they do? They got me some pretty powerful evidence - all us - pretty powerful evidence. ... I decided to intervene. That's right. I got in there, with my sleeves up, and decided to go for it. ... ``All the regulators pointed out ... we did nothing improper. ... There was no change made by what we attempted to persuade them to do, or bring to their attention. ... We didn't do anything wrong in any meetings. We acted as senators should have. They weren't intimidated until a couple of years later, when they got darn worried that they hadn't done their jobs. ... ``I was asked to make a status inquiry and I did. There were jobs involved. This was a major employer. ... ``I've had to say some things that are difficult to say about a brother lawyer, a fine prosecutor as far as I know, by reputation. But I've been mistreated by him in this process. ... ``To do other than dismiss the charges against me is unjust. I broke no law. I broke no rule. I broke no standard. I committed no improper conduct. ...
DOC.HEAD: Ethics Committee Special Counsel Robert S. Bennett in response:
DOC.TEXT: ``In essence, what we have heard in response to my very detailed opening is me, my conduct - my conduct. All of this - all of this is my fault. ``Now, members of the committee, I have swum in Senate legal waters for a long time and like a fat old brown trout in Yellowstone River, I am not going to rise to that artificial fly, Senator, and I ask that you not be distracted by it. ... ``The only trophy that I want is a is a real big brown trout. I don't find this particularly enjoyable. In fact, I find it very stressful. I've been asked to do a job, and I've done it. I feel like I'm in a lion's den. ... ``The issue in this case is not me. ... The issue in this case is the conduct of the senators. ``These are the standards that were written by this committee, when it cited as its subject matter jurisdiction the code of ethics for government service, which says that you should never accept for yourself or your family favors or benefits under circumstances which might be construed by reasonable persons as influencing the performance of their governmental duties. ... ``The one thing I've learned in my investigation ... is this case is an aberration, and that you spend each day and every hour of every day with ladies and gentlemen of this United States Senate that manage to deal with these very difficult issues of constituent service and fund-raising. And they do it with honor and they do it with integrity. ...''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Will Allow 122 Western Workers To Go
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with report that 3 Britons, 14 Belgians also will be allowed to leave. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Iraq will release 122 Dutch, Belgian and British nationals who completed a government-commissioned dredging operation, a spokesman for the project said today. Those being allowed to leave are all the Westerners who worked on the dredging project run by the Dutch companies Volker Stevin and Koninklijke Boskalis, project spokesman Gerard Anneveldt said. He said the first workers will arrive home next week. Dutch television reported the 105 Dutchmen, 14 Belgians and 3 Britons will depart by ship. The $60 million dredging project was commissioned by President Saddam Hussein's government before Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. It was completed despite the U.N. trade embargo imposed Aug. 6. The Dutch government said at the time it regarded the project as a service not covered by the embargo. Although dredging was finished several weeks ago, the workers were not allowed to leave until Iraqi officials verified the depth of the channel earlier this week, Anneveldt said. The two Dutch companies dredged a 36-mile-long channel connecting the southern Iraqi port of Umm Qasr to a waterway leading to the Persian Gulf. About 150 Dutch nationals remain in Iraq and Kuwait, including those working on the dredging project. Hundreds of other foreigners have been barred from leaving since Aug. 2, although Saddam has allowed some to leave.

DOC.HEAD: White House Announces Plan for Visit to Turkey
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will make a state visit to Turkey, one of the front line states in the Persian Gulf crisis, within the first six months of 1991, the White House announced today. He will be the first American president to visit Turkey since Dwight D. Eisenhower stopped there in 1959. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Bush, during a meeting today with Turkish President Turgut Ozal, accepted his invitation to visit Turkey ``in the first part of 1991.'' Deputy press secretary Roman Popadiuk defined the time frame as the first six months of next year. Fitzwater said the two leaders would confirm a date soon. ``The president's visit will symbolize the particularly close ties between the United States and Turkey and is intended to contribute to a continuation of the excellent relations between the two countries,'' Fitzwater said in a written statement. Turkey, which borders Iraq, has firmly aligned itself with the United States against Baghdad. On Wednesday, Bush will join in the wrapup of a 34-nation summit here and then fly to Saudi Arabia for talks with King Fahd and the exiled leader of Kuwait, Amir Ahmad al-Sabah. Bush will visit with U.S. troops in the Saudi kingdom on Thanksgiving Day and then fly to Egypt for talks with President Hosni Mubarak.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Announces a Pershing Missile Base Closing
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Army said it removed the last nuclear missiles from a base in southern Germany today as part of a 1988 treaty with the Soviets. Under the treaty, the United States and the Soviet Union pledged to get rid of their intermediate-range nuclear missiles in Europe. The weapons removed today were nine Pershing missiles at the base in Schwaebisch Gmuend, near Stuttgart in Baden-Wuerttemberg, a U.S. military statement said. The United States still has 27 Pershings in Germany and they will be withdrawn gradually, the statement said. The Pershings were deployed in Germany starting in 1983 to counter Soviet SS-20 intermediate-range missiles; 108 Pershings were deployed at the time of the treaty.

DOC.HEAD: Atlanta - Nation's Crime Capital - Begins Enforcing Youth Curfew
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to UPDATE with three children detained over the night. Picks up 3rd graf, `The American....'
DOC.TEXT: America's crime capital imposed the city's strictest curfew since the Atlanta child murders of the early 1980s, threatening to jail parents of youngsters caught on the street after hours. Three children were caught violating the curfew, which went into effect at 11 p.m. Monday, police said today. Two youths were picked up by their parents from police stations. The third, a 12-year-old girl, was taken home after her parents refused to pick her up, said Deputy Chief W.J. Taylor. The girl's parents were issued a warning, Taylor said. He did not say what time the children were picked up. The American Civil Liberties Union has threatened to challenge the law, but city officials say it is needed to help the reverse the highest rate of serious crime in the nation. Mayor Maynrd Jackson praised the curfew, adopted by the City Council 13-1 on Nov. 5, as an excellent way of keeping youngsters from being used as drug runners or lookouts. The measure requires those under 17 to be off the street between 11 p.m. and 6 a.m. weeknights and between midnight and 6 a.m. weekends, unless participating in school activities, returning from work or accompanied by an adult. Parents of repeat offenders could get up to 60 days in jail or $1,000 in fines. Police Chief Eldrin A. Bell said officers would focus on ``known drug locations, nightclubs and places of ill repute.'' FBI statistics show Atlanta had 210 reported serious crimes per 1,000 residents during 1989, higher than any U.S. city. There were 246 murders in Atlanta last year, but 106 between January and June this year, down 14 percent. The curfew is the latest move in the city's effort to control crime, including the hiring of Bell as police chief three months ago. During his 29 years on the force, Bell was twice demoted and developed a reputation in some quarters as a cop willing to bust heads first and let a judge sort things out later. He was cleared of charges of using excessive force during a 1984 incident in which he allegedly pistol whipped a motorist. The curfew is similar to one adopted at the height of a series of 29 slayings of young blacks in metropolitan Atlanta that terrorized the city in the early 1980s. The original curfew applied to children 15 or younger and did not penalize their parents. It had rarely been enforced in recent years. Wayne Williams was convicted in 1982 of murder in two of the 29 slayings of young blacks in metropolitan Atlanta between 1979 and 1981. Investigators have blamed him for 22 more of the slayings. He is serving two life sentences. Officers who spot curfew violators are to take them home if they live nearby. Youths from outside the area will be taken into custody until they can be picked up by a parent. ``What we have asked is for parents to ultimately have responsibility for their children,'' said City Councilwoman Davetta Johnson, who proposed the curfew penalties. But Michael Hauptman, president of the local ACLU chapter, said his organization has notified city officials that it considers the curfew unconstitutional. ``In the event we receive any complaints from parents and or children, it is our intent to take this matter into court,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Northwest Pilot Charged With Drunken Driving Enters Plea
DOC.TEXT: A former Northwest Airlines pilot charged with drunken driving pleaded guilty to a lesser charge and was fined $627. Hans Falkenberg, 39, of Prescott, Wis., was stopped for speeding May 28 in the Twin Cities suburb of Cottage Grove, but refused to submit to a blood-alcohol or urine test. He was given a misdemeanor citation accusing him of driving under the influence of alcohol and pleaded innocent. When stopped, Falkenberg was on his way to work to fly a regular passenger flight. He was fired by the Eagan-based Northwest for violating company rules against drinking within 12 hours of a scheduled flight. He is appealing the firing. Falkenberg pleaded guilty last week in Washington County District Court in Stillwater to careless driving. He also was given a suspended sentence of 45 days in jail and an additional $200 fine on the condition that he commit no similar offenses and have no alcohol or drug convictions for a year, said Cottage Grove City Attorney Jack Clinton. Falkenberg has entered an alcoholism treatment program and agreed to follow recommendations made upon completion of a chemical dependency assessment. Almost three months before Falkenberg was pulled over, three Northwest Airlines pilots were arrested after flying a passenger plane while intoxicated from Fargo, N.D., to Minneapolis. The pilots were convicted and sentenced to prison terms ranging from 12 to 16 months.

DOC.HEAD: Sikh Militants Kill 13 in Attack on Market
DOC.TEXT: Suspected Sikh separatists opened fire today on a busy shopping area of the city, killing 13 people and injuring at least 15, police and witnesses said. It was the latest in a series of killings over the past few days in the northern state of Punjab, the scene of a lingering separatist campaign by Sikh militants. At least 120 people have been killed in Punjab in the past week. Victims have included passengers pulled out of a bus and shot, people going on morning walks and members of security forces. The latest attack occurred in the Sikh holy city of Amritsar. About five militants entered the Krishna Kot market in the city, cut electricity connections to the area and walked down the street firing at shops on both sides with automatic rifles, said police superintendent Sanjeev Gupta. At least 11 of the victims were Hindus and two were Sikhs, he said. The site of the killing was less than a half-mile from the Golden Temple, the holiest Sikh shrine. Subhash Kumar, a resident of Krishna Kot, said many of the victims were standing outside shops when they were gunned down. ``'I saw at least three people killed outside'' a store that rents videocassettes, he said. ``Two others were killed in front of a restaurant.'' At least 15 other people were killed by the militants in other parts of the state Monday and Tuesday, United News of India reported. The killings were reported from separate parts of Punjab, a rich farming state on the border with Pakistan. Sikhs form only 2 percent of India's 880 million people but are in a majority in Punjab. Sikh radicals have been fighting for an independent nation since 1982, claiming their community is discriminated against by the Hindus, who make up 82 percent of the country's population. At least 2,850 people have been killed in Punjab this year in violence blamed on the militants.

DOC.HEAD: Freed Spy Says Jail Changed Her Attitude Toward Blacks
DOC.TEXT: A South African woman who spent four years in a Zimbabwean prison for spying on the African National Congress said the ordeal changed her attitude toward blacks and the anti-apartheid movement. Odile Harington, 30, met with reporters Friday for the first time since her release Nov. 1, and she blamed herself for getting caught spying. ``I was naive. ... I was an idealist,'' Harington said. She said she decided to spy on the ANC in 1986, after a terrorist blast injured two white children. ``At the time, I thought that acting against the ANC was in the interests of the country,'' she said. Harington was arrested in Zimbabwe that same year while posing as an ANC supporter, and she confessed to giving Pretoria information on ANC activities in Zimbabwe. The ANC, the largest black opposition group in South Africa, was illegal in South African at the time, and many ANC guerrillas lived in exile in sympathetic neighboring countries such as Zimbabwe. ``My attitude toward the ANC changed'' in prison, Harington said. ``I was reading newspapers and seeing things from the point of view of the Zimbabwean government. Also, living with blacks changed my attitude in a way that wasn't possible in the South African situation before I left.'' Harington has refused to say who recruited her and has not commented on her experiences in jail. It has been widely reported that she was tortured. The former spy praised the changes that occurred in South Africa during her incarceration. Zimbabwe's government said it freed and pardoned Harington because of President F.W. de Klerk's reforms, which include legalizing the ANC and promising to end apartheid. ``Things have improved and I have matured,'' she said. ``I think it's wonderful that the government and ANC are negotiating.'' Harington has not said what she will do in the future. She said she didn't get paid for her spying services. The South African government said it will help her adapt and find a job. Harington was originally sentenced to 25 years in prison after her 1987 trial, but the sentence was reduced to 12 years on appeal.

DOC.HEAD: CNN Turns Over Tapes to Judge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with court proceedings today. Picks up 9th graf, `CNN's attorney ...'
DOC.TEXT: Cable News Network today handed over to a federal judge tapes of Manuel Noriega talking on the telephone from his prison cell. After receiving the tapes from a team of CNN lawyers, U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler gave them to federal Magistrate William C. Turnoff. CNN unsuccessfully appealed Hoeveler's earlier temporary order barring the network from airing the tapes. Some of the tapes were broadcast before an appeals court and the U.S. Supreme Court upheld the order. Hoeveler previously said he would give the tapes to the federal magistrate so that Hoeveler, who will preside over Noriega's drug-trafficking trial, is not ``tainted'' by any disclosures about Noriega's defense strategy. Noriega's attorneys claim the tapes disclose defense maneuvers and have damaged the deposed Panamanian dictator's chances for a fair trial. Hoeveler said today the tapes would be transcribed and translated from Spanish, then would be studied by Turnoff. Hoeveler said he didn't know how long that would take. The tapes will be reviewed to decide whether they would damage Noriega's right to a fair trial. If the judge then orders a permanent ban on further broadcasts, CNN can again appeal, eventually to the U.S. Supreme Court. ``We are confident that when Magistrate Turnoff reviews these tapes and reports to the judge, CNN will be found not to have violated the court order,'' said Steven Korn, lawyer for Turner Broadcasting System Inc., CNN's owner. Korn said the conversations aired were not covered by the judge's order against the broadcast of conversations protected by attorney-client privilege. On Monday, a Noriega attorney, Jon May, also said he would ask for an immediate contempt hearing aimed at forcing CNN to pay fines of up to $300,000 for each violation of the judge's order. He said he would ask the all-news network for a log of how many times it aired the tapes. ``We're certainly going to suggest that might be one way of solving a lot of problems, and I think an appropriate one, considering the fact that General Noriega's defense was damaged by CNN,'' May said of his proposal that fines against CNN be used for Noriega's attorneys. CNN's attorney said the network doesn't expect to pay any fines. He said that the conversations aired were not covered by the judge's order against the broadcast of conversations protected by attorney-client privilege. The fines could help solve another problem plaguing the defense - a freeze on Noriega's bank accounts that has kept him from paying his lawyers. The private attorneys have said they cannot stay on the case without some money. Hoeveler said last week he would decide soon whether to give Noriega government-paid counsel instead. The dispute over the tapes has raised questions about attorney-client confidentiality, the right to a fair trial and the First Amendment. Noriega has asked that the case be dismissed because of the taping, the freezing of his assets, and other alleged government misconduct. The fallen dictator is jailed outside of Miami on charges of taking bribes to protect the cocaine trade. His trial isn't expected to begin before the spring.

DOC.HEAD: Four Palestinians Killed in Ambush Near Israeli Zone
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Palestine Popular Struggle Front claiming responsibility, comment from Israeli officials, ADDS distance of village from Israeli security zone. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli officer and four Palestinian guerrillas died in an eight-hour firefight in southern Lebanon after the Israelis ambushed the guerrilla squad, police said today. Police said two Palestinians, including the commander of the raiding party, were wounded in the ambush by about 75 Israeli soldiers and allied Lebanese militiamen near this village in the foothills of Mount Hermon. A Lebanese army corporal driving along a nearby road was also hurt. In Jerusalem, the Israeli army said 1st Lt. Yaron Yogev, 23, was shot and killed after his unit spotted and attacked the guerrilla squad on Monday night. The army statement also said that a fifth guerrilla may have been killed in the firefight. It did not mention the participation of Israeli-allied Lebanese militiamen. Police said the battle with machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades raged under parachute flares for eight hours before the Israelis and the militiamen of the South Lebanon Army pulled back three to five miles south to the security zone Israel maintains north of its border. The bodies of the four slain Palestinians remained on the battleground near Ain Atta at daybreak after the Israelis and militiamen withdrew at 4 a.m., a police spokesman said. ``They may be booby-trapped. Explosive experts are needed to examine the corpses before removing them,'' said a police spokesman, who cannot be named under standing rules. He said Israel and the South Lebanon Army must have been tipped in advance about the raid to lay the ambush for the 14 raiders, who belonged to Samir Ghoshe's Palestine Popular Struggle Front. The group claimed responsibility in a statement distributed in Beirut. The Front, backed and financed by Libya, is among the most militant hard-line factions of Yasser Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization. But the group had seldom been involved in attacks against Israel or its security enclave in southern Lebanon in the past. The Front commander and his assistant, who was also wounded, were seen heading back with eight surviving attackers to the Syrian-controlled Bekaa valley in eastern Lebanon. ``We belong to the Palestine Popular Liberation Front and Libya's Revolutionary committee,'' one guerrilla shouted to a small group of reporters, flashing the V-for-victory sign. ``I'll shoot you if you take pictures.'' Israel has controlled the zone since it withdrew the bulk of its army from Lebanon in 1985 after three years of occupation. It said it needed a buffer area against guerrilla raids, but Lebanon frequently accuses Israel of seeking to expand its territory permanently. The enclave covers 440 square miles from the Mediterranean coast to Mount Hermon slopes. It is controlled by the 3,000-member South Lebanon Army, supported by 1,000 Israeli soldiers. A senior Israeli official said the Israeli army would continue to operate beyond the security zone to foil guerrilla actions. ``When we think there are going to be terrorist attacks on Israel from outside the security zone, we feel that we have a free hand to act in order to prevent in advance attempts to infiltrate,'' said Yossi Olmert, director of the Government Press Office. Olmert said there had been 17 infiltration attempts by land and sea this year in which 36 Arabs and two Israelis were killed. ``None of them has reached Israel itself and this is exactly why it is vitally important for us, even more than before, to emphasize the significance of this security zone as an effective buffer,'' he told reporters.

DOC.HEAD: Special Gas Masks For Bearded Jews, Cost $20 Million
With PM-Israel-Gas Masks
DOC.TEXT: The army will distribute hundreds of thousands of balloon-like gas mask attachments to observant Jews who cannot wear the standard mask because of their beards, an army official said today. The daily Maariv said the special attachments will ensure a tight fit despite facial hair and will cost the government $20 million. Israel began distributing gas masks to the entire population on Oct. 15 because of the Persian Gulf crisis and Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's threat to attack Israel with chemical weapons. The problem for observant Jews comes because religious law forbids men from shaving, and the standard gas masks don't seal properly over facial hair. The army official, who spoke on condition of anonymity under military regulations, said the attachment is a flexible covering that extends out from the mask to include the beard within the area sealed from contamination. The Civil Defense Corps developed the attachments despite a ruling by one of Israel's chief rabbis, Mordechai Eliyahu, saying ultra-Orthodox Jews could shave their beards to save their lives. In issuing the ruling in August, Eliyahu urged men to carry razors in their pockets to be prepared for a chemical attack. Rabbinical rulings notwithstanding, Maarive noted the special attachments were developed because the Defense Ministry was under pressure from small but influential ultra-Orthodox political parties. The army official said distribution of the special attachments would begin next week in Bnei Brak, a religious suburb of Tel Aviv. Maariv said a total of about 600,000 attachments would be handed out. The army official said the Civil Defense Corps had been flooded with special requests since the gas mask distribution began. ``Every time a different group comes with different problems,'' he said. ``We have the children with asthma, and the beard-wearers were also a problem.''

DOC.HEAD: Park-Size States Share Summit Glory
DOC.TEXT: San Marino. Liechtenstein. Luxembourg. Smaller than many state parks in the United States, these tiny European nations have an equal place at the Paris summit table with the mighty United States and Soviet Union. Tuesday's session symbolized the egalitarian principles on which the 34-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe is based. A key speaker was Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, the master of Europe's economic powerhouse. The chair was held by Gabriele Gatti, head of government of SanMarino, population 21,000. It may seem like a joke that tiny states, surviving largely on the sale of postage stamps or on quirky tax laws attracting visitors to cheap, duty-free shopping, take their place in such a lofty forum. San Marino has seven embassies, but is normally represented abroad by Italy, which surrounds it. Liechtenstein has ceded diplomatic representation to neighboring Switzerland. But the presence of small states at this summit reminds mightier leaders of two crises they now face: Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, and the rising nationalism of numerically small peoples all over Eastern Europe. Edward Fenech-Adami, prime minister of tiny Malta, summed up the perils of ignoring small states in his summit speech Monday. ``The aggressive action by Iraq is an eye-opener to the essential need for small states to receive special consideration in devising a realistic system of security,'' he noted. A common theme of many summit speeches has been the need to confront the enflamed ethnic passions in Eastern Europe, where nationalism could undo the gains of democracy in the past year. In its 15-year history, the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe has advanced by accepting that the borders drawn by World War II, which plonked millions of people in Eastern Europe outside the nations to which they culturally belong, are final. It must therefore now find a way to give voice to the demands of Europe's many ethnic minorities, and accommodate emerging states such as the Baltic lands of Estonia, Lithuania and Latvia. Soviet objections have guaranteed so far that the three Baltic republics - whose 1940 annexation remains unrecognized by the United States - cannot attain even observer status at the Conference. Washington says only that the Baltics should eventually take their place at the CSCE, but that it does not wish to meddle in Moscow's affairs by demanding recognition of Baltic independence. As so often in the 15 years of the CSCE, it took smaller nations to bring the issue into the public eye: Czechoslovakia's Vaclav Havel, lauded by many speakers for his role in last year's East European revolutions, and Denmark's premier Poul Schlueter. This symbolized the vital part often played by the smaller states in bringing Europe to the consensus that protects the interests of all CSCE participants and thus remains the principle of all its decisions. At virtually all CSCE conferences, the neutral and non-aligned nations - those not in NATO or the now-crumbling Warsaw Pact - have worked to mesh the rival demands of East and West on everything from human rights to the environment. The tiny city-state of the Vatican is another important player. Cardinal Agostino Casaroli, the Pope's Secretary of State, gently reminded the summit Monday that ``the Holy Chair is, in fact, a power.'' Although occupying a tiny corner of European territory, Casaroli noted, the Vatican is ``a `power' engaged in every part of the world ... exercising its universal mission.''

DOC.HEAD: Norway Announces Environment Fund Financed by Oilfield Tax
DOC.TEXT: Norway intends to set up a fund, financed by a tax on its offshore oilfields, to help less wealthy countries combat global warning, Norwegian Prime Minister Gro Harlem Brundtland told leaders from 34 nations Tuesday. She told European and North American leaders attending the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe that environmental protection should be a significant part of any plans for regional or world security. ``The rehabilitation of our European environment will be a test case of whether we are capable of dealing with our common responsibilities,'' she said. She called on the leaders to ``take the lead in the effort to save our common future, such as in the negotiations in a world climate convention.'' To implement environmental agreements ``wealthier countries must make financial and technological resources available,'' she said in announcing the Norwegian fund. In Oslo, press spokesman Egil Helle at the oil and energy department said the tax would be on natural gas coming from Norway's extensive North Sea oilfields. Norway is one of Europe's largest producers of oil and gas, two of the principal hydrocarbons that when burned produce carbon dioxide, a ``greenhouse'' gas that scientists say appears to be causing a rise in global temperatures. Mrs. Brundtland's minority Labor Party has said the tax would generate several hundred thousand dollars, a portion of which would be used to finance the climate fund. Environmentalists have urged an international accord setting up a multilateral climate fund to help less affluent countries develop cleaner energy technologies and develop energy efficient systems. Earlier this year, a global fund was set up at an international conference in London to help developing countries cut their emissions of ozone-depleting chemicals. The United States, which produces about one-fourth of the world's carbon dioxide, has led the countries opposing a similar fund to deal with global warming.

DOC.HEAD: City Hall Going Broke? Tourists Don't Care
DOC.TEXT: The city may be in danger of going broke, but one facet of its economy is booming: Tourists are showing up in droves. Bookings are nearly double at the Convention and Visitors Bureau and the trolley tour company tha takes people to the Liberty Bell and Independence Hall has added a second line and is considering two more. Visitors to Independence Hall last weekend said they'd heard about the city's fiscal mess. But they had no second thoughts about making the trip. ``That wouldn't keep us away,'' said Jamie Robinson of San Jose, Calif. ``We traveled 3,000 miles and we're going to see all we can.'' The only question is what happens if the money crunch gets so bad that trash pickup, police and fire protection are affected. Short of that happening, said Bruce Wolfepacke, manager of the American Trolley Tour Co., ``I don't see the city going broke as affecting us.'' The city isn't due to run out of money until after the $30 million payroll on Dec. 14. The mayor, the council and the state haven't been able to agree on a rescue plan. That doesn't worry Tom Muldoon, president of the Convention and Visitors Bureau. ``The amount of money that the city is short is not an enormous amount,'' Muldoon said. ``Eventually, they are going to work this out at City Hall. It's just a question of who bites the aspirin - or who owns the aspirin.'' From July through October the bureau booked 134 convention and tourist groups in Philadephia for a total of 127,000 room-nights, Muldoon said. That's up from the same four-month period of 1989, when the bureau booked 101 groups for 65,000 room-nights. Pat Walsh of Centipede Tours, a source of guides and transportation for tour groups all over the city, said business is looking good for next year, too. ``We already have 500 tours booked for next year,'' she said, adding that her company averages 2,000 to 2,500 tours annually. ``It's early to have that many bookings,'' she said. ``I can't figure it out, but I'll take it.'' All that brisk business comes in spite of direct economic effects on tousit attractions. City-owned attractions like Betsy Ross House and the Philadelphia Zoo have suffered problems unseen by tourists, such as hiring freezes and slightly curtailed hours. And eight historic buildings at Independence National Historical Park remain closed because the National Park Service didn't budget enough money. In 1989, tourists spent $142 million in the Philadelphia area, of which $8.1 million went to local governments, according to a report for the Convention and Visitors Bureau. The more than 4,500 people employed in tourism contribute directly to city coffers through the wage tax of 4.96 percent on city residents and 4.3125 percent on non-residents who work in the city. Nearly half of the city's $2.2 billion general fund comes from the wage tax. No breakdown was available of how much tourism industry workers contributed, but the overall tax raised $918.2 million last year and is projected to raise $954.9 million in fiscal 1991. Other tourism-related contributions to the city treasury include a 5 percent amusement tax on sporting events and concerts, which raised $6 million for the 12 months ended June 30 and is projected to bring in $6.2 million this fiscal year. A 5 percent hotel tax raised $7.8 million in fiscal 1990 and is expected to raise $8.7 million this year.

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf Glance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Here are the latest developments in the Persian Gulf crisis: --- Saddam Hussein called on parliament to free all Germans held hostage in Iraq. In releasing the Germans, the Iraqi president contrasted Bonn's attitude with that of Washington and London. ``The decision of banning some foreigners from travel was adopted on the hope of giving reckless minds in the administration of (President) Bush and (British Prime Minister Margaret) Thatcher an opportunity to delay in carrying on the procedure toward the abyss of evil,'' INA quoted him as saying. Iraqi officials said approval was certain. --- A group of 45 House Democrats filed suit Tuesday to try to force President Bush to seek authority from Congress before ordering a U.S. military attack to drive Iraqi troops out of Kuwait. The lawsuit seeks an injunction to bar Bush ``from launching or initiating an offensive military attack by United States forces against Iraq without obtaining a declaration of war or other explicit authorization from the Congress. --- In Baghdad, there was another sign Tuesday that the trade embargo is having an impact. The state press said the country's legislature had voted to impose the death penalty on anyone hoarding wheat, barley, rice, corn and other grains for trading purposes. --- Indian news reports said Tuesday that Iraq is refusing to allow an Indian ship, its crew and 14 Red Cross workers to leave until it unloads more than 4,700 tons of rice. The ship docked at the Iraqi port of Umm Qasr in September with 10,000 tons of food for Indians in Iraq and Kuwait. It had been scheduled to leave with some of its cargo. --- Iraq will release 122 Dutch, Belgian and British nationals who completed a government-commissioned dredging operation, a spokesman for the project said Tuesday. Those being allowed to leave are all the Westerners who worked on the dredging project run by the Dutch companies Volker Stevin and Koninklijke Boskalis, project spokesman Gerard Anneveldt said. --- In a joint New York Times-CBS poll published Tuesday, 47 percent of respondents said the Bush administration has been too quick to get U.S. forces involved and has not been diligent enough about seeking diplomatic solutions. Only 38 percent felt the same way in August, the poll said.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev-Bush Summit in Moscow Early Next Year
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS date in 17th graf from May 1989 to May 1990.
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Bush are planning a January summit in Moscow, U.S. and Soviet officials said today. U.S. officials in Washington said they were confident obstacles to a long-range nuclear weapons treaty could be resolved in time for the meeting, and that setting a summit date could spur negotiations. The officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Bush is keeping to his plan only to hold a Moscow summit if a Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty was ready for signing. But they expressed confidence the outstanding issues could be resolved by the first half of January. The two leaders discussed the treaty, which would reduce their long-range nuclear missiles by up to 50 percent, at a dinner meeting Monday night, said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Soviet spokesman Vitaly Ignatenko did not tie the summit to an arms reduction signing. He said only, ``U.S. President George Bush will pay an official visit to Moscow at the beginning of January.'' Asked about an agreement, he said, ``If it's ready, they will sign it.'' It would be the fourth summit for Bush and Gorbachev, not counting their Monday dinner. `It's obviously within our grasp,'' an official said of the elusive pact to reduce long-range bombers, missiles and submarines. ``If you don't use the summit as an opportunity it may slide away.'' Bush and Gorbachev are in Paris participating in a 34-nation summit charting the course of the world now that Cold War divisions have ended. On Monday, leaders of NATO and the Warsaw Pact attending the summit signed an agreement drastically reducing their conventional forces of tanks and other weapons throughout Europe. It is the most far-reaching arms control accord in history. Bush had hoped to go to Moscow in December to sign the START pact, but negotiators are still wrestling with three major unresolved issues. They are: --The kinds of testing and other restrictions to impose on the 154 heavy, ground-based SS-18 intercontinental ballistic missiles the Soviet will retain under the treaty. --Whether the Soviet Backfire bomber is to be classified as a strategic weapon, as the United States demands. That would mean counting Backfires against numerical weapons limits established in the treaty. --The restrictions to be imposed on U.S. and Soviet transfers of weapons barred under the treaty to allies. This issue primarily concerns arms Washington would like to turn over to Britain outside the treaty's limits. The two leaders held their first summit, to get to know one another, on board ships moored off the Mediterranean island of Malta in December 1989. They met again in May 1990 in Washington, where Bush and Gorbachev signed agreements to eliminate chemical weapons and complete a treaty to slash long-range nuclear arsenals. Their last summit was in Helsinki on Sept. 9. That one-day meeting was devoted largely to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Agriculture Secretary Yeutter Staying On The Job
With AM-Labor Secretary
DOC.TEXT: Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter has no plan to resign from the Cabinet, his chief spokeswoman said Tuesday, denying speculation he would soon step down. Rumbles have sounded on Capitol Hill and elsewhere that Yeutter was headed for greener pastures following completion of the 1990 farm bill and the conclusion next month of international trade talks. One of the latest to surface is that Yeutter might be in line for an ambassadorship, perhaps to Germany, if that should become available. Kelly Shipp, who has been Yeutter's press secretary since 1987 when he was President Reagan's U.S. trade representative, said reports of his leaving the cabinet soon - perhaps within 90 days - are ``not true.'' Specifically, on Yeutter seeking or being touted for an ambassador's job, Shipp said that is ``not true, absolutely, patently false.'' Yeutter, with Shipp in his entourage, just returned from a week of meetings in Europe where the Uruguay Round of talks under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade is stalled over agricultural strategy. The U.S. view, advocated vigorously by Yeutter for years, is that trade-distorting policies, including export subsidies and some internal price supports, are bad for everybody. Some countries share the U.S. position, but others - notably the European Community - are still balking. As a result, the Uruguay Round of trade talks could wind up at an impasse on some of the major agricultural issues. ``People have always speculated that the secretary was going to leave after the Uruguay Round,'' Shipp said. ``But he never said that, he doesn't feel that way. He hasn't even focused on life after (USDA), whenever that's going to be.'' When President-elect George Bush chose him as secretary of agriculture in December 1988, it was reported that Yeutter had really wanted to get back into the private sector after 3{ years on the trade job. There was also talk at the time that Yeutter and Bush had agreed the Agriculture Department commitment would last only through the formulation of the 1990 farm bill - which is awaiting Bush's signature - and the conclusion of the GATT negotiations. But Shipp said Yeutter made no such deal with Bush. ``He and the president never talked about his departure,'' she said. Yeutter, who will be 60 on Dec. 10, has an interest in a 2,500-acre family farming operation in Nebraska. He holds doctorates in law and economics and has held many public and private posts, including Agriculture Department service in the early 1970s and president of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange from 1978 to 1985.

DOC.HEAD: `Carnal Knowledge' by Jules Feiffer Opens Off-Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: In his cartoons, Jules Feiffer is a master at analyzing relationships between men and women. He can capture the peculiarities of their anxieties with a few words and a few frenzied line drawings. What's more, his observations are scalpel-sharp, very funny and quick to the point. But the writer runs into trouble trying to extend those observations into a whole evening of theater. That was the problem with his last play, ``Elliott Loves,'' and it is the problem with ``Carnal Knowledge,'' an older Feiffer work that became a well-known Mike Nichols movie some 20 years ago. Now the stage version finally has arrived in New York, opening Monday at off-Broadway's tiny, 99-seat Kaufman Theater, and it's a tedious evening of theater. ``Carnal Knowledge'' - the play - seems like a darker, more morose version of one of Feiffer's fine comic strips but stretched beyond endurance. It flattens the actors and exhausts the audience. The 1971 film version starred Jack Nicholson, Art Garfunkel, Candice Bergen and Ann-Margret. This production has the lure of three young stars - Jon Cryer, Judd Nelson and Justine Bateman plus one newcomer, Karen Byers - in pivotal roles. None is shown to good advantage, particularly in a disastrous second act. ``Carnal Knowledge'' covers a nearly 20-year period, following two Amherst College graduates from the late 1940s into the swinging '60s. The play is at its best in the opening scenes when the two college students - Sandy, played by Cryer and Jonathan, played by Nelson - solemnly discuss the mysteries of women and more specifically, sex. ``Are you going to let your wife work?'' goes one discussion. ``Is it better to love or be loved?'' goes another. Sandy is a naive romantic, Jonathan a cynical lout whose vision of women never gets much beyond the bedroom. Sandy meets Susan, a woman who ends up being much too smart for him but who eventually is bedded by Jonathan. Act 2 jumps nearly 20 years, but the two lead actors don't seem to age at all. The baby-faced Cryer, who is quite affecting in the first act as the innocent Sandy, looks completely out of place after intermission as an older, successful doctor who does marry Susan and has three children. Nelson's character is more intriguing, but the actor's performance doesn't vary. Jonathan's repulsive, one-note treatment of women eventually becomes boring and Nelson emphasizes that relentless quality. Justine Bateman gives a zombie-like performance as Susan, and when the woman disappears after the first act, she isn't missed. But the women who replace her in the lives of Sandy and Jonathan - a neurotic model played by Karen Byers and an aggressive, mannish girlfriend played stridently by Mimi Quillin - are even less sympathetic. The evening degenerates into a series of unhappy conversations between two unhappy men about their unhappy love lives. The bare-bones evening, directed by Martin Charnin, has the feel of a glorified workshop production. The setting is minimal, except for an unnecessary turntable that spins around several times for no discernable reason on the small stage. Charnin uses his actors remarkably well, with the action shifting very quickly from conversation to conversation. But the problem with ``Carnal Knowledge'' is that what these characters are talking about isn't very interesting in the first place.

DOC.HEAD: Film Buffs Unearth Set Of 1923 `The Ten Commandments'
DOC.TEXT: In a Hollywood time warp, a filmmaker is unearthing an ancient Egyptian city, built and buried not by pharaohs but by legendary director Cecil B. DeMille. Archaeologists are uncovering the City of the Pharaohs, erected for DeMille's 1923 silent film ``The Ten Commandments,'' with as much enthusiasm as if it were a real Egyptian city. ``This is utterly unique,'' said Jarell Jackman, executive director of the Santa Barbara Trust for Historical Preservation. ``It gives you a sense of time having passed - that movies are now part of history. ``Some archaeologist may be uncovering Disneyland 500 years from now.'' The movie city, one of the largest sets in film history, included walls 110 feet high and 75 feet wide. The entrance was flanked by four 35-foot Pharaoh statues and 21 huge sphinxes. When he was finished with the movie, DeMille had the set buried in the local sand dunes. A search of the northern Santa Barbara County site with ground-penetrating radar shows that much of the original set remains intact, said archaeologist John Parker, who compared the readings with old charts of the movie set. The readings show large objects in the place where the sphinxes should be, leading excavators to believe the statues remain intact. Peter Brosnan, a Los Angeles screenwriter and documentary filmmaker, is spearheading the campaign to get financing for the excavation project and secured a $10,000 grant from the Bank of America. Brosnan dug up one of DeMille's horse heads on a 1983 trip to the dunes about 150 miles northwest of Los Angeles, and then started to preserve the site as a historical treasure. ``It's a hobby that got out of control,'' he said. On Monday, Brosnan proudly showed off some unearthed treasures. ``Take a look at this guy,'' he said. ``That's the Pharaoh.'' Brosnan will use the excavation to help complete a documentary video on DeMille and the buried set.

DOC.HEAD: First Ladies Visit Picasso Exhibition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: adds 3 grafs, Mrs. Bush visits AIDS research institute.
DOC.TEXT: A portrait of Jacqueline Picasso, whose dark beauty and intense gaze fascinated Spanish artist Pablo Picasso for nearly 30 years, enchanted Barbara Bush during a tour Tuesday of recently acquired masterpieces. Mrs. Bush was accompanied by Michele Rocard, wife of French Premier Michel Rocard, and several other wives of government leaders attending the 34-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. The ladies were divided into four groups for their 45-tour of the Grand Palais, where more than 400 paintings, lithographs, drawings, sketch books, sculpture and ceramics are on public display until Jan. 14. ``Jacqueline Aux Mains Croisees'' (Jacqueline With Crossed Hands), executed in 1954 in the early days of her relationship with the artist, shows the young dancer sitting on the floor, her hands hugging her knees. The works, which once belonged to Jacqueline, Picasso's second wife, were donated to the government by her daughter, Catherine, in partial payment of inheritance taxes. Jacqueline Picasso committed suicide in 1986, never having recovered from her husband's death. Wearing an elegant, bright red dress adorned with waist-high gold buttons and a flared, pleated skirt designed by Arnold Scaasi, Mrs. Bush listened attentively to explanations provided by Gerard Regnier, the head curator of the Picasso Museum. ``Is she crying?'' Mrs. Bush asked, looking closely at the painting. ``She's beautiful, with that look of an Egyptian sphinx. I think she's my favorite,'' she said. The portrait is the highlight of the exhibition, the first portrait of Jacqueline - Picasso painted more than 70 during their 29 years together - to enter France's national collections. Asked how she liked Picasso's view of women, Mrs. Bush just raised her eyebrows. The American first lady was also fascinated by the dozens of sketch books displayed in glass cases under dim light. Picasso's hands were never idle, and he would draw in accounting books, on newspaper, cardboard - even tablecloths and napkins. ``I can't imagine he kept them all. I wanted to go through them page by page,'' Mrs. Bush said. Raisa Gorbachev, dressed in a mustard suit with black buttons and black sweater, did not visit the exhibition. She joined the group for lunch at the Hotel Matignon, the official residence of the French premier. The guests dined on lobster stew in sea urchin sauce, filet of beef, cheese, fruit and sherbet, washed down with two vintage wines. Mrs. Bush ended the afternoon with a visit to the famed Pasteur Institute, named for the French scientist Louis Pasteur and now a respected AIDS research center. Mrs. Bush, accompanied by Danielle Mitterrand, wife of the French president, was not allowed inside the research labs that contain the deadly virus. ``We didn't get within spitting distance,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Financial Woes Could Derail New York City's Education, Anti-Crime Plans
DOC.TEXT: Plans to crack down on crime and boost the quality of education in New York City could be gutted by the state's financial woes, say city officials bracing for the loss of millions of dollars. A plan unveiled Saturday to wipe out a state budget deficit of nearly $1 billion will cost the city about $100 million this year, Gov. Mario Cuomo said. But Mayor David Dinkins said ``an initial review suggests these costs may be greater.'' The cutbacks come after Dinkins already announced plans for layoffs and service reductions to close a city budget shortfall of $400 million this fiscal year and $1.6 million next year. ``We have no buffer left,'' lamented city Budget Director Philip Michael. ``There's nothing left under a rock.'' Officials also say the lost revenues could cripple Dinkins' $1.8 billion plan to hire 6,500 more police officers and the city's agreement to increase teacher salaries 5.5 percent. The plan to beef up the Police Department was to be paid for by a payroll tax on city residents and commuters that would require the state Legislature's approval. It already faced stiff opposition before Cuomo announced his proposed cutbacks. ``This is not the most positive climate for seeking any tax increase,'' noted Thomas Reppetto, director of the Citizens Crime Commission. Cuomo's plan also seemed to generate new pressure on Dinkins to back out of the city's Oct. 1 agreement with its teachers for 5.5 percent pay raises. Cuomo wants to reduce state aid to the city's schools by more than $70 million - money city officials were counting on for the teachers' raises. Schools Chancellor Joseph Fernandez also said the budget cuts could result in the layoffs of as many as 4,000 school employees, most of them teachers. United Federation of Teachers spokesman Bert Shanas said the union would fight to keep the increases. ``As far as we are concerned, we have a legal binding contract,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Considering Lynn Martin for Labor Post
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is considering Rep. Lynn Martin of Illinois to succeed outgoing Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole, an administration source said Tuesday. Martin, who earlier this month lost a bid for the Senate seat held by Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., told Bush last Thursday that she was interested in the secretary's job, said the source, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. A 10-year House Republican, Martin had talked to Bush about the job immediately after she lost the Nov. 6 election and then again last week before he left for his Thanksgiving trip to Europe and Saudi Arabia, the source said. Martin has also discussed the matter with presidential chief of staff John Sununu, the source said. Constance Newman, director of the Office of Personnel Management, is the other candidate most frequently mentioned to replace Mrs. Dole, who is stepping down this week to become president of the American Red Cross. Mrs. Newman, one of the Bush administration's highest ranking women, is not discussing her job prospects, said an OPM spokesman. He said he did not know if she had been contacted by the White House. The administration source who said Martin had been contacted said he did not know if the White House had discussed the job with anyone else. Martin was unavailable for comment Tuesday because she was in Oman representing Bush on a ceremonial mission. Martin, who gave up her House seat to make the failed effort to unseat Simon, would give the Bush administration a cabinet secretary with strong congressional ties. However, Martin has never had a close alliance with organized labor. Her best voting score from the AFL-CIO came in 1988, when she got a 46 out of a possible 100 on issues tracked by the 14.2-million-member labor federation. When Bush tapped Mrs. Dole for the labor post two years ago, his action was seen as a way for Republicans to mend fences with organized labor leaders who had endured a hostile relationship with the Reagan administration. Both Martin and Mrs. Newman would also give Bush the opportunity to replace Mrs. Dole with another woman. Martin is white; Mrs. Newman is black. The source said he did not know when Bush would make a decision about Mrs. Dole's replacement. Mrs. Dole, 54, will officially leave office Friday. Deputy Labor Secretary Roderick DeArment will serve as acting secretary until a replacement is named and confirmed by the Senate. Congress does not return until January.

DOC.HEAD: Massachusetts Budget Cuts Leave Winners as Blue as Their Ribbons
DOC.TEXT: Budget cuts at Massachusetts fairs have left some blue-ribbon winners seeing red. ``Dear Mr. Dukakis. ... What did you do with it all?'' 10-year-old Melissa Belski wrote to the governor after learning the $78 she won this summer for several entries would not be forthcoming due to a $300,000 budget cut at the Division of Fairs. Melissa, of Great Barrington, felt she had earned that money. She had entered two lambs, a cross-stitched sachet, flower arrangements, hand-dipped candles and photos. She eventually got her prize money, partly through donations from well-wishers who had read about her situation. But others were not so fortunate, said division director Stephen F. Quinn. ``The fairs were allotted the money. After the fairs were all held and all was said and done, I was informed that the monies were gone,'' Quinn said. The cuts, which came in a year when millions were slashed, didn't attract much attention at first. But since then, the reaction has ranged from the girl's letter to winners in Greenfield giving their prizes back in a gesture of support for their local fair. Barber Harold Sears was among those who turned $200 back to the Franklin County Fair after learning it was having to come up with the prize money itself. ``Agriculture is the last thing that our politicians are thinking about and they control the purse strings. This is one way of kind of satisfying ourselves a little bit that we are doing something worthwhile,'' Sears said. Larger fairs dipped into reserve funds to make good on prizes; smaller outfits couldn't afford that, Quinn said. Many of the fairs hardest hit were in the Berkshires, including the Great Barrington Fair, said state Sen. Peter Webber. Webber hopes to get at least part of the lost $300,000 restored when the Legislature reconvenes. ``It's a promise that was made and they had every right to expect that if they won the prize there'd be a premium paid,'' he said. Quinn said he doubted fairs could afford a second year without prize money, which would discourage exhibitors, especially young people who rely on the prizes to defray travel and other costs. ``Everybody in the system is going to hurt,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Business Leader Calls For National Exam
DOC.TEXT: A national test should be created so graduating high school students can demonstrate to American business an ability to read, write and compute ``at world-class levels,'' a business leader told a House panel Tuesday. ``Business has lost confidence that a high school diploma reflects actual skills gained,'' William H. Kolberg, president of the National Alliance of Business, told a subcommittee of the House Committee on Education and Labor. Kolberg said the government must set up a framework for a national examination system that would be administered by the states. Student abilities would be assessed on the basis of predetermined national basic skills requirements, he said. There is growing controversy over the need to test all students leaving high school - not just those interested in attending college. Kolberg's comments come less than a week after the head of the nation's largest testing organization opposed the idea in a letter to the president's Education Policy Advisory Committee. Gregory Anrig, president of the Educational Testing Service, said a proposed exam to judge students and their schools would be unnecessary, unwarranted and wasteful. The president's panel reportedly is preparing to recommend national testing of all students in grades four, eight and 12. ``Business, certainly, needs assurance that students have achieved a certain level of competency upon graduation no matter where in the country they went to school,'' Kolberg told the subcommittee on elementary, secondary and vocational education. The National Alliance of Business, founded in 1968 by Henry Ford II and President Lyndon Johnson, is a non-profit organization with 2,800 businesses as members. A recent alliance poll of personnel officers at the 1,200 largest U.S. corporations found that only 36 percent were satisfied with the competency of new employees entering the work force. Also, business leaders thought that both reading and math competency had slipped in the past five years. Kolberg said ``a system of national standards coupled with assessment would ensure that every student leaves compulsory school with a demonstrated ability to read, write, compute, and perform at world-class levels in general school subjects.'' While generally supporting the idea, Sol Hurwitz, president of the Committee for Economic Development, told the panel the government first must make sure that all students have equal educational opportunities. That would require greater financial support for such early childhood education programs as Head Start, he said. William Lurie, president of the Business Roundtable, said his association of more than 200 chief executive officers of large corporations is considering support in the next Congress for an initiative to expand use of the National Assessment of Educational Progress. NAEP, popularly called the nation's report card, is the only national assessment of what American students know and can do. Since 1969, nationwide samples have been taken in reading, mathematics, science, writing, history, geography and other subjects.

DOC.HEAD: Roof Wrangle Threatens Damp Christmas at Church of the Nativity
DOC.TEXT: It could be a wet Christmas for pilgrims in Bethlehem this year because Christian sects are squabbling over who should repair the leaking roof above Christ's birthplace. There is little disagreement that the roof of the ancient Church of the Nativity needs fixing. Even last winter, worshipers had to weave their way among buckets set out inside the basilica to collect winter rainwater. But the question of who should perform the repair work gets tangled up in complex rules dating to the 1850s on which sect controls which section of the church. Unfortunately, repair of the roof is not specifically mentioned in the codes. Clerics of the Greek Orthodox Church traditionally clean the roof, and they argue that this is precedent for doing the repairs. Twice in the past week - once in the dead of night - Greek Orthodox have sneaked to the roof to do the deed. Both efforts drew letters of protest from the Roman Catholics and Armenians, and on Monday the Israeli army intervened. ``If you've seen the physical condition of the basilica you know the problems,'' Shmuel Hamburger, the Israeli military government's liaison with the churchmen, said Tuesday. ``The dispute between the three communities over who will do what in repairs means it goes unrepaired.'' Hamburger said the Israeli government was willing to do the work, as Israel and other governing powers like Jordan and the British did before. Now, as in the past, the three communities could send representatives to supervise, he said. Greek Orthodox church officials could not be reached for comment despite repeated telephone calls. Newspaper reports say the church is adamant that the roof is its property and can only be repaired by the Greek Orthodox. The dark and musty church was built by Constantine in the year 330 and restored and enlarged in the sixth century by Byzantine Emperor Justinian. It is believed to be the oldest Christian church in continuous use. Year round, but especially at Christmas, pilgrims flock to the stone structure, which stands above a grotto believed to be the site where the Christ child was born. Tourism has been sharply reduced by both the three-year Palestinian uprising in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip and the more-recent Persian Gulf crisis, but Israeli tourism officials predict some pickup at the holiday. The church has miraculously escaped most ravages of conquering armies. Legend has it, for example, that the Persians left it alone in the seventh century because the garb of the three wise men in mosaics on the facade was similar to their own dress. The roof didn't fare as well. In 1482, Edward IV of England supplied lead for a new roof. Ottoman Turks removed it in the early part of the 17th century to make ammunition. Worship and maintainance of the church is regulated by a code, known as ``the Status Quo,'' that was developed by the Turks to prevent just such disputes as the roof wrangle. The code was accepted by the British, Jordanian and Israelis. The code is very specific. For example, the silver star that marks Christ's birthplace is dusted daily by the Greek Orthodox; twice each week, the Orthodox and the Armenians wash it. The nearby manger is exclusively under Roman Catholic control. George Hintlian, a spokesman for the Armenian community, believes the roof dispute will be resolved amicably. ``This is a periodic repair,'' Hintlian noted. ``It has been done twice under the Israelis, twice under the Jordanians before them.'' He said the situation called for cooperation: ``When something is not part of the status quo, it must be done by consensus.'' Hamburger says Israel is willing to get to work. Asked if it could be completed by Christmas, he said: ``It depends on the weather ... and so on.''

DOC.HEAD: San Francisco To Move Hiring Halls Indoors From Street Corners
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Hiring halls are being revived for the city's hundreds of day laborers, mostly immigrants, who now crowd street corners in the largely Hispanic Mission District hoping to catch the eye of passing contractors. Corner job lines provide the best work prospects for unskilled, often undocumented laborers with little or no English. But the gatherings draw complaints from residents and businesses who say men discouraged by a fruitless day of waiting intimidate customers and make neighborhoods unsafe. And labor advocates say disorganization and desperation leave day workers vulnerable to dishonest employers. ``When it's done in the chaos of the street, you have the problem of people being cheated and people being hurt,'' said San Francisco Supervisor Jim Gonzalez. ``We're hoping to restore dignity to people who just want to get a job, if only for a day.'' A $70,000 pilot project expected to begin in February would provide access to jobs with fair wages, a record of one's employer, and services such as toilets, telephone numbers where a worker could be reached in an emergency, and a cup of coffee. Workers would show up at the hiring hall each morning and put their names on slips of paper that contractors draw from pools divided by skill, Gonzalez said. The system is patterned after a program in Los Angeles. About 60 of the 300 people who show up at two hiring halls in Los Angeles find work each day, said Bill Molina, coordinator of the Los Angeles day labor program. By comparison, Gonzalez estimates only 10 percent of casual workers in San Francisco get work by standing on a corner. Molina concedes that the 13-month-old program helps just a small fraction of the 3,000 workers who gather on Los Angeles street corners each day. The weak link, he says, are the employers. ``It's the employers who still go to pick up day laborers and a lot of them are the unscrupulous employers who rip them off because they know the men on the street are desperate,'' he said. But Molina and program planners in San Francisco say success is not measured just by how many people find work each day. ``I think the intent is to provide a more secure place to look for a job, where more protection will be given them, community services will be given them, where contractors will be able to work in a much more orderly way,'' said Mauricio Aviles, a spokesman for the Mission Hiring Hall, one of the community groups working on the San Francisco program. Chaos rules on street corners where job-seekers wait for contractors. At the sight of a passing truck filled with lumber, clusters of men rush into the street. Some reach for identification and green cards, hoping to gain an advantage by their legal status. ``How many people do you need?'' they ask. ``What kind of work? How much do you pay?'' Workers have agreed among themselves not to work for less than $4.50 an hour, and for some jobs not less than $7 an hour, said Lina Avidan of the Coalition for Immigrant and Refugee Rights and Services. By mid-morning, fewer trucks pass and job prospects wane. ``How can 70 people get a job with 10 or 15 contractors a day?'' asks Jose Esparza, 21, who for the last 2{ months has been crowded out in the hustle for jobs by new immigrants from Central and South America. Before then, he worked an average of two days a week, said Esparza, who came from Mexico when he was 11. Despite the pitfalls, many jobless, including Esparza, aren't convinced that the hiring hall will actually get them more work. ``We are not too happy, but it's a good way to find jobs. It's better than waiting in the employment office, in a 50-guy line, and you get to the front and they say `We'll call you,''' said Esparza. ``Here, we work,'' he said. David Schermerhorn, a business agent at Warehouse Local 6 of the International Longshoremen's & Warehousemen's Union said he was pleased to see the union tradition being applied to unskilled workers. ``We certainly need it - I'm not saying the union - we need to have something so the guys have some kind of organization,'' Schermerhorn said. ``I drive by every day just wondering what it would take to make a connection with the guys and how to help them. I know they are being abused and I haven't figured out how to help them.''

DOC.HEAD: Construction Site Collapse Searched in Downtown Washington
Laser Photo
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 3 grafs new to update with search completed; subs 11th graph to add first reference to Murphy.
DOC.TEXT: Officials today finished searching the site of a downtown construction site collapse and said no victims were found. The sudden collapse forced evacuation of the adjacent building that houses United Press International, swallowed several construction trailers, part of an adjoining alley and a light pole. Witnesses said the accident caused a bright explosion that lit the night sky. ``We've completed the search, and we didn't find anyone, and we've finished our part of the investigation,'' said District of Columbia fire department spokesman Capt. Ted Holmes. Although fire officials said after an all-night search that they doubted there were any victims in the rubble, they sent rescue crews into the 60-foot site to check one construction trailer that had been pitched into the hole. UPI spokesman Milt Capps said the news service was able to restore service quickly to its clients by switching some operations to other bureaus. For example, he said, the Los Angeles bureau was temporarily filing the agency's main domestic news wire. He said Reuters was helping UPI distribute photographs to its customers and that National Public Radio was helping the news agency maintain its broadcast and audio network services.
