He said it was his ``understanding that the building (housing the news service) may have been undermined. I am told that the alley way between the site and our building is virtually no more.'' Officials also ordered dirt hauled to the site in an attempt to secure it from further collapse. The collapse caused cracks in several adjoining streets and forced police to cordon off a three-block area. Representatives from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration arrived at the scene early today to supervise the investigation. The cause of the cave-in has not been determined, said another fire department official, Battalion Chief Ambrose Murphy said. OSHA inspectors were schedued to meet with engineers and consultants this afternoon to discuss the accident. Three construction trailers and a van parked on the street adjacent to the site tumbled into the cavity about four blocks from the White House. Fire Chief Ray Alfred said an employee of the contractor told firefighters he was the last person to leave the site and extensive explorations during the night confirmed no one was trapped in the hole. Subway service was closed at the station nearest the site Monday night out of fear vibration from passing trains could make the cave-in worse. Service at the station resumed today. The cave-in left several cracks on the street that serves as a major commuter route between Washington and the heavily populated northern Virginia suburbs. Murphy said several surrounding streets would remain closed for several days. At UPI, Capps said some operations were switched to a UPI computer center in suburban Virginia. Capps said editors and writers would be working from press galleries in the U.S. Capitol and, by laptop computer, from various locations around the city. He said he did not know how long it would take to make the building safe for occupancy.

DOC.HEAD: City Suspends Traffic Court Employees for Unpaid Tickets
With AM-Philly Finances
DOC.TEXT: An assistant budget director for the city's Traffic Court division has been suspended because of nearly $2,000 in unpaid traffic tickets dating back to 1984. According to court records, T. Milton Street owes $1,967 for 19 tickets. Violations included running a stop sign, reckless driving, driving without a license and driving an unregistered vehicle. Street, a former Republican state senator, said he had no intention of paying the fines and didn't have the money to do so. Street's son, T. Milton Street Jr., also was suspended from the department. He owes $876 in fines on 11 outstanding traffic citations, authorities said. Traffic court officials said neither Street is legally entitled to drive. The Streets and five other department employees were suspended without pay Monday by Traffic Court President Judge George Twardy. The judge said he ordered a review of all 206 Traffic Court employees for back tickets after learning of the elder Street's unpaid tickets Friday from a newspaper report. Of the seven employees with unpaid traffic fines, the Streets owed the most, the judge said. ``I think it's a disgrace. If our people here don't respond (to traffic citations), what are the people on the street going to do,'' Twardy said. Twardy said the suspended employees could pay their fines or request hearings to contest them. But even if they resolve the fines, their reinstatement is still subject to Twardy's approval. Street was hiring by the traffic court division last year at an annual salary of $30,000. ``I believe that Judge Twardy wants to get rid of Milton Street junior and senior and he directed a court supervisor to go through old tickets and find anything in Milton Street's name,'' Street said. He said the fight is really a disagreement over policy. He said he disagrees with the requirement that poor people who want to fight a ticket must post collateral first. Street said the practice was discriminatory. Twardy said it's the law.

DOC.HEAD: Hay Bill Provides Rare Laugh at Budget Session
With AM-Philly Finances
DOC.TEXT: There's not much humor left in the struggle to keep the city afloat, but a bill for a non-urban item needed by police horses brought mirth to officials deciding which bills could be paid this week. ``Hay,'' said an aide to Finance Director Elizabeth C. Reveal, revealing a lack of country experience, according to the Philadelphia Daily News. ``That's almost like food for animals, isn't it?'' ``Yes, Joe, it's just like food,'' Ms. Reveal replied. She joined the group's chuckling, but the snickers ended abruptly when she said: ``Pay it.'' Ms. Reveal and six aides went through 931 new bills totaling $12.5 million Monday and tagged $7 million for payment. Priority went to spending for vital services, such as police, fire, foster care, prisons and food - including hay. The remaining $5.5 million joined a longer list of expenses deferred while the city tries to stave off insolvency. The deferred payments list has grown to 46 pages and includes about 2,250 bills totaling $23 million and ranging from $25 to $1.7 million.

DOC.HEAD: Burma Sentences Two Opposition Leaders to 10 Years
DOC.TEXT: Burma's military rulers have sentenced two opposition leaders to 10 years in jail, their toughest move yet against the party that won May's general election, a political source said Tuesday. In New York on Monday, the U.N. General Assembly took up a resolution demanding that the government free its political prisoners and expressed concern about its failure to hand power to the National League for Democracy after its landslide poll victory. A military tribunal in Rangoon sentenced the league's Kyi Maung and Chit Khaing on Monday, said the source, who was reached in the Burmese capital from Bangkok and spoke on condition of anonymity. Kyi Maung, 72, was the party's acting leader and a retired army colonel. He was considered a moderate and a potential mediator between the military and more radical opposition elements. Chit Khaing, 69, was in charge of the league's publications. Most of the league's other leaders are behind bars. The source said it appeared the two were sentenced for violating Burma's Official Secrets Act, an offense which carries a maximum 14-year term. The government detained them under the act on Sept. 6. Western diplomats said then it appeared they were accused of passing to other league members a secret document given to them by military intelligence chief, Maj. Gen. Khin Nyunt. Kyi Maung and Chit Khaing were among the 392 league members who won parliamentary seats in May. Political sources in Rangoon have reported the arrest of at least 50 other members of the party since late October, including about 15 members of parliament. The clampdown included raids on Buddhist monasteries and the arrest of hundreds of monks. On Nov. 9, Maung Ko, 52, a leading league organizer, died in military custody. Political sources said relatives believed he was tortured to death. The prime minister, Gen. Saw Maung, said he committed suicide. Amnesty International on Monday called attention to the torture reports surrounding Maung Ko's death. It has cited numerous reports of routine torture in custody. The London-based human rights group says the government has detained many hundreds, perhaps thousands of opponents without charge or trial or sentenced them to prison terms after unfair military trials. It says at least 100 people have been sentenced to death, although it was not clear if any of the sentences had been carried out. The league's general secretary, Aung San Suu Kyi, has been under house arrest since July 1989, and its chairman, Tin Oo, was sentenced to three-years jail last December. The draft U.N. resolution expresses concern over the failure of the government to obey ``the will of the people'' by handing power to the opposition. It was introduced by Sweden and co-sponsored by 20 countries - the 12 European Community nations, and Australia, Canada, Austria, Norway, Iceland, Poland, Sweden and Hungary. The General Assembly will vote on it around Dec. 18. The draft also ``stresses its conviction ... that all citizens detained with respect to their political activities ought to be released immediately and restored to the full enjoyment to their right to participate in the government of their country.'' Saw Maung came to power in September 1988 as troops killed thousands of people to crush a student-led uprising for democracy. Thousands of students fled the clampdown to neighboring Thailand. Bangkok, which has close ties with Saw Maung's government, recently hardened its attitude to the students after two of them hijacked a Thai Airways flight on Nov. 10. On Tuesday an Interior Ministry official said United Nations and other relief workers helping the Burmese students in Thailand must get government approval for their programs or face fines or imprisonment. Thailand classifies Burmese students as illegal immigrants. Under its immigration law, anyone helping illegal immigrants faces a $2,000 fine or five years in jail, the official said on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Moves to Make Ruble Only Legal Currency in Soviet Union
With AM-Soviet-Hunger, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The weakening ruble would become the only legal currency in the Soviet Union under legislation tentatively approved Tuesday by one chamber of the national legislature. The official Tass news agency said the proposed law was aimed at halting ``dollarization'' of the Soviet economy - the rapidly growing use of U.S. dollars in both the official and underground economies. Yuri Blokhin, a legislator who introduced the bill in the Soviet legislature's Council of Nationalities, said a national currency policy was necessary to boost the ruble's purchasing power. But it was unclear how the legislation, if enacted, would effect the scores of joint-venture businesses now operating in the country, or how it would fit into President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plan to create a market economy. It was also uncertain how the law would be received by the secessionist republics, such as the Baltic states, which have been considering establishing their own currencies. To become law, the legislation requires approval by both chambers of the Supreme Soviet parliament. No date was set for further consideration. Ivan Ivanov, deputy chairman of the government's Foreign Economic Commission, acknowledged the bill was a temporary measure that would have to be replaced once the ruble becomes convertible on foreign exchange markets. Officials have said they intend to make the ruble convertible in stages. They have not announced a timetable. Soviet citizens hold an estimated $324 million worth of foreign currency, acquired mostly from tourists and work for foreign companies. Ivanov said the law would let banks and Soviet citizens buy and sell foreign currency only at stock exchanges and auctions at market-determined rates. Current law requires all currency transactions to be conducted through the government-run banking system. Since Aug. 1, Soviets have been permitted to spend the foreign currency at special stores without telling the government where they got the money. Only certain Soviets are permitted to have foreign currency bank accounts, such as those who have worked abroad or for foreigners. Such stores range from government-run ``Beriozka'' stores selling food, alcohol and luxury goods, to the foreign-owned Christian Dior fashion outlet, two Western-style supermarkets and two Pizza Hut restaurants. They accept only foreign cash or credit cards. Ivanov said the legislation would prevent foreign currency from being circulated as legal tender within the Soviet Union. Tourists can buy about 5.5 rubles for one dollar, but the black market rate is closer to 20 rubles per dollar. For some transactions, such as taxi rides, dollars or American cigarettes are preferred to rubles. The government recently slashed by 70 percent the exchange rate for international commercial transactions to spur exports and cut imports. The rate since Nov. 1 has been 1.8 rubles per U.S. dollar, compared with the previous rate of .56 rubles to the dollar. The demand for dollars has soared in recent years because thousands of Soviets are taking advantage of newly relaxed border controls to travel abroad for the first time. The government has its own huge foreign currency reserves, but no official statistics exist on it and the law apparently would not affect it.

DOC.HEAD: Housing Plunge Sets Record; Worse News Still Ahead
DOC.TEXT: Home building plunged 6 percent in October, the government said Tuesday, extending the longest construction slide on record and sinking housing starts to their lowest level since the 1981-82 recession. Industry observers pointed to shrinking consumer confidence and the growing inability of builders to obtain credit as causes of the nine-month decline, the longest since the government began keeping track in 1959. Many believe the slide will continue into mid-1991, especially in light of broader weakening in the U.S. economy. ``Consumers are scared to death,'' economist Martin Regalia of the National Council of Savings Institutions said, echoing the sentiments of many analysts. ``They're concerned about their incomes.'' ``Business confidence is just as bad,'' added Thomas Holloway, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association. ``We're also seeing the adverse impact of builders unable to get credit.'' The Commerce Department said starts of new homes and apartments in October fell to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.04 million units. That was lowest level since construction of 902,000 units began in June 1982. ``The details of the October housing starts statistics indicate that the industry's condition is even more dire than had been thought,'' said Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, a New York securities firm. She noted that applications for building permits fell 6.8 percent to 925,000, the lowest level since 913,000 applications were filed in June 1982, ``indicating that a rebound in starts is not foreseeable in the immediate future.'' Building permits are often a barometer of future activity. Construction of single-family units dropped 1.0 percent to 854,000 units, a level Regalia said was approaching ``recessionary levels, which are the low 700,000s.'' But for Dan Pincus, a builder in Brick, N.J., ``it's almost better to admit we're in a recession so we can start talking about how to get out of it.'' ``Customers are just running into holes,'' Pincus said, forcing his firm to lay off most of its workers and cancel projects. The crews that remain and his suppliers and subcontractors are being asked to wait for payment until his houses are sold. ``My cash flow has been stretched to the limit,'' he said. ``We're down to building one house now, where we would have had three or four previously.'' The construction industry has lost 185,000 construction jobs nationally in the last five months, including 80,000 in October, the Labor Department reported recently. Analysts also point out that declining construction often means declining sales of appliances, furniture and other home furnishings as well as building supplies. Construction of multi-family units such as apartments and condominiums plummeted 23.3 percent to 187,000 units after a 17.3 percent drop in September. Analysts point to high vacancy rates in many areas of the country, which make builders hesitant to begin new projects and lenders reluctant to make new money available. ``The vacancy rates, the overbuilding have left us with inventories that suggest this weakness will continue,'' Regalia said. In addition, some contractors are waiting for the government to issue regulations designed to make apartments more accessible to the handicapped before committing themselves to new projects. Starts in the Northeast, scene of some of the slowest housing activity recently, shot up 38.5 percent to 144,000 units. But starts were down elsewhere - 16.9 percent to 266,000 units in the West, 10.4 percent to 395,000 units in the South and 2.5 percent to 236,000 units in the Midwest.

DOC.HEAD: Highlights of Thatcher's Political Career
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief chronology of highlights of British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's political career: --- 1958 - Elected to the House of Commons, representing the north London suburb of Finchley. 1961 - Appointed a deputy minister for Pensions and National Insurance, serving until 1964. 1970 - Appointed education secretary in Cabinet of Conservative Prime Minister Edward Heath, serving until 1974. Feb. 11, 1975 - Defeats Heath in contest for leadership of the Conservative Party, then in opposition. May 4, 1979 - Becomes prime minister when Conservatives win parliamentary majority in general election. April 2, 1982 - Argentine forces invade the Falkland Islands, claiming the British colony as their own. Britain sends a naval task force and reclaims the South Atlantic islands June 14-15 after the Argentines surrender. The war cost 255 British lives and 650 Argentine. July 9, 1982 - Begins second term as prime minister after Conservatives win general election. March 12, 1984 - The National Union of Mineworkers, opposing plans to close 20 unprofitable mines, begins a strike that lasts 51 weeks - the longest and most violent strike in British history and a watershed in Mrs. Thatcher's effort to crush union power. Oct. 12, 1984 - Mrs. Thatcher escapes injury as Irish Republican Army bombs her hotel in Brighton during the Conservative Party conference. Five people are killed and 31 injured. March 3, 1985 - Miners vote to return to work without a settlement. Jan. 6, 1986 - Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine resigns from Cabinet in dispute over American-led takeover of Westland PLC helicopter manufacturer. Heseltine sought a British-European rescue bid. June 11, 1987 - Leads Conservatives to election victory, becoming the only prime minister of the 20th century to win three elections consecutively. Oct. 26, 1989 - Nigel Lawson, chancellor of the exchequer, resigns following conflicts Mrs. Thatcher over the monetary policy. Nov. 1, 1990 - Deputy Prime Minister Sir Geoffrey Howe, a former foreign secretary and the last of Mrs. Thatcher's original Cabinet, resigns over her stance toward European union. Nov. 13, 1990 - Howe tells House of Commons that Mrs. Thatcher is jeopardizing vital British interests and dividing the government. Nov. 14, 1990 - Michael Heseltine declares his challenge for leadership of the party and the prime minister's job, Mrs. Thatcher's first serious challenger after 15 years at the helm of the party and 11{ in power. Nov. 20, 1990 - Conservatives in House of Commons hold a leadership election. Heseltine forces Mrs. Thatcher into a second-round ballot, scheduled for Nov. 27.

DOC.HEAD: Desert Filled: It's a Multinational Invasion of Media
With AM-Gulf-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Dan, Peter, Tom, Ted and Sam are on the duty roster. Bryant and Willard have come and gone, but The Juice has just arrived for Thanksgiving football. They are part a multinational force invading Saudi Arabia. No, it's not a military exercise for Operation Desert Shield. It's an influx of media, soon to be joined by White House reinforcements for Thanksgiving Day. As of Tuesday, 517 journalists had registered with the Joint Information Bureau, the media center run by the American military and the Saudi government. Since Operation Desert Shield was deployed in August, more than 1,200 journalists have signed on. More than 300 are flying with President Bush, due to meet and greet the troops on Thursday. From ABC to the Voice of America, from the American Spectator to the Wall Street Journal, reporters are combing the sands. There's a veritable cornucopia of alphabets: CBS, NBC, CNN, BBC, ITN and PAOs, which is militaryspeak for public affairs officers, whose job is to escort the media. It's not just an American show. There are reporters from Britain, France, Germany, Japan, Italy, Greece, Portugal, Brazil and Egypt, among others. Nobody is making a bigger splash than ABC, which has nearly 50 people on the Joint Information Bureau registry. The network is running five shows out of Saudi Arabia, including its nightly news program with Peter Jennings. Dan Rather of CBS and Tom Brokaw of NBC fill out the anchor spots, while CNN has a current crew of 19. ``It's been a major commitment on our part. We've earned our stripes,'' said Jim Miller, who heads CNN's operations in Saudi Arabia. Willard Scott of NBC's ``Today'' show broadcast live all last week, and Bryant Gumbel was here earlier. Former football star O.J. ``The Juice'' Simpson arrived Tuesday and will appear with U.S. Marines on Thursday's NBC program that precedes pro football. The onslaught has turned the miniature golf course and a garage roof of the main media hotel into ``Satellite Alley'' because so many of the dishes are bouncing signals off orbiting electronic stations. Nearby is a carpeted and air conditioned tent that will serve as the White House media center. Joint Information Bureau officials have told some PAOs they will be so busy that they should postpone their turkey dinners for a day. The media glare is a bit bewildering to the Saudis, whose Islamic kingdom has never before been under such scrutiny. The government has entertained heads of state and accompanying reporters, and hundreds of Moslem reporters come to Saudi Arabia each year to cover the pilgrimages to Mecca and Medina. But there has been nothing like this, and requests for additional visas by American newspapers and organizations run in the thousands, according to Mohamed Khayat of the Ministry of Information. Some of those awaiting admission may be disappointed, and others may only get visas good for two to four days. ``Friendly countries have sent their children here to defend Saudi Arabia, and they want to get news about their children. We understand this,'' Khayat said. ``There is no limit. But we think the number is sufficient. It covers the major media organizations,'' he said. Privately, Saudi officials are edgy over the number of journalists. One government official who asked not to be identified said no more visas would be issued at least until Bush and the White House press corps are long gone. Another official, also speaking on condition of anonymity, said restrictions were imposed on new visas because of reports about a protest in which Saudi women drove their own cars. Women sent to cover the story must observe some restrictions imposed on Saudi women - like the driving ban - but it hasn't stopped them from working. Women now represent the Washington Post, Los Angeles Times, Wall Street Journal, Philadelphia Inquirer, National Public Radio, Voice of America, Dallas Morning News, New York Newsday, Associated Press and all the U.S. television networks. Transportation can be a problem for women reporters if military escorts aren't available. Molly Moore of The Washington Post said she spent about $200 for a cab to take her to a military base and wait for her for six hours. ``The biggest headache for me is not being able to drive or rent a car. I've spent a fortune in cab fares. But other than driving, they haven't stopped me from anything I wanted to do,'' Ms. Moore said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Iraqi Parliament Votes To Free Germans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs on assembly vote. Pickup 5th pvs, `Saddam told..'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Iraqi parliament, acting at the behest of President Saddam Hussein, voted tonight to free all the remaining Germans held in Iraq and occupied Kuwait. Parliament speaker Saadi Mahdi Saleh said there were 124 Germans still in Iraq and Kuwait. No specific arrangements were made for their departure, and there was no indication when they would be freed. It was not known how many member of the 250-member National Assembly attended the session to consider Saddam's request. Only one lawmaker, Jamil Sheik Issa, voted against the measure. Earlier this week Saddam said all foreigners would be allowed to leave between Dec. 25 and March 25, but Information Minister Latif Nassiyif Jassim indicated Monday that some might be allowed to leave earlier. Earlier reports said there were about 280 Germans in Iraq and Kuwait, with some held at strategic sites to ward off a possible attack by the U.S.-led multinational force. The vote today referred to 124 Germans, and there was no explanation for the discrepancy. Hundreds of foreigners have been prevented from leaving Iraq and Kuwait since Iraq seized the emirate Aug. 2. Saddam told delegations from France and Switzerland on Monday that more Europeans would be allowed to go free, the official Iraqi News Agency reported. The report today on the meetings with a five-member Swiss parliamentary delegation headed by Christian Democrat opposition member Edgar Oehler and by French politician Jean-Marie Le Pen did not say how many Europeans would be released or when they would be allowed to leave. On Monday, Iraq announced an unspecified number of Swiss would be allowed to leave ``in appreciation'' of the Swiss delegation's visit to Baghdad. INA said Saddam told both delegations that dialogue should be used to solve the Persian Gulf conflict. ``As human beings, we are flexible in our way of thinking and behavior, but on the basis of the right path, humanitarian relationship and dialogue, not threats,'' the president said. Saddam again accused the United States of seeking to control the world's oil reserves. He also repeated his Aug. 12 statement that all the region's problems were linked to a solution of the Palestinian problem. The United States and its allies have said Saddam's attempt to absorb Kuwait should not be linked to the Palestinian-Israeli dispute. Concerning the German hostages, Saddam said a recent statement by Chancellor Helmut Kohl calling for a peaceful solution to the Persian Gulf crisis, as well as the historic friendship between the two peoples, prompted his decision. The Western allies have accused Saddam of trying to use the hostage issue to try to split the alliance against him. In releasing the Germans, the Iraqi president contrasted Bonn's attitude with that of Washington and London. ``The decision of banning some foreigners from travel was adopted on the hope of giving reckless minds in the administration of (President) Bush and (British Prime Minister Margaret) Thatcher an opportunity to delay in carrying on the procedure toward the abyss of evil,'' INA quoted him as saying. Saddam allowed 120 Germans to leave with former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt earlier this month. The call to the assembly to free the hostages, referred to in Iraq as ``guests,'' was the same procedure used to free hundreds of French and Bulgarian hostages. Iraq announced Monday that 250,000 more troops were being sent to Kuwait - Saddam's answer to Bush's announcement Nov. 8 that up to 200,000 more U.S. troops will be sent to the gulf. Also Monday, Information Minister Jassim declined to say if something short of an attack, such as passage of a U.N. resolution authorizing offensives, would be enough to disrupt the planned hostage releases. ``We are watching the situation,'' said Jassim when asked if such a resolution would block the plan. At a news conference, Jassim declined to guarantee that Westerners in Kuwait could emerge from hiding without risking arrest and relocation to a potential military target. Five Germans and two Americans were reported arrested Saturday in Kuwait. ``This is a procedural thing that is not related to the political attitude,'' said Jassim. ``Every foreigner should report to Iraqi authorities so they can be registered and protected by Iraqi authorities. This is a matter of rules and regulations.''

DOC.HEAD: Ag Department Responsible for Iraq Food Loans
With AM-Gulf-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A member of Congress criticized the Agriculture Department Tuesday for extending billions of dollars in loan guarantees to Iraq for food from American farmers throughout the 1980s. ``Today, the U.S. is pledging to make war on Iraq,'' said Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y. ``For the last seven years, though, we pledged the same country free credit.'' Schumer released a General Accounting Office report that says USDA continued to approve credit guarantees ``even though Agriculture's risk analysis documents for fiscal years 1989 and 1990 rated Iraq as a high-risk market.'' ``It seems that the U.S. desire to build a strategic and agricultural trade relationship with Iraq outweighed the apparent financial risks involved and discounted evidence of Iraq's human rights violations,'' the report said. Schumer, chairman of the task force on urgent fiscal issues for the House Budget Committee, requested the GAO study. He is a long-time foe of federal spending on agriculture programs. Export guarantees for Iraq's purchases totaled $4.9 billion from 1983 to 1989. Another $500 million was approved in 1990. When President Bush announced the trade embargo after Iraq's Aug. 1 invasion of Kuwait, a total $2 billion in debts remained. Under the terms of the loan guarantee program, the federal government must pay the banks that extended the credit to Iraq if Iraq doesn't meet its debts. The Agriculture Department has confirmed that private banks have begun asking it to make good on the credit guarantees, which were used to buy wheat, rice and other commodities. Not all of the $2 billion is due at once. The loans are spread out, some of them running through 1995 or later. No money is lent directly by the department. Once a country is approved for the guarantee, private lenders and exporters work out a plan with the foreign buyer, subject to USDA approval. Larry McElvain, director of USDA's Commodity Credit Corp. for the Foreign Agricultural Service, said the government didn't start getting claims on Iraqi loans until the trade embargo began.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq To Free German Hostages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with parliament approving release of Germans. Pickup 4th pvs, `Saddam told...'
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein put his key pawns in the Persian Gulf crisis back into play again today by asking parliament to free all Germans held hostage in Iraq. The National Assembly quickly agreed. The move came a day after Saddam ordered the deployment of 250,000 more troops into Kuwait. Their deployment would boost the number of Iraqi soldiers in the oil-rich emirate to about 430,000. There was only one dissenting vote when the National Assembly met late today and voted to allow all Germans to leave Iraq and Kuwait. No specific arrangements were made for the Germans' departure. Parliament speaker Saadi Mahdi Saleh said there were 124 Germans in Iraq and Kuwait - a number far below the estimated 280 Germans reported earlier. There was no explanation of the discrepancy. Saddam told delegations from France and Switzerland on Monday that more Europeans would be allowed to go free, the official Iraqi News Agency reported. And a Dutch company reported today that 105 Dutchmen, 14 Belgians and 3 Britons who completed a government-commissioned dredging project also will be allowed to depart. Hundreds of foreigners have been prevented from leaving Iraq and Kuwait since Saddam's troops overran the emirate Aug. 2, and the Western allies have accused Saddam of trying to use the hostage issue to try to split the alliance against him. In releasing the Germans, the Iraqi president contrasted the German government's attitude with that of Washington and London. ``The decision of banning some foreigners from travel was adopted on the hope of giving reckless minds in the administration of (President) Bush and (British Prime Minister Margaret) Thatcher an opportunity to delay in carrying on the procedure toward the abyss of evil,'' INA quoted him as saying. Saddam allowed 120 Germans to leave with former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt earlier this month. Saddam's troop buildup was a clear response to Bush's announcement Nov. 8 that up to 200,000 more troops would be sent to the gulf, giving the U.S.-led multinational force an offensive military option and bringing the number of U.S. troops in the region to about 430,000. Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff, told ABC's ``Good Morning America'' today that the United States would closely monitor troop movements. ``It seems to me this is part of Saddam Hussein's headline-of-the-day program. Yesterday it was troop buildup, the day before that it was a hostage release,'' Powell said. ``What he's trying to do is take the world's eye off the ball. And that ball is his aggression against the nation of Kuwait, his aggression in the region, his threatening our economic lifeline.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater called the announcement of Iraq's new deployment ``another instance of him (Saddam) thumbing his nose at the United Nations.'' The U.N. Security Council has passed 10 resolutions - including a trade embargo - in an effort to force Iraq out of Kuwait. In Baghdad, there was another sign today that the trade embargo is having an impact. The state press said the country's legislature had voted to impose the death penalty on anyone hoarding wheat, barley, rice, corn and other grains for trading purposes. Indian news reports said today that Iraq is refusing to allow an Indian ship, its crew and 14 Red Cross workers to leave until it unloads more than 4,700 tons of rice. The ship docked at the Iraqi port of Umm Qasr in September with 10,000 tons of food for Indians in Iraq and Kuwait. It had been scheduled to leave with some of its cargo. On Monday, President Bush failed to get Soviet agreement on a proposed U.N. resolution authorizing force against Iraq. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev went so far only as to agree that force in the gulf ``cannot be ruled out,'' officials said. Bush met with Gorbachev in Paris, attending a summit that included the signing Monday of an arms reduction treaty by NATO and Warsaw Pact members. His secretary of state, James A. Baker III, has been pressing hard in meetings with foreign ministers for a U.N. resolution authorizing an attack to drive Iraq from Kuwait. Bush focused in large part on the issue in a dinner with the Soviet president. Later, Fitzwater tried to minimize differences between the two leaders on the use of force, saying: ``We are united on this issue. We have a conceptual agreement that force cannot be ruled out.'' A poll published today, meanwhile, indicated Americans are increasingly worried that Bush favors the military option over the diplomatic route to resolve the Persian Gulf crisis. In the joint New York Times-CBS poll, 47 percent of respondents said the Bush administration has been too quick to get U.S. forces involved and has not been diligent enough about seeking diplomatic solutions. Only 38 percent felt the same way in August, the poll said. The poll of 1,370 adults was done by telephone Nov. 13-15. It has a margin for error of 3 percent.

DOC.HEAD: In Mother Russia's Cupboard, Few Beets and Cabbage, But Lots of Garlic
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party newspaper Pravda on Tuesday took a grim inventory of the Soviet pantry for the winter and warned that ``almost everywhere, supplies are worse than last year.'' Although it predicted there would be no ``real hunger'' in the coming months, Pravda said the food that Russians traditionally count on, such as cabbage and beets, will be in short supply. ```Cabbage soup and porridge is our food.' It's a famous Russian proverb. It appears that now we can't even get this humble portion,'' Pravda correspondent A. Platoshkin wrote. Leningrad Mayor Anatoly Sobchak on Monday made a public appeal to the West for emergency food aid for his city, the second-largest in the Soviet Union, to avoid famine and discontent with the reform movement. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who is lining up Western aid for his nation during his current trip abroad, admitted in a speech to the national legislature Friday that the country faces critical shortages at the start of winter but insisted the government has enough supplies. The Pravda correspondent said he agreed with Gorbachev's assessment that there were adequate reserves, although he also wrote that ``what's in storage doesn't mean it makes it to the table.'' Pravda said there should be enough bread for the nation after the government bought 66 million tons of grain, which is more than last year. But vegetables, potatoes and other foods were in short supply. The reason for the shortages, according to Pravda, is that enterprises in the various republics are disobeying orders from the central government to fulfill their quotas. As the Soviet republics push for local control over their economies, political structures and culture, they are disregarding orders from the central government. This has caused the ``paralysis of power'' that has stalled Gorbachev's reforms and led him on Saturday to propose restructuring the executive branch of government and put it entirely under his control. He said Saturday an emergency program would be drafted within two weeks to try to solve the country's food shortage. In the vast Russian republic, which has more than half the country's population, the potato supply is little more than half of what is needed, Pravda reported. Potatoes are known as the ``second bread'' because of their importance in the Russian diet. ``Sometimes ... it was our first and last bread,'' Platoshkin wrote. ``It could be called our national love. We devote many proverbs and songs to potatoes. ``But maybe, at the present moment, we're going to have to play a funeral dirge,'' he said, noting that the many potatoes stored in dirty, damp cellars will rot before the winter is out. The article did not address the potato needs for Moscow, where citizens and soldiers helped gather this autumn's potato crop following heavy rains that hindered the harvest. Pravda said there also were shortages of other basic foods: fresh and sour cabbage, carrots, beets, tomatoes and the Russian favorite, pickled onions. Only garlic was in oversupply, it said. In the Ural Mountains cities of Sverdlovsk, Chelyabinsk and Tyumen, there is an critical shortage of meat and dairy products, Pravda said. At Sobchak's urging, Leningrad's City Council voted last week to begin rationing meat, poultry, eggs, flour, butter and other staples starting Dec. 1. Many other cities throughout Russia and the Ukraine already ration food, sugar, vodka, matches, soap and other necessities. In an interview with The Associated Press, Sobchak said some people in Leningrad had accused him of being too proud to ask for help, but that for the good of the city, he would ``get down on my knees'' if necessary. Sobchak, a member of the Supreme Soviet legislature, is the first high-level Soviet official to appeal publicly for food donations from the West. He said the West German government and a private U.S. organization, AmeriCares, already were preparing shipments. ``A month ago, I thought we could avoid foreign aid. Today, I think we can't,'' he said. ``The food situation has worsened, and by the time we take steps to increase stockpiles and improve distribution, we could already have placed our major cities ... in danger of famine.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Elizabeth Taylor says her doctors were blunt with her when she was hospitalized earlier this year with a near-fatal case of pneumonia. ``They told me that I was dying,'' Miss Taylor said in a USA Today interview published Tuesday. ``They said it in front of my sons, too.'' Miss Taylor, 58, was first hospitalized at Daniel Freeman Marina Hospital on April 9 with what was described as a sinus infection. But her condition worsened and she was transferred to St. John's in serious condition with viral pneumonia. She was placed on a respirator and intravenous medication and doctors said she was near death on April 22. Miss Taylor rallied, however, and she was released in June. Miss Taylor offered a candid account of her hospital stay. ``Oh, sweetheart, I had so much machinery coming out of my throat, my nose, my neck, it was like science fiction,'' she said. ``Colorful, too .... with the tubes, you can see pieces of yourself floating by. Very gross Technicolor!'' --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Axl Rose, the tattooed lead singer of the heavy metal band Guns 'N Roses, is seeking a restraining order against a woman he allegedly struck with a wine bottle last month in a scuffle at his home. Rose, 28, asked a Superior Court judge Monday to prohibit his neighbor, Gabriela Kantor, from having any contact with him, his wife, Erin, or any visitors to their West Hollywood condominium. Rose was arrested Oct. 30 for investigation of assault after he allegedly struck Ms. Kantor on the head with a wine bottle in the hallway outside his home after she complained about his loud music. The rock star was released on $5,000 bail after being jailed for four hours. Ms. Kantor was treated at a hospital. Prosecutors will decide by Nov. 29 whether to file criminal charges against Rose, said Mike Botula, a spokesman in the district attorney's office. Rose filed documents Monday that contended the Oct. 30 incident began with Ms. Kantor ``banging incessantly and hysterically'' on Rose's door. She then allegedly ``threatened to stab, injure and kill'' the singer with the wine bottle, according to the petition for a temporary restraining order. Ms. Kantor does not have a telephone listing in West Hollywood and could not be reached for comment. ---
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version also moved on the sports wire.
DOC.TEXT: A 12-year-old boy who was severely burned when he refused his attacker's demand that he take drugs will get a special award from the American Sportscasters Association next week. David Opont will receive the ``Hero of the Year'' award from Vice President Quayle at the sportscasters' dinner in New York, organizers said. ``David Opont is a symbol of bravery and courage that our young people can look to with pride,'' said Louis O. Schwartz, president of the association. Opont was burned over 50 percent of his body in the attack in March. After several skin grafts, he was released from the hospital in August. His attacker was convicted of attempted murder for tying up Opont and setting him on fire. The 14-year-old defendant also was found guilty last month of kidnapping, robbery and other offenses. Under juvenile law, the defendant, who was not identified because of his age, can be confined to a detention center for three years, but the sentence can be extended each year afterward until he is 21. --- NEW YORK (AP) - The widow of baseball great Jackie Robinson, one of the founders of the recently defunct Freedom National Bank, says her husband ``would have been devastated'' by the bank's recent closure. ``Being chairman and founder of Freedom was one of the major achievements of his post-baseball career,'' Rachel Robinson said in an interview published Tuesday in the New York Post. ``He loved the bank, and worried about it a lot.'' Robinson, who broke baseball's color barrier in 1947, formed the Harlem-based bank in 1964 with others to help residents and small minority-owned businesses obtain mortgages and loans. Freedom, the nation's fourth-largest black-owned bank, lost $4 million over the last two years before being closed by federal regulators on Nov. 13. ``Freedom Bank, as we know it, has no future. That bank has been terminated. We should not be talking in terms of reviving Freedom. We have lost that bank and that opportunity,'' said Mrs. Robinson, who became a member of the bank's board of directors in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher's Challenger: A Man of Ambition and Flair
With AM-Britain-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nothing was so memorable about Michael Heseltine's years in the Cabinet as his departure. He resigned in the middle of a meeting in January 1986, walked out of the prime minister's residence, told reporters he had quit, and walked down Downing Street alone. The videotape of Heseltine's exit has been shown repeatedly on British television, every time some ruckus in the Conservative Party hinted Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's position was in jeopardy. Just as often, Heseltine would say - as he said as recently as Nov. 6 - that he could not foresee the circumstances in which he would challenge her. Eight days later he changed his mind and launched the most serious political challenge to Mrs. Thatcher in her 11{ years in power. On Tuesday, he forced Mrs. Thatcher into a second-round ballot to determine the party leadership - and that of the nation. Tall and handsome with flowing blond hair and piercing blue eyes, the 57-year-old Heseltine is a self-made millionaire who doesn't quite fit any faction of the governing Conservative Party. Critics accuse him of volatility and showmanship. As his challenge to her leadership loomed, Thatcher aides commented: ``all glamour and no substance.'' The most famous story about Heseltine dates from his days at Oxford University, when he is said to have sketched his future, decade by decade, on the back of an envelope. According to his unofficial biographer and fellow Conservative lawmaker, Julian Critchley, Heseltine marked down his goal for the 1990s: ``Downing Street.'' As he finally made his move for the prime minister's office and the tenancy of 10 Downing St., Heseltine denied the story of the back of the envelope. But his ambition, nurtured for years in political exile, has not been disguised. He is a politician with a flair for the dramatic gesture, and the patience to wait for the prime minister to stumble. Critchley, an admirer but no longer a close friend, describes Heseltine as ``95 percent calculation and 5 percent Celt,'' a reference to Heseltine's passion and his birth in Wales. As defense secretary from 1983 to 1986 at the height of the propaganda battle over the deployment of U.S. nuclear missiles in Britain, Heseltine donned a flak jacket for a confrontation with anti-nuclear protesters at a missile base. Politically, he's dead center in the party while Mrs. Thatcher stands well to the right. But many on the Tory left distrust him for views that include an enthusiastic advocacy of a U.S. program that requires the unemployed to work for welfare. He calls his political philosophy ``caring capitalism,'' which contrasts with the robust, self-made stance of Thatcherism. ``I find it difficult to reconcile with what I understand to be the core of Tory philosophy that there are people sleeping in the doorways of so many central London streets,'' Heseltine said in a recent interview with The Independent on Sunday. Mrs. Thatcher attacked him for his economic views, which she said smacked of the policies of the socialist Labor Party and of the Soviet Union. Heseltine was environmental secretary in Mrs. Thatcher's first Cabinet, the golden boy who seemed destined for bigger things. In 1983, he became secretary of defense. The rift came in 1986 in a dispute over the acquisition of the financially troubled British helicopter-maker Westland PLC. Heseltine, always pro-European, favored a European consortium while Mrs. Thatcher favored a U.S. corporation, Sikorsky. The feud culminated in Heseltine's walkout from a Cabinet meeting. Heseltine then conducted a patient campaign of a leader in waiting. He has swept round the country addressing party meetings, spreading good will and glamour and assiduously avoiding direct criticism of Mrs. Thatcher. Subtle criticisms, however, were always there, particularly about her combative stance against the rest of the European Community and a controversial new local government tax, the so-called poll tax. Michael Ray Dibdin Heseltine was born March 21, 1933, into a middle-class Welsh family. His father was a structural engineer. Starting with $2,000 from his grandfather, he made one fortune in property and then another in magazine publishing. He and his wife, Anne, who have two daughters and a son, have a magnificent house in London's Belgravia district and a country mansion where he has planted 2,500 species of trees and shrubs. It also has a lake for his lifelong hobby of birdwatching. ``I haven't been driven by money,'' Heseltine once said. ``I saw money as an important part of the process of being independent - and in enabling me to pursue a political career.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Refuses Bail For Son Of Interior Secretary
DOC.TEXT: A judge on Tuesday refused bail to the son of Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan, saying Robert Jeffrey Lujan, who was arrested on a rape charge, was ``an unreasonable danger'' to the community. Circuit Court Judge Donald M. Haddock rejected an appeal from Lujan's attorney who argued that the young man was not a threat to flee and had no history of violent behavior. Lujan's attorney, Robert Powell, said he would take the case to the Virginia Court of Appeals. Lujan, 28, was arrested Wednesday and held without bail on charges of raping a woman resident of the same apartment building where Lujan lives with his parents. The 48-year-old woman testified she awoke to find Lujan - naked and armed with a shotgun - sitting on her bed. Powell has said Lujan has admitted spending several hours in the woman's apartment, but added the woman invited him to the apartment and that the sexual relations were consentual. Manuel Lujan said after the arrest that his son, who had a federal felony drug conviction in 1983, has a severe drinking problem.

DOC.HEAD: Milli Vanilli's Rob and Fab Face The Music
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with news conference, comments from record company. Pickup 8th graf pvs: `This is...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The Milli Vanilli duo said today they made a ``pact with the devil'' when they pretended they sang on a hit album, and they contended it was all with the knowledge of their record company. ``We were scared. People threatened us,'' said Milli Vanilli member Rob Pilatus at a news conference today. ``(But) we're happy that it's over.'' Pilatus declined to say who threatened him and partner Fabrice Morvan. But he said Arista Records President Clive Davis knew about the deception that has rocked the pop music industry. Arista has denied the allegation. ``Arista Records and their executives did not know that Rob Pilatus and Fab Morvan did not sing on the Milli Vanilli album, and any assertions to the contrary are false and libelous,'' the company said in a statement today. Milli Vanilla was stripped of its Grammy on Monday, the first act forced to return a Grammy in the 34-year history of the award. The National Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences rescinded the 1989 best new artist Grammy, one day before the two planned to surrender the honor. Pilatus said the album gave them fame and fortune, but it came at a high cost. He said they were seduced by the money and success because they were poor and living in a Munich housing project. ``You get something, for that you make a pact with the devil,'' said Pilatus. Goaded by the media to prove they could sing, Pilatus cursed and said, ``I'll do it.'' The two then burst into a few lines from the song ``Girl, You Know It's True'' from their the best-selling album by the same name. The duo admitted last week that they did not sing a note on the album. They also lip-synced at concerts and on the Grammy awards show in February. The album sold about 7 million copies. Pilatus, 25, from Germany, and Morvan, also 25 and a native of the Caribbean island of Guadaloupe, were stripped of its best new artist Grammy Award following revelations that other singers substituted for the pop duo on ``Girl, You Know It's True.'' ``This is the first time this has ever happened'' in Grammy history, academy president Michael Greene said. ``I do think it's an isolated incident. We are as upset about it as the public has the right to be.'' Greene said academy trustees voted overwhelmingly to take back the award. A decision on what to do with it will be made by an academy subcommittee Dec. 5. Greene said the duo's wish that it be given to the three singers who actually sang was ``not a possibility.'' The academy recognizes ``packaging'' groups is part of the music industry, Greene said. But misleading record labels are unacceptable, he said. The album label ``said `Vocals: Rob and Fab.' That was just absolutely false,'' he said. Milli Vanilli's German producer, Frank Farian, who disclosed the deception, said in a statement that by returning the Grammy, ``Rob and Fab can put this episode behind them and mark the beginning of a new career for themselves.'' Vocalists Johnny Davis, Charles Shaw and Brad Howell reportedly were the real singers. ``I'm very pleased that it's coming out. ... I'm pleased that they are taking action in America,'' Shaw said on Monday's ``Entertainment Tonight.'' Shaw said he earlier tried to persuade people he was one of the singers, but getting anyone to believe him ``was like running my head into a brick wall.'' Meanwhile, an Oakland woman who bought her son a Milli Vanilli tape filed a class action lawsuit in state court Monday seeking a refund for anyone in California who bought the group's recordings or attended one of their concerts. ``I want everyone to be able to get money back. I don't want the producer in Germany to profit from what he did to these kids,'' Sheila Stalder said. The lawsuit also seeks to recover profits and place them in a trust benefiting consumer groups as outlined in the state's consumer protection law, said Stalder's lawyer, Alan Caplan.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Shows Little Worry Over New Iraqi Troop Buildup
With AM-Gulf-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon said Tuesday that Iraq's announced plan to send 250,000 more troops to Kuwait may be only a psychological ploy, but left open the possibility that even more American GIs could be deployed in response. Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said that because new Iraqi reinforcements may lack adequate training and supplies, their deployment to Kuwait could hurt rather than help Saddam Hussein's war-making ability. ``It's not clear that large numbers of additional, probably less capable units significantly adds to his combat power in theater; and in fact, might present him with new vulnerabilities rather than added strength,'' Powell said. Meanwhile, 45 House Democrats filed suit in U.S. District Court seeking an injunction to prevent President Bush from ordering a military attack on Iraqi forces in Kuwait without first getting a go-ahead from Congress. The issue should be debated in Congress because ``there are millions of American people in this country who have serious questions about going to war,'' said Rep. Ronald V. Dellums, D-Calif., who organized the lawsuit. ``The president of the United States on his own cannot make that kind of determination.'' At the Pentagon, chief spokesman Pete Williams said officials hadn't seen the lawsuit. In response to reporters' questions, he added that Congress has been kept fully abreast of U.S. military actions in the Persian Gulf. ``Members of Congress have been informed, consulted, met with, briefed by (the Pentagon and the White House) ... on every aspect of this operation so far,'' Williams said. On Monday, the state-run Iraqi News Agency reported that Saddam had decided to form seven additional army divisions and call up more than 150,000 reservists for active duty, ``adding to our forces over a quarter of a million fighters.'' Iraq already has about 430,000 troops in Kuwait and southern Iraq, according to Pentagon estimates, facing off in the gulf area against 230,000 American troop and at least 100,000 others sent by U.S. allies and other Arab nations. Two weeks ago, Bush announced plans to send U.S. reinforcements to the gulf that are expected to increase the American force to about 430,000 by January. In an interview today with ``CBS This Morning,'' Powell said he doubted that Bush would answer Saddam tit-for-tat with still more troop deployments. The chairman said the latest Iraqi buildup plan may simply put fresh troops in Kuwait to replace rather than to reinforce those that have been there since the Aug. 2 invasion. Williams, however, stressed that it was too early to know whether Saddam's latest announcement would require a U.S. response of additional troop deployments, but he said a further Iraqi buildup could be a reason to send more American troops. An increase in Iraqi forces in Kuwait, from about 165,000 in early September to 430,000 in October, was a key reason cited by the Pentagon for Bush's decision earlier this month to send in a new wave of U.S. reinforcements. Williams said U.S. military authorities would be monitoring Iraqi troop movements for evidence of a buildup. He said there was not yet any such evidence. ``It's hard to know whether this is something Iraq intends to do or whether this is just a propaganda ploy to get the attention off its occupation of Kuwait and the hostages,'' Williams said. ``If Iraq does follow through on this announcement, it would be a further tightening of its grip on occupied Kuwait, just the opposite of what the world has asked Iraq to do, which is to withdraw from Kuwait,'' the spokesman said. Williams declined to comment on Powell's remark that additional Iraqi troops in Kuwait could give Saddam ``new vulnerabilities,'' although Williams said the deployments could make it harder for Saddam to defend Iraqi territory in the event of a U.S. offensive.

DOC.HEAD: Baltic Officials Protest Exclusion From Summit
DOC.TEXT: The foreign ministers of the three Baltic republics protested Tuesday at the Soviet move excluding them from the work of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. They urged participants to help them gain a ``full and complete'' role in the 34-nation summit. At a news conference organized by Denmark and Iceland, the three praised France for its efforts. Through a French invitation, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania were able to take part Monday in the opening ceremonies of the three-day summit meeting of 34 leaders. However, their hoped-for participation in summit work was cut short by the Soviet refusal to allow them status as independent states. Lithuanian Foreign Minister Algirdas Saudargas, in a statement signed by his delegation, said, ``Monday afternoon we were informed that our accreditation was no longer valid because of the Soviet veto.'' Because CSCE decisions are made by consensus, the Soviet refusal to allow the Baltic representatives to participate was final. The three ministers said the Soviet move rejecting their participation as independent states counters principles of the Helsinki accords. They said a growing number of countries supported ``complete and total'' participation of the Baltic nations in the CSCE process. Estonian Foreign Minister Lennart Meri listed nations supporting Baltic participation in the CSCE process as: France, Denmark, Iceland, Norway, Sweden, Czechoslovakia, Poland and Britain.

DOC.HEAD: Vote Forces Thatcher Into Runoff for Leadership
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Labor Party proposing motion of no confidence, CORRECTS percentage of Thatcher lead. Pickup 10th pvs, `In the...'
DOC.TEXT: Former Defense Minister Michael Heseltine today forced Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher into a second-round ballot in their struggle for leadership of the Conservative Party. The close vote was a sharp setback to Mrs. Thatcher, who has governed Britain for 11{ years. She won 204 votes from party members of the House of Commons and Heseltine received 152 votes. If she had received two more votes from the 16 members who abstained, she would have won on the first ballot. If Mrs. Thatcher loses the leadership of the party, she would step down as prime minister. ``I confirm it is my intention to let my name go forward to the second ballot,'' a calm Mrs. Thatcher told reporters outside the British Embassy in Paris. t was expected, however, that some of her supporters would urge her to step down rather than risk a humiliating defeat. The opposition Labor Party compounded the political turmoil by tabling a motion of no confidence in the government. That motion, which likely would be debated before the second ballot in the leadership contest, could bring down the government and force a national election. ``Whatever the outcome of the current election in the Conservative Party, a substantial proportion of that party will continue to have no confidence in whatever leader is chosen,'' Labor leader Neil Kinnock said. A smiling Heseltine greeted reporters outside his home. ``I am overwhelmed with gratitude to my parliamentary colleagues who in such large measure have given me their support,'' said Heseltine, who stood hand-in-hand with his wife, Anne, outside their home. ``It is the end for her,'' said Conservative lawmaker Robert Rhodes James. The 204 votes gave Mrs. Thatcher a lead of 14.6 percent, when she needed a 15 percent advantage to win outright. In the second ballot, on Nov. 27, a simple majority would be sufficient to win. However, other candidates would be free to step forward. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd has indicated he might run against Heseltine if Mrs. Thatcher dropped out. The prime minister learned of the result in Paris, where she was attending the 34-nation summit on European security. Mrs. Thatcher had been at pains to keep up business as usual earlier today - although the business last weekend included a round of lengthy interviews with newspapers about the leadership challenge. Mrs. Thatcher, 65, had argued that Heseltine's economic policies were a betrayal of her free-market crusade. Heseltine, 57, portrayed himself as a Thatcherite with better prospects than Mrs. Thatcher. He pointed to a flurry of opinion polls that showed voters would be more favorable to the Conservatives if he were party leader. He also promised to review an unpopular local services tax sponsored by Mrs. Thatcher that is widely deplored as unfairly favoring the wealthy. ``Increasingly they are saying, with sadness and reluctance, that she must go,'' Heseltine said Monday. Heseltine's ambition to become prime minister had been evident ever since he walked out of his last Cabinet meeting in January 1986. He had insisted for years, however, that he could not foresee trying to unseat Mrs. Thatcher. Mrs. Thatcher was first elected in 1979 and re-elected in 1983 and 1987. She has been in office longer than any European leader. The Conservatives, burdened by high inflation, high interest rates and the unpopular local services tax have trailed the opposition Labor Party in opinion polls for 16 months. The so-called poll tax replaced the property tax with a flat tax on every adult. Millionaires pay the same as laborers, and for many households the tax burden has increased. The Conservatives have suffered recent embarrassing losses in elections to fill vacancies in Parliament. The revolt in the Tory ranks followed a 12-nation European Community summit in Rome at the end of October. Eleven of the leaders, over Mrs. Thatcher's vociferous dissent, agreed on a timetable for establishing a central European bank, followed by a single European currency. Her deputy, Sir Geoffrey Howe, predicted that Mrs. Thatcher would eventually fall into line with Britain's European partners, as she had done in the past. But with signs indicating the contrary, Howe resigned Nov. 1. A week ago, Howe delivered a scalding speech in the House of Commons, accusing Mrs. Thatcher of jeopardizing Britain's vital interests. Heseltine, who has long advocated closer ties within Europe, entered the race for party lea. Heseltine's resignation, like Howe's and that of Nigel Lawson as treasury chief last year, involved Euroder the next daypean integration. In Heseltine's case, it was a row over whether a European consortium - his choice - or a U.S. corporation would take over the ailing helicopter manufacturer, Westland PLC. All three former ministers also complained of Mrs. Thatcher's forceful and sometimes abrasive style.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Troops, PLO Guerrillas Fight in Lebanon; Five Killed
DOC.TEXT: Israeli troops attacked a squad of PLO guerrillas near Israel's self-designated security zone in southern Lebanon, and one soldier and four guerrillas were killed in the firefight, police said Tuesday. Ten other guerrillas fled, two bleeding of wounds they suffered in the nightlong clash with Israeli troops and allied militiamen of the South Lebanon Army. A Lebanese Army corporal driving on a nearby road in the foothills of Mount Hermon also was wounded. The military command in Israel confirmed the clash near this village, about three miles north of Israel's so-called security zone. It identified the dead officer as 1st Lt. Yaron Yogev, 23. It said he was shot after his unit spotted and attacked the ``terrorist'' squad. The battle with machine guns and rocket propelled grenades raged under parachute flares for eight hours before the Israelis and SLA militiamen pulled back to the security zone, police said. The bodies of the four guerrillas lay on the ground near Ain Atta for several hours after the Israeli-SLA force withdrew. ``They may be booby-trapped. Explosive experts are needed to examine the corpses before removing them,'' a police spokesman said. He cannot be identified under standing rules. He said Israel and the SLA apparently were tipped about an attempt to infiltrate the security zone. The police spokesman said the guerrillas belonged to Samir Ghoshe's Palestine Popular Struggle Front. The group claimed responsibility in a statement distributed in Beirut. It identified those killed as Mohammed Omar Sharif, Ahmed al-Amed, both Palestinians, and Samir Izzidin Shami and Hamadah Dafi, who were Lebanese. The Front, backed and financed by Libya, is a hard-line faction within Yasser Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization. It has seldom been involved in attacks against Israel or its border enclave. The wounded guerrillas are Palestinians. Police identified them as the squad commander and his assistant, but did not provide names. They were seen heading back with eight surviving attackers to the Syrian-controlled Bekaa valley in eastern Lebanon after the battle. ``We belong to the Palestine Popular Struggle Front and Libya's Revolutionary Committees,'' one guerrilla shouted to a small group of reporters, flashing his fingers in a victory sign. ``I'll shoot you if you take pictures.'' Israel staked out the security zone in 1985, when it withdrew the bulk of its invading army after a three-year occupation. The zone covers 440 square miles, stretching from the Mediterranean coast to the slopes of Mount Hermon. It is controlled by the 3,000-strong SLA, which is backed by 1,000 Israeli soldiers. Radical Palestinians and pro-Syrian Lebanese leftist factions as well as Iranian-backed Shiite Moslem fundamentalists are involved in guerrilla warfare to force out the Israelis. The Israelis have left the security zone several times in the past few months in pursuit of guerrillas, and a senior Israeli official said Tuesday the army would continue that policy. ``When we think there are going to be terrorist attacks on Israel from outside the security zone, we feel that we have a free hand to act in order to prevent in advance attempts to infiltrate,'' said Yossi Olmert, director of the Government Press Office. Olmert said there had been 17 infiltration attempts by land and sea this year in which 36 Arabs and two Israelis were killed. ``None of them has reached Israel itself and this is exactly why it is vitally important for us, even more than before, to emphasize the significance of this security zone as an effective buffer,'' he told reporters.

DOC.HEAD: Ethics Committee Explores Role of Arizona Senators
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Inserts grafs 14-15, McCain's administrative, to update with afternoon testimony. This is the writethru promised in advisory, which mistakenly identified it as 8th Ld. This may stand for PMs.
DOC.TEXT: An aide to Sen. John McCain told the Senate Ethics Committee today that Sen. Dennis DeConcini tried to coax her boss into meeting with federal regulators on behalf of savings and loan millionaire Charles Keating Jr. The committee explored the role of the two Arizona senators in those meetings with federal regulators as it began a fourth day of hearings into allegations five senators improperly intervened on behalf of Keating and his Lincoln Savings and Loan. Today's testimony, while a detailed and tedious contrast to dramatic declarations of innocence durig previous sessions, revealed the divisions and conflicting stories among the five senators who are battling for their political reputations and futures. Gwendolyn van Paasschen, an economics aide to McCain, testified she felt her boss was ``being coaxed along into'' a meeting with top S&L regulator Edwin Gray. She said she felt DeConcini wanted McCain there because as a Republican he would lend a bipartisan aura to the meeting. She was concerned, she said, because at the time of that April 1987 meeting, McCain had received more in campaign contributions from Keating than had DeConcini, and thus stood to be more embarrassed if word of the meeting became public. McCain went to that meeting but said he did so on his own, with the understanding the agenda would be limited to a discussion of the length of federal regulators' examination of Lincoln and a disputed appraisal of Lincoln's assets. Other testimony has suggested DeConcini went beyond that agenda to propose a deal with regulators on Lincoln's behalf. ``It was my view that what Senator DeConcini suggested was inappropriate,'' Ms. van Paasschen said. In addition to DeConcini and McCain, the committee is investigating Sens. Donald Riegle, D-Mich., Alan Cranston, D-Calif., and John Glenn, D-Ohio. Keating was a financial contributor to the senators' campaigns and favored causes. The collapse of his once high-flying empire is estimated to cost taxpayers as much as $2 billion to cover federally insured deposits. Ms. van Paasschen also testified that Riegle, who is chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, ``was involved in setting up'' the April 2, 1987, meeting with Gray, something Riegle has denied. Under questioning by Riegle's attorney, Tom Green, she said learned about Riegle's role from McCain and others - despite previous statements by her to investigators that she did not know the extent of Riegle's involvement. Ms. Van Paasschen backed McCain's assertion that he refused to negotiate with Gray in the April 2 meeting. According to earlier testimony, McCain's refusal prompted Keating to call the senator a ``wimp.'' Committee special counsel Robert S. Bennett has contended DeConcini went beyond the agreed-upon agenda for the meeting with Gray. Bennett contends DeConcini offered the regulator a deal on behalf of Lincoln Savings and Loan - saying the thrift would make more home loans if federal regulations limiting riskier investments were dropped. McCain's administrative assistant, Chris Koch, testified that McCain gave Keating an angry ``dressing down'' in a March 1987 meeting after being told Keating was calling him a ``wimp'' for refusing to negotiate with Gray. McCain ``told Mr. Keating he had not spent 5{ years in a prisoner of war camp (in Vietnam) to have his courage or integrity questioned,'' Koch said. `` ... John said there were certain things he could do and certain things he couldn't do. He said, `I can't go in and do your bidding for you. ... I can't go in and break arms and legs for you'.'' In testimony Monday, Bennett ridiculed senators' claims that he invented ethical standards in suggesting they dealt improperly with Keating. ``In this body, with all due respect, are your standards a double one?'' Bennett asked Monday. ``Are you above everyone else?'' Earlier Monday, DeConcini delivered a fiery, emotional defense of his own dealings, in the last of the five senators' opening statements. Bennett followed with a rebuttal to the senators in which he directly challenged assertions by Cranston, DeConcini and Riegle that there were no ethical rules that prohibited their efforts on behalf of Keating, a constituent and contributor. ``The greatest deliberative body in the whole world - you can't hack it under my standards?'' Bennett said. ``These are not my standards ... These are your standards.'' At issue is where the line falls separating appropriate help for a constituent from improper intervention with federal officials on behalf of a financial contributor. DeConcini, angrily defending his honor and his political career, repeatedly referred to Bennett as ``special prosecutor,'' not his correct title, and accused him of seizing on ``rumors ... lies ... hearsay.'' ``I submit this is disgraceful. I submit there is a bias, and I think it is unconscionable,'' DeConcini said.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Pledges to Fight On For Leadership
With AM-Britain-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher waited only a few minutes Tuesday to declare that she would fight on in a contest for the leadership of Britain and the Conservative Party. ``I am naturally very pleased that I got more than half the parliamentary party and disappointed that it is not quite enough to win on the first ballot,'' she told reporters outside the British Embassy, where she had received news of the voting of party parliamentarians in London. ``So I confirm that it is my intention to let my name go forward to the second ballot,'' she added, appearing determined and composed. Mrs. Thatcher failed by only two votes to gain a first-round victory over former Defense Minister Michael Heseltine. She received 204 votes, Heseltine gained 152 and 16 Conservatives abstained. A first-ballot victory required 206 votes; but a candidate needs only a majority to win in the second round next Tuesday. Mrs. Thatcher, who was in Paris for a European summit, was expected to come under pressure from some of her allies to step down rather than prolong the contest. The opposition Labor Party also sought to take advantage of the political infighting by proposing a motion of no confidence in her government. After talking very briefly to reporters, she went back into the Embassy. She had earlier warned her host, President Francois Mitterrand, that she might be a little late for the evening's entertainment in Versailles. Earlier, Europe's longest-serving prime minister had busied herself with top-level meetings and, according to sources close to her, avoided telephoning London for updates on the election. Mrs. Thatcher started the day in talks with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Mitterrand and continued with a series of meetings with the heads of state of Turkey, the Netherlands and Bulgaria. The talks were dominated by events in the Persian Gulf, sources said. Mrs. Thatcher voted by proxy so she could attent the Paris summit of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. Sources close to the prime minister said that her domestic political problems did not come up during the talks Tuesday, although several leaders did say ``good luck, and all that.''

DOC.HEAD: Collapse of Warsaw Pact Could Leave Security Gap in Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: The Warsaw Pact's demise, predicted Tuesday by East European leaders, may leave the countries searching for a security organization to substitute for the once-mighty military alliance. Hungarian Prime Minister Jozsef Antall declared the organization ``an outdated military structure'' and said it should be scrapped shortly. ``We trust that the conditions for dissolving the Warsaw Treaty will be available before the end of 1991, but not later than spring 1992,'' he said in a speech to a 34-nation summit of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. A day earlier, Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel described the Warsaw Pact as ``an outdated remnant of the past.'' ``It came into being as a typical product of Stalinist expansion and was an instrument of subordination of the communist countries to the Soviet Union,'' said Havel in his speech to the conference. Reflecting Antall's remarks, Hungary has been at the forefront of the drive to get rid of the military alliance, which the Soviet Union set up in 1955 in response to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Some other members of the Eastern alliance, however, are hesitant to get rid of an organization that, despite its domination by the Kremlin, has provided security guarantees. ``This is a big dilemma at the moment that no one has quite solved,'' said Jane Sharp, a senior researcher at the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute in Sweden. Havel said he could imagine the Warsaw Pact remaining - but only as ``a temporary consultative organization'' on disarmament issues. Antall didn't appear willing to go that far. He told a news conference that Hungary did not see any reason for keeping the Warsaw Pact around as a forum for discussions. ``We do not consider the maintenance of a political organization necessary either,'' he said, speaking through an interpreter. Hungary, Czechoslovakia and Poland are considered the most interested in turning closer to the West. Polish officials, mindful of their border with a united Germany in the strategic center of Europe, have been less forward about doing away with the Warsaw Pact. The other Warsaw Pact members are the Soviet Union, Romania and Bulgaria. East Germany pulled out when it merged with its Western neighbor. On Monday, the 22 nations representing NATO and the Warsaw Pact signed a non-aggression pact, declaring an end to their military rivalry and promising not to attack each other. There had been some thought that the summit of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which opened on Monday in Paris, could set the building blocks for an over-arching political and security organization that would draw in all the 34 nations. But that ambitious goal seems unlikely now. The summiteers were expected to wind up their meeting on Wednesday by promising to meet together more often and agreeing to set up a permanent secretariat in Prague, Czechoslovakia. That still leaves the East European nations in a quandary. NATO, the 16-nation Western alliance, has moved quickly in recent months to draw the East European countries closer to it. A new liaison program was set up so that the countries' ambassadors to Belgium, where NATO is located, would have access to the alliance. But NATO officials repeatedly insist they cannot invite the former Soviet satellites to apply for membership because such a move would leave the Soviet Union isolated militarily. ``It would be considered too provocative,'' said Ms. Sharp. There are few alternatives. Italian Foreign Minister Gianni De Michelis has suggested the European Community, the 12-nation trading bloc, set up a defense arm. It could, he said, adopt the Western European Union, a security grouping of nine NATO nations. Were the East European nations to join the community in the future, they would then have automatic security membership. Havel suggested that NATO ``could become one of the supports of a new European security system.'' If it agreed, he told the conference, the alliance ``should perhaps proceed at a substantially faster pace in changing inwardly and adapting itself to its new future.'' With reduced East-West tensions, NATO is trying to emphasize its political rather than military role. Havel suggested the Western alliance might put together ``association agreements with other European countries.'' He offered no details but such accords would be designed to bring the East European countries even closer to their Western neighbors.
