DOC.TEXT: A European Ariane rocket blasted off from the northeastern tip of South America Tuesday, carrying two U.S. telecommunications satellites into space. The rocket, carrying the GSTAR-4 and SATCOM-C1 satellites, lifted off at 8:11 p.m. (6:11 p.m. EST) from the Ariane facility here. It was the 40th launching of an Ariane rocket since the European space program began.

DOC.HEAD: Frozen Waste Falls From Airplane
DOC.TEXT: A frozen block of human waste that apparently fell from an airliner ripped through the roof of a county highway department building, nearly striking a worker, authorities said. Steven Kinney, a mechanic working in the building, said he heard a loud crash Monday evening and ran into the next room, where he found blue ice splattered around a tractor and a gaping hole in the roof. The three-pound block of ice narrowly missed Richard Radtke, who was repairing the tractor's engine. ``It sounded like an explosion,'' said Radtke, 55, of Elkhorn. ``It was really loud, I'm tellin' ya. It sounded like something blew up.'' Workers called police and gathered some of the ice into a freezer to back up their story. ``The odds are better of winning the lottery than having a piece of ice crash though the roof, almost killing a guy who's working on a tractor,'' Kinney said. ``It's crazy, this thing. I've never seen a case like this before,'' said Walworth County Sheriff's Detective Clay Hansen. Hansen said the sheriff's department will try to determine which airline dropped the ice chunk. A piece of the ice will remain preserved in the department's freezer for investigators to take to the state's crime lab. In spite of Hansen's comment, chunks of ice colored blue by lavatory disinfectant have fallen to the ground before. The National Transportatiohn Safety Board warned in August that the government isn't doing enough to protect airliner engines from the same effect. Airliner toilets are designed to be emptied by crews on the ground, but occasionally one will leak and the liquid will freeze on the outside of the fuselage at high altitudes. In addition to simply falling to the ground, the ice chunks can fly into the plane's engines. The problem has knocked the engines off two planes in recent years and caused others to fail. On Feb. 12, an Eastern Airlines Boeing 727 was forced to shut down one engine on a flight from Atlanta, Ga., to Sarasota, Fla. On Jan. 4, a Northwest Airlines 727 jet flying over Madison, Fla., lost one engine due to ice from a toilet leak, and a similar incident tore the engine off an American Airlines 727 over Las Cruces, N.M., on April 16, 1985, the safety board said. Both planes landed safely.

DOC.HEAD: Automaker, Union Inaugurate Program on Motion Trauma
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. and the United Auto Workers union will cooperate in the nation's most extensive program to combat repetitive motion injuries, Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole said Tuesday. One hundred thirty-eight plants and an estimated 302,000 workers will take part in an effort similar to those being undertaken by Chrysler Corp. and Ford Motor Co. last year and earlier this year, the Labor Department said. The GM pact is part of a settlement of government charges that the nation's largest automaker violated safety and health rules at plants in Trenton, N.J., and Oklahoma City, Okla. GM will pay $360,000 in fines for the alleged violations. A spokeswoman said GM would have no immediate comment. Repetitive motion traumas, also referred to as cumuluative trauma disorders, are disorders of the musculoskeletal and nervous systems caused by repetitive jotions or exertion over extended periods. Painful and sometimes crippling, they range from back injuries to a nerve disorder of the hand and wrist to various tendon ailments. They comprise about 48 percent of the workplace injuries for which the department's Occupational Safety and Health Administration keeps records. Preventive measures include redesigning work stations to better accommodate the body by, for example, adjusting workbench heights. Also, devices can be used to prevent excessive lifting or similar exertions. Tools and training can be redesigned. Under the agreement, the company and union agreed to: -Convene annual meetings for six years to discuss progress being made in combating the disorders. -Analyze jobs at each plant with potential repetitive-motion hazards and devise ways to lessen the risk, including workplace redesign where feasible. -Training of all emplpyees in avoiding repetitive motion trauma. -Provide medical attention to allow early detection and treatment. The company would move workers falling victim to injury to other jobs. -Establish procedures for resolving disputes over whether particular jobs pose a risk. -Keep records of injuries and illnesses caused by repetitive motion. Others unions representing GM workers are expected to reach separate agreements, the department said.

DOC.HEAD: Brutal Rape, Beating Death Not Typical of Housing Complex, Tenants Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf,`Harbour's 7-year-old ...' to CORRECT child's age to 7. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Police say the rape-murder of a young woman rivals New York's Central Park jogger case in savagery, but they and residents say it does not reflect the housing project where the victim and some of her alleged attackers lived. ``Franklin Field is not a bad place,'' said Thelma Smith, an 18-year resident of the Franklin Field housing complex, adjacent to where the battered body of Kimberly Rae Harbour was found the day after Halloween. ``It's as nice as any other place to live,'' she said Tuesday. ``We don't have many problems around here. There's a lot more places with a lot more bad things happening, but you never hear about it.'' The 26-year-old woman's body was found in a playing field next to the project in the city's Dorchester section where she lived with her 7-year-old daughter. ``She was attacked and a mutilated body was found in Franklin Field, raped and stabbed, stabbed over a hundred times, beat with a bottle, raped repeatedly,'' said Dave Rodman, spokesman for the Suffolk County District Attorney's office. Eight teen-agers were arraigned in the case Monday. Three were ordered held without bail. Five juveniles were placed in the custody of the state Division of Youth Services. Police Detective Peter O'Malley said at the arraignment that a bloodied tree limb, broken glass and Harbour's clothing were found at the scene. Some police investigators said she was robbed of only $1 and her coat. Police Superintendent Joseph Saia declined to say Tuesday which of the suspects actually live in the housing project. Saia said he wanted to avoid giving the project a stigma of being laden with crime, and credited residents with assisting in the investigation. ``This was a result of community help, which we used to obtain probable cause and gave us enough to make the arrests,'' he said. ``We have several witnesses and people who made statements, and we were able to put it together.'' Smith, 63, chairwoman of the Franklin Field Task Force, denied there were any street gangs in the neighborhood and said the arrested youths often participated in activities at the local youth center. ``I never had no trouble out of them,'' she said. ``They were respectful to me. Whenever I would go to the teen center and if they were talking they would stop and say `Hi, Ms. Smith.''' Kevin Sims, 19, said he often leaves the complex in search of something to do. ``Sometimes, you know, they get bored and go and do something stupid,'' Sims said of neighborhood youths. ``Most of the time when something bad happens it's because of people from outside. They come and start trouble. I don't know if that's the case or not.'' Lt. Detective Edward McNelley, head of the homicide squad, said Tuesday that Harbour was accompanied by a friend, Laura Peterson, when the two were attacked on Oct. 31. ``The group spilt in two, half went after one and the other half went after the other and after they finished robbing (Peterson) they all went after Ms. Harbour,'' McNelley said. McNelley said Peterson was struck at least once but ``she fled, she got away from them and fled.'' McNelley and other police officials said Monday that the murder had similarities to the New York Central Park ``wilding'' incident in 1989 in which several youths roamed the park, randomly attacking joggers and strollers. A 29-year-old banker was raped, beaten and left for dead, and spent several weeks in a coma. But Saia steered away from such comparisons. ``We knew this was an isolated case,'' he said. Harbour's 7-year-old daughter, Tatiana, has moved to Richmond, Va., to live with relatives.

DOC.HEAD: British Double Agent Philby Honored on Soviet Stamp
DOC.TEXT: Harold ``Kim'' Philby, the late British double agent who fed key secrets to the Soviet Union for 26 years, was among the master Soviet spies honored on Tuesday with their portraits on postage stamps. The Stamp Publishing and Trading Center of the government's Communications Ministry issued five new stamps honoring ``Soviet intelligence officers,'' the official Tass news agency said. The government has celebrated its spies before on stamps, but it appeared to be the first time a Western defector was singled out. Philby died in May 1988 in Moscow, 25 years after he defected from Britain following the discovery that he was a KGB spy. For 26 years before that, he turned over damaging secrets to the Soviets while working for Britain's MI6 intelligence agency. He told a Soviet interviewer before his death he had considered the Soviet Union his home since the 1930s. The other spies to be portrayed in stamps were Col. Rudolf Abel, who was captured in the United States and exchanged in 1962 for Gary Powers, pilot of the downed U-2 spy plane; Konon Molodyi, captured in England in 1961 and swapped for British spy Greville Wynne, and Stanislav Vaupshasov, a highly decorated agent in German-occupied Byelorussia during World War II. Tass identified the fourth only as I. Kudrya, an underground resistance fighter. He was not mentioned in standard biographical references.

DOC.HEAD: Wilder Urges Virginia Military Institute To Admit Women
DOC.TEXT: Gov. L. Douglas Wilder urged Virginia Military Institute Tuesday to admit women, ending more than a year of silence on the state-supported school's 151-year tradition of allowing male cadets only. ``I believe that no person should be denied admittance to a school supported by state funds solely because of his or her race or gender,'' Wilder said at a news conference. The governor urged the school to settle a federal lawsuit in which the U.S. Justice Department is challenging VMI's admissions policy as unconstitutional. Wilder also said the ``possibility could arise'' that he would withhold state funds to the school if the policy is not changed. Attorney General Mary Sue Terry, who has been defending VMI, told reporters later the governor is ``the ultimate architect'' of state policy and she is ready to cooperate with him. But Joseph M. Spivey III, president of the VMI Board of Visitors, said the Lexington school would continue to fight the lawsuit. ``The board believes that VMI's mission, policy and system of education are on sound constitutional ground and that the Justice Department's attempt to force VMI to abandon those principles is misguided,'' Spivey said in a statement. ``We have just been abandoned by our commander-in-chief,'' said Robert Chenery, a senior cadet from Chesapeake. Chenery called Wilder's move a ``wee bit of a knife between the shoulder blades'' since the governor told cadets at their May graduation that the school should decide its policies. Sylvia Clute, a Richmond lawyer who founded Friends of VMI for Equality, hailed Wilder's announcement. Ms. Clute said her daughter, a medic with the Army Reserve, has been ordered to prepare for possible shipment to the Middle East. ``I faced the prospect of my daughter going to war while the state of Virginia was denying her admission to a military college,'' Ms. Clute said. Wilder said he decided to speak out because U.S. District Judge Jackson L. Kiser refused this month to dismiss him as a defendant in the lawsuit that is set for trial in April. The governor said he is not appealing that ruling so he had to give his response to the lawsuit. The Justice Department filed its lawsuit last winter on behalf of an unidentified northern Virginia girl who said she wanted to attend VMI. VMI and The Citadel in Charleston, S.C., are the only two state-supported military schools in the country that bar women cadets. The nation's military academies began admitting women years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Erasmus Book Sells in London for Almost $1 Million
DOC.TEXT: A 16th-century book of proverbs by Desiderius Erasmus that traced the history of famous sayings like ``God helps those who help themselves'' sold Tuesday at Sotheby's for $975,000. The volume, titled ``Adagia'' (``Proverbs'') and printed in 1523, was the personal copy of the Dutch humanist scholar and contained more than 2,500 lines of his writing in which he annotated, revised and added to his work. The book was sold by an anonymous collector in Europe and bought for another European collector by Nico Israel, an Amsterdam dealer. By the time Erasmus died in 1536 his proverbs had welled from 818 in the first edition of his works dated 1500 to more than 4,000 in the 10th edition, in pursuit of his aim to make the wisdom of the past widely available. Among the proverbs were ``One swallow doesn't make a summer,'' ``Looking a gift horse in the mouth'' and ``Blowing one's own trumpet,'' which he tracked to their sources in Greek and Latin classical literature. ``The book became a key work of the Renaissance and every scholar had to have a copy,'' said Sotheby's manuscript expert, Susan Wharton. ``Erasmus's idea of jotting down aphorisms, maxims, proverbs and witty sayings, which he instructed his pupils to follow, has persisted to our own time,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: State to Try Zhivkov for Misappropriation of Funds
DOC.TEXT: Former Communist leader Todor Zhivkov will face trial on charges of misappropriation of funds and abuse of power, Bulgaria's prosecutor general announced Tuesday. Zhivkov, 78, ruled Bulgaria for 35 years, but has been under house arrest since he was ousted last year by reform-minded Communists. Prosecutor General Martin Gounev told the state BTA news agency that Zhivkov would be tried for misappropriation of $3.7 million. Gounev gave no date for the trial, but said it would be held soon. Zhivkov's right-hand man, Milko Balev, is also to face trial for the misappropriation of funds, BTA reported. The investigation against Zhivkov and Balev was completed in July, but the defense had asked for a delay of his trial to give it time to study more than 100 volumes of evidence. Zhivkov has admitted he made mistakes but has denied committing crimes. The announcement came as public pressure mounted on the all-Socialist government of Andrei Lukanov to resign. The Socialist Party, successor to Zhivkov's Communist Party, won a majority in the June elections and holds 210 of the 400 seats in Parliament. But Lukanov has been unable to push his economic reform program, which includes steep price hikes, through Parliament. The legislature is to vote on the controversial package Thursday. Lukanov has said he will resign if it is not passed. Because of deadlocks in Parliament, Lukanov has been unable to introduce reforms necessary to turn around the shortage-plagued economy. The opposition Union of Democratic Forces issued a statement Tuesday supporting a call by the trade union confederation Podkrepa for a general strike next week if Lukanov's government does not resign before then. ``We can no longer hold in check people's discontent,'' BTA quoted the statement as saying. However, the statement said a final decision on calling a general strike would be made after Thursday's Parliament session. University students have said they plan to organize a human chain around Parliament by Wednesday if Lukanov's government does not resign.

DOC.HEAD: Afghan Leader Meets Exiles, Conflicting Rumors About His Visit
DOC.TEXT: President Najibullah of Afghanistan, on a surprise visit that stirred rumors of a new peace initiative, met Tuesday with several Afghan exiles, his spokesman said. Presidential spokesman Sarwar Yourish declined to further identify who Najibullah met. He would not say whether they were representatives of the Afghan opposition or where the meetings were taking place. Najibullah arrived Monday for what was announced to be a four-day stay in Geneva, seat of the U.N. headquarters in Europe and main site of the U.N.-sponsored talks that resulted in the 1988 agreement on the withdrawal of the Soviet troops from the embattled country. Unofficial reports from Kabul, the Afghan capital, speculated that he would try to launch a new attempt to reach a settlement with Afghan guerrilla leaders. The Soviet news agency Tass quoted circles close to the Afghan mission in Geneva that he would ``probably'' meet opposition representatives. Sources close to some fundamentalist guerrilla groups said Najibullah left Kabul on the advice of his associates because his personal safety could no longer be guaranteed. Rebel sources said that guerrilla commanders launched coordinated attacks Monday on Afghan government targets in three provinces surrounding Kabul. A member of Hezb-e-Islami, the most radical group in the Moslem guerrilla alliance, said the purpose of the operation was to take Kabul. Najibullah's spokesman, questioned about the various reports, referred a reporter to a news conference the president scheduled for Wednesday. Soviet troops intervened in Afghanistan in 1979 to prop up Kabul's Communist government from attack by the Moslem guerrillas. The Soviets pulled out in 1989 but still send military aid to Kabul.

DOC.HEAD: Mediator Says Angolan Foes Close to Cease-fire Accord
DOC.TEXT: The Angolan government and U.S.-backed UNITA rebels are close to reaching a cease-fire to end their 15-year-old civil war, the chief mediator at their peace talks said Tuesday. After five days of negotiations, the two sides reached agreement on 80 percent of a cease-fire document proposed by the Portuguese mediating team, State Secretary for Foreign Affairs and Cooperation, Jose Manuel Durao Barroso, said. He said no date was fixed for signing a cease-fire. But he did not rule out the possibility of an accord at the next round of negotiations scheduled for before January. Durao Barroso told a news conference a number of key issues remained to be resolved. ``We are climbing a very high mountain,'' he said, ``and the last few meters (yards) are the most difficult.'' The meeting in this coastal resort 16 miles west of the Portuguese capital of Lisbon was the fifth between the Angolan government and UNITA, or the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, in Portugal since April. The two delegations focused on the cease-fire document, but also discussed a second paper dealing with introduction of multiparty democracy in Angola. Durao Barroso said the complex question of integrating the two armies was not discussed at the Estoril talks. He said both sides had agreed on a series of steps to implement the cease-fire, beginning with the cessation of hostilities and the confinement of armed forces in predetermined control zones. Both sides have accepted international verification of the cease-fire, but differences remain on the eventual role of the United Nations, the United States and the Soviet Union. Durao Barroso said the Angolan government had accepted a UNITA demand for recognition as a legitimate political force, but added divergences existed over details. In Paris on Monday, rebel leader Jonas Savimbi expressed optimism that an accord was near. ``A way is now open, nothing more is going to block the process,'' Savimbi told journalists after a meeting with Portuguese Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva in the French capital. Delegations from the United States and the Soviet Union attending the Estoril talks as observers. Durao Barroso said their presence had greatly helped the talks. The Angolan civil war is one of the last Cold War regional conflicts. Both superpowers continue to supply arms to their allies in Angola. UNITA has been fighting the Soviet-backed Angolan government since the southern African nation gained independence from Portugal in 1975. According to government figures, more than 350,000 people have died in the conflict.

DOC.HEAD: Defendant Throws Book at Judge, Judge Throws Book at Defendant
DOC.TEXT: A former Marine who is now a circuit judge doesn't hesitate to throw the book at a defendant, especially when a defendant tries throwing the book at the judge. A man accused of rape lost his temper in court Monday when Judge Walter Colbath refused to reduce his bond to let him get out of jail before his January trial. Defendant Byron Bryant picked up a copy of the courtroom-drama bestseller ``Presumed Innocent'' and threw it at Colbath, hitting him on the shoulder. Startled but unhurt, Colbath ruled Bryant in contempt, and the defendant shot back some profanity. Colbath ruled Bryant in contempt again. Bryant swore again. That exchange continued until Bryant, 23, was slapped with his fifth contempt of court citation and removed by Palm Beach County deputies. ``The guy just lost it,'' the judge said later. ``Up until that point, he had been behaving himself.'' Back in court Tuesday, Colbath found Bryant guilty of three counts of contempt and sentenced him to consecutive terms of five months and 29 days on each count. The number of counts was reduced because of appeals court precedent for people who yell at judges in court. But Colbath agreed to a defense request for a speedier trial and reset the case for Dec. 3. Bryant already has been in custody for almost a year. The judge wasn't concerned about the flying book incident. ``I've had guys throw a lot more dangerous missiles at me,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Ontario Premier Opens Legislature
DOC.NOTE: Eds: all dollar figures are U.S. equivalents
DOC.TEXT: Premier Bob Rae, leader of Ontario's newly elected left-wing government, opened the provincial legislature's new session Tuesday with few specifics for a nervously awaiting business community to ponder. Rae repeated his New Democratic Party's campaign promises to introduce legislation on car insurance, increase the minimum wage and support laid-off workers. He also declared a moratorium on new nuclear power plants. But the only figure in the speech, read by Lt. Gov. Lincoln Alexander, was $602 million for a public works project to repair roads, schools and government buildings, a plan he said would create critically needed jobs. Rae, whose party won 73 of the 130 seats in the legislature in Sept. 6 elections, said: ``My government recognizes that it assumes office with great expectations and that not all of these expectations can be met.'' Political observers say the NDP won not so much because Ontarians wanted a socialist government but because of a funding scandal involving the Liberals and because Liberal Premier David Peterson decided to call an election two years early after his pollsters told him he would be a shoo-in. During the campaign, the NDP promised programs that would cost more than $1.7 billion. Once in office, the Rae government found itself faced with a $2.1 billion deficit left by the outgoing Liberals. Since its founding in 1961, the New Democrats have formed governments in British Columbia, Saskatchewan, Manitoba and the Yukon territory. But their coming to power in Ontario, Canada's richest and most populous province, made for some sleepless nights for the business community. Rae has tried to calm fears that he will try to spend and tax his way out of Canada's recession. Business seems to have taken a wait-and-see attitude. ``To come in here after six weeks and announce, whammo, we're going to spend here and spend there. ... That would be irresponsible,'' the premier told reporters just before his speech. The speech made no mention of the minimum corporate tax and inheritance tax promised by the NDP and feared by business. Among other measures, Rae said his government would increase the minimum wage from $4.60 an hour to 60 percent of the average industrial wage - or $5.70 to $6.06 an hour.

DOC.HEAD: BST Review Taking Longer Than Expected
With AM-Milk Chemicals a0729
DOC.TEXT: Review of a controversial milk-increasing hormone is taking longer than expected and probably won't be completed by next spring as originally planned, a Food and Drug Administration official said Tuesday. ``The sheer amount of data is more than we expected'' and is responsible for the delay, said Gerald B. Guest, director of the FDA's Center for Veterinary Medicine. The hormone is bovine somatotropin, or BST. In August, the agency publiished a review of 120 scientific studies to support its contention that the hormone is safe for humans to ingest. All cows' milk contains small amounts of the hormone, which cows produce naturally. It is digested like any protein, the FDA says. Administration of the hormone, produced by genetic engineering techniques, can increase milk production by 10 percent to 25 percent. Some dairy organizations and consumer activists have opposed use of the hormone on the grounds that its safety in long-term use remains in doubt and the last thing dairy farmers need is something to improve production of a commodity in surplus supply like milk. Some states have forbidden use. Four companies have applied to the FDA for permission to sell the hormone. The current review is aimed at determining whether the hormone is safe for cows. In August, the agency said it expected to finish in the spring of 1991. That deadline, Guest said, ``is going to slip a little.'' Asked if the review would last into 1992, he replied, ``I hope not, but there's always that possibility.'' The deadline slippage was first revealed in remarks by Guest at a dairy industry symposium on Monday and reported in the Milwaukee Sentinel on Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Germany Will Face Harder Times After Elections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs, RECASTING economist's conclusion. Picks up 7th graf, `Such charges...'
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's political rivals are trying to persuade voters that eastern Germany is a time bomb set to explode weeks after the national elections on Dec. 2. Experts say that is true, to some extent: Thirty days after the vote, the former nation's difficult economic road will begin a deep dip. A social expert for the opposition Social Democrats said Tuesday that at least 1 million people are holding postdated layoff notices that will not kick in until next year. Rudolf Dressler said the party, trailing badly in most polls to Kohl's Christian Democrats, compiled the information from industry councils and personnel offices in the former nation. An independent economist agreed that hundreds of thousands of people still working nevertheless have already received layoff notices effective early next year. The Social Democrats' claim was their latest effort to persuade voters that Kohl is covering up an impending economic disaster that will hurt eastern Germans more than they realize, and force their wealthy western neighbors to pay higher taxes because of it. Such charges have failed to erode Kohl's status as the man most likely to win the first united German elections since 1933. It is clear, however, that former East Germany is only in the early stages of a difficult transition from communism to capitalism. Eastern Germans already have seen prices for food and other necessities, kept artificially low by the Communists, zoom to Western levels, even as their salaries have remained about one-third of their wealthier neighbors. In January, many of the remaining subsidies also will begin to disappear. Heavy subsidies for public transportation - which allow eastern Germans to ride subways for only 20 pfennigs (13 cents) a trip - will be lifted. Subsidized rents, some of them only 60 marks a month ($40), will be allowed to begin rising, and energy costs also are expected to start climbing. Berlin economist Heine Flassbeck, one of the authors of a comprehensive look at the immediate future of the eastern German economy, said 500,000 public-sector workers are to be laid off by April. In the private sector, he said, the question of whether trade with Eastern European nations will break down could affect 500,000 other workers. Many firms say their contracts will run out on Jan. 1 and won't be renewed, Flassbeck said. ``There is a certain gray area ... where something like that could happen, but we have no concrete information,'' he said. Right now, eastern Germany officially has 537,000 unemployed people, a rate of about 6.1 percent. But there are almost 2 million people receiving reduced pay at lower hours under a Bonn-financed program to keep unemployment low. Kohl's critics say this is just another form of unemployment compensation. Flassbeck said it is clear that many of the people in this category likely will lose their jobs next year because they work in industries most vulnerable to the new Western competiton. His independent institute, the German Institute for Economic Research, and the nation's four other leading economic think tanks last month published a report that said unemployment could reach nearly 4 million by the end of next year for a 50 percent jobless rate. Likewise, the costs of cleaning up the environment of one of the world's most polluted nations, and repairing an infrastructure largely neglected since World War II, is expected to reach hundreds of billions of marks. The Institute for Economic Research of the World Economic Archives in Hamburg said Tuesday that the costs of unification could reach 15 billion marks ($10 billion) next year and that higher taxes may be necessary. Kohl has promised not to raise taxes to pay for unification, but his chief opponent, Social Democrat Oskar Lafontaine, has charged that he will have no choice. The debate mirrors the U.S. presidential election of 1988, when President Bush based his successful campaign on a promise not to raise taxes. He recently relented on that stand.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Rules In Favor of Prosecutor in Christian Brando Case
DOC.TEXT: An appeals court on Tuesday ruled in favor of authorities seeking the return of Marlon Brando's daughter from Tahiti to testify at her brother's trial on charges of killing her lover. But a prosecutor said he will abandon the effort if independent doctors find Cheyenne Brando is too sick to testify. ``We will do nothing to hurt this girl,'' said Deputy District Attorney Steven Barshop. Christian Brando is charged with the slaying of Miss Brando's Tahitian lover, Dag Drollet, and his trial has been delayed by the dispute over Cheyenne's testimony. Barshop said the ruling by the 2nd District Court of Appeals may assist prosecutors in persuading French authorities in Tahiti to arrange an independent psychiatric examination of the 20-year-old Miss Brando. She has twice been hospitalized after suicide attempts in the past month, and charges against her in the French territory in connection with Drollet's death have complicated the issue of whether she would be allowed to leave. The appellate court ruled that a lower court judge does have jurisdiction to issue a ``letter of rogatory,'' an international document requesting formal assistance from the government of another country. They referred the case back to Superior Court Judge Joel Rudof, who had concluded he had no such jurisdiction. ``Every court of this state has power to make all orders necessary for the effective conduct of proceedings before it,'' said the decision. Barshop said that if the letter of rogatory is issued, prosecutors would ask not only for Miss Brando's return but for an independent psychiatric examination. Christian Brando's lawyer, Robert L. Shapiro, said he also would like to have Miss Brando examined to prove she is physically and mentally unable to testify. Shapiro said he gave prosecutors a letter Monday from the head psychiatrist at the Tahiti hospital where Miss Brando is under treatment, saying that ``her emotional and mental state requires her continued hospitalization.'' Although Shapiro expressed a desire to start Christian Brando's trial soon, all lawyers in the case said further proceedings cannot move ahead until the appeals court decision becomes final in 30 days. Barshop said the district attorney's office has discussed sending psychiatrists to examine Miss Brando but has no assurances the French authorities in Tahiti would permit it. Miss Brando was seven months pregnant with Drollet's child when the 26-year-old Tahitian was shot to death at the Brando mansion. A month later, Miss Brando left for Tahiti where she gave birth to a son. On Nov. 1, Miss Brando was reported to have taken an overdose of tranquilizers and antidepressant drugs and was hospitalized in a coma. On Nov. 11, she was again reported hospitalized after trying to hang herself.

DOC.HEAD: Devil's Night Fire Total Is 411, Includes Blazes Not In Official Count
DOC.TEXT: Minute-by-minute fire records show city firefighters responded to 411 fires over last month's three-night Devil's Night period, although the official figure released was 281 blazes. Detailed computerized fire-run sheets were released by the city under Freedom of Information Act requests filed by news organizations. The records show that in addition to the blazes that Mayor Coleman A. Young publicly reported for the Oct. 29-31 period, there were 26 additional rekindled fires and 104 fire runs for burning leaves, warming fires or blazes in trash bins. City Fire Marshal Don Robinson claimed the latter group didn't count as fires in the official count because they didn't endanger property. That assessment is based on the counting policy used by the National Fire Prevention Association. Robinson also said Detroit does not count rekindled fires as separate fires because they start from the same source. Rekindled fires are ones that flare up after firefighters believe they've been put out. Numerous fires that were not included in the count were extinguished by police, public works employees and residents. Structure fires accounted for 209 of the blazes over the three days. Seventy-five of those were reported at vacant dwellings. The Oct. 29-31 period has been associated with arson in Detroit since the early 1980s.

DOC.HEAD: Duo Says Fraud Was `Pact With Devil,' Claim They Were Seduced, Victimized
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf, `The German-born ...' to CORRECT that Pilatus was raised in Germany; picks up 13th graf, `There was ...' SUBS 16th graf, `The pair ...' to CORRECT year to 1989, sted 1988. Pick up 17th graf, `Singing coach ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LA3
DOC.TEXT: The disgraced pop music duo Milli Vanilli surrendered their best new artist Grammy Award on Tuesday and claimed their phony act as lipsyncing front men was a ``pact with the devil'' that victimized them. Rob Pilatus and Fabrice Morvan, whose stardom was shattered last week with the revelation that they never sang on the debut Milli Vanilli album, said they were seduced into the deceit because they were poor, young and naive. ``You get something, but for that you make a pact with the devil,'' Pilatus said at a news conference. ``We feel really, really sorry about our fans,'' he said. ``We really love our fans ... We just hope that they understand that we were young, that we just wanted to live the life the American way.'' The pair and manager Carsten Heyn charged that Arista Records President Clive Davis knew they were faking. Arista has repeatedly denied the claim. Heyn also said recording industry officials worldwide knew of the deception. The pair presented a videotape of themselves recording the hit song ``Girl You Know It's True'' in a studio last weekend, but that was greeted with skepticism and yells from reporters to prove they really could sing. Pilatus belted out a few lines from the song and Morvan joined in with the rap portion of the tune. Trustees of the National Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences voted Monday to rescind Milli Vanilli's Grammy. The pair held up their trophies Tuesday and declared they were returning them with recommendation they go to the real singers. Academy president Michael Greene said giving the trophies to the singers who actually sang was ``not a possibility.'' Voice coach Seth Riggs, who said his clients include Michael Jackson, Madonna and Stevie Wonder, gave a testimonial to the duo's singing abilities, saying they were better than the men who actually were recorded. Pilatus claimed he and Morvan were victimized because they were living in poverty in a Munich housing project when German producer Frank Farian offered them the deal. He said that at the time they even had to steal food. Pilatus, who was born in New York and raised in Germany, described in broken English a growing sense of guilt that came along with stardom and money. ``There was everytime something that we had to lie,'' he said. ``We had very guilty complexes.'' The album ``Girl You Know It's True'' sold 7 million copies worldwide and made the two unknowns international stars. Pilatus and Morvan, a native of the Caribbean island of Guadaloupe, are both 25. Farian last week confirmed growing rumors that the duo did not sing on the album. It actually featured the voices of vocalists Johnny Davis, Brad Howell and Charles Shaw. Pilatus said Shaw's role was minimal and the Grammy really belongs to Davis and Howell. The pair also lipsynced through an appearance on February's Grammy show in Los Angeles when Milli Vanilli was honored as best new artist of 1989. Singing coach Riggs said he was there and that Pilatus and Morvan were ready to sing but were told to fake it. He did not know who gave the order. The duo also did not say who it was. The duo's attorney, Alan Mintz, supported their claim that they had pressed the producer to be allowed to actually sing and that the producer only came forward with the truth because Pilatus and Morvan were about to. Meanwhile, an Oakland woman who bought her son a Milli Vanilli tape filed a class action lawsuit in state court Monday seeking a refund for anyone in California who bought the group's recordings or attended one of their concerts. In Illinois, Chicago college student Karen L. Smith on Tuesday also sued in Cook County Circuit Court, claiming fraud because the CDs she bought named Pilatus and Morvan as performers.

DOC.HEAD: Self-Made Millionaire Grabs Political Limelight
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to RECAST, ADD attribution, details; trims. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WAR50
DOC.TEXT: A businessman who has emerged from nowhere into the spotlight of Poland's presidential campaign is a citizen of Canada and Peru who claims to have made a fortune bringing cable TV to the Amazon. Candidate Stanislaw Tyminski placed a strong third in the latest polls for Sunday's election, giving new weight to his attacks on established political leaders. The darkhouse candidate is being investigated for slander for some of his comments, newspapers are attacking him and questions abound about the Pole who came home to run for president after making a fortune in the West. According to Bob Spanski, a Tyminski campaign aide in Canada, the candidate was born in a Warsaw suburb in January 1948. He left Poland at age 21, first going to Sweden, then arriving nearly broke in Canada in 1970. He became a Canadian citizen in 1975. According to his campaign, he spent the early 1980s in Iquitos, Peru. After a gasoline barge on the Amazon was confiscated, Tyminski decided that the people of Iquitos needed cable TV, said Frank Ollie, partner in Tyminski's Toronto computer company, Tranduction. ``He got a couple of VCRs from Miami and a couple of tapes and began going from dwelling to dwelling with a coaxial cable and a staple gun ... and that grew overnight into a very reputable company.'' Tyminski then returned to Canada, where he heads Transduction and leads the Libertarian Party of Canada. Tyminski decided to run for president on a lark, during a visit to Poland in September to attend to his company and promote a book of his political and economic ideas, titled ``Sacred Dogs,'' Ollie said. The free-spending 42-year-old was a surprise entrant among the six candidates who managed to collect 100,000 signatures for a place on Sunday's ballot for Poland's first free presidential election. A fresh face who said he would apply his business wizardry to the shattered economy, Tyminski appealed to disenchanted Poles and played on their admiration of the well-heeled, polished leaders of the West. It didn't seem to matter that his Polish was rusty at best, that his Peruvian wife spoke no Polish at all, or that he hadn't lived in Poland for the two decades when Poles struggled to throw off communism. Poland is willing to allow emigrants to keep their citizenship even if they become citizens of other countries. Tyminski's attacks on the familiar politicians have played well. ``The anti-inflationary plan threatens to bring civil war,'' he told audiences struggling under the economic reforms creating high prices, unemployment and uncertainty. ``The country has been engulfed by recession; we have neither a government nor a parliament.'' Tyminski was largely dismissed as an also-ran until an opinion poll Friday. It showed his support had nearly doubled, to 17 percent of those who intend to vote, compared with 19 percent for Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki and 35 percent for Solidarity leader Lech Walesa. A second poll Sunday produced similar results. In a speech Saturday, Tyminski accused Mazowiecki of betraying the nation through policies creating recession, inflation, ``poverty and exhaustion (that) pose a threat to national existence.'' He claimed the government was issuing false statistics that showed inflation and unemployment to be only half as serious as they are. The charge from the outsider-turned-contender went beyond the bounds of the normally heated political discourse in Poland's fledgling democracy. ``A Liar or a Fool,'' the pro-Mazowiecki Gazeta Wyborcza newspaper said in a headline Tuesday. ``A week before the elections, we know as much about Tyminski as he has told about himself. And from what he says, and how he says it, an image of an imbalanced individual emerges,'' the newspaper said. Attorney General Aleksander Bentkowski ordered a slander investigation. ``I consider the accusation (of national betrayal) to be fully justified by the attempt to sell our best enterprises to foreign capitalists,'' Tyminski said during a nationally televised advertisement Monday. He cited an addendum to a draft law on privatizing state industry, saying the prices were dramatically undervalued. But reporters pointed out to Tyminski at a raucous news conference Tuesday that the numbers he was challenging were actually the total sales of the companies, not their selling prices. Tyminski - whose replies in Polish and English often seemed incoherent - would not withdraw his accusation, saying ``it came from the heart.'' He said Mazowiecki showed ``ignorance of the best interest of the country in the economic sense.'' In Iquitos, there is excitement about whether a local woman might become Poland's first lady. A respected Peruvian news magazine, Caretas, profiled Tyminski, mentioning a photo in his former restaurant showing him bare-chested with two live snakes hanging around his neck. Tyminski says he is a Polish ``patriot'' back to stay, at least until the vote is in. ``I am doing everything to win and I cannot think of losing,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Grand Jury Subpoenas Mayor Young's Company Records in Police Probe
DOC.TEXT: A federal grand jury investigating alleged police corruption has asked to see records from Mayor Coleman Young's private consulting company, the mayor's lawyer said. Attorney Peter Kelley refused to say if the mayor has been subpoenaed, but said the grand jury subpoenaed records from his business, Detroit Technology and Investments Inc. Federal court briefs filed Monday in the 6th Circuit U.S. Court of Appeals showed the grand jury is investigating the disposition of $2.4 million from a Detroit police undercover fund. Earlier this year, City Auditor Roger Short told the City Council that a two-year audit of the fund ending June 30, 1987, found no documentation for $847,500 in expenditures. The grand jury again subpoenaed undercover police officer Sylvester Chapman, who refused at July 18 and Oct. 24 hearings to disclose what happened to $100,000 to $300,000 from the fund. Chapman kept no records of money given to informants, funds he received under an arrangement with police Chief William Hart, the records said. Chapman faces up to 18 months in prison for refusing to tell the federal grand jury how he spent the money. He contends that naming informants would harm future police operations. The federal government said in its brief that allowing Chapman to retreat behind the informer's privilege ``would be tantamount to giving undercover police officers and their commanding officers a license to steal.'' The gran jury was reported to be investigating the police department and former civilian deputy police chief Kenneth Weiner's connection to Young's company. No charges have been filed in connection with the police fund. Weiner is on trial on fraud charges in an alleged scheme to bilk millions of dollars from investors in his and others' companies that dealt in precious metals. The trial, which began in September, is expected to last several more weeks. Young has been subpoenaed to testify in the trial, but the mayor's attorney said he doubted Young would take the stand.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Barely Clings to Party Post, Faces Second Vote Next Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to CLARIFY party voting rules, raise reference to vote being by parliament members, SPECIFIES Thatcher would not have to resign as prime minister if she loses, but would be expected to. Picks up 15th graf, `Partisans on...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos PAR7,48, LON2,8
DOC.TEXT: The Conservative Party staggered Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher with lukewarm support Tuesday, forcing her into a second round of balloting in a fight for leadership of party and country. Mrs. Thatcher fell two votes short of a quick defeat in the sternest challenge of her 11{ years as party leader. She rejected calls by some to step down and vowed to battle on in another round of voting next Tuesday. Former Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine, smiling and looking very much like the winner after the vote by his Conservative colleagues in the House of Commons, also declared himself ready for round two. ``It is my intention to let my name go forward for the second ballot,'' a calm and determined Mrs. Thatcher told reporters outside the British Embassy in Paris, where she was attending a summit on European security. If Mrs. Thatcher loses the leadership of the party, she would be expected to step down as prime minister. The Conservatives have a 98-seat majority in the 650-seat House. The opposition Labor Party moved to capitalize on the turmoil in Conservative ranks by introducing a motion of no-confidence that is likely to come to a vote before Tuesday. The motion would bring down the government if it carries. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, in Paris, noted that Mrs. Thatcher has been the closest ally of the Reagan and Bush administrations, but said the vote was an internal British matter. ``We feel very positive about our relationship with her and with that country,'' Fitzwater said. ``But beyond that, we really can't have any comment.'' Mrs. Thatcher, the longest-serving prime minister in Europe, has suffered a loss in popularity because of a local services tax that is widely viewed as favoring the rich. Her government also has been blamed for high inflation and high interest rates. The Conservatives have trailed Labor in opinion polls for 16 months. Heseltine also focused his campaign on Mrs. Thatcher's attitude toward Europe, which has caused strains within her party. Heseltine, standing hand-in-hand with his wife, Anne, outside their home, told reporters: ``I am overwhelmed with gratitude to my parliamentary colleagues who in such large measure have given me their support.'' Heseltine forced the issue by winning enough votes to deny Mrs. Thatcher a first-ballot victory in an unprecedented ballot among the 372 Conservative members of Parliament. Because 16 lawmakers abstained, Mrs. Thatcher needed 206 of the remaining votes, which would have given her a winning margin of 15 percent out of the total 372-member Conservative caucus, as party rules stipulate. She received 204 votes to Heseltine's 152. In the second round, a simple majority can win, but other candidates now are free to join the race. If necessary, a third and final ballot would be held Nov. 29. Partisans on each side urged the other to give up. Mrs. Thatcher faced pressure to resign rather than end her career in defeat. ``I suspect she may have polled her maximum number of votes today,'' said Conservative legislator Ivor Stanbrook, who supported Heseltine. `I am absolutely astonished that he got so many and that so many of my colleagues should have been so disloyal,'' Conservative lawmaker Ivan Lawrence said on Sky Television. ``The party is obviously in trouble, and there is no point in hiding it,'' said Teddy Taylor, one of Mrs. Thatcher's most outspoken supporters in the House. He urged her to continue. Mrs. Thatcher has been the Conservative leader since 1975, and was the only Tory leader in this century to lead her party to three consecutive election victories - in 1979, 1983 and 1987. Despite being embroiled in a fight for her political life, the woman known as ``the Iron Lady'' changed into a formal gown and smiled as she went to a summit banquet at Versailles. Mrs. Thatcher, 65, put the best face on the result, saying ``I'm naturally pleased that I got more than half the parliamentary party and disappointed that it's not quite enough to win.'' The pound fell nearly half a cent, from $1.9695 dollars to $1.9650, following the vote. Mrs. Thatcher was to return Wednesday to address the House of Commons on the summit, and to have her weekly meeting with Queen Elizabeth II. Heseltine, 57, pledged during the six-day campaign to overcome Tory factionalism to win the next general election in 1992. He pointed to a flurry of opinion polls that indicated voters were more enthusiastic about the Conservative Party with him as the leader. A self-made millionaire, Heseltine had been a member of Mrs. Thatcher's first Cabinet in 1979 as environment secretary, and was named defense secretary in 1983. He quit, bitterly and abruptly, in the middle of a Cabinet meeting in January 1986. The leadership contest erupted unexpectedly following a European Community summit meeting in Rome at the end of October, at which Mrs. Thatcher was once again all alone against the 11 other leaders. She vociferously rejected an agreement in principle for a single central bank and single currency for the EC. Fed up with such views and her autocratic style, Deputy Prime Minister Geoffrey Howe quit Nov. 1, then delivered a scathing resignation speech last week that inspired Heseltine to make the challenge.

DOC.HEAD: Ariane Rocket Blasts Off With Two U.S. Satellites
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with additional details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A European Ariane rocket blasted off from the northeastern corner of South America Tuesday, carrying two U.S. telecommunications satellites into outer space. The rocket, loaded with GSTAR-4 and SATCOM-C1 satellites, lifted off at 8:11 p.m. (6:11 p.m. EST) from the Ariane facility here. It was the 40th launching of an Ariane rocket since the European space program began 10 years ago, and the final launch of 1990. The rocket deployed the SATCOM-C1 19 minutes after takeoff at an altitude of 188 miles, and the GSTAR-4 four minutes later at 438 miles high. SATCOM-C1 and GSTAR-4 were built by General Electric's Astrospace Division and launched respectively for GTE Spacenet and GE American Communications Inc. They are expected to remain in service for about 13 years, providing communications links for the continental United States, Hawaii and Alaska. The launch countdown proceeded in recent days despite a strike by some workers at the launch facility who did not accept work and salary conditions agreed upon by four unions. Ariane launches resumed in July after a five-month suspension following the explosion of a rocket less than two minutes after takeoff in February. Two Japanese communications satellites aboard were destroyed. An investigation showed a clogged pipe was responsible for the accident, but a French magazine reported the rocket was sabotaged. The claim was never proven. The last launch was last month, when two satellites made by Hughes were put into orbit. The next launch is scheduled for January, when an Ariane will lift into space two satellites, a Eutelsat-II-F2 for European telecommunications, and an Italsat-1 for Italy's space agency. Arianespace, the commercial branch of the European Space Agency, plans nine Ariane launches in 1991. It has signed contracts worth $3 billion to launch 34 more satellites. Tuesday's launch used for the first time the Ariane-42P, one of the six versions of the rocket, which uses two boosters of solid rocket fuel. The Ariane-42P can place a payload of up to 2.6 tons into geostationary orbit 22,500 miles above the surface of the Earth. The last several launches have used four strap-on boosters of liquid fuel.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to FIX Writethru designator.
Four Life Terms For Man Convicted in Womens' Disappearance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 10th graf, `Grissom was ...' to add that fourth life term given for aggravated kidnapping. Picks up 11th graf pvs, `Grissom was ...' DELETES now redundant reference to aggravated kidnapping in last graf.
DOC.TEXT: A man convicted of murdering three women who disappeared more than a year ago and whose bodies have never been found was sentenced Tuesday to four life prison terms. Richard Grissom Jr. was sentenced in Johnson County District Court by Judge William Gray after an emotional appeal from the father of a victim. ``Mr. Grissom has been given all the courteous treatment and rights due him under Kansas law,'' Ralph Butler said. ``The cowardly and premeditated crimes and the evil intent of these crimes requires that Richard Grissom be given the absolute maximum sentence that the law allows.'' Grissom, 30, showed no emotion when he was sentenced. District attorney Paul Morrison said it will be 105 years before Grissom's case could come before a parole board. Grissom was convicted on circumstantial evidence. He was driving a car rented by one of the victims shortly after she disappeared, and a few drops of blood were found in that car. He also had credit cards and some personal belongings of all three women. He also had copies of keys to their apartments and had worked as a painter at the apartment complexes where they lived. Prosecutors contended the motive for the killings was the $3,600 withdrawn from their bank accounts shortly after they disappeared. The defense called no witnesses during the three-week trial and argued that prosecutors had not proved their client committed any crimes or that the women were dead. The jury deliberated about 12 hours before convicting Grissom. Grissom was sentenced to a minimum of 90 years and a maximum of 360 years for the murders of 34-year-old Joan Marie Butler of Overland Park and roommates Christine Rusch and Theresa Brown, both 22 and of Lenexa. Both towns are Kansas City suburbs. Grissom also lived in Lenexa. He was given a fourth life term for the aggravated kidnapping of Miss Rusch. Grissom was convicted Nov. 4 of three counts of first-degree murder. Grissom is expected to appeal. Jessica R. Cunen, the chief appellate defender for the state, was appointed to represent him. The judge urged Grissom to tell the families where they could find the bodies. ``None of them can be brought back,'' Gray said. ``But your part in the lives of the remaining victims - the families - is still up to you. ``You have to consider whether you have any consideration or any compassion for these people. I encourage you to think about it.'' ``The sentences were a relief, but the families still want to know where the bodies are,'' said Harold Brown, father of Theresa Brown. ``The pages aren't completely closed yet. Maybe someday he will find it in his heart to tell us what he did with the girls.'' Gray sentenced Grissom after rejecting a defense motion for a new trial. Defense attorney Tom Erker argued Grissom received ineffective counsel from the public defender's office for several months after his arrest in July 1989, a month after the disappearances. Grissom also was convicted of two counts of aggravated burglary, burglary, misdemeanor theft and four counts of robbery.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Supreme Court Justice Announces Her Retirement
DOC.TEXT: Bertha Wilson, the first woman appointed to the Supreme Court of Canada, will retire in January, Justice Minister Kim Campbell announced Tuesday. Wilson, 67, a native of Kirkaldy, Scotland, began her legal career in Nova cotia in 1957. In 1975, she was the first woman appointed to the Ontario Court of Appeal. Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau appointed Wilson, a liberal, to the Supreme Court in March 1984. Campbell paid tribute to Wilson saying she ``helped open the legal profession and the administration of justice to Canadian women. ``Your example has been an inspiration to a generation of women pursuing careers in the law. ``In your judgments and commentaries, you have articulated values of fundamental importance to all Canadians and have challenged us to identify and eradicate inequalities in our society.'' There was no word on when a successor might be appointed.

DOC.HEAD: Indictment Against Fired Dallas Police Chief Quashed on Technicality
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3 grafs for graf 4-5, `Vines could ...' to UPDATE with comment by Vines. Picks up 6th graf, `Vines was ...'
DOC.TEXT: A perjury indictment that cost former Police Chief Mack Vines his job was thrown out Tuesday after a judge ruled its allegations were too vague. Former Texas Court of Criminal Appeals Judge John Onion quashed the misdemeanor perjury indictment in a hearing, a court spokeswoman said, referring all other questions to Assistant District Attorney Ted Steinke. Steinke said the DA's office was drafting a new indictment that would be filed Wednesday. ``This happens every day in the courthouse. It's not unusual at all,'' he said. Vines said he was relieved the perjury charge was thrown out. ``I hope and pray that ... the assistant district attorney and the district attorney's office will see the wisdom in not refiling,'' he said. ``We'll review the new indictment, if they file, and see if it's properly done,'' said his attorney, Bill Boyd. ``If not we'll file to quash, again. If they've done it right, we'll prepare for trial.'' Vines was fired by Dallas City Manager Jan Hart on Sept. 12, hours after being indicted on the perjury charge. He is accused of lying to a special panel investigating the June 1989 firing of officer Patrick LeMaire, who fatally shot an unarmed man last year. LeMaire was reinstated in July by an administrative law judge but declined to return to the police force. The perjury charge alleged that Vines lied to the panel about a telephone conversation he had with assistant police chief Greg Holliday on Aug. 2, the night before Holliday was to testify before the panel. Holliday said Vines tried to influence his testimony. Vines has maintained his innocence. Boyd said the indictment was quashed because ``the law in Texas requires that if you allege perjury, you must first show the statement that you allege to be false and then state what you claim the truth to be.'' ``They made a general allegation in the indictment as to what they claimed to be false and they made no allegation as to what they claimed the truth to be,'' he said. Tuesday's action was the latest setback in the district attorney's prosecution of Vines, who had been police chief for two years. Prosecutors initially filed the case in state district court, but were told last month that the court had no jurisdiction because official misconduct was not alleged. The case was moved to Dallas County Criminal Court, where Judge John McCall stepped aside and asked Onion to preside. The city began a nationwide search for a new police chief after Vines' dismissal. Sixty-two candidates have applied for the job, including Acting Chief Sam Gonzales.

DOC.HEAD: Prince Philip Camps Out in Australian Outback
DOC.TEXT: There was no ``princely'' accommodation available Tuesday night for the Duke of Edinburgh. Instead, Prince Philip got a true taste of Outback hospitality by spending the night in a tent, sampling native food and using an outdoor shower. The location was about 520 miles northwest of Brisbane on property recently bought by the Queensland state government. Prince Philip's overnight visit with Queensland's Environment Minister Pat Comben follows the government's initiatives to protect and preserve two mulga land properties. The duke and Queensland Premier Wayne Goss were expected Wednesday to announce steps for the preservation of mulga lands, arid areas that are home to threatened species. Prince Philip arrived over the weekend for a 10-day visit.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Fighting Rocks El Salvador, At Least 27 Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with higher casualty figures, communique details. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto SAL6
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of rebel fighters attacked more than a dozen military positions in El Salvador on Tuesday. At least 27 people were killed and 141 were wounded, authorities said. The fiercest fighting was in the eastern provincial capitals of San Francisco Gotera and Usulutan, where combat lasted more than five hours. Fighting was reported in seven of the nation's 14 provinces. Leftist guerrillas attacked the main air base on the outskirts of the capital, damaging one aircraft and an airman's dormitory, and several military positions within a 15-mile radius of San Salvador. A telephone survey of hospitals, first aid centers, military officers in the field and town officials provided the casualty figures. Victims included guerrillas, soldiers and civilians, the officials said. Rebel sabotage damaged electrical installations and power lines affecting about two-thirds of this Central American nation of more than 5.5 million people, the government electrical company said. A rebel communique said the coordinated attacks in eastern, northern and central El Salvador were meant to punish the army for human rights abuses and inflexibility at the negotiating table. The Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, or FMLN, attacked major garrisons in the east at Usulutan and San Francisco Gotera shortly after 2 a.m. with mortars, rocket-propelled grenades and rifle fire. A resident of Usulutan city, reached by telephone, said combat was fierce until 7 a.m. He said two air force helicopter gunships and C-7 combat planes lent support to soldiers battling rebels on the city's outskirts. The guerrillas also hit military detachments in Santa Elena, Puerto Parada and Concepcion Batres - all in Usulutan province. Heavy combat was reported from Guatajiagua in Morazan province near San Francisco Gotera. Fighting was also reported from the northern provincial capital of Chalatenango, seat of a main garrison, and from Cuscatlan, La Paz and La Libertad. Army positions were attacked in San Jose Guayabal, Suchitoto, Apopa, Nejapa, Quetzaltepeque and Zacatecoluca - in central El Salvador near the capital. In a communique signed by its senior five commanders, the FMLN called the attacks a limited operation to prod President Alfredo Cristiani's rightist government back to negotiating. The administration called it a terrorist offensive. The rebel communique described the offensive as ``a military response to the armed forces' impunity, repression, military operations and the intransigence of the government, which refuses to demilitarize society and clings to a criminal army.'' It warned that a large-scale offensive may be launched if the administration still refuses to negotiate. An FMLN spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity, told foreign correspondents: ``After holding talks with national groups and foreign governments, it was decided not to launch an offensive that had been planned, but a military operation instead to push the negotiating process.'' He did not specify which groups or foreign governments were consulted. A government official told a news conference the offensive ``cannot be interpreted as isolated attacks. We have observed relief columns and seen that the FMLN is in a position to beef up its units that carried the (initial) attacks.'' The attacks followed the anniversary of the army's massacre of six Jesuit priests on Nov. 16, 1989, during a rebel offensive in the capital. Those killings cost El Salvador half of its $85 million in U.S. military aid planned for 1991. Rebel and government negotiators have held five rounds of peace talks since May. The talks have bogged down amid mutual charges of intransigence. The rebels express willingness to demobilize and join the political process only if the current armed forces are disbanded. The guerrillas, international human rights groups and U.S. congressional investigators say the U.S.-backed armed forces murder and torture political opponents and are corrupt. Thousands of civilians have been killed by the army or army-linked death squads in the 11-year-old civil war but no officer has been convicted of a crime involving politically motivated human rights abuse. In all, more than 73,000 people have been killed in the war, including at least 30,000 civilians.

DOC.HEAD: Rough Seas Hinder Diving Effort at Leaking Tanker
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2 grafs for grafs 3-4, `Jones said ...' to UPDATE with leak slowed to a trickle and to CORRECT spelling of Cyprus. Picks up 5th graf, `The leak ...'
DOC.TEXT: A tanker that started taking on water while carrying 24 million gallons of oil to Korea has been given permission to head for San Francisco, the Coast Guard said Tuesday. ``We hoped the ship could come in during daylight hours, but now it looks like it won't be until Wednesday,'' said Coast Guard Chief Petty Officer Lance Jones. Divers managed to ``slow the leak to a trickle on Tuesday, but they can't do any welding until the flow is stopped,'' Jones said. The diving operation got off to a slow start because of rough seas. The tanker Kiku Pacific, owned by the Admitos Marine Co. of Cyprus, took on 30 inches of water Monday in a leak from a 19-inch cooling water pipe in its engine room, according to Coast Guard Lt. Dick Kermond. The leak was controlled after the Coast Guard dispatched the Cutter Sherman and a C-130 aircraft carrying a salvage pump to the tanker, floating about 140 miles southwest of San Francisco. Five-foot swells delayed diving operations that had been expected for Tuesday. The plan called for the divers to go down and plug the leak from the outside. ``They are slowly making headway on the flooding,'' Jones said. ``They've rigged up some pumps, and the water in the engine room is slowly diminishing.''

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Editor Accused of Impersonating Prosecutor Cleared
DOC.TEXT: A judge dismissed all charges Tuesday against the former chief editor of the Johnstown Tribune-Democrat, accused of impersonating a state prosecutor and pressuring a man suing his brother to back off. Theodore N. Beitchman won the dismissal after he and a former subordinate testified he was not at work when the harassing telephone calls were made. Beitchman, who resigned as editor in chief after his arrest Oct. 1, told District Justice Susan McEwen he went home sick after working less than a half-hour on March 13, the day of the telephone calls. The newspaper's managing editor, Larry Hudson, testified that he supervised the newspaper's production that day, supporting Beitchman's contention. Beitchman, 44, was accused of calling Henry Malinowski, identifying himself as an assistant attorney general and pressuring Malinowski to drop a lawsuit against Beitchman's brother. Telephone showed the calls were made from the Johnstown newspaper to Malinowski's home and business on March 13, but McEwen said there was no proof Beitchman made them. She dropped charges of harassment and impersonating a public servant. ``I don't want to gloat, believe me,'' Beitchman said. ``I'm just so happy it's over.'' Malinowski had sued Beitchman's brother, Arthur, to recover money for repairs to his car, which was damaged in an accident involving Arthur Beitchman's son. Chief Deputy District Attorney Ted Fritsch said he was considering refiling charges, using additional evidence, but he declined to elaborate. Defense attorney Ronald Elgart said the phone calls were a setup. ``It sounds like somebody had it in for Ted Beitchman,'' Elgart said.

DOC.BYLINE: NBC to Cancel Black Daytime Series, Put in Faith Daniels Show ^By JAY SHARBUTT
DOC.TEXT: NBC is axing its low-rated ``Generations'' soap opera and giving ``Today'' newscaster Faith Daniels her own daytime show in January, network sources said Tuesday. Station affiliates also will be told Wednesday that NBC is working with Linda Ellerbee, who left NBC News four years ago, to develop a new daytime information-entertainment series, said the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. NBC declined to comment. The network only would say that NBC Entertainment Group chairman Brandon Tartikoff and NBC Entertainment president Warren Littlefield have taped a report to be sent to affiliates via closed-circuit TV on Wednesday. The report, taped at NBC studios in Burbank, Ca., primarily will concern NBC's struggling daytime schedule, the network said. Although ``Generations'' has been third in its time period, various black groups have been campaigning to save the series, which broke new ground when it premiered in March 1989 by focusing on a black family as well as a white one. Daniels' show would succeed it in late January, according to a source familiar with NBC's plans for the change. Daniels would continue on ``Today.'' Ellerbee's possible series, for which she has taped a pilot, still is under development and has not yet been scheduled. The show, produced by Mark Monsky, former executive producer of the syndicated ``Hard Copy'' series, is tentatively entitled ``Women's Diaries.'' Ellerbee, who has been doing independent programs and has her own production company, left NBC after it axed her ``NBC News Overnight'' series, a low-rated, yet much-discussed late-hour series. Although first in prime time ratings, NBC has been seeking ways to bolster its daytime schedule, which has been a distant third in the ratings. According to season-to-date Nielsen estimates, CBS is first with a 5.5 rating for its daytime shows, followed by ABC with a 4.6. NBC has averaged a 3.1. Each ratings point represents 931,000 homes.

DOC.HEAD: Atlantis Lands Safely in Florida
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with comment from departing astronauts; EDITS to tightens. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `It's very ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CSB1
DOC.TEXT: Atlantis and its five astronauts safely returned home from a secret military mission Tuesday, gliding smoothly to the first space shuttle landing in Florida in five years. The shuttle, diverted from the California desert because of high winds and damp runways, swooped through a clear, brilliant blue sky and touched down at Kennedy Space Center at 4:43 p.m. Its arrival was heralded by the customary twin sonic booms. ``Welcome home. It sure was a beautiful sight,'' Mission Control told the crew. It was Kennedy's sixth shuttle landing; the last one was in 1985, when Discovery blew a tire. Workers had to scramble to prepare for the landing, assembling a convoy of support vehicles and bringing in extra personnel. Atlantis had begun its mission Thursday with an unusual nighttime liftoff. ``We're here in Florida and we didn't expect to be here when we left,'' Atlantis' commander Richard Covey said before leaving with his crew Tuesday night for Johnson Space Center in Houston. ``The KSC folks did a good job of getting ready for us, and they did a super job of getting us out of town last Thursday night when we said we were going to go,'' Covey said. About 250 people, including two busloads of workers from the launch control center, watched the landing from bleachers and a grassy strip adjoining the paved runway. They whistled and cheered, waving small American flags. Launch director Bob Sieck was among about a half-dozen NASA officials who greeted Covey, pilot Frank Culbertson Jr. and the rest of the crew. ``It's very special, just like the launch,'' Sieck said. ``You have to remember that half the workforce (at Kennedy) has never seen a shuttle landing.'' ``They worked so hard to get it off, it's only fair that they should see it land,'' said NASA safety official Al Parrish. William Lenoir, head of NASA's space flight program, said a quick check of the shuttle showed it to be ``very clean'' with dings on only a few of the heat-resistant tiles. Atlantis was supposed to land Monday at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., but high wind forced Mission Control to call off the plan and extend the shuttle's flight. Flight director Randy Stone said Atlantis had enough power and supplies to stay aloft until Thursday, although it's doubtful NASA would wait until then to bring the shuttle home. A quarter-inch of rain fell on the Mojave Desert lakebed late Monday and early Tuesday, creating pools of water on the natural surface runways and making them unsuitable for landing. The concrete runway would have been the only option there on Tuesday and probably on Wednesday. The outlook for Wednesday at Edwards was no better, prompting NASA to opt for Kennedy. The sky over Kennedy was clear Tuesday, and wind speed was well within landing limits. Kennedy's 2.8-mile-long paved runway, which has 1,000-feet overruns on both ends and is 300 feet wide, provides less room for maneuvering than the wide-open desert. Discovery, the last shuttle to land at Kennedy, blew a tire and sustained brake damage during a 1985 landing. Atlantis had been orbiting amid a Pentagon-imposed silence since Thursday. Sources said the astronauts deployed a satellite Friday to spy on Iraq by either photographic surveillance or electronic eavesdropping. In addition to Covey, an Air Force colonel, and Culbertson, a Navy commander, the all-military crew has three mission specialists: Army Maj. Charles Gemar, Air Force Lt. Col. Carl Meade and Marine Col. Robert Springer. The mission was the seventh and last secret shuttle flight for the Defense Department. Two more Pentagon missions are planned for the shuttle, but the cargoes are unclassified. Atlantis was supposed to lift off in July with the spy satellite, but was grounded by hydrogen leaks. The spacecraft reportedly was modified to observe the Persian Gulf while the shuttle was being fixed. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is preparing for its next shuttle flight, an astronomy mission that has been on hold since May. Columbia is scheduled to lift off with seven astronauts and the $150 million Astro observatory in early December. NASA saved $1 million by landing Atlantis at Kennedy and about a week in shuttle processing time since the ship does not have to be transported now across the country. The agency has modified Kennedy's landing strip and developed new shuttle brakes with the intent of landing on a regular basis in Florida in the next year or so. Twenty-nine of the 37 shuttle flights to date have ended at Edwards. Columbia was diverted to White Sands, N.M., in 1982 because the desert lakebed was flooded. The shuttle Challenger's Jan. 28, 1986, flight ended 73 seconds after liftoff in an explosion that killed seven astronauts.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 21st graf: ``White House,'' Fitzwater declines comment on one report; DELETES last graf and edits remaining last two grafs to trim
DOC.HEAD: Soviets Say Security Council Should `Take Stock'
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union said Tuesday the U.N. Security Council should ``take stock'' of its sanctions against Iraq and decide whether a new course of action is necessary. But the Soviets again rebuffed President Bush's efforts to rally support for a resolution authorizing military force. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, emerging from a 90-minute meeting with Secretary of State James A. Baker, told reporters, ``We need to consult with our colleagues and partners in the Security Council.'' But he stopped considerably short of backing any measure that would advocate the use of force. Shevardnaze said the council should ``take stock of things and pass appropriate judgment on what it has been doing.'' Then, if necessary, he said, the body should ``adopt new resolutions with a view to implementing all the previous decisions.'' The Persian Gulf crisis dominated the unofficial agenda at the 34-nation Conference on Cooperation and Security in Europe, although French President Francois Mitterrand's spokesman said the conference would not issue any statements on the crisis. ``There will be no common declaration by the 34 on the Gulf,'' Hubert Vedrine said after a 45-minute private meeting of the leaders. Discussion in the closed session focused on such matters as immigration from one European country to the next and the continent's environment. German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, speaking to a public session of the summit, called for action to ensure that the democratic process in Eastern Europe does not collapse. ``Following the opening of national borders, there must now be no borders which perpetuate the prosperity divide,'' Kohl said. Kohl's spokesman, Hans Klein, said that in a closed-door session a number of nations expressed concern about an ''uncontrollable refugee stream from the East.'' On other topics: -Norwegian Prime Minister Gro Harlem Brundtland said her country intends to set up a fund, financed by a tax on its offshore oilfields, to help less wealthy countries combat global warming. -The foreign ministers of the three Baltic republics - Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania - protested at the Soviet move excluding them from the work of the conference summit. -Hungarian Prime Minister Jozsef Antall said he hoped ``the conditions for the complete dissolution of the Warsaw Pact'' will be created by early 1992. Antall is the first Warsaw Pact leader to talk about the complete demise of the military alliance and to offer a deadline. In another distraction, British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher learned that former Defense Minister Michael Heseltine won enough votes from Conservative members of Parliament to force a second-round ballot next week that will decide if her 11 years in office will come to an end. Thatcher has been America's steadiest ally on a range of issues, including the effort to rally support for sterner action against Iraq. Baker had been pressing a last-ditch effort to strike a deal before Bush's trip to Saudi Arabia on Wednesday. However, the Soviet leader's statement indicated that the two sides were still far apart.
