Even so, Baker said: ``The United States and the Soviet Union have been united in their approach to this problem'' since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``We are united today. We intend to remain united,'' he added. As the Paris summit wound down its second day, both U.S. and Soviet officials unveiled plans for a superpower summit in Moscow early next year to sign a treaty on reducing long-range nuclear weapons. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said there was no firm date for the summit, although he said both countries were shooting for January. Fitzwater said having a nuclear arms treaty to sign was a prerequisite for the summit, but holding the session in January ``is what we have been talking about and shooting for.'' Even before the end of the Baker and Shevardnadze meeting, Fitzwater said it seemed ``very unlikely'' that support could be rallied for a resolution to step up pressure before the president's trip to the Middle East. The United States is seeking a new resolution giving advance authority to using military action to drive Iraq's Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait, although officials said exact language has not yet been drafted. Shevardnadze, in effect, agreed that the matter should be reopened by the United Nations - but declined to go beyond that. Resolutions already approved by the Security Council impose an economic boycott on Iraq and occupied Kuwait, call for Iraq's unconditional withdrawal and insist upon restoration of Kuwait's previous government. The resolutions do not authorize military action as such, but do leave the door open to other measures if Iraq fails to respond to the steps. Fitzwater refused to confirm a report that one resolution being discussed would call for automatic military action if Saddam had not withdrawn in what Fitzwater called ``a month or two months or three months or something like that.'' The spokesman said: ``There are any number of approaches that are being considered. We will not comment on any one of them.'' Bush had failed to break the impasse during a two-hour private dinner the night before with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. He flies to front-line Saudi Arabia on Wednesday to meet with Saudi leaders and the exiled emir of Kuwait on the crisis. He will spend Thanksgiving with U.S. forces in the region and will meet with Egyptian leaders on Friday. Baker will travel to Yemen and possibly beyond to try to drum up support for U.S. moves, officials said Tuesday night. Kim Hoggard, a State Department spokeswoman, said Baker would fly to Yemen on Thursday ``to discuss the situation in the Persian Gulf and further steps we can take within the United Nations framework.'' Sources, demanding anonymity, said Baker might travel on to Oman where he would confer with Malaysian officials. Both Yemen and Malaysia are members of the 15-nation Security Council. Yemen is the only Arab nation on the council and has in the past shown sympathy for Iraq. It will assume the council's rotating presidency in December, taking over from the United States. Meanwhile, Fitzwater criticized Saddam Hussein's decision to release German hostages, saying ``He has spawned a cottage industry of political ploys.'' Earlier in the day there was a flurry of separate meetings among leaders. Gorbachev met with Thatcher, who has issued calls for military action against Iraq, stronger even than Bush's. Thatcher also met with French President Francois Mitterrand, who like Gorbachev has counseled patience. Ignatenko announced the Bush-Gorbachev summit at a briefing here. On the subject of a strategic arms reduction treaty, Ignatenko would only say, ``If it's ready, they will sign it.'' U.S. sources said a summit seems likely early in January. But, for the record, deputy White House press secretary Roman Popadiuk said: ``We have nothing to announce.'' It would be Bush and Gorbachev's fifth face-to-face sessions as leaders - Monday night's dinner and four ``summits,'' including meetings earlier this year in Helsinki and Washington and one a year ago in Malta. Bush may visit Turkey on the same trip. After Bush's meeting on Tuesday with Turkish President Turgut Ozal, the White House announced Bush would pay a state visit to Turkey ``in the first part of 1991.'' Turkey is letting American bombers use its airfields and has closed a pipeline used by Iraq. But it has shown little enthusiasm about a military confrontation with its neighbor. Bush also met with Polish Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki. According to White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, Mazowiecki promised a Polish hospital ship and rescue ship in support of U.N. Persian Gulf policy.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Tries to Soothe Palestinians; Iraqis Vote to Free Germans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 16 `The president' to drop 2nd full reference to Gorbachev. Picks up graf 17 pvs, `Also Tuesday...'
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi lawmakers voted Tuesday to allow all German hostages to leave Iraq and occupied Kuwait, and Saddam Hussein was reported to be patching up his ties with a key ally by promising better treatment of Palestinians living in Kuwait. Meanwhile, a former CIA official said Iraq was ``casing'' U.S. military installations in the Middle East as possible terrorist targets if war breaks out in the gulf. ``I don't believe the Iraqis are going to unleash that capability against the Americans at this time,'' said Vincent M. Cannistraro, who resigned as a terrorism anaylst in September. ``But they are certainly preparing themselves, positioning themselves to do so once the situation changes.'' Saddam last week pledged to halt Iraqi army harassment of the estimated 400,000 Palestinian workers and their families who live in Kuwait, a senior Palestine Liberation Organization official said. The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Saddam made the promise in a meeting with Yasser Abed Rabbo of the PLO's Executive Committee. Palestinians returning to Jordan have complained of torture and executions in Kuwait. The Iraqi lawmakers approved the special treatment of Germans following a personal request by Saddam. There was only one dissenting vote. The vote came after 90 minutes of debate, during which the lawmakers heard from at least 10 of the ``guests,'' as Iraq calls foreigners barred from leaving since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The hostages who addressed the National Assembly said freeing the Germans would encourage European countries and the United States to show their willingness to avert war and negotiate a settlement to the Persian Gulf crisis. Parliament speaker Saadi Mahdi Saleh said there were 124 Germans remaining in Iraq and Kuwait. No specific arrangements were made for their departure. In Paris, German Foreign Minister Hans Dietrich Genscher said of Iraq's action: ``I believe we should appreciate above all that the hostages are to be freed.'' The gulf crisis continued to dominate the unofficial agenda in Paris at the 34-nation Conference on Cooperation and Security in Europe. French President Francois Mitterrand's spokesman, Hubert Vedrine, said the conference would not issue any statements on the crisis. The January contract for light sweet crude, the benchmark blend of U.S. oil, fell $1.81 to $28.91 a barrel Tuesday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, erasing a $1.72 gain from the previous session. President Bush's failure to secure an agreement with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev on the U.N. resolution to authorize military action was viewed as indicating war was unlikely soon, analysts said. Bush flies to Saudi Arabia on Wednesday to meet with Saudi leaders. He plans to spend Thanksgiving with U.S. forces in the region. Supply officers are trying to assure that all 230,000 Americans deployed in the gulf will get fresh Thanksgiving dinners. The president voiced optimism that he would be successful in overcoming Soviet objections to a U.N. resolution authorizing the use of military force against Iraq. ``Just be patient and all will be well,'' he told reporters when asked about Gorbachev's reluctance. Also Tuesday, the chairman of the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff said Saddam's order sending 250,000 more troops to Kuwait was a publicity ploy. Gen. Colin Powell said it was possible that Saddam plans to use the extra troops to replace weary soldiers at the front lines. ``But at the moment, it's just part of his headline-of-the-day program where he tries to divert world opinion from his own aggression,'' the four-star general told CBS' ``This Morning.'' ``Yesterday was a troop buildup. The day before that, it was a hostage release.'' In Washington on Tuesday, a group of 45 Democratic lawmakers filed a lawsuit to try to force Bush to seek authority from Congress before ordering a U.S. military attack to drive Iraqi troops out of Kuwait. ``We believe the president has a responsibility to send to Congress a declaration of war,'' said Rep. Ronald V. Dellums, D-Calif. The issue should be debated in Congress because ``there are millions of American people in this country who have serious questions about going to war,'' Dellums said. ``The president of the United States on his own cannot make that kind of determination.'' Saddam met in Baghdad with delegations from France and Switzerland on Monday and told them more Europeans would be allowed to leave, the official Iraqi News Agency reported. A Dutch company reported that 105 Dutchmen, 14 Belgians and three Britons who completed a government-commissioned dredging project will be permitted to depart. Hundreds of foreigners have been prevented from leaving since Saddam's troops overran Kuwait, and the Western allies have accused Saddam of trying to use the hostages to split the alliance against him. The official Iraqi News Agency quoted Saddam as saying that freeing the Germans would encourage others to distance themselves from the Western allies pushing for war with Iraq. German Chancellor Helmut Kohl told Bush this week that a peaceful solution was still possible. ``Whoever believes the problem can be solved militarily must consider not only the mission, but the end of the whole undertaking,'' Kohl said. Germany's constitution prohibits the deployment of German troops outside the country's borders. Germany provided merchant ships to transport U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia and contributed $2 billion to support the U.S.-led multinational force in the gulf.

DOC.HEAD: Muhammad Ali To Share Thanksgiving with Hostages in Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Muhammad Ali, who converted to Islam in the mid-1960s, flew to Iraq to share a Thangsgiving meal with U.S. hostages in Baghdad, an anti-war group said Tuesday. The three-time heavyweight boxing champion, who changed his name from Cassius Clay in 1964 after adopting the Moslem faith, was scheduled to arrive in the Iraqi capital Wednesday, said Gavrielle Gemma, spokeswoman for the Coalition to Stop U.S. Intervention in the Middle East. The retired boxer from Louisville, Ky., will meet with unspecified Iraqi leaders before sharing a Thanksgiving meal with several Americans refused permission to leave Iraq, she said. Ali was not representing the anti-intervention coalition, but the group had helped him with travel arrangements, Gemma said. Ali also planned to visit athletes, local schools and other groups during the viit expected to last through the holiday weekend, she said. Mike Brennan of the U.S. State Department in Washington said Ali would not have to check in with them before traveling to Iraq as long as he intended to spend no money there. This would mean, for example, that his expenses would be picked up by someone in Iraq, he said. Since its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, Iraq has prevented thousands of Westerners from leaving the two countries in an effort to deter an attack by a U.S.-led multinational force massing in the Persian Gulf region.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Legislature Passes Tough Ethics Bill in Wake of Lobbying Scandal
DOC.TEXT: An ethics bill hailed as one of the toughest in the country cleared the state Legislature unanimously Tuesday as lawmakers sought to restore public confidence amid a criminal investigation. The bill would prohibit gifts over $100 from lobbyists and political action committees to more than 32,000 state and local public officials. It makes exceptions for food and drink and for gifts from relatives, fiances and roommates. The measure, which would take effect Jan. 1, would impose a fine of up to $5,000 and a two-year lobbying ban on lobbyists who violate it. Officials could be removed from office. The measure passed the House 119-0 with little debate, then was approved by the Senate 39-0. The Legislature then adjourned its 3{-hour special session on the subject. The bill was sent to Gov. Bob Martinez, who is expected to sign it. The bill was sparked by an investigation into legislators' acceptance of trips to hunting lodges, ski resorts and foreign countries from lobbyists and their failure to report them as the law now requires. State Attorney Willie Meggs has subpoenaed records from dozens of lobbyists as part of the probe. ``I believe it's one of the toughest pieces of ethics legislation ever written in this country,'' said Rep. Everett Kelly, a Democrat who chaired the joint committee that drafted the bill. Senate Republicans, led by Minority Leader Ander Crenshaw, tried to amend the bill to prohibit officials from accepting any gifts from lobbyists, no matter their value. ``Under this bill, (a lobbyist) couldn't give you a $400 set of golf clubs,'' said Sen. Richard Langley, a Republican. ``But he could give it to you one club at a time.'' But Sen. Tom Brown, a Democrat who was the chief Senate sponsor, urged no changes so the bill wouldn't have to return to the House for further consideration. He said the $100 limit could be changed by the Legislature in the future. Bill Jones of the Common Cause government watchdog group said the bill was ``a good first step,'' but paled in comparison with the need for campaign finance reform. The measure clearly defines what a gift is and makes several exceptions, most importantly allowing lobbyists to pay for food and drink of any price if it's consumed at a single sitting. Government entities - such as state commissions, school boards and city councils - could give officials gifts, but universities and colleges could not. That would end such perks as football weekends for legislators. Gifts such as those from government entities and from a person who isn't a lobbyist would have to be reported quarterly if over $100.

DOC.HEAD: British Businessman Said Feared Kidnapped in Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: Two Beirut newspapers on Tuesday published a letter from friends of a British businessman who said he has been missing in Lebanon since April and is feared kidnapped. The letter was published in Arabic by the daily Ad-Diyar and in French by L'Orient-Le Jour. It was signed by ``friends of British businessman Robin Gregson'' and addressed to ``his kidnappers.'' The letter said Gregson's disappearance was reported to the British Embassy three months ago but was ignored. But an embassy source said: ``The embassy was notified sometime in April of his disappearance and was in touch with his wife back in Britain.'' The source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, would say nothing else other than to confirm that Gregson reportedly disappeared near Chekka and Jounieh. The letter said: ``Our friend Robin Gregson went missing more than six months ago between the town of Chekka and the port of Jounieh. He was heading for Jounieh to leave via its port on April 21.'' Chekka is a coastal town in Syrian-policed north Lebanon and Jounieh is the main port in the Christian enclave, which is controlled by rightist militiamen of Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces. A passenger boat line serves the Christian enclave with daily trips from Jounieh to Larnaca, Cyprus. ``We have inquired about his whereabouts with the Lebanese and Cypriot immigration authorities as well as with a number of political parties in north Lebanon, but to no avail,'' the letter said. A police spokesman, who cannot benamed under standing rules, speculated that Gregson ``might have been held by one of the various militias.'' ``To his kidnappers we say: Release Robin so he could return to his family and friends,'' the letter said. ``More than seven years ago he chose to live in Lebanon because he loved Lebanon despite all that has happened.'' An editor at Ad-Diyar, speaking on condition he not be named, said the letter was contained in an ``unsealed white envelope dropped in the newspaper's mail box. It did not carry a sender's address.'' No details were available on what Gregson was doing in Lebanon. Because his disappearance remains unconfirmed, Gregson was not listed among the 13 Westerners missing in Lebanon and believed kidnapped by pro-Iranian underground factions. The missing Westerners include six Americans, four Britons, two Germans and an Italian. Terry A. Anderson, the 43-year-old chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, has been held the longest, since March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Auburn Faculty Asks University President to Explain Tenure Refusal for Priest
DOC.TEXT: Auburn University's faculty senate on Tuesday asked President James Martin to explain his refusal to grant tenure for a Roman Catholic priest rebuked by the Vatican. Martin, however, balked at discussing his denial of a permanent position for Rev. Charles E. Curran and told the senate to take its complaint to the board of trustees, which already has expressed support for the president. ``I totally reject even the slightest insinuation that I or my decisions have violated anyone's academic freedom,'' Martin told the senate. Curran, the only American barred by Rome from teaching Catholic theology, accepted a one-year appointment at Auburn, where he now teaches in an endowed professorship. The school initially advertised the post as being tenured, and Curran said he learned the job was not tenured only after he had already decided to accept it. In the spring, Martin overruled two faculty committees that had recommended Curran for the tenured position as Goodwin-Philpott Eminent Scholar of Religion. Martin has refused to explain his decision, either publicly or to Curran. The faculty senate, which could have asked Martin to reverse his decision, adopted a resolution that asked the president to make arrangements by Dec. 7 to meet with the tenure promotion committee and discuss his denial of tenure. If Martin fails to comply with the request, the senate will ask its executive committee to call a meeting of the entire faculty, which could lead to a formal censure or a vote of no confidence. University Senate Chairman Gary Mullen said before the meeting that the senate was not concerned with why Martin denied tenure for Curran. ``Our worry is the subversion of the tenure process,'' he said. But Miller Soloman, an English professor and former senate chairman, said, ``We want to give (Martin) every chance to explain ... what his reasons were for not granting Dr. Curran tenure. The fact that he would not divulge his reasons taints Dr. Curran's reputation.'' Curran, 56, had said he did not plan to attend Tuesday's meeting. ``I am not really a player in this anymore,'' Curran, author of 20 books on Christian ethics and morality, said in an interview last week. ``It is all going on around me.'' Curran has been involved in disagreements with Rome since the 1960s. He led opposition to a 1968 Vatican decree against artificial birth control and also disputes the church's stance against abortion. In 1986, the Vatican cited Curran for his disagreements with church doctrine and barred him from teaching Catholic theology. Since then, some 750 Catholic theologians have signed a statement supporting him, and the University of Notre Dame Press still publishes his books.

DOC.HEAD: Contra Leader's Wife Accuses Government of Torturing Husband
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with archbishop doubting plot. Picks up 6th graf, `Presidential spokesman' with minor editing to trim
DOC.TEXT: The wife of a former Contra leader accused the Sandinista-run police of torturing her husband to force a confession in which he implicated the vice president in an anti-government conspiracy. The government of President Violeta Chamorro denied her claim, but the nation's Roman Catholic archbishop was quoted as saying the purported plot was just ``a show'' and raising questions about her presidency. Aristides Sanchez was released Monday after spending four days in El Chipote prison on suspicion of planning a 2-week-long series of protests by former Contras and their sympathizers. Before his release Sanchez signed a confession implicating Vice President Virgilio Godoy, which was read on national television Monday night by security officials. Sanchez and his wife left Monday on a plane for Miami without speaking to reporters. Cecilia Rodriguez de Sanchez, in an interview by phone from Miami with a Managua radio station Tuesday, claimed her husband was drugged, kept in cells ``full of rats in 100-degree heat'' and in ``a drawer, like they have in the morgue.'' La Prensa newspaper, which is owned by Mrs. Chamorro's family, ran a front-page story quoting Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo as calling Sanchez's alleged confession and the televised appearance of government officials ``a show.'' He said Mrs. Sanchez told him her husband was tortured and drugged while in custody and ``I am worried about that,'' according to the paper. It quoted Obando y Bravo as saying he spoke to Mrs. Chamorro about the political situation and believes ``she does not have all the information that she should have and all the control that a person who guides the destiny of a country should have.'' Presidential spokesman Danilo Lacayo said Sanchez, 47, was treated well and kept in an air-conditioned office because of his heart condition. There was no answer at Sanchez's residence in Miami. Before returning to Nicaragua this year, he was a leader-in-exile of the U.S.-backed rebel forces that tried for 10 years to oust the leftist Sandinista government. The Sandinistas lost February's elections to a coalition headed by Mrs. Chamorro and Godoy. Since taking office in April, Mrs. Chamorro has kept Sandinistas in control of the army and police, to the chagrin of Godoy and other coalition members. Mrs. Sanchez said her husband was forced to sign the confession and go into exile or face a lengthy prison stay. He was held at El Chipote, the maze of rotting cells and torture chambers where dictator Anastasio Somoza kept his political foes before he was ousted by the Sandinista-led revolution in 1979. Lacayo said Sanchez was free to return from exile if he wished to face conspiracy charges. He said Sanchez was visited by representatives of the church, the Organization of American States and his wife. OAS representative Santiago Murray said he saw Sanchez on Thursday. ``We spoke for about 15 minutes. He seemed to be in good health,'' Murray said. But he couldn't vouch for Sanchez' overall treatment. In Sanchez' confession, he accused Godoy and other leaders of the fractious, 14-member government coalition of organizing the protests to force Mrs. Chamorro to resign. Godoy, who has praised the anti-government demonstrations, said Sanchez's accusations were ``a tragicomedy.'' ``They are trying to involve me in everything. If tomorrow there is an eclipse, they'll probably blame me for that too,'' Godoy said. Godoy and others claim that Mrs. Chamorro is being manipulated by her chief of staff, Antonio Lacayo, who they believe is too cozy with the Sandinistas. Since late last month, demobilized Contra fighters and disaffected members of the governing coalition have blocked roads and seized town halls, mostly in southeastern Nicaragua, to demand that Sandinista officials resign. At least 10 people have died in clashes between protesters and armed forces. The protests have eased a bit in recent days. Sanchez's confession, as read by Sandinista Police Commander Javier Lopez, said the conspirators hoped to whip up discontent and ``make Nicaragua ungovernable through fomenting chaos and anarchy.'' ``All these pressures would force (Mrs. Chamorro) to resign and thus Dr. Virgilio Godoy Reyes would be able to assume the presidency of the republic,'' the confession said. Godoy mocked the broadcast as following ``the most exact Sandinista style.'' The Sandinistas often paraded accused conspirators before television cameras to read confessions to the nation.

DOC.HEAD: Law Students Sue Harvard For Discriminatory Hiring
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2 grafs for 6th graf, `Harvard spokesman ...' to UPDATE with dean's comments. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `The lawsuit ...' SUBS 2 grafs for 10th graf pvs, `Last year ...' to include further comment. Picks up 11th graf, `The lawsuit ...'
DOC.TEXT: A group of Harvard Law School students filed a lawsuit Tuesday against Harvard University, charging that it discriminates on the basis of sex and race in hiring law school faculty members. ``We'd like to sue our school,'' second-year law student Linda Singer cheerfully told the clerk of the Middlesex County Superior Court. The 38-page lawsuit alleges that Harvard Law School has failed to hire any minority women, Asian Americans, native Americans, disabled, Latinos or openly homosexual men or women to tenured or tenure-track faculty positions. The lawsuit also charges that Harvard Law's faculty includes far fewer blacks and women than are represented in the general population of lawyers. The university's hiring practices ``operate to disproportionately exclude qualified women and minority candidates for tenured and tenure-track positions,'' the lawsuit claims. ``These hiring practices constitute a continuing pattern and practice of discrimination in violation of state law.'' The law school's dean, Robert C. Clark, said the lawsuit has no merit. ``The issue of diversity on the faculty is an important one and the law school's record is strong,'' Clark said in a statement. ``In the past decade, 45 percent of those whom the law school has hired in tenure-track positions have been women or members of minority groups.'' The lawsuit, signed by 11 Harvard Law students, was filed by a student group called the Harvard Law Coalition for Civil Rights under a state law which bars discrimination in hiring by businesses or institutions with 15 or more employees. According to the coalition, five of 66 tenured and tenure-track faculty members at the law school are women, or 7.58 percent. Nationwide, at law schools approved by the American Bar Association, 23.7 percent of faculty are women. The students maintain that women make up 36.75 percent of the law graduates since 1980. Of the law school's four tenure-track faculty members, two are black but none are women, the lawsuit says. And three of 62 tenured positions, or 4.84 percent, are black. Clark did not challenge the students' figures but said that the lawsuit failed to mention that about one-third of the school's part-time lecturers are women or minorities. Last year, law students occupied Clark's office for two days to protest Harvard's hiring policies. The lawsuit asks the court to order Harvard to give weight to diversity in its hiring decisions, establish an affirmative action hiring plan, and allow visiting faculty members to be hired immediately without going through a one-year waiting period. Derrick Bell, who in 1971 became the first black appointed to a full-time faculty post at the law school, attended a sidewalk news conference after the students filed the lawsuit. He took an unpaid leave of absence in April to protest Harvard's hiring policies. Bell rejected the argument advanced by Harvard and other universities that affirmative action plans dilute the quality of faculty. ``The diversity vs. quality argument is a smoke screen intended to obscure the fact that these schools' faculties remain predominantly white and male and that the quality of their teaching and scholarship covers a wide range from excellent to abysmal,'' Bell said.

DOC.HEAD: Census Bureau Says Detroit Tops Million Mark
DOC.TEXT: Volunteers scouring Detroit for people missed by U.S. Census counters helped push the city over the 1 million mark needed to retain big-city political clout and federal and state dollars, Census officials said Tuesday. Preliminary census figures released in August estimated the city's population at 970,000, a tally city officials challenged, sending out volunteers to search every street for uncounted Detroiters. While the final count still isn't in, Census Bureau Director Barbara Bryant told Mayor Coleman Young that the city had topped 1 million. Included in the recent tally were such people such as military personnel stationed elsewhere during the first count, Bryant said. ``It includes people who might have been in a winter home on April 1. That, for example, added 22,000 people to the count,'' she said. ``Hooray, hooray, hooray,'' Rep. John Conyers, a Democrat, said from his office in Washington. ``The powers that be finally got the message that the oppressed, the homeless, and the impoverished don't always have phones and houses from which to be recorded.'' The preliminary count would have continued a steady decline from 1.2 million in 1980, 1.5 million in 1970, 1.7 million in 1960 and a high of 1.9 million in 1950, according to Census Bureau figures. Officials have estimated that falling below 1 million would cost Detroit about 16 percent of its annual operating revenue of $1.9 billion. For example, about one-fourth of the city's $1.1 billion general fund budget is from shared portions of state sales, income, intangible and single business taxes, and other levies that would be cut if population dwindled. The city would lose $38 million to $50 million in state-shared tax revenue in the first year new formulas were adopted, according to Michigan Citizens Research Council figures. Young mounted a massive ``Detroit, Were You Counted?'' campaign to round up uncounted residents. By Oct. 24, the deadline for submitting additional names to the Census Bureau, Young said the volunteer forces had found 121,350 uncounted residents and estimated the final count would be at least 1.1 million. Census spokesman Jerry Blocker said agency officials found that some of the names fed into the computer had been already counted. But ``if they were missed, they will definitely be counted,'' Blocker said Tuesday. ``We don't have a final figure, but we will tell you it's over a million.''

DOC.HEAD: Nosair Indicted In Kahane's Murder
DOC.TEXT: The man accused of assassinating Rabbi Meir Kahane, the controversial anti-Arab activist, was indicted Tuesday on second-degree murder charges, a district attorney's office said. A grand jury also charged El Sayyid Nosair, 35, of Cliffside Park, N.J., with attempted murder, assaulting a police officer, second-degree assault, criminal possession of a weapon, reckless endangerment and coercion, District Attorney Robert Morgenthau said in a statement. Second-degree murder carries a maximum sentence of 25 years to life in prison. Nosair apparently acted alone and police authorities have found no evidence that he is linked to any Mideast terrorist organization, Morgenthau said. Nosair allegedly shot the rabbi once behind the ear with a .357-caliber Magnum on Nov. 5 as Kahane finished delivering a speech to a Zionist group in a hotel in midtown Manhattan. Nosair then allegedly shot and wounded someone in the audience who tried to stop him as he ran out and jumped into a cab. He allegedly got out of the cab a block away and shot a U.S. Postal Service officer, who returned the fire and struck the gunman in the neck. Nosair has since recovered. Nosair was being held without bail from his original arraignment. The Brooklyn-born Kahane served for four years in Israel's parliament but was barred from holding office in 1988 after legislators there approved a law banning parties with a racist platform. Kahane, who campaigned to drive Arabs from Israel, also founded the Jewish Defense League in this country and urged American Jews to arm themselves against anti-Semites. Nosair, who was born in Egypt, had been employed by the city Department of General Services fixing heating and air conditioning systems in court buildings. Police have said Nosair was taking prescription drugs for depression when the shooting happened.

Less than two weeks after President Bush ordered 200,000 more troops to the Persian Gulf to gain parity with Iraq, Saddam Hussein has again raised the stakes, ordering another 250,000 troops of his own into Kuwait. In another frustrating development for U.S. gulf policy, Bush failed on Monday to get Soviet agreement on a proposed U.N. resolution authorizing force against Iraq. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev went so far only as to agree that force in the gulf ``cannot be ruled out,'' officials said. A poll published today, meanwhile, indicated that Americans are increasingly worried that Bush favors the military option over the diplomatic route to resolve the crisis precipitated by Iraq's Aug. 2 seizure of Kuwait. ---= LONDON (AP) - Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher faced the toughest challenge of her 11{ years in power today as Conservative lawmakers, worried by low poll ratings, gathered for a vote on whether to keep her as party leader. The 372 Conservatives in the House of Commons must choose between Mrs. Thatcher and her former defense secretary, Michael Heseltine. Mrs. Thatcher, 65, spoke confidently of winning, while Heseltine's supporters were hopeful they would gain enough votes to force a second ballot. The prime minister, in Paris for a 34-nation summit, says she hasn't finished her mission as Britain's longest-serving prime minister of the century, and that Heseltine would betray her free-market economic crusade. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - The Senate Ethics Committee's attorney is ridiculing senators' claims that he invented ethical standards in suggesting they dealt improperly with savings and loan millionaire Charles H. Keating Jr. ``In this body, with all due respect, are your standards a double one?'' special counsel Robert S. Bennett asked Monday. ``Are you above everyone else?'' The ethics panel is holding its fourth day of hearings today into allegations that five senators improperly intervened with federal regulators on behalf of Keating, owner of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif. Keating was a financial contributor to the senators' campaigns and favored causes. The collapse of his once high-flying empire is estimated to cost taxpayers as much as $2 billion to cover federally insured deposits. ---= ATLANTA (AP) - America's crime capital imposed the city's strictest curfew since the Atlanta child murders of the early 1980s, threatening to jail parents of youngsters caught on the street after hours. No arrests were reported in the first few hours after the curfew went into effect at 11 p.m. Monday. The American Civil Liberties Union has threatened to challenge the law, but city officials say it is needed to help the reverse the highest rate of serious crime in the nation. Mayor Maynard Jackson praised the curfew as an excellent way of keeping youngsters from being used as drug runners or lookouts. ---= NEW YORK (AP) - Can cobblestone survive in the asphalt jungle? That issue, and those surfaces, have divided a historic block and left the street a half-cobbled, half-paved patchwork of ruts and potholes. Franklin Street's cobblestone controversy pits some of the artists and professionals who have moved into lofts in the old textile district in lower Manhattan against businessmen still trying to make a living there. And it raises the question of how much the city is willing to spend to preserve a street surface that went out with the horse and buggy. ``At a time when the city is raising taxes and laying people off, it's elitist to spend hundreds of thousands of dollars on cobblestones for one block,'' said Waring Abbott, who thinks cobblestones belong in a museum. ``Why not put them on Fifth Avenue, too?''

For release Thurs PMs, Nov. 22, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Charles Kuralt Off the Road for Thanksgiving
DOC.TEXT: Millions of Americans will be sitting down to Thanksgiving dinner, and Charles Kuralt will be ... well, the CBS commissary isn't that bad. Honest. At least he'll be off the road. He and co-anchor Lesley Stahl will be working as usual on ``America Tonight,'' the late-night CBS News series that began in October as an outgrowth of CBS' specials on the Persian Gulf crisis. Kuralt, who reckons he has logged a million miles for the ``On the Road'' tales of American life he's done for the ``CBS Evening News'' since 1967, returned last week from three weeks of campaigning and working. The campaign was a publicity tour for his fifth book, ``A Life on the Road,'' a chronicle of his youth and life at CBS since he joined the network as a writer in 1957. Unlike most scriveners wandering the book-tour desert, Kuralt, 56, continued at his regular job. He co-anchored ``America Tonight'' from Chicago, Los Angeles and San Francisco. It was an experience as odd as it was exhausting, he reports: ``I'd run around and praise myself all day, then work on that show all night.'' He also continued anchoring ``CBS News Sunday Morning.'' The campaign and tour wouldn't have come to pass had he not agreed to write ``A Life'' after his last book, the best-selling ``On the Road With Charles Kuralt,'' a collection of the road pieces he'd done for CBS. It helped, though, that he took the liberty of spending the advance for the new book before writing it: ``Of course. Don't you always? First, you spend the advance. Then, finally, you learn you have to write the book.'' The last is a horrible moment for most authors. Facing the prospect of demands for a return of the publisher's advance money, they commence tussling with the muse. Thanks to the patience of his publisher, Kuralt's tussle came in bits and pieces, then in a flurry of typewriter-pounding when the publisher said the book was coming out this fall, ready or not. The book emerged three years after Kuralt agreed to write it. It got a nice pre-publication boost last month when the New York Times' travel section excerpted part of it. Suprisingly, the part didn't concern the reports on small-town America for which Kuralt is best known. Instead, it was his lamentation that it's no fun to fly on airlines anymore, that travellers face cramped seats, unsmiling flight attendants and airport ``hubs'' that are little more than treadmills to oblivion. He readily agreed with a suggestion that the fun started to fade when propellor-driven DC-7s were phased out and the era of jets, particularly jumbo jets, began. Maybe it's his age, he said, but, ``I used to find flying somewhere kind of romantic. Now it's become an ordeal.'' There is the possibility that next year, Kuralt may return not to airlines, but to his CBS bus. There could be more ``On the Road'' pieces - his last was in January - should CBS decide at the end of December to park its half-hour ``America Tonight'' series. Of what will happen, Kuralt said, ``I don't know for sure. I assume that it depends on part on events in the Persian Gulf, if that heats up. That's just my assumption. Nobody's ever told me that. ``But the word is that it's going to go off the air (at the end of the year) because the network has all these action-adventure shows they want to try out in that time period.'' He referred to the fact that CBS is considering installing a revolving set of series in January against NBC's ``Tonight,'' ABC News' ``Nightline'' and Arsenio Hall's syndicated ventures in admiring visiting celebrities. (No decision has been made yet and ``America Tonight'' ``has not been told definitely that it's off at the end of December,'' a CBS spokeswoman said.) If the series continues, ``I'm going do this as long as it's on, or as long as they want me to,'' Kuralt said. But if it gets a closing notice, the bus on which he does his ``On the Road'' pieces is parked in Chicago, ``waiting for me to come back to work if I can manage it. And that's my fervent hope. ``Because that's the thing I've enjoyed most - wandering around and doing those little stories.'' --- Elsewhere in television ... CONNIE FACES STARS: Connie Chung, whose scheduled ``Face to Face With Connie Chung'' series was put on hold when she said she wanted to try to have a baby, tonight has a ``Face to Face'' special featuring interviews with Joanne Woodward and her husband, Paul Newman, and with Kevin Costner. On Dec. 10, she'll anchor another ``Face to Face.'' But instead of celebrity chats, it'll have two investigative reports.

DOC.NOTE: $Adv23
For release Fri PMs, Nov. 23, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Penn & Teller's `Don't Try This At Home' - As If You Would
DOC.TEXT: Teller speaks! Penn is silent! Ha! Got your attention! Those two swindlers of sleight, those Houdinis of hustle, stick to their usual roles for their NBC special tonight: ``Penn & Teller: Don't Try This At Home!'' But for this interview, Teller speaks, Penn doesn't. Penn (last name Jillette; tall, wide, loud, boots, bracelets, funny haircut) usually handles the talking for their act. Teller (no last name, shorter, slighter, mild and innocent-eyed) is eloquently silent. His last speaking role on television was the 1987 made-for-cable movie ``Long Gone;'' before that, he acted in an episode of ``Miami Vice.'' He's usually the bemused, smiling object of their crazed, perilous magic. For the grand finale of their NBC show, Teller gets driven over by a 70,000-pound truckload of concrete blocks. Miraculously, he is not squished. ``It's something we always wanted to do,'' Teller said in a telephone interview from the daring duo's midtown Manhattan workshop. ``For five years we've been saying `Wouldn't it be fun to drive a truck over Teller?''' It is not a pretty sight. Even Teller admits he was a bit squeamish when the trick first was tested - on Penn & Teller's ``director of covert activities'' Robbie Libbon. ``I nearly jumped out of my skin,'' Teller said. It will give you the creeps, and the boys cling to their tradition of revealing how they do it. They also perform a beautifully choreographed illusion to music - then give away the secret of that, too. Penn performs a silent, very romantic fire-eating duet with the lovely model Carol Perkins, who ``learned fire-eating in about a half hour,'' Teller said. ``I've tried to learn fire-eating for about five years.'' There's also a great bit where Penn loudly declares that all magicians who produce animals onstage are wimps, and the two isolate themselves inside a glass booth and produce thousands of live bees. Honest. ``You learn to move very slowly and deliberately,'' Teller said. It's not really a trick, he explained. Bees sting only when they're protecting their nest or if they're pushed. Teller said he was stung only twice, while Teller got 20 stings. It is creepy in the extreme. ``We worked up to it gradually,'' Teller said. ``At first, we wore the full beekeeper's outfit, then just the headgear, then `OK, we'll take gloves off now, then we were covered in bug repellent. . .. By the time we got on the air, we thought part of the entertainment value for the audience was watching bees all over our heads and faces.'' The lads also took the precaution of testing themselves and their crew against the venom of a full range of stinging insects. Their guest, Jane Curtin, performs a classic sleight of hand with audience members. Her patter is warm and sweet until she's ``compelled'' to do a Penn & Teller-designed trick called ``The Infected Ear.'' She gets nasty. It's great. One cannot pigeonhole the art of Penn & Teller as comedy, horror, suspense, magic or ``the new vaudeville.'' Teller isn't interested in trying. ``Figuring that out isn't my job,'' he said. ``I do know a couple of things. One is that we're basically self-taught; we really aren't following anybody else's rules. We're doing stuff that Penn likes and I like. That's the only qualification. Penn likes it and I like it. ``We just put together what we thought was good without putting it into a classification, without worrying about the terminology,'' he said. And now for the silent portion of our interview, in which Penn (large, loud, funny hair) does not speak. Teller handed the phone to Penn. Penn remains silent. In the background, Teller can be heard shouting, ``He's smiling! He's nodding! I think he thinks you're an OK guy! Now I'm going to put his head underwater!'' What is Penn's expression under water, Teller? ``He's trying to do a bemused smile and it's not quite working.'' --- Elsewhere in television ... STILL CRAZY AFTER ALL THESE YEARS: Television never tires of giving us characters and situations that would play better in Looney Tunes - and certainly with a greater sense of realism. ``Broken Badges'' is one such. It aspires to be an action drama about a team of police on psychiatric leave from their jobs. This is reassuring. Imagine, emotionally disturbed people with guns AND badges! New Orleanians will wince at seeing Miguel Ferrer try to play a New Orleans policeman of Cajun ancestry who pronounces the term of enderament ``cher'' like the entertainer's name, instead of halfway between ``shay'' and ``sheh.'' And they'll scream when another supposed New Orleans policeman pronounces the city ``New Aw-LEENZ,'' instead of ``Noo Orlins,'' as the locals say it.

DOC.HEAD: Prison Beauty Shop Gives Inmates Reason to Feel Good
DOC.TEXT: The chatter resembles that of any beauty salon. Women tease each other about their ages and their graying hair as they sit under hair dryers and flip through timeworn magazines. Posters of the latest hairstyles cover the battered walls, and the pungent odor of the solution used for permanents fills the air. The tools of the beauty trade at the medium-security Florence-Crane Women's Facility are nothing special, but they're of some concern. Scissors, electric razors and chemicals can be dangerous - especially in the hands of convicted criminals. Some of these women are locked up for life. Some can receive no visitors. But still, inmates say, the prison beauty shop serves an essential purpose. ``Everyone feels better, even if they've had a bad day,'' said beautician Diane Carter, serving 20 years on drug and escape charges. ``It's just like going shopping - you get depressed and you go shopping.'' ``It's not a privilege. It's a necessity for a lot of us,'' said Sherron Butler, who is serving up to 14 years for writing bad checks and escape. ``We're also still human beings and if you love yourself, you're going to take care of yourself. When I got here, I said, `Great, they have a beauty shop. I can continue to be me.''' Butler was getting this season's favorite style, the $25 wave nouveau. In addition to the curl, she often comes in to have her hair colored - autumn mist is her shade - and to buy cocoa butter lotion. Rather than chip off her nail polish, she can spend a quarter to dip her fingers and toes in nail polish remover. Inmates can have nail polish outside the shop, but the remover contains alcohol and stays put. The shop has its regulars, but most inmates cut each other's hair in the housing units, where they're permitted to check out blunt-ended scissors. Each state prison has a hair care area where inmate barbers are supervised by a civilian cosmetologist, said Gail Light, a spokeswoman for the Michigan Department of Corrections. In federal prisons, basic haircuts are free, said Dan Dunne, assistant public information officer for the U.S. Bureau of Prisons in Washington, D.C. Inmates who want something special, like a perm or dye, can buy the materials at a commissary and bring them to the prison's cosmetology unit for application, he said. The beauty shop at the Florence-Crane facility is cramped. One authentic cosmetology chair is joined by a host of outdated barber equipment bought used or donated. Hairdryers line the wall near the window sill, where a newly arrived air conditioner blows comfort on feverish, summer days. Mildred Perry, one of four inmate beauticians, remembers converting the space from junk room to beauty shop when she was transferred to Florence-Crane in 1985. ``There was a desperate need for a beauty shop,'' said Perry, who is serving a life term for second-degree murder. ``We knew the self-esteem would go down. They didn't care about themselves any more. ``This was the only chair, there was one working spigot with cold water and one bucket. It just grew and grew. We had to get a crochet needle to pull the hair through the cap for the first frostin job we did.'' Most of the cosmetology unit's operating costs are covered by what they charge customers, and its prices are competitive with outside shops. A price list hangs near the rinse sink: $14 for ``jazzing color,'' $20 for a frosted perm, $6 for hot oil and condition treatment, $5 for a plain cut. Money never changes hands. Women contact the cosmetology unit for an appointment, and the civilian cosmetologist, who operates mostly as an observer, checks their accounts to make sure they have enough. The shop in the main prison is open two days a week, and the four prisoners serve about a dozen customers each day. An annex salon is open Saturdays. Some of the workers had cosmetology experience before being sent to the prison. Others picked it up in prison. Inmates have asked for a certification program so they'll be able to get cosmetology jobs when they leave prison, but there is no money to pay for it. The beauticians, who get $1.50 a day and a free hairdo a month, must hand in their nurse-like smocks and are searched before they leave work, said assistant deputy warden Terri Baker. No incidents other than minor thefts have been reported, probably because corrections officers and the civilian cosmetologist always are watching. Beautician Serena Gordon, serving a life term for second-degree murder, said she's never been threatened with violence by a customer who didn't like the way her hair turned out. She recalled a young woman with black hair who wanted it frosted. ``When I got done, she just started crying,'' Gordon said. ``She didn't realize it was going to make her look that old.'' Gordon also gave a professional bleach job to another inmate whose hair temporarily turned green. ``That time,'' she said, ``I cried.''

DOC.HEAD: Alleged Drug Barons Elected to Parliament
DOC.TEXT: An alleged drug baron and two men suspected of opium dealing are members of the new Parliament, creating speculation that Pakistan's already sluggish anti-drug campaign may founder. Officials say about 30 tons of heroin are shipped from Pakistan every year. Domestic and foreign narcotics officers have criticized successive governments for failing to stop the trade. ``They have not been able to successfully prosecute and imprison what you would call a major'' drug figure, a narcotics agent said, on condition of anonymity. The United States, frustrated by the lack of action, has threatened to cut off more than $500 million in economic and military aid that already has been frozen because of suspicion that Pakistan is developing nuclear weapons. Ayub Khan Afridi, said to be one of Pakistan's main drug traffickers, won a National Assembly seat in the Oct. 24 elections. At least two other successful candidates are suspected of large-scale involvement in the opium trade. A diplomat said, also on condition of anonymity: ``We've told them, `You have a handful in the National Assembly that everyone recognizes are ear-deep in the heroin trade. It's only going to get worse'. ``It's the National Assembly that passes the laws, and if criminals are influencing how the law is written, you can pass some pretty ineffective laws.'' In 1983, Afridi was convicted in absentia and sentenced to one year in jail after failing to show up in court to answer charges of drug trafficking. Records also show at least five outstanding arrest warrants on similar charges. Several anti-drug agencies in Pakistan and abroad have sought Afridi's arrest, but with no success. Afridi dismisses the allegations as a baseless slander campaign conducted by former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto during her 20 months in power. ``That's rubbish,'' said Zahid Sarfraz, interior minister in the caretaker government that replaced Ms. Bhutto when she was dismissed in August. Sarfraz, who was in charge of narcotics control, said the drug charges against Afridi had nothing to do with politics. Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's new government created a Narcotics Ministry and put Rana Chandar Singh in charge. Analysts doubt that Singh, a Hindu, will be able to penetrate the orthodox Moslem tribal country where the drug trade is based. The diplomat said: ``Perhaps that's why he got the job.'' Drug raids and arrests are made periodically, and some are impressive. Narcotics agents confiscated more than 3,800 pounds of heroin with an estimated street value of $130 million an 800 tons of hashish, chemicals used for making heroin and a cache of semiautomatic rifles and missile launchers. At least one person charged after the raid is a member of the Baluchistan provincial assembly and of the province's governing party. Such raids are highly publicized, but Pakistani and foreign narcotics officials say only small-time operators and couriers go to jail. The tribal area, where opium and heroin are produced, is a lawless strip of rough terrain along the border with Afghanistan where Pakistani authorities have little authority. As one narcotics agent described it: ``The tribal area is a sanctuary where they can operate virtually with impunity.'' Sarfraz, the former interior minister, found one of the outstanding arrest warrants for Afridi shortly before turning the ministry over to his successor, but could not order the arrest after he left office. In an interview, he said of Afridi: ``Is he bigger than the government of Pakistan? Either we let the name of the government of Pakistan be dragged through the mud or we arrest him.'' Although a spokesman for the Sharif government said Afridi's arrest was imminent, he apparently is back in the sanctuary of the tribal area.

DOC.HEAD: Pinochet Still Army Chief, but Political Power Fades
DOC.TEXT: Former President Augusto Pinochet still is the army commander, but has been losing political ground to Patricio Aylwin, the elected civilian who succeeded him. Even right-wing politicians who supported the 74-year-old general during his 16{ years of military rule, which ended in March, are saying he should stay out of politics. The annual revision of the armed forces high command this month gave Aylwin the opportunity for a clear demonstration of his political authority. For the first time since the political coup that brought him to power in 1973, the makeup of the high command was not determined by Pinochet alone. Aylwin vetoed the promotions of two generals. Pinochet challenged his right to do so but Aylwin was upheld by the General Comptroller's office, which rules on the legality of government decisions. Pinochet retained command of the army after leaving the presidency, under a clause in the 1980 constitution the military regime wrote, and Aylwin cannot fire him. Before the transfer of power, aides to Aylwin predicted the general would retain great political authority and threaten Chile's newly restored democratic rule. That has not happened. Most observers acknowledge Pinochet's power has faded, for several reasons: a financial scandal involving army officers, Aylwin's skillful handling of relations with the military and the disciplined, non-political attitude of the other service commanders. In occasional comments to reporters, Pinochet insists he now is ``totally out of politics,'' but some of his public actions suggest otherwise. Last May, he publicly criticized Aylwin's establishment of a commission to investigate human rights abuses under the military regime. In response, Aylwin summoned the general to the presidential palace and rejected the ``political connotations'' of his remarks. Later, Pinochet caused an international incident by saying the German army was made up in part of ``marijuana smokers, drug addicts, longhairs, hommosexuals and unionists.'' After Aylwin condemned the comments, Pinochet withdrew them and apologized. On Sept. 11, the 17th anniversary of the coup, Pinochet caused a political uproar by saying he would do it again under the same circumstances. Even some old supporters are putting distance between themselves and the general, saying he has has no legitimate political role. ``Gen. Pinochet is no longer a political option in Chile,'' said Sebastian Pinera, a leading right-wing senator. Another senator, who was an ambassador under Pinochet, sided with Aylwin in the dispute over the high command. Pro-goverment politicians who once feared the continued presence of Pinochet as army commander now say they may have been wrong. ``Pinochet is not yet checkmated, but he is nearing the end of his match,'' said Camilio Escalona, a Socialist congressman. Loyalty to Pinochet and support for him are believed to be firm in the army, but only in his militare capacity. Aylwin told an interviewer on state television he does not think he will have trouble with the army, and said of Pinochet: ``I understand that he who ruled the country as an absolute master for nearly 17 years now has trouble accommodating to his new role, subordinated to the president of the republic and to the minister of defense.'' The conflict with Aylwin on the high command caught Pinochet in a weakened position. A congressional commission is investigating an army payment to one of his sons of the equivalent of $3 million, apparently for the purchase of a metallurgy plant. Newspapers have reported in recent weeks on an illegal savings and loan organization in which several army officers participated. Many Chileans expect a decisive moment in relations between Pinochet and the civilian government in February, when the commission investigating human rights abuses issues its final report. Trials are expected to result, many of them involving military officers. Before leaving office, Pinochet said repeatedly he would not accept trials of military men on human rights issues.

DOC.HEAD: When Bad News is Good News
DOC.TEXT: Yes, there is a future for homeowners distressed by falling housing prices, and oddly the good news is the bad news. The latest report on housing starts was even weaker than glum forecasters had anticipated, falling to an annual rate of just 1.04 million units in October, a level not seen since the deep recession of 1981-1982. It was also the ninth straight month of contraction in the rate, which has fallen 27 percent this year alone, bringing the latest level of new housing construction to half the rate that existed in 1978. That's only part of the bad news. Among the other elements of a miserable housing picture are declining economic confidence, layoffs and job insecurity, and various unknowns associated with a recessionary economy. The good news is that housing and real estate are cyclical, the down cycle generally creating conditions for the next up cycle. When current construction fails to meet demographic needs it tends to strengthen future demand. That situation may not exist now, because too much housing may have been built in the 1980s and because growth in the lower age level of homebuyers has slowed. But should the low rate persist, it could lead to future shortages. Almost every homeowner understands the supply-demand factor because it made such an impression on 1980 markets. Denied a chance to buy because of high interest rates in the 1970s, homebuyers swamped the market in the mid-1980s. The supply-demand equation was upset by the rush of buyers, which in some regions reached levels never seen before. As so often occurs in housing, builders caught up with the demand just as it was headed back down again. If the current downturn persists well into next year, a change in the equation could occur again. Artificial incentives to build, such as big tax deductions, have been removed from the marketplace, making it a less attractive area of enterprise. It could mean starts will be slow to rebound. Still another factor might develop - it is being widely forecast - in the form of lower interest rates. History has shown a very direct correlation between falling interest rates and rising housing sales. How much rates are likely to fall is now one of the biggest guessing games in the entire marketplace. Historically, a slowdown of economic activity brings down interest rates, too, but don't expect any plunge. Among the reasons why: - The United States has borrowed a lot of money from foreigners, and it behooves the Federal Reserve to be wary of the exodus of dollars because of low returns. - Continuing inflation fears. - Too much existing debt. But what seems to be a growing number of economists are convinced that America has had its fill of debt, that the desire for it has been muted by the dangers, and that borrowing as a way of life will decline. One economist, Robert Barbera of Sherson Lehman Bros., even foresees an ``anti-debt environment.'' He refers to ``debt's demise'' and ``the ending of the 30-year debt cycle.'' If so, interest rates should fall. The news has indeed been bad for homeowners who cannot sell their houses or cannot afford their interest payments. But if the past is a criterion and the forecasts can be believed, better times are coming.

DOC.HEAD: City's Last Family Farm Hangs on in Queens
DOC.TEXT: John Klein weeds a row of beets and white radishes with a turn-of-the-century, wood-and-iron push hoe. Nearby, tall zucchini plants sprout limp yellow blossoms. His mother, Barbara, sells corn, cucumbers, tomatoes and fruit to passers-by from a stand on the street. This is New York City's last family farm, two green acres in the Fresh Meadows section of Queens, surrounded by small brick apartment houses, an elementary school, paved ball court, and a broad street noisy with buses and traffic from nearby expressways. ``A couple of weeks ago, these guys from Florida got off the Clearview Expressway and came down the street asking directions, and they couldn't believe there was a farm in the middle of Queens. They thought they were in the Twilight Zone,'' said Klein, 25, a fourth-generation farmer. The two acres - slightly bigger than a square city block, with a chain-link fence on three sides and a lawn and tall oaks in front - are all that's left of a 100-acre spread that was sold off piece by piece over the years. The Kleins grow beets, carrots, scallions, radishes, basil, dill, parsley, cucumbers, squash, and kohlrabies - ``stuff that doesn't need that much room to grow,'' Klein explained. The rows are so short, he has to weed them by hand. ``It's too small to use a tractor,'' he said. ``By the time you got there, you'd have to turn it around.'' But the family also grows corn, melons and produce that needs more space on 100 acres in Riverhead, on Long Island's eastern tip. It's trucked in each day to the farm stand. Open July to November, seven days a week from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m., the farm stand on 195th Street and 73rd Avenue does a brisk business. ``In Queens, to find a farmer's market, this is really an oasis,'' said Sylvia Ehrlich as she examined tomatoes. ``I come here all the time - the stuff is delicious,'' agreed Michael Morache, who was buying zucchinis. Freshness is key. ``I go out and pick it in the morning and by the end of the day, it's home in their refrigerator,'' said Klein. ``We run out and pick the basil and dill and parsley right away for people because if you leave it out for a half-hour, it gets wilted.'' His great-grandfather, Adam, began farming in Fresh Meadows in the 1890s. His great-aunts, Margaret and Stella, live in two brick houses on the remaining two acres. Why keep the Queens land, when the family owns 100 acres in Riverhead? ``It's definitely a tradition, but it's making a living also,'' said Klein. ``If you go out to Riverhead, on every corner there's a farmstand. But we're the last ones here.'' Certainly Queens is better known as home to the Mets, Archie Bunker and 2 million of the city's 7.5 million residents than as an agricultural community. But Queens, like the other four boroughs, has a rich farming past dating to the 1600s. Only in the 1800s did industry and housing begin to replace open space around the city. Narrow, winding streets in Lower Manhattan recall cowpaths. Bleecker Street in Greenwich Village harks back to the Bleecker Farm of colonial times. In the 1830s, trains chugged ``through miles of rocky wasteland overrun by pigs and goats'' from what is now Little Italy up to Harlem, according to the Works Progress Administration Guide to New York City. Small farms - called truck farms because their produce was trucked into urbanized areas to be sod - remained common in Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island and the Bronx until after World War II, when developers gobbled up land to build housing. Henry Ludder, the Queens borough historian, recalled cutting across vegetable fields as he walked home from school in Bayside, Queens, in the early 1940s. ``I can remember pulling a carrot or a beet out of the ground, rubbing the dirt off on my pants and chewing it as I went along,'' he said. About 20 farmhouses dating from 1679 through 1871 around the city are designated landmarks; most are owned by historical societies. Two - the Queens County Farm Museum in Floral Park, and the Decker Farm, owned by the Staten Island Historical Society - remain working farms. But the Klein enterprise is the last family owned farm within city limits. Even the Klein farm in Riverhead is one of a vanishing breed. ``I imagine another 25 years, Riverhead will be like here, and you'll be out there writing about the last farm,'' said Klein's father, also John, 47. After Adam Klein sold most of the Queens property, he bought farmland in Hicksville, Long Island, and then was pushed out further east to Melville, and again out to Riverhead. ``I guess we can't go too much further or else we'll be in the ocean,'' said the younger Klein. ``There's no farms in Hicksville now and there's only four or five farms left out in Melville and property is worth a million dollars an acre out there, so the guys holding it are just dumb,'' his father said. Would he consider selling the two acres in Queens? ``If I didn't want to farm anymore, I'd just plant it with grass, put a big swimming pool in the back,'' he said. ``If you don't have to sell it, why sell it?''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tues AMs, Nov. 27

For release Wed AMs, Nov. 28, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Gossip-Loving James Beard Heats Up Foodies' Gossip Lines
DOC.TEXT: James Beard, often called the dean of American food, rose early most days. Not to get to the markets or his stove, but to talk on the telephone - a morning constitutional of gossip that could last two hours. Now Beard himself, five years after his death at 81, is at the center of a roiling kettle of gossip. Fermenting the gossip is a pair of biographies, both a tribute to his pivotal role in the development of an American cuisine. One of the books is a celebration; the other is a portrait ``warts and all.'' ``There is a `bonfire of the foodies' quality about this,'' said Robert Clark, who is writing a third biography of Beard. ``These are all good-hearted people who are competing to sit on his throne and then competing for status and stature in the food business.'' Beard was the genius behind the ``discovery'' of American cooking, reveling in the fine preparation of simple, local ingredients - the same qualities that have become watchwords of good eating in this country. Many people who knew him called him a ``walking encyclopedia'' of gastronomy. Food, he preached, should always be fun. He gave up hope of a career in the opera after nodes developed on his vocal cords, and turned to acting, but soon found few parts for a man his size (6-foot-4 and 200 to 300 pounds), according to Evans Jones' book, ``Epicurean Delight.'' So he brought drama to an early love - food. ``Like theater, offering food to people is a matter of showmanship, and no matter how simple the performance, until you do it well, with love and originality, you have a flop on your hands,'' he once wrote. Stylish and outgoing, Beard also had a remarkable ability to attract all sorts of people willing to help him cook, write, organize his life and, in later years, get around. ``James gave to everybody; but the bargain implied giving in return,'' wrote Barbara Kafka, the editor of the other Beard book, ``The James Beard Celebration.'' ``People would do unbelievable things for Jim in work and in personal service, things he accepted with such ease and lack of self-consciousness that any notion of burden was eschewed,'' she wrote. Beard traveled frequently and found friends, students and colleagues everywhere he spent time: Oregon, California, New York, London and France. There were cooks, restaurateurs, writers, childhood friends, theater, movie and opera people. He wrote 22 books and countless newspaper and magazine articles, consulted for restaurants, catered, opened cooking schools, and was a spokesman for kitchen equipment and food products. He was a pioneer of backyard cooking and of television cooking shows, though he lacked Julia Child's affinity for the camera. ``To oversimplify matters, he was the person who almost single-handedly transformed America's eating habits from salt and pepper and ketchup on the table to much more complex pleasures,'' said George Lang, owner of the New York restaurant Cafe des Artistes, and also a food columnist and friend of Beard's for 35 years. Until Beard, cooking in America was essentially European, said Kafka, whose book is full of reminiscences and recipes from those who knew Beard. Her book is an invitation to join Beard and his friends and their food, and was published to raise money for the James Beard Foundation, established four years ago in Beard's Greenwich Village townhouse by Child, Peter Kump, its president, and others. The foundation offers workshops, book parties, dinners and exhibits of food photography and art. A scholarship program is expected to begin granting money next year. ``Both books are really quite wonderful in their own way,'' Lang said. ``The question is what you're interested in. If you're interested in recipes for your main course, then Barbara Kafka's book will be for you, and the anecdotes will be dessert.'' The opposite is true for Jones' book. Clark, who edits the Journal of Gastronomy, said his book will include no recipes, but will be ``the story of American food over a 100-year period as told through the life of James Beard.'' Beard grew up an only child in Oregon, where his mother had run a hotel and where she instilled in him her fascination with fine food. ``I cooked fairly seriously by the time I was 14 and 15,'' Beard is quoted as saying in Kafka's book. ``I never really learned. I had a funny feeling that I could take something I ate and reproduce it - like a musician with music.'' It was a time Beard also documented, in ``Delights and Prejudices,'' his 1964 memoirs. At least in part, Beard's efforts to write a sequel inspired Jones and Kafka. ``He apparently tried to break his writing block with several people,'' said Kump, a Beard friend who opened Peter Kump's New York Cooking School. Jones' wife and editor, Judith Jones of Alfred A. Knopf Inc., said Beard made some tapes with her husband, which became material for his book. And Kafka's book begins with a transcript of a tape he made with her. Beard the gossip might have delighted in Beard the topic of gossip, friends said. Jones writes of friendships that fell apart, business difficulties and the effects of Beard's domineering mother. Some people were unhappy that both books mention Beard's homosexuality, Clark said. In Kafka's book, Beard himself brings it up, in a tape he made, saying, ``By the time I was 7, I knew that I was gay. I think it's time to talk about that how.'' Jones has heard the accusation that his book is homophobic, perhaps in part because the subject is introduced in a footnote. But he insisted he was merely being discreet, and that Beard's sexuality is irrelevant. ``There is a strong feeling of wanting to protect his memory and wanting to inherit his reputation on the part of a lot of people,'' Clark said. ``He made people feel like he was totally theirs. And I think the world is full of people who feel that they knew him best.'' ``We didn't quite know how sticky that would be,'' Mrs. Jones said. Kafka won't discuss Jones' book. Asked why, she said, ``Have you read it to the end?'' In the final chapter, Jones describes her as a writer who at the time she and Beard met, may have known more about ``courts of intrigue than she did about the world of food.'' ``I haven't read what Barbara calls her book,'' Jones said. But beyond the gossip and the disagreements, Kump said, it's important that so much is being written about Beard. ``Jim made a tremendously significant contribution to gastronomy in this country,'' Kump said. And, he noted, all but two of Beard's own books are back in print.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Wed AMs, Nov. 28
