DOC.HEAD: Golden State Praying For Rain, But Bracing for Fifth Drought Year
DOC.TEXT: The first few storms of the rainy season have arrived in California, bringing a little moisture and a torrent of hope that the state will dodge a disastrous fifth year of drought. The four-year drought, the worst in 60 years in some areas, already has cost the nation's most populous state hundreds of millions of dollars in losses, hitting farmers the hardest. Worst-case scenarios for another dry year call for business shutdowns, heavy crop damage, wildlife losses and devastating brush fires. Lawmakers also envision one of the fiercest water wars in state history between cities and farmers. The state's top weather forecasters have been running numbers through their computers all summer, and the best they can come up with is that nobody knows what the winter will bring. ``The only thing left is to appeal to the higher being to bless us with rain,'' said Ralph Klages, a nursery owner in the Los Angeles suburb of Monterey Park. ``It's frustrating and it's scary, because we have a lot to lose.'' The rainy season, which began Nov. 1, has gotten off to an unsettling start. A series of mid-November storms people hoped would dump lots of rain and snow petered out, leaving precipitation levels in most areas well below seasonal averages. Even in the absence of storm clouds, many Californians see a silver lining. Water experts say the drought might accelerate water management plans to avoid the day fast-growing California wants more water than it can get. But many of the solutions - from additional water storage to desalination plants - are too far in the future to help most Californians, who are bracing for the worst if the winter of 1991 comes up dry. In the Southern California mountains, ski lift operators who have had to make do with small snow packs in the past worry that shrinking water supplies could even keep them from making fake snow. ``We haven't had a good snow winter in a few years,'' said Monica Bandows with Bear Mountain Ski Resort near Big Bear Lake. ``But now there is a chance that if the lake falls below a certain level, we'll no longer be able to pull water out for man-made snow.'' Ron Klievoneit, who operates French Gulch Marina on Lake Isabella in Kern County, said business has declined 25 percent since the lake level dropped. Some store owners have gone out of business, he said. ``A lot of them have not had enough of a cushion and have gone defunct,'' said Klievoneit. ``We've owned this place for nearly 10 years. We've been successful at it. And I will just have to find ways to be successful for years to come.'' Farmers also could have to find a way to get through another dry year. Agriculture suffered an estimated $480 million in drought-related losses this year, according to the state Department of Water Resources. In California, farmers get their water from several sources, including their own wells and state and federal water projects. Unless the 1991 water year is wetter than last season, farmers could have their government water supplies cut by one-half to two-thirds, federal and state officials say. ``Tree crop farmers are having particular problems,'' said Mike Henry, spokesman for the California Farm Bureau Federation in Sacramento. ``Last year, they started seeing trees beginning to stress. The roots are searching for water and they're not finding any. The tree itself starts to change its metabolism to survive and not produce fruit.'' Urban residents also face water cutbacks. State deliveries could drop as much as 13 percent and federal deliveries could decline 25 percent to 50 percent, officials said. Some cities already have imposed rationing, most notably Santa Barbara on the hard-hit Central Coast, where some residents paint their dead lawns green and wash their cars with dry rags. That area has no access to government water supplies and relies solely on local sources. Los Angeles, the state's largest city, had voluntary water conservation this summer. After early success, the water use inched back up near the end of summer, and mandatory rationing next summer could be imposed. A cut in water supplies to industrial users would be devastating. A 24 percent reduction could cost Los Angeles industry $25 billion and 350,000 jobs, according to estimates by William S. Wade, a consultant to the Metropolitan Water District, a Southern California water broker. Electronics manufacturers, for instance, rely heavily on water, and even a small cutback in their already tight supply could force them to reduce production. With water in short supply, the competition could turn ugly. Some lawmakers say Southern Californians could lobby state and federal water authorities to pressure central California farmers into giving up more of their supplies. ``It could get very cannibalistic for awhile,'' said Assemblyman Jim Costa, D-Fresno. Humans aren't the only ones who suffer in a drought. In the Angeles National Forest, the drought is hurting wildlife by drying up water sources and making the plants less nutritious. Mule deer are having fewer fawns, black bears are coming down from the hills to the campgrounds looking for food and water, and smaller, less mobile animals such as wood rats and ground squirrels are dying, said forest biologist Bill Brown. Animals also have gone beyond the campgrounds and into neighborhoods. In San Diego County, people have reported foxes eating cat food, raccoons slurping pool water and bobcats lurking around jogging trails. The dry brush also increases the possibility of wildfire. The state had one of its worst fires in history this summer when hundreds of homes were destroyed in a Santa Barbara area fire. Water officials say they have no idea how much precipitation the state can expect this winter. But even a normal winter won't solve all the state's problems, they say. Experts say the state needs a wetter-than-normal winter, and even a second normal winter. ``If we get a normal water year, we can make all the state water deliveries,'' said state Water Resources engineer Bob Fingado. ``However, that would leave our reservoirs at the same level, and that's low.'' And even after the state gets out of the current drought, California's problems aren't over. The population explosion is straining the basic water system. Officials now are drafting long-term water plans, including better conservation, improving the coordination between water agencies and finding ways to reuse water. California could become the leader in building plants that make sea water drinkable. Although a very expensive source of fresh water, desalination facilities are under construction or in the planning stages in Los Angeles, Santa Barbara and Marin counties. ``This drought should really serve to be a wake-up call for all of us,'' said Byron Buck, director of water resources planning for San Diego County.

DOC.HEAD: Beijing Prepares for Exercise in Socialist Democracy
DOC.TEXT: The campaign season for local government offices in Beijing opened with plenty of hoopla. The city Communist Party chief shook hands at the main department store. A brass band played. Vans with loudspeakers cruised city streets and, the official Xinhua News Agency reported, volunteers gave out 1 million pamphlets. Only the candidates were missing. They are chosen weeks later, but there is no suspense for voters. Only members or supporters of the ruling party are nominated. Incumbents who supported last year's pro-democracy movement already have been purged. ``It's like taking part in a play ... performed for the Communist Party,'' a woman voter said, on condition of anonymity. ``We don't put much value on our voting rights.'' For the Communists, the elections are a deadly serious play, the basis of their claim to be the people's choice. All other officials are appointed in some fashion, so China's assertion of democracy rests entirely upon popular elections held every three years for the lowest-level representative bodies: district people's congresses in urban areas and county people's congresses in the countryside. The congresses make no laws and function mainly as conduits for passing citizen complaints and ideas to higher levels. Beijing has 18 such congresses with a total of 17,000 delegates. Other parts of the country held elections in the spring, but balloting in Beijing was delayed until Dec. 26. The reason given was that everyone was too busy getting ready for the Asian Games, held in September. Officials also may have wanted to keep the elections from coinciding with the anniversary of Beijing's massive pro-democracy demonstrations, which the army crushed in June 1989. Among other things, the marchers wanted more say in picking government officials. Voters say they have little part even in choosing the local congresses. ``God knows how the candidates are chosen,'' the woman said. After the single burst of citywide publicity that opened the election season in late October, preparations reverted to closed-door committees that take nominations from such official groups as the Communist Youth League and All-China Women's Association. A group of at least 10 voters can put a candidate forward, but few do. The candidate would be unable to organize publicity activities and would have little chance of success. The law allows two candidates for each seat, but voters say there usually is just one. Because there are no competing parties, television ads or debates, campaigns are placid events. It is not mandatory to vote, but failure to do so is frowned upon and would be noticed. Chinese officials insist the system is more democratic than multiparty elections in the West, which they say keeps power in the hands of the rich. ``Our election rights may not be the same as in the West, but equality is a basic principle,'' Xu Jingyu, chairman of the election commission in Beijing's Chaoyang District, said in an interview. He acknowleged not everyone can run for office, only those with correct ideological views, but said this was in keeping with the constitution. ``Delegates have to be able to represent the views of the masses,'' he said. ``How can someone who opposes the (party's) four basic principles do that?'' The emphasis on ideological correctness is especially strong this year, in keeping with the country's conservative turn after the democracy movement was crushed. A public notice addressed to ``comrade voters'' in the Chaoyang District called for vigilence against ``bourgeois liberals'' who might seek to sabotage the election. There have been no reports of any such plots. ``Bourgeois liberals'' are people who favor Western-style democracy with more than one party. Xu was unable to explain why some people accused of being bourgeois liberals were elected to past people's congresses. The most prominent example is astrophysicist Fang Lizhi's wife, Li Shuxian, a physics teacher at Beijing University who shares her husband's dissident views and was elected in 1987. She was expelled from the Haidian District People's Congress in 1989, soon after police accused her and Fang of counterrevolutionary crimes. They since have been allowed to go to the West. ``People change,'' Xu said. ``Maybe when she was elected, she didn't have this problem.''

DOC.HEAD: French Women Fight For Law Against Sexual Harassment
DOC.TEXT: In the Middle Ages, French feudal lords bedded the wives of their serfs and called it a nobleman's right. Nowadays, male executives prey on female employees, but some women are fighting back. It is a new, difficult battle for French women, 70 percent of whom work outside the home. According to a survey by the European Community's executive commission, 36 percent of working women in France reported being harassed sexually by bosses or co-workers. ``Sexual harassment has been around for centuries, yet it's still a taboo subject,'' said Marie-Victoire Louis, a sociologist and co-founder of the Association to Fight Violence Against Women at Work. ``Any woman who brings charges of sexual harassment against her employer runs the risk of being ridiculed, isolated, not believed, and, naturally, of being fired, if she hasn't been already.'' Prospects of better treatment on the job are improving for women, who make up 41 percent of the work force. The National Assembly is working on legislation, expected to pass in the spring, that would make sexual harassment a crime punishable by large fines and prison terms of two to five years. The government agency that monitors women's rights is looking for ways of changing labor laws to enable inspectors to intervene in harassment cases and make employers responsible for the security of female workers. ``Only the employer can put an end to sexual harassment,'' Mrs. Louis said. ``By law, employers are required to provide working conditions which respect the employees' health and safety, and that includes an environment free of sexual harassment.'' She said the campaign against sexual harassment got an unexpected boost from a satirical film about two female postal workers who turn the system to their advantage. ``Promotion Canape'' (Couch Promotion), written and directed by Didier Kaminka, has attracted about 1 million viewers since it opened in October. Xavier Gelin, the producer, said negotiations were under way for a Hollywood remake. ``For me, sexual harassment can be defined as repeated advances that end up turning into blackmail,'' Kaminka said in an interview. ``Sexual harassment is rampant when there's high unemployment and young, inexperienced women without specialized training are afraid to lose their jobs.'' Kaminka said he spent four months inside the postal service, where he found the expression ``couch promotion'' to be part of the vernacular. One scene shows actress Grace de Capitani obtaining a desirable apartment from the postal service's housing administrator only after promising sex. ``Officials said publicly that everything in the film is fiction, but I can tell you it's all true,'' Kaminka said. Mrs. Louis criticized the film for playing down the violence that accompanies many acts of sexual harassment. In her small office in eastern Paris, she pointed to a pile of dossiers of women who had been abused verbally and physically, beaten and raped by their male employers. She described Mrs. A., a dental assistant who submitted to her boss's repeated advances because she had an unemployed husband and a baby. When she finally rejected him, he reduced her salary, bullied her and slapped her. Charged with assault, he denied sexual harassment and said Mrs. A. had consented to his attentions. She later withdrew the charges in exchange for a letter of dismissal and 40,000 francs ($8,000) in damages. Another case involved Mrs. B., 24, hired by a town official who abused, threatened, raped and blackmailed her for two years. Mrs. B. finally went to authorities and the official was charged with several sex and assault offenses involving other women, including a minor. Despite a statement of support from the mayor, the official was convicted and sent to jail. He was released, however, and the case is still pending. Fanny-pinching, skirt-chasing males have been French theater fare for centuries, from Moliere's Tartuffe to the heroes of slapstick boulevard comedies, but Mrs. Louis said: ``There's nothing funny about the abuse of an employer's power.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Wednesday AMs Nov 28

DOC.HEAD: Chicken Growers Say `Feudal' Contracts Keep Them From Industry's Riches
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Americans eat more poultry every year, and the big chicken processing companies have been reporting record earnings. But at the production end of this booming business, many family farmers who raise the birds say they're struggling to get by. Now they're banding together for bargaining clout and fighting the companies in court - and winning millions. ---

Six weeks after delivering thousands of day-old chicks to Forest Powell's poultry houses, a ConAgra truck rumbles back to pick up the flock, now grown to four-pound broilers. The process usually is simple. The truck returns to the processing plant, pulls onto a scale, is unloaded and then weighed again. The difference determines how much Powell gets paid. It also can help decide whether he gets another flock, whether he stays in business. Though his birds seemed as plump as ever a few years ago, Powell's flock weights were mysteriously falling - or so the records from the ConAgra scales said. He couldn't sleep for worrying about the debt he owed on his three chicken houses and equipment, more than $80,000 at the time. Powell, consistently a top-rated grower, was told he'd get just one more batch of chicks, one six-week chance to save his livelihood. Under his contract, he'd have no appeal. ``I could have just lost my whole farm,'' he said. Again and again, he and his wife, Dorothy, pored over the company weight charts, ``and finally we come up with it.'' What they came up with was evidence of systematic underweighing, evidence amplified in the trial one year ago of a fraud suit filed by Powell and 267 other growers for ConAgra, the nation's second-largest chicken processor. Witnesses testified that ConAgra workers hiked the weights of ``empty'' trailers with such tricks as loading them with heavy steel drainage grates or standing on the scales. A U.S. District Court jury in Dothan, Ala., awarded the growers $13.6 million, including $9 million in punitive damages. It was a case, said Judge Myron Thompson, of ``the rich seeking to get richer by stealing from those who could least afford to be stolen from.'' ConAgra has appealed. That isn't the only example of the rich seeking to get richer at the expense of independent growers, according to some agriculture officials and growers themselves. Companies sometimes lure farmers into making huge investments in chicken houses with ads boasting of easy money waiting to be made. But the reality of the business today is that contracts afford growers no protection against unexpected expenses ordered by the company, such as extra fans, and no protection against sudden firing, they say. Contracts that companies offer to chicken growers generally run flock-to-flock and permit termination without stated cause, often with as little as 20 days' notice. ``What you've got,'' said Vreeland G. Johnson, a lawyer for the growers, ``is a feudal system, almost. These people are at the total whim and mercy of the processors.'' Consider: - Underweighing and other alleged inequities have prompted complaints from North Carolina to Texas, the heart of the broiler-growing belt. ``Everybody has the same problems, everywhere,'' said Mary Clouse, who edits Poultry Grower News, a newsletter. ``It's David and Goliath.'' - State agriculture authorities in Florida, Texas and Minnesota have zeroed in on contract problems. ``An oligopoly is developing in which a handful of mega-companies will soon control over 43 percent of the total U.S. poultry meat products market,'' said a January study by the Texas Department of Agriculture. - A lawsuit by fired growers in Louisiana, which ended in a sealed cash settlement, accused ConAgra of maintaining ``oppressive and one-sided'' contracts. The suit said that after growers invested in chicken houses, ConAgra imposed contract terms that hadn't been previously agreed on. It also contended the company's standards for production were ``ill-defined.'' ConAgra contended the fired growers had performed poorly. ``We have and have had for a number of years good grower relationships throughout the country,'' said Lynn Phares, ConAgra's vice president for public relations. ``We want happy growers. The vast, vast majority do indicate satisfaction.'' - In Arkansas, the leading chicken-producing state, 200 growers turned out in October to organize for better contracts. The meeting in Nashville, Ark., was a first. ``Growers have been afraid to speak out for fear of being laid off,'' said Bill Fritts, a leader of the group. Arthur Gaskins, president of the Northeast Florida Broiler Growers Association, was one who spoke out and got laid off by Cargill, the Minnesota-based agribusiness conglomerate. Gaskins, who had grown chickens for Cargill for nearly two decades, charged that he was cut off in retaliation for a suit the growers group filed alleging weight falsifications. In April, U.S. District Judge John H. Moore II in Jacksonville, Fla., ordered Gaskins reinstated. The judge found ``substantial likelihood'' that the growers would succeed in their claims against Cargill, including unlawful ``coercion, intimidation and discrimination against agricultural producers based on the exercise of their legal rights.'' No trial date has been set in the case, attorneys said. ``We have done nothing to defraud or manipulate growers,'' said Greg Lauser, a spokesman for Cargill, which is appealing the injunction and denies intentional wrongdoing. Some improper weighing was done by ``low-level employees'' who since have been fired, he said, adding that growers were compensated, with interest. But Gaskins maintains low-level employees are not the problem. ``The whole contract system is wrote to benefit the integrator. It's a take-it-or-leave-it contract,'' the farmer said. The industry denies being unfair and insists that relations between companies and all but a minority of growers are satisfactory and mutually profitable. ``It's not one of these deals where you get rich in a hurry, but it's been a very stable type of situation where, whether the market goes up or down, the guy on the farm gets his money - so the market risk is taken out for him,'' said Bill Roenigk, vice president of the National Broiler Council, a Washington-based poultry industry group. ``We have a waiting list for growers,'' noted Ms. Phares, the ConAgra spokeswoman. Grower advocates agree that the job can make money, especially for growers whose chicken house loans are paid and who operate in areas such as Maryland, where they have a choice of processors to contract with. But most areas of the country don't have much competition among the chicken processors, so growers are left at the mercy of one firm. They say their risk comes when they sign 15-year mortgages on chicken houses that can cost $65,000 each, or make expensive company-mandated improvements with no guarantees beyond a seven-week contract. Lengthening contract periods to match growers' mortgage periods was among reforms proposed by the Texas Agriculture Department study. The report also called for grievance procedures, bonded weighers and ``flexible contracts with a set minimum operating margin of profit.'' It found growers' return on a 20,000-bird flock ranged from $579 to $4,835. But money was not the biggest problem the study found. Growers ``have no due process ... and they don't have any recourse and they don't have many rights,'' said the Texas Agriculture Department's Richard Salmon.

DOC.HEAD: ANDALUSIA, Ala.: Richard Salmon.
DOC.TEXT: In August, a reform law took effect in Minnesota, mandating that companies give 180 days notice and compensation for cancellation of an agricultural contract that required an investment of $100,000 or more. It also established a state office to investigate complaints and settle disputes. The Minnesota law apparently is the first of its kind. Florida legislators considered a bill after the Gaskins case that would have required 60 days termination notice. After hearing testimony from both sides, including some growers who said they were happy with present contracts, a committee shelved the bill. But state Sen. Karen Thurman, the chairwoman, said it would be reintroduced if companies don't make changes. ``You really don't want to get involved with free enterprise,'' she said. ``But at the same time you want to make it fair.'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Christopher Sullivan is the AP's Southeast regional reporter, based in Atlanta.

DOC.HEAD: `I Lost My Vehicle, My House, My Land'
With BC-Chicken Feuds
DOC.TEXT: Terry Howell figures he got nothing out of the chicken-growing business except some hard-learned lessons. ``I lost everything I had,'' said Howell, 32, who borrowed about $100,000 at age 19 to set himself up with chicken houses, equipment, a pickup truck and a trailer home for himself and his new wife. ``I lost my vehicle, my house, my land. Everything.'' He and his wife divorced ``because of the money problems.'' At one point, he said, they pawned their television for cash to buy groceries. When he went into the chicken business, Howell was following his father, who cosigned on his loan. The younger Howell insists he built chicken houses and conducted his business just as required by the company he contracted with, ConAgra. He blames his failure on underweighing of the flocks he raised. He is one of 268 chicken growers who sued ConAgra and won $13.6 million last year. ConAgra has appealed, denying any intentional wrongdoing and saying it compensated growers fairly when the weighing mistakes were discovered. Howell would like to use his share of the award, which averaged nearly $51,000 for each grower, to go to college ``and pick up something that I can make good money at. ... I was totally relying on the chicken business.'' Even without weighing problems, such reliance is a mistake, grower advocates say. Farmers considering the business should be skeptical, they say, of company promises. A Perdue Farms ad published last year in a Maryland newspaper announced in large type: ``This Investment Comes Complete With a $218,000 Security Blanket.'' Perdue spokesman Brian Taws said the figure represents revenue for 444 production weeks - more than eight years. He declined to comment on complaints about the ad. Gregg Wilbanks, who runs a Louisiana financial consulting firm for farmers, spoke to potential chicken house investors at a recent meeting sponsored by a bank. ``A lot of people had the idea they could quit work and make a lot of money,'' he said. But on a typical loan for a chicken house, Wilbanks calculates $11,750 in annual payments to subtract from $18,000 revenue. Other expenses will leave the farmer about $1,500 annually per house, he said. Although business tax deductions can raise the bottom line, Wilbanks said, ``It's not a full-time job unless you've got 15 or 20 houses. ... It's a good sideline income.''

DOC.HEAD: Sky Isn't Falling for Chicken Business
With BC-Chicken Feuds
DOC.TEXT: Every week, 115 million chickens are slaughtered to feed the U.S. appetite for cordon bleu, McNuggets and everything in between, according to the National Broiler Council, a poultry industry group. Driven largely by a demand for lower-cholesterol, lower-fat meat, poultry consumption has grown to 73 pounds a year per person, up from 49.7 pounds a decade ago, said Bill Roenigk, vice president for the Washington-based council. Beef consumption has fallen during the same period from 76.4 pounds per person to a projected 67.4 pounds this year. The top 10 broiler chicken producing states, in order, are Arkansas, Georgia, Alabama, North Carolina, Mississippi, Texas, Delaware, Maryland, California and Virginia. About 25,000 farmers raise the chickens, nearly all under contracts with processing companies. Tyson Foods is by far the largest processor, handling 75 million of the 400 million pounds processed weekly, the broiler council said. The next largest are ConAgra, 30 million pounds; Gold Kist, 25 million; Perdue, 25 million; and Pilgrim's Pride, 15 million. Cargill ranks 21st at 4.5 million pounds per week.

DOC.HEAD: Actor Playing `The Flash' Wanted More Substance Than a Red Suit
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: When he was cast in the CBS series ``The Flash,'' John Wesley Shipp said he had second thoughts about playing a fantasy superhero in bright tights. ``One of the issues I wanted to address before I took the job was how much time he spent out of the costume,'' said Shipp, who was selected from about 50 actors who auditioned. ``When I first heard about `The Flash,' I said, `No thanks.' I thought I'd just be running around in a union suit. But they are taking the character of Barry Allen, his alter ego, very seriously, so there is something in it for me as an actor. It has a fantasy element, but we also try to deal with social issues. We've done shows about drug addiction and the homeless.'' Nevertheless, the attraction of the new CBS show, airing Thursday nights, is the fantasy of the Flash's incredible speed - and the startling special effects that make it look real. Other comic book heroes have found success in television, including ``Superman,'' ``Batman,'' ``The Incredible Hulk'' and ``Wonder Woman.'' But ``Captain America'' and ``The Amazing Spider-Man'' were less successful, and ``The Flash'' is struggling to find an audience. ``The Flash'' comic book made its first appearance in January 1940, but never achieved the fame or the appeal of such comic book classics as ``Superman'' and ``Batman'' and disappeared by 1950. It was revived - and modernized - in 1956, and the CBS series is based on that version. A third incarnation currently is running in comic books. ``The Flash'' also is Barry Allen, a young scientist who comes from a family of Irish policemen. Allen's father is none too happy that he hasn't become a policeman, too. ``One of the things I liked is that when Barry gets the super powers in a laboratory accident, his first reaction isn't, `OK, I'm going to save the world,' '' Shipp said. ``He goes to another scientist, played by Amanda Pays, and asks her what it means. He worries that it might mean premature aging. He decides to use the powers after his policeman brother is killed.'' Shipp said he thinks some comic book characters have been treated in a ludicrous manner by television. ``You have to create a world of your own,'' he said. ``You can't put a guy in a red suit with wings on his head on Hollywood Boulevard. ``I don't want `The Flash' to become a vigilante. I don't want him to abuse the power. I'm after the writers to explore its effects on Barry. Some people just want to make it the good guys vs. the bad guys.'' The show is expensive: The pilot cost $6.5 million, and each episode costs $1.4 million, Shipp said. A great deal of the technical wizardry goes into making superhuman speed look authentic. ``We walk a thin line between something that can be sophisticated and something that can be laughable,'' Shipp said. ``We do a lot of night shooting. We use a lot of wet streets and reflected lights. You have to be careful how you use the suit. To me, it has to be used as a visual effect. It has to be carefully lit and photographed.'' The look of ``The Flash'' is a mixture of vintage styles with the 1990s, completely omitting the 1960s, '70s and '80s. The wardrobes combine long coats and fedoras from the 1930s with contemporary clothes. The vehicles are from the '30s, '40s, '50s and '90s. The look of speed comes from an unusual smear effect. It requires a long exposure of the main scene and a second film in which Shipp re-creates his movements exactly in front of a blue screen. The two images then are combined on digital videotape to give the appearance he's moving at 600 mph while everyone else is moving at normal speed. The special suit Shipp wears is a type of body appliance that gives him an imposing, heavily muscled appearance. It's in 30 pieces and takes about 30 minutes to put on. And it's so hot that it's equipped with a cooling system. Before beginning ``The Flash,'' Shipp played the father in the sequel to the film ``The NeverEnding Story.'' He also worked in such soap operas as ``The Guiding Light,'' ``As the World Turns'' and ``Santa Barbara.'' ``The sequel takes the father-son relationship further,'' he said of ``The NeverEnding Story.'' ``It's funny. In that father-son relationship, I was the father. In `The Flash,' I'm the son in the father-son relationship. The actor in `The NeverEnding Story' who plays my son, Jonathan Brandes, plays a street kid in the `Flash' episode we're shooting now.''

DOC.HEAD: No Evidence of Speculative Mania in 1970s Farmland Runup, Report Says
DOC.TEXT: If, instead of heading for Las Vegas, a high-roller in 1980 bought a typical acre of U.S. farmland for $750 in hopes of turning a fast buck, the profit would hardly have been the stuff of a gambler's dreams. The speculator could have sold the one acre in 1982 for a record $823. That would have been a profit of less than 5 percent a year. But it would have been a profit. And there are more losers than winners at roulette tables. After the U.S. farmland boom of the 1970s peaked in 1982, however, it was downhill for years, with the bottom in 1987 at an average of $599 per acre. By 1990, according to the Agriculture Department, farm real estate prices nationally - including buildings as well as land - had recovered to around $693 per acre. These are only averages. No doubt there have been some speculative land deals that have resulted in somebody getting rich. But did speculators help run up farmland prices in the 1970s so much that the bottom was bound to fall out of the market in the 1980s? A USDA analysis says it is doubtful that speculation and easy credit policies led to the farmland bust. There is little doubt, however, that the slide in land prices was a huge factor in the financial crunch that gripped the nation's agriculture in the mid-1980s. Land is the main asset of farmers, and when values crumbled their collateral shrank, and so did their borrowing power. ``Many market observers said (farmland) prices reflected a speculative mania rather than expected farm income,'' the report said. ``Speculative manias, often called bubbles, occur when investors buy an asset intending only to sell it later at a higher price, rather than using it to generate income over a number of years.'' The report was written by Fred Kuchler and Abebayehu Tegene of the department's Economic Research Service and is in the November issue of Agricultural Outlook magazine. ``While there is some circumstantial evidence of a speculative bubble in the 1970s, the long-run stable relation between farmland prices and returns (as measured by cash rental rates) leads to the conclusion that bubbles have most likely not occurred in farmland markets,'' the report said. ``Rather,'' it added, ``expectations about future farm incomes and other economic factors have determined, and continue to determine, farmland prices.'' The report also said that many analysts believe ``aggressive lending policies touched off a speculative bubble in farmland prices'' during the 1970s. ``That conclusion appears to be incorrect, but the evidence does not rule out the possibility that aggressive lending, reflected in lower mortgage rates or greater volumes of credit, could have caused investors to re-evaluate their expectations,'' the report said. ``The lenders probably made farmland a much better investment.'' Recently the American Bankers Association released an independent study that said a liberalization of Farm Credit System lending policies nearly 20 years ago led to the boom-and-bust era in agriculture. According to the study, the cooperatively owned Farm Credit System - which includes federal land bank associations - was authorized by Congress in 1971 to raise its collateral limit for farm real estate loans. That meant larger loans to buy land. The bankers' study said the liberalization ``unleased a boom in land prices in rural America that saw the inflation-adjusted value of farmland nearly double from 1971 to 1980.'' But the bankers' study said the boom was unsustainable and that by the mid-1980s the average real value of farmland, after allowing for inflation, was almost down to its 1971 level. The USDA reports it is impossible to prove conclusively that speculative bubbles exist or do not exist. One reason is that economists do not agree exactly on how much income should be attributed to land. ``If there was no speculative bubble, the runup in farmland prices during the 1970s must reflect big shifts in expectations,'' the report said. ``Farmland investors might have believed that farm income would rise at a faster pace or that income would continue to rise at the rate of the 1950s and 1960s.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Nov. 25

DOC.TEXT: Despite economic gloom and higher fuel prices, American drivers plan to hit the road in higher numbers this Thanksgiving, but the nation's airlines aren't expecting a similar surge. The American Automobile Association reported Monday that more people are expecting to drive 100 miles or more for Thanksgiving, based on a survey of 1,500 adults. The airlines, meanwhile, are predicting no improvement over last year, a discouraging sign for an industry that has been hit hard by sluggish demand and steady increases in jet fuel prompted by the Persian Gulf crisis. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Tens of thousands of workers made sick by asbestos will receive sharply reduced compensation payments from the Manville trust under a plan to resolve the nation's biggest product liability case. The long-awaited restructuring, unveiled Monday, is designed to insure payments to victims of lung cancer and other respiratory ailments, clear a court backlog and create a model for companies facing huge liabilities for asbestos products. The plan includes up to $520 million in new contributions to the trust by Manville Corp., which was driven into bankruptcy court in 1982 by mounting asbestos lawsuits. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Oil prices rallied sharply on news that Iraq will send another 250,000 troops into Kuwait. Light sweet crude oil, the benchmark blend, had dropped about $1 a barrel in early trading Monday on the New York Mercantile Exchange as traders focused on prospects of peace in the gulf. But prices shot up after Iraqi President Saddam Hussein announced the military buildup. Crude settled at $31.50 per barrel for December delivery contracts, up $1.72. --- CARACAS, Venezuela (AP) - The state oil monopoly plans to increase its capacity for oil production, from the current 2 million barrels daily to 4.2 million barrels daily by 1996, a newspaper reported. Petroleos de Venezuela's ambitious expansion plans would cost about $20 billion, according to the daily El Diario de Caracas, which quoted oil sources on Monday it did not identify. The newspaper said that while Venezuela's production capacity would rise to 4.2 million barrels a day, the country would have a production target of just 3.7 million barrels a day. --- DALLAS (AP) - Greyhound Lines Inc., the nation's largest intercity bus line that sought bankruptcy protection after a strike, has filed a reorganization plan that transfers most of the company's value to creditors and keeps its routes operating. The plan, entered Monday in federal bankruptcy court in Corpus Christi, will reduce Greyhound's debt by $171 million and reshape its corporate structure. Creditors will receive new common stock and $165 million in securities under the plan. Equity held by Greyhound's present owners will be canceled. --- NEW YORK (AP) - CBS Inc. said it expects to post a loss in the fourth quarter because of a weak advertising market and unexpectedly large losses on its television broadcasts of major league baseball. The company also said on Monday that it expects lower earnings from continuing operations for all of 1991 compared with this year. The glum forecast comes as CBS reportedly planned a meeting with its affiliates board to propose a reduction in the estimated $160 million the network pays about 200 affiliated stations for carrying its shows. --- MILAN, Italy (AP) - Floor traders, protesting government inaction on long-awaited regulatory reforms, have halted stock trading in Italy for a second consecutive session. The strike by about 1,000 floor traders began on Friday and was scheduled to last through Wednesday. On Monday, picket lines outside the two largest Italian markets in Milan and Rome prevented trading in equity and bonds. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Consumer Products Safety Commission issued its yearly holiday warning against dangerous toys and said it may adopt regulations requiring labeling of playthings with small parts that little children could choke on. At its annual toy safety news conference, the commission on Monday cautioned parents and other shoppers to beware of balloons, small balls and marbles, as well as small parts, when buying gifts for the very young. The commission said it received reports of 33 deaths related to toys between January 1989 and September 1990. --- PROVIDENCE, R.I. (AP) - Bank examiners investigating a possible $13 million embezzlement at a bank closed by the state studied the institution's murky records while police searched for its missing president. A handful of angry depositors showed up at the Heritage Loan and Investment Co. on Monday demanding their money but were turned away by state police. Dozens more called, seeking reassurance their money was safe. The state obtained a judge's order putting the two-office bank into receivership Sunday after a four-day run drained $13.6 million of its $22.4 million in deposits and weakened a private bank insurance system. ---
DOC.HEAD: By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: The stock market gained ground Monday, picking up where it left off in last week's advance, even though oil prices and interest rates turned upward. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up 61.64 points last week, rose 15.10 to 2,565.35. The dollar traded mostly lower as gold prices rose. Bonds fell sharply.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Manville Trust, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts, figures and details about asbestos and the Manville Personal Injury Settlement trust, which is to be reorganized under a plan presented to a federal judge Monday.
DOC.HEAD: WHAT IS ASBESTOS?
DOC.TEXT: Asbestos is a flaky, white mineral with natural fire, heat and electrical resistance. It was used widely for decades in various industries, predominantly shipbuilding, boiler-making and construction. During World War II, asbestos manufactured by what was then known as Johns Manville Co. and several other companies provided the bulk of asbestos used in shipyards nationwide. Hundreds of thousands of workers were exposed to asbestos, but it wasn't until the 1970s that a definitive link between the mineral and severe respiratory diseases including lung cancer was established. Asbestos today has been removed from public buildings nationwide.
DOC.HEAD: WHO'S LIABLE?
DOC.TEXT: Manville Corp., which was the nation's leading asbestos maker, entered Chapter 11 bankruptcy court proceedings in 1982 because it couldn't meet its legal liabilities from thousands of asbestos health lawsuits. The Manville trust was formed as part of the company's 1988 court reorganization. Dozens of other companies nationwide face mounting legal problems due to asbestos liability. Several have entered bankrptcy court, others are financially burdened by the liability and many are looking to the Manville settlement as a possible model for resolving claims. Asbestos cases comprise the biggest product liability issue in U.S. history.
DOC.HEAD: LEGAL HISTORY
DOC.TEXT: Plaintiffs and defendant companies have been wrangling over asbestos compensation since the mid-1970s and well over $2 billion has been paid out to workers or their families. Thousands of claimants have died before being paid. Companies have been held liable predominantly for a failure to provide adequate health warnings to workers. Today more than 90,000 asbestos lawsuits crowd federal and state court dockets nationwide. Mass trials often are held resolving hundreds of cases at a time. Jury awards have ranged from nothing to more than $1 million for individual plaintiffs.
DOC.HEAD: THE TRUST
DOC.TEXT: The Manville trust is the biggest claims resolution mechanism in the country. It was set up with about $3 billion in cash and Manville securities. The Washington, D.C.-based trust has paid more than $1.1 billion to settle over 23,000 claims to date. But it has another 130,000-plus claims pending and faces an estimated 100,000 future claims. Earlier this year the trust declared it had run out of cash and said some claimants wouldn't get any money until well into the 21st century. U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein ordered an overhaul of the trust to meet its claims. The trust blames the cash drain on the fact that it received more claims, resolved cases faster and paid more than it had expected. Critics say it was badly managed and squandered its cash.
DOC.HEAD: THE PLAN
DOC.TEXT: The trust previously had settled cases based on the time of filing rather than the type of disease and victims' need. The restructuring scraps that plan, dividing claims into two categories: serious ailments such as lung cancer and less severe problems. Claimants will receive only about 45 percent of their settlements' value. Annual payments will be made, dividing the total amount owed to a claimant by the total amount of the trust's available resources. Claimants in the first group will receive priority during the plan's first two years; the second group won't receive any payments until the third year of the plan. The plan caps plaintiffs lawyers' fees at 25 percent of settlements and dismisses all litigation against the trust. The plan still must be approved by Weinstein and is expected to face legal appeals from dissatisfied parties.
DOC.HEAD: WHO PAYS?
DOC.TEXT: Manville Corp. has agreed to inject an additional $520 million over seven years into the trust, which owns 80 percent of the company's common stock. Manville is to pay $280 million in dividends over four years to the trust and another $240 million in years four through seven. The trust also holds $1.8 billion in Manville bonds which it plans someday to sell. Manville is to make $75 million a year in bond payments to the trust starting next year and give the trust 20 percent of its annual profits beginning in 1992. Participants in the restructuring envision using the stock dividends for three years and then selling the bonds and some common stock to finance payments to victims. All agree there still is not enough money to meet victims' demands.

DOC.HEAD: Asbestos Fund Restructuring Unveiled, But Opposition Expected
With PM-Asbestos-Glance
DOC.TEXT: The overhaul of the cash-starved Manville trust fund is designed to guarantee compensation for tens of thousands of American workers made sick by asbestos, but payments aren't likely to resume for a year or more. The proposed restructuring, unveiled Monday, slashes fees for plaintiffs lawyers and ensures at least some payment to all claimants within three years of its enaction. But the plan, submitted to U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein, already is being criticized by some attorneys for plaintiffs and companies with asbestos liability. A key victims' advocacy group also said it will oppose the reorganization. ``It is a terrible compromise,'' said Heather Maurer, executive director of the Asbestos Victims of America, an advocacy group for 18,000 victims based in Soquel, Calif. ``I don't think giving an individual $3,000 or $4,000 is in any way just compensation for their diseases and deaths.'' The restructuring effort is designed to help resolve the biggest product liability issue in U.S. history. Asbestos, once considered a miracle fiber, has caused thousands of deaths from lung cancer and other ailments, and resulting lawsuits have sent several companies into bankruptcy court and strangled court dockets nationwide. The Manville trust is the biggest asbestos health claims resolutions mechanism. Formed as part of Manville Corp.'s 1988 bankruptcy reorganization, the trust has paid more than $1.1 billion to settle about 23,000 claims since its formation in 1988. But it faces another 130,000-plus claims and was ordered restructured after running out of cash earlier this year. The restructuring plan calls for paying claimants based on the severity of their illnesses. Cancer and other serious diseases are in one group, with lesser ailments in the second. The plan caps lawyers' fees at 25 percent of clients' settlements and orders dismissal of tens of thousands of lawsuits against the trust. Both steps should produce hundreds of millions of dollars more for plaintiffs. Its architects defend the plan as the only way to deal with a severe cash drain during the trust's first two years of operation, when it settled claims on a first-come, first-served basis. ``There is not enough money to compensate everybody as if the funds were unlimited,'' said Christopher Placitella, a Woodbridge, N.J., plaintiffs lawyer who helped negotiate the plan. ``The objective is that hopefully everyone will be treated equally.'' The plan is certain to face opposition. Weinstein today is expected to appoint an independent outside reviewer and schedule court hearings in New York, New Orleans, Chicago and San Francisco for within 60 days. Payments will remain suspended until the restructuring takes effect. In addition to the hearings, potentially lengthy court appeals are expected that lawyers said could take a year or more. The plan was approved by a committee of plaintiffs lawyers by 5-2. The dissenting attorneys argued that the plan treats claimants with lesser illnesses unfairly by deferring their payments. The trust also is to rely on its 80 percent ownership of Manville stock for funding after the first three years of the plan. If the depressed stock price doesn't rise, the trust's assets will be hurt severely. Lawyers for companies with large asbestos liabilities said the plan attempts to increase other defendants' payments to victims by prohibiting juries from learning the size of Manville settlements. It also will make other companies pay full settlements to plaintiffs then wait in line to collect the trust's share. Manville, once the nation's largest asbestos maker, via the trust generally has been assessed the largest share of jury settlements. ``The net effect is reducing Manville's share and trying to make the other companies pay more than their fair share,'' said Andrew Berry, a Newark, N.J., lawyer for several defendants. Payments would be made annually to claimants based on a percentage of the trust's available resources. Claimants are to receive a maximum 45 percent of settlements until all claims are at least partially met. Manville trust payments have averaged about $43,000, but are forecast to fall more than half for serious diseases and even more for less severe ailments under the new scheme. Payments would be made only to an estimated 23,000 first-group claimants during the plan's first two years. The group includes relatives of workers who died before being compensated. The more than 100,000 claims in the second group would begin receiving payment in the plan's third year. Payments are to be made first to those with hardships, then according to disease severity, then to claimants over 70 years old and finally to those who filed first. Payments to all Manville claimants except those with urgent health or financial needs were suspended in July. The Washington, D.C.-based trust originally was funded with about $3 billion in cash and Manville securities. Manville, a Denver-based manufacturing and minerals maker, has agreed to pump up to $520 million into the trust over seven years.

DOC.HEAD: Unprecedented Strike Halts Stock Trading In Italy
DOC.TEXT: An unprecedented four-day strike by floor traders is paralyzing Italian stock markets, dashing a trading volume of hundreds of millions of dollars daily and possibly scaring off foreign investors. The National Association of Bourse Floor Traders says its 1,000 members' chief gripe is government inaction on long-awaited regulatory reforms intended to make the markets more competitive internationally. The reforms would regulate public tender offers, insider trading and financial intermediaries. Another change, merging floor traders with security intermediaries, including brokers, commission dealers and banks, would be aimed at making stock trading smoother and upgrading the Italian bourse. The floor traders also are protesting the increased paperwork associated with a proposed 30 percent tax on capital gains. Rino Formica, the Socialist finance minister, called the blockade of stock operations a ``revolt'' against the proposed tax. The traders reject the claim that they are upset over the tax. ``The idea of a tax on capital gains has been long digested by Italian markets. We are protesting slowness in implementing reform, which is hurting the competitiveness of Italian markets and prompting investors to flee,'' said a member of the Milan-based Association, who spoke on condition of anonimity. Italy's stock business is confined to about 200 brokers. It is considered a relatively weak market in Europe because of the limited number of listed companies, 220, and because there isn't a law against insider trading. The association is increasingly worried that London's SEAQ trading circuit could siphon a significant amount of business from Italian exchanges. Some analysts predict that up to 40 percent of the trading in Italian stocks would be done in London unless the Italian parliament passes reform laws. Several Italian blue chip companies, such as Fiat, Generali, Olivetti, Pirelli, Montedison and Sip, are traded in London and have been quoting prices during the strike in Italy. The strike, initiated Friday, is scheduled to last through Wednesday when a delegation of traders and the government are set to meet in Rome to discuss the case. In the meantime, picket lines outside the two largest Italian markets in Milan and Rome prevented trading in equities and bonds. Only foreign exchange quotations by bank officials were completed. Although several floor dealers emphasized that they were seeking protection for their jobs, the labor action did not get full support from leftist trade unions. L'Unita, the organ of the Italian Communist party, called the stock market strike ``a protest by the rich against a most sacred tax.'' Albert Alonzo, an Italy analyst with Barclays De Zoete Wedd of London, noted that ``to close the market down does not endear the market to foreign investors.'' The blockade in fact comes at a difficult time for Italian financial markets, already in deep malaise following a drop in trading volume and in prices, due in part to the Gulf crisis. The Milan stock market index fell about 25 percent from last January to mid-November, while quotations of blue chips such as Fiat and Olivetti hit the lowest levels in years. ``The worst problem, however, is the confusion about the capital gains tax and about when reforms will be enforced,'' said a Milan broker.

DOC.HEAD: Vegas Resort Dramatic Financial Success First Year
DOC.TEXT: The Mirage Hotel celebrates its first anniversary as the premier showplace on the glitzy Strip this week and chairman Steve Wynn says it has exceeded his heady forecast of a year ago by ``miles and miles.'' At a time when gaming competitors Donald Trump and Bally Corp. are facing mounting financial woes, Wynn's Mirage is the talk of the industry. ``We'll do 40 to 50 percent better than our best expectations,'' Wynn said in a weekend interview. Even prophets of doom in the financial community are backing off dire predictions made a year ago when Wynn opened the $630 million, 3,100-room resort, which features a flaming volcano, white tigers and bottlenose dolphins. Hotel revenues the first year will run between $600 million and $650 million, Wynn said, his fingers sweeping across the latest monthly balance sheet. Before his resort opened a year ago Thursday, Wynn was forecasting cash flow of $130 million to $140 million. Gaming analysts projected $110 million to $120 million. Now, Wynn says, that figure will be closer to $180 million to $200 million. ``The amazing thing is that we keep expecting it to slow down and it doesn't,'' Dan Lee, a gaming analyst with First Boston Inc., said Monday. ``Ordinarily the second year a casino is open is more profitable than the first, but with the year they had, that will be hard to top,'' Lee said. The success of the resort has prompted Wynn to borrow another $100 million for upgrades at the property such as a $14 million, 1.5 million gallon home for five dolphins. The idea of $500 million-plus in debt doesn't bother Wynn. ``You've got a property here that's appraised at somewhere north of a billion, probably $1.2 billion,'' Wynn said. Wynn estimates 25,000 to 45,000 people visit the Mirage daily, surpassing Hoover Dam as the most popular attraction in Southern Nevada. The estimates mean that 13 million of the 19 million people who visited Las Vegas the past year stopped by. An estimated 750,000 people overwhelmed the resort on opening weekend a year ago. Wynn's Mirage has had a domino effect on this gaming community, which mesmerized him when he visited as a 10-year-old boy 38 years ago. The Mirage has transformed the Strip and has sparked a multibillion-dollar building boom of new hotels and massive additions to existing properties. The hotel boom has spread to the rest of the city's economy, making it one of the fastest-growing cities in the country. Wynn's hotel and casino was the most expensive in the world until Trump opened his $1.2 billion Taj Mahal earlier this year. The Taj has been unable to meet its debt service and faces financial reorganization. Wynn's parent Golden Nugget Corp. sold its Atlantic City property to Bally in 1987 for $440 million. He thinks the sale was a smart one, as New Jersey gamers face increasingly tough times. ``We saw the outcome of the Atlantic City process pretty much the way it worked out,'' Wynn said. ``That's why we wanted to sell. We became very concerned about the Atlantic City market in '86. We thought it was going to run out of steam, that the regulatory policies of state law were going to kill it. The politicians are the ones who screwed it up. ``The failure is Atlantic City, not Donald Trump's ego,'' Wynn said of problems at the Taj Mahal. ``They're all in trouble. It isn't just the Taj, it's the town. The trouble is the guys there have to overcome the city, whereas here, the city helps make the hotel. ``The problem is much deeper than whether Donald Trump or Bally's or anyone else is smarter. The guys who knew the town haven't had a way to get out or they would have. ``He would have been much stronger if he'd left the Taj alone,'' Wynn said of Trump, who once called Wynn a ``classic under-achiever.''

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Conditions Bankruptcy Filing on Suit by Drivers
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound Lines Inc. has tied its bankruptcy reorganization to a dispute with the National Labor Relations Board over treatment of its striking drivers. In a Chapter 11 plan filed with a bankruptcy judge in Corpus Christi Monday, Greyhound said it will restructure itself and issue new stock, most of which will go to unsecured creditors. The plan must be approved by U.S. bankruptcy Judge Richard S. Schmidt and Greyhound's creditors. Its completion also hinges on how Schmidt views the NLRB's charges against Greyhound on behalf of 6,000 drivers who went on strike in March. The NLRB has charged Greyhound with unfair labor practices and says the company owes the drivers more than $80 million in back pay and damages, attorneys say. The filing says Greyhound will not proceed with the reorganization if drivers win more than $40 million. The company earlier asked Schmidt to define any amount of money the NLRB wins for strikingdrivers as an unsecured claim at the bottom of Greyhound's list of obligations. ``If those two conditions are not met, we would not try to confirm this plan we would pull it back and re-look at it,'' said George W. Hanthorn, senior vice president and general counsel for Greyhound. Attorneys for the drivers received copies of the plan late Monday and had no immediate comment. Under the plan, all of Greyhound's routes will keep operating. ``I think really the key to the plan is the way our operations have come back since the strike,'' Hanthorn said. ``Without those improved and good operations, a plan like this we have proposed on this fast a track couldn't happen.'' Passenger revenue fell below half of 1989's monthly levels during the first part of the strike, but steadily increased over the summer and, in October, was 90 percent of the 1989 figure. The company would like to complete the reorganization process by next spring or early summer, Hanthorn said. Greyhound filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy code in early June, three months after the drivers went on strike over wages and benefits. The expense of fighting the strike and a fall in revenue after the strike siphoned cash Greyhound needed to operate, the company said then. The plan shows Greyhound placing less emphasis on its charter service. Its food subsidiary will be liquidated and travel service subsidiary, which is assigned no value in the plan, will be dissolved. Reducing its charter business, eliminating some routes and consolidating others allowed Greyhound to hire substantially fewer drivers to replace the members of the Amalgamated Transit Union who struck the company. About 600 drivers crossed the picket line and the company hired more than 3,000 other replacements.

DOC.HEAD: Revised Counts Against Keating, 3 Others Will Be Challenged
DOC.TEXT: Defense lawyers in the Lincoln Savings securities fraud trial will challenge a revised indictment that increases the number of criminal counts from 42 to 46 against Charles Keating Jr. and three others. A grand jury handed up the original indictment, and only a grand jury - not prosecutors - should be allowed to make major changes in it, said Abbe Lowell, an attorney for Keating co-defendant Judy J. Wischer. ``You can't add more counts without a grand jury voting on it,'' said Lowell. Prosecutors filed the revised charges Monday against Keating in an attempt to salvage 22 of the original 42 counts. They had been set aside by a judge who said they were too vague or failed to state an offense supported by evidence in nearly 4,600 pages of grand jury testimony. Among other things, the amended indictment provides more specific examples of alleged wrongdoing by Keating and three top executives of his companies in the sale of $200 million in now-worthless junk bonds at Lincoln branches. Deputy District Attorney William Hodgman said the revised charges correct flaws cited by Superior Court Judge Lance Ito on Nov. 9, when Ito ordered the 22 counts dismissed. Defense attorneys are expected to challenge the new charges on many grounds. The earliest Ito could rule on the matter is Dec. 3, the next hearing date in the case. The charges Ito set aside involve 20 counts of selling securities without government approval, one count of lying to regulators and one count of advertising securities for sale without filing copies of the ads three days in advance with the Department of Corporations. However, the heart of the case is contained in 20 counts Ito let stand. Those charges contend elderly investors were misled about the safety of high-yield, high-risk bonds they purchased at Lincoln branches. The junk bonds were issued by American Continental Corp. of Phoenix, a development company owned by the Keating family. American Continental in turn owned Irvine-based Lincoln. About $250 million in bonds, most of them sold at Lincoln branches, became worthless on April 13, 1989, when American Continental sought bankruptcy protection. Lincoln was seized the next day. Experts say its failure will cost taxpayers $2 billion, the biggest S&L bailout yet. In civil suits including a $1 billion racketeering action, Keating is accused of looting the thrift.

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Company Recalls Hot Dogs Suspected Of Contamination
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This was in PM-Washington in Brief on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A Chicago company is recalling more than five tons of hot dogs suspected of being contaminated by food poisoning. Agriculture Department officials said on Monday that David Berg & Co. is recalling 10,000 pounds of bulk-packed ``David Berg Beef Frankfurters'' distributed in California, Illinois, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania and Texas. Also being recalled are about 1,400 pounds of retail-packaged ``David Berg Deli Beef Franks'' distributed in the Chicago metropolitan area. The franks may be contaminated with listeria monocytogenes, an organism that can cause listeriosis, which was described as ``a rare but potentially serious disease.' The bulk-packed hot dogs are sold in 10-pound boxes and are distributed to hot dog vendors, delicatessens and restaurants. ``EST. 1'' appears inside the USDA inspection seal on the box label. All bulk franks with the code 60250 on the bottom of the box are being recalled. The 12-ounce retail packages were distributed to grocery stores and supermarkets in Chicago. ``EST. 1'' appears in the inspection seal on the package label. All retail packages with ``Sell by Dec. 10'' stamped on the side of the package are being recalled. None of the company's other products are involved in the recall, said Ronald J. Prucha, associate administrator of the department's Food Safety and Inspection Service.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Dip In Tokyo, Dollar Nearly Unchanged
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, The Nikkei ... to CORRECT the closing Nikkei average. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, A total ...
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices fell today on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, while the dollar closed nearly unchanged against the Japanese yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which gained 346.53 points Monday, declined 312.68 points, or 1.33 percent, closing at 23,205.48. A total of only 210 million shares were traded on the first section, down from 300 million shares Monday. Iraq's announcement that it was increasing its forces in Kuwait dampened investors' buying interest, said Masahiko Fujita, an analyst with Yamaichi Securities. ``As shown in the day's trading volume, most market players, including institutional investors, took a wait-and-see position,'' he said. The dollar closed at 128.93 yen, down 0.02 yen from Monday's close of 128.95 yen. It opened at 129.23 yen and ranged between 128.90 yen and 129.28 yen. Some $6.14 billion changed hands in spot currency trading, down from $8.48 billion traded Monday. ``It's a quiet market,'' said Masaya Ueno, a dealer with Fuji Bank. Ueno said the market still generally anticipated a lower dollar, although its direction has yet to be clearly determined. He and other dealers said the dollar rose in early trading after news reports that Iraq would add about 250,000 troops to the 430,000 in Kuwait and southern Iraq, but later slipped lower. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 85.34 points, from Monday's close of 85.32. Their yield fell to 7.635 percent from 7.640 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Mitsubishi Buys Half Of Union Carbide Subsidiary
DOC.TEXT: Mitsubishi Corp. said Tuesday that it had agreed to buy a 50 percent interest in UCAR Carbon Company Inc., a wholly-owned subsidiary of Union Carbide Corp. Mitsubishi said its will pay about $230 million for the stake and that said Union Carbide, based in Danbury, Conn., will retain ownership of the other 50 pc of the UCAR Carbide Company. UCAR is an international supplier of carbon and graphite electrodes to steel and other industries, Mitsubishi said. It has 19 manufacturing facilities in nine countries. In 1989, UCAR had sales of $802 million, Mitsubishi said. Mitsubishi said the sale fits both its own international-expansion strategy and Union Carbide's restructuring plans. With the stake in UCAR Mitsubishi said it had broadened its own supply of electrodes beyond Japanese sources. UCAR'S current management will continue to operate the company, Mitsubishi said.

DOC.HEAD: Santa Fe Spinoffs Set For Dec. 4
DOC.TEXT: Santa Fe Pacific Corp. has announced it will split into three independent entities on Dec. 4. in a move it says will benefit shareholders. The railroad, energy and real-estate conglomerate said Monday that its board of directors approved a previously announced plan to spin off Santa Fe Energy Resources and Catellus Development Corp., formerly Santa Fe Pacific Realty, to shareholders. Santa Fe stockholders of record as of Nov. 29 will receive a special, tax-free dividend consisting of one share of common stock of Santa Fe Energy Resources for every 3.3 shares of Santa Fe Pacific held, and one share of Catellus for every 4 shares of Santa Fe Pacific. Distributions of fractional shares will be settled in cash. The spinoffs will leave the Chicago-based parent company with three interests: the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway, Santa Fe Pacific Minerals Corp. and a 44 percent stake in Santa Fe Pacific Pipelines. Santa Fe announced in April its plan to spin off the Houston-based energy and San Francisco-based real-estate units as part of a far-reaching restructuring program begun in 1987. Chairman Robert Krebs said in a statement that the values of Santa Fe's diversified assets have not been reflected in Santa Fe's stock price. Santa Fe Pacific stock closed 25 cents lower at $13 a share Monday on the New York Stock Exchange. ``Our stockholders should benefit from this separation because it will place a spotlight on the values inherent in those companies,'' he said. ``In addition, the directors, management and employees of all three companies will now be able to focus their energies on better utilizing and developing their assets,'' he said. Santa Fe previously sold 18.3 percent of Santa Fe Energy Resources to the public. Its stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange. Santa Fe also has sold a 20 percent stake in the real-estate subsidiary to a limited partnership formed by JMB Realty Corp. and the California Public Employees Retirement System. Santa Fe said Catellus has been approved for trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

DOC.HEAD: Popeyes Franchisees Sue Chain's Founder
DOC.TEXT: A lawsuit filed by a group of Popeyes Famous Fried Chicken franchise owners in 20 states claims chain owner Al Copeland violated state and federal antitrust laws by forcing franchisees to purchase products from his companies. The suit filed Monday also alleges Copeland has transferred food items and confidential company information to Church's Fried Chicken, a larger competitor which Copeland bought last year. ``Quite simply, given the financial drain that Church's represents, it has caused Popeyes to forget the people who made it what it is today,'' said Brent Barriere, attorney for Independent Popeyes Franchise Group. IPFG is made up of more than 50 people who own more than 200 Popeyes franchises in 20 states. Al Copeland Enterprises Inc. and a subsidiary called Diversified Foods & Seasonings Inc., which sells spices, beans, gravy, biscuit base and other products to Popeyes franchises, are also named as defendants in the 33-page suit. ``We do not have a statement. There is no response at this time,'' said Copeland's spokeswoman, Kit Wohl of the publicity firm Watts Wohl & Associates Inc. She said there are nearly 800 Popeyes in 39 states and nearly 1,200 Church's restaurants in 24 states around the country. As of June, she said, Al Copeland Enterprises owned 130 Popeyes and had 646 Popeyes franchises; it owned 752 Church's outlets and had franchises with 444. The lawyer for the franchise group said, ``Popeyes, in part, at least, because of its swallowing of Church's has failed to respond to the interest of franchisees, has been distracted with promotions ... and ... has not given the type of support ... and advertising that franchisors are required to give under the franchise agreement.'' The lawsuit said that IPFG's members never expected Popeyes to change the fundamental nature of its system. ``In addition to the distraction caused by Church's ... we think Popeyes is engaged in direct competition with Popeyes franchisees,'' Barriere said. He said that Church's outlets within Popeyes franchise areas guts the exclusivity which franchisees have bargained and paid for. The suit asks for 15 specific orders, including ones to:

- Make Copeland's get rid of its interest in any Church's restaurant in the same market as an existing Popeyes franchise. - Keep Copeland's from adding to Church's menu items similar to those on Popeyes restaurants. - Make Copeland's separate all marketing, training and advertising workers for the two chains. - Make Copeland let franchises buy food and other products from alternative suppliers and to make specifications for their proprietary products available to those suppliers.

DOC.HEAD: Boeing Mulls Cutbacks in Space Station Project
DOC.TEXT: Boeing Co., a contractor on the space station, has scrapped plans to expand its work force next year on the project. Boeing is working with NASA on potential cutbacks in the project required by congressional budget trimming. ``We expect growth on the space station program to remain relatively flat for the next few years,'' Boeing spokeswoman Peri Widener said Monday from Huntsville, Ala., where Boeing's space station program is based. Widener said the company has dropped plans to increase its 1,000-member work force on the project by 10 percent to 15 percent in 1991. The space station is designed to be constructed on Earth and carried into space aboard roughly 20 shuttle flights. McDonnell Douglas Corp. is the main contractor on the space station. Boeing has a 10-year, $1.6 billion contract to build several key elements of the space platform, including a 44-foot habitation module for the eight-member permanent crew and a second module to be used for experiments with commercial materials such as electronics and medicinal drugs. Boeing will also build the ``nodes'' that will connect the modules. The entire platform is to be reassembled in space by shuttle astronauts. Boeing had been counting on the space station to boost its faltering military defense program. The company's Defense and Space Group lost $474 million last year and anticipates additional heavy losses for this year. But last month Congress ordered the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to trim $6 billion out of the $37 billion space station budget over the next six years. NASA was also ordered to cut spending for the current fiscal year to $1.9 billion from a budget proposal of $2.45 billion. NASA, which planned to spend up to $4 billion annually on the project in coming years, was also given an annual spending cap of $2.6 billion. NASA spokesman Mark Hess said the agency began a 90-day review last week to come up with ways to slim down the original version of the ambitious project. All contractors have been asked for their suggestions, he said. Widener said Boeing has submitted a preliminary proposal to NASA that suggests possible alterations that could help the program meet its budget constraints. Widener declined to elaborate on the proposal.

DOC.HEAD: Bellcore Says It Has Time-Stamp To Protect Records, Settle Patent Disputes
DOC.TEXT: Bellcore researchers say an electronic ``notary public'' they developed can tighten electronic security systems by proving when a document was created and whether it has been altered. Customers could submit any type of document electronically for time-stamping under the Bellcore time-stamping service, or the TSS. Computer experts said Monday that no electronic security system is impenetrable, but they say if the TSS works as touted, it will be the most secure system of its kind. ``With other computer security systems, you can't maintain the level of security that they claim you can maintain here,'' said Paul Zorfass, director of computer research at the Yankee Group in Boston. ``It sounds like something that would have great appeal to individuals who have a careful requirement for control.'' As technology has advanced and more records have been computerized, such security systems have become high-priority items for businesses and researchers. ``If you have an important researcher, you have a situation where a notary public stamps his notebook, say every two weeks,'' said Scott Stornetta, a research scientist at Bellcore who developed the system along with Stuart Haber. ``What this is, is an electronic notary public.'' The system will be installed at Bellcore's headquarters in Morris Township within the next six months for testing, he said. The company has applied for a patent and will probably license the product soon after the patent is granted, Stornetta said. Bellcore provides research and other technical support to the companies of Ameritech, Bell Atlantic, BellSouth, NYNEX, Pacific Telesis, Southwestern Bell Corp. and U.S. West. Costs have not been determined, but Stornetta said the electronic security program would be within a range acceptable to virtually anyone who needs such a device. In the case of an invention, a company could submit a description of the product while still keeping the idea secret from the TSS, Stornetta said. That would be done by sending only a small representation of the original document to the time-stamping service. A mathematical process called hashing would be used to create a ``digital fingerprint'' that represents the entire data. Changing even one character in the original text would change the digital fingerprint, showing that the document had been altered. Bill Garvin, a product manager at Computer Associates in Garden City, N.Y., said Bellcore appears to be improving an already existing security system. Computer Associates, a leader in the electronic security field, already has a system called CA-EXAMINE that can detect whether a computer file or program has been altered. What it cannot do is verify when a particular file originated. ``I can see it having use,'' Garvin said, ``but it doesn't sound like something that would be a head-to-head competitor.'' Bill Strapko, a senior consultant at International Data Corp. in Framingham, Mass., said the Bellcore system will be watched closely by the industry. ``For example, in the area of software, people are saying, `I did this before they did,' and there are all kinds of problems like that,'' Strapko said. ``The time-stamp sounds like it could prove that they did develop something first.'' He cautioned, however, that no electronic security system has been developed that is foolproof. ``If somebody is sharp enough, they can probably go into this system and beat it too,'' Strapko said. ``No matter what security system you have, there is a backdoor into it, unfortunately.''
