DOC.HEAD: Speculators Dump Grain and Bean Futures
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices retreated this morning at the Chicago Board of Trade. Speculators had bid prices up the last two sessions, anticipating an announcement of a grain deal between the United States and the Soviet Union. ``They didn't get it, so they're dumping,'' said John Frazier, agriculture director of Gerald Inc. in Chicago. Some traders said they fear the U.S. may not be as ready to help the Soviets with food after Mikhail Gorbachev on Monday failed to give a firm military commitment in the Persian Gulf. In early trading, wheat was 4 cents to 4\ cents lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.48{ a bushel; corn was 1 cent to 2} cents lower with December at $2.25 a bushel; oats were 2\ cents to 3 cents lower with December at $1.08{ a bushel; and soybeans were 3{ cents to 7 cents lower with November at $5.62 a bushel. Livestock and meat futures declined on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .20 cent to .50 cent lower, with the December contract at 79.07 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent to .25 cent lower with January at 87.65 cents a pound; live hogs were .50 cent to .75 cent lower with December at 52.95 cents a pound; and frozen pork bellies were 1.60 cents to the limit 2 cents lower with February at 70.25 cents a pound. On Monday, cattle and pork bellies settled higher, while hogs were mostly lower.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Officials Say Higher Texas Oil Production No Longer Needed
DOC.TEXT: Higher oil production in Texas is no longer needed because world supplies currently exceed demand, Federal energy officials have told the Texas Railroad Commission. The commission voted unanimously Monday not to renew an emergency order allowing oil wells across most of Texas to pump at maximum capacity. ``The Department of Energy did not think it was still a necessity,'' said commission Chairman Kent Hance. The commission had approved the 90-day emergency order increasing oil production in August at the request of the U.S. Department of Energy. The agency said the additional oil was needed to make up for losses resulting from the U.S. trade embargo against Iraq. Although there was a fear that oil supplies would dwindle after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait Aug. 2, several other nations - led by Saudi Arabia - stepped up production to fill the loss. Now, Railroad Commissioner Jim Nugent said, there is an ``oversupply of oil in the world.'' ``We don't want to be endangering any of our Texas reservoirs by overproduction,'' Nugent said. ``If the nation is in danger and there's a critical shortage, we're certainly willing to work with producers and the federal government to up production, but not when there isn't an urgent national need.'' In a memo to the commission Friday, agency official Ronald Schultz Jr. said the Energy Department had decided additional production was no longer needed because oil supplies exceed world demand by 100,000 barrels of oil per day and are expected to exceed demand by 1 million barrels per day in March if a war does not break out in the Persian Gulf. Commission spokesman Brian Schaible said officials had estimated Texas could produce an additional 20,000 barrels of oil a day under the emergency order, but he would not know for another month the actual production in September. After Nov. 29, the wells will go back to their normal production levels, Schaible said. The rate in August was 1.7 million barrels a day.

DOC.HEAD: Volkswagen to Make Cars in Northern China
DOC.TEXT: The German automaker Volkswagen and a Chinese factory signed a contract Tuesday to establish one of China's largest automotive joint ventures. Construction will start next year on an $800 million auto plant in the northeastern city of Changchun, with the capacity to build 150,000 Golf sedans each year, the official Xinhua News Agency reported. Volkswagen already operates a joint venture in Shanghai that produces Santana sedans. That facility can produce 60,000 cars annually, but has been limited by the government to less than 20,000 because the cars are made basically from imported kits. Parts are being localized gradually. Volkswagen's partner in the new venture is the No. 1 Motor Vehicle Plant of Changchun, which has been making Audis under a licensing agreement. Xinhua did not say what proportion of imported and locally made parts would go into the new Golfs. It said Volkswagen had agreed to transfer to the joint venture all the manufacturing technology needed to make Golfs. In addition, the German corporation will buy engines and spare parts from the joint venture. Volkswagen will be responsible for selling 15 percent of the cars on the international market, Xinhua said, a potentially difficult target. China has always pressed its joint ventures to export, but the technology of Chinese-made cars is too outdated and prices are too high to compete on world markets. Volkswagen's Shanghai-made Santanas are sold in China for about $27,000. China's No. 2 Automobile Works recently formed a joint venture with the French carmaker Citroen that also is expected to produce 150,000 cars annually by the year 2000. France's Peugot, U.S.-based Chrysler and Japan's Isuzu already operate joint-venture car plants in China, and domestically made cars have begun to outnumber imports on Beijing streets.

DOC.HEAD: WPP's Shares Plunge For Second Day After Earnings Pronouncement
DOC.TEXT: Shares in the advertising giant WPP Group PLC dropped today for the second consecutive session following the company's announcement that its profit would be ``somewhat below'' market forecasts. Shares of WPP, which owns the ad agencies J. Walter Thompson and Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, finished at 115 pence, or $2.27, a share on London's Stock Exchange, down from Monday's close of 279 pence, or $5.50, a share. Today's decline follows a drop of 99.5 pence, or 26 percent, on Monday, when the company announced that its 1990 pre-tax profit wouldn't match the market forecasts of 110 million pounds, or $217 million, because of a ``general economic downturn.'' Clients spend less on advertising during a slowing economy. The company's pre-tax profit, the preferred indicator of profit performance in Britain, came to 75 million pounds, or $122.4 million, in 1989. It had after-tax profit of 40.5 million pounds, or $66.1 million, on revenues of 4.4 billion pounds, or $7.19 billion, last year. After the anouncement, analysts cut their pre-tax profit estimates to anywhere between 65 million pounds and 90 million pounds.

DOC.HEAD: CBS Plans 20 Percent Cut in Payments to TV Affiliates
DOC.TEXT: CBS Inc. today announced plans to cut payments to television network affiliates for carrying its programs by 20 percent next year in a move that will save the media company about $30 million. The announcement comes a day after CBS announced that it expects to post a loss in the fourth quarter and lower earnings next year. It cited the deteriorating national advertising climate and the costs of entertainment and sports programs for its financial forecast. CBS executives met privately on Monday with representatives of the 208 TV stations that are affiliated with the CBS Television Newtork to discuss the proposed compensation reductions. CBS paid its affiliates $153 million this year in compensation. The company said that was more than either major network competitor, NBC or ABC, paid their affiliates. CBS estimated NBC pays $132 million a year to its affiliates while ABC pays an estimated $110 million. As part of its latest budgetary reviews, CBS said steps were taken to control costs in every area of the company, including affilate compensation. CBS said that in an effort to reduce the impact of the compensation cuts, it was planning to give the local stations more commercial time in news and sports programming to sell to local advertisers. In addition, CBS said it would increase local commercial time on broadcasts of the 1992 Winter Olympics. ``We have a mutual stake in each other's financial health and viability,'' said Tony Malara, president of CBS Affliate Relations. ``Given our improved programming performance, we need to insure that our financial picture will be sufficient to continue to support it.'' Spokesman George Schweitzer said the 20 percent compensation cut scheduled to take effect Jan. 1 was an across-the-board for all affiliates. Some stations, particularly smaller ones, rely more heavily than others on the payments and are expected to resist it. A call was placed to Berry Smith, head of the CBS Affiliate Advisory Board and an executive at Schurz Communications Inc. in South Bend, Ind., for reaction to the CBS plan but he was said to be traveling.

DOC.HEAD: Bahrain Carrier Orders 12 Jetliners
DOC.TEXT: Gulf Air, owned by the Persian Gulf nations of Bahrain, Qatar, Abu Dhabi and Oman, has ordered 12 767-300 extended-range jetliners, Boeing Commercial Airplane Group said Tuesday. The order is worth $1.15 billion, Boeing said. Three of the airplanes will be delivered within a few weeks, Boeing spokesman Steve Smith said. Gulf Air already operates six 767-ERs, the largest 767 fleet in the Middle East. It will use the new airplanes to extend service, including new flights to Singapore and Sydney. The 767 is a twin-engine, wide-body aircraft. The Gulf Air planes will seat 212 passengers in three classes. They will be powered by engines from General Electric Co. Boeing said 44 customers have ordered 516 767s so far. For the year Boeing has sold 497 planes, worth a total of $44 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Topps Hoping '91 Promotion Is Home Run For Baseball Card Business
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Did your mother throw away all your baseball cards? Would you like to get some of them back? You may get the chance next year. Topps Chewing Gum Inc. is celebrating the 40th anniversary of its first card by giving away 300,000 vintage cards - including the 1952 Mickey Mantle worth $8,000 - with its regular 1991 packs that sell for 50 cents. The promotion is a marketing coup for the leader in the sports card business, at a time when the competition has never been so hot. Half a dozen companies are after a share of the multimillion-dollar industry, which no longer caters just to kids, but adult investors reliving those days when they bought cards to flip on the playground or stick in the spokes of their bicycles. ``It's ferocious - fierce,'' said Ed Deke, a part-time collector who runs a sports card show in Fairfield, Conn. ``A lot of people have gotten into it.'' Baseball cards still make up 80 percent to 90 percent of the business. But some of the companies have expanded to - or deal exclusively in - football, basketball and hockey cards, as well as non-sport cards featuring heroes real and imaginary. The industry is so lucrative that the NBA has its own line of cards this season. Pro Set Inc., Dallas maker of football and hockey cards, will add a line of golf cards in mid-December. Upper Deck Co. is adding hockey cards. Next year's baseball cards from Score of Westport, Conn., will feature 13 ``Dream Team'' players in various stages of dress, from a bare-chested Jose Canseco to Will Clark in a double-breasted suit. And more companies are expanding into non-sport products, like Pro Set's Music Superstar cards and Upper Deck's Comic Ball cards - Looney Tunes characters in baseball garb. Topps makes cards with Batman, the Simpsons and Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. Among other competitors in the card business are Fleer Corp. of Philadelphia, Donruss - a division of the Bannockburn, Ill., candymaker Leaf, Inc. - and the Canadian firm, O-Pee-Chee. Opinions are split on whether all these companies can survive, with the glut of products on the shelf. While analysts think the industry will thrive in the 1990s, the same may not be true for individual companies. ``The me-toos, the ones that don't really have a strong franchise and a very big base of customers, are going to find it extremely difficult to exist,'' said Stanley Lanzet, an analyst with Arnhold and S. Bleichroeder Inc. in New York. Topps egan in 1951 with a deck of baseball cards that could be used to play a game. It made its first individual cards in 1952, such as the Mantle card, the Roy Campanella card worth $1,300 and the Eddie Matthews card worth $1,750. Fleer and Donruss entered the scene in 1981; Upper Deck joined in 1989. But Topps is still the big kid on the block, with $246 million in revenue in its latest fiscal year, up from $198 million the year before. The other companies are private except Fleer, which went public in June and reported $119 million in sales in the first nine months of 1990. Topps' customers could make some bucks of their own with next year's promotion, which will give away one of every Topps card ever made with the 1991 packs. Most of the cards will go directly into the 1991 packs, although the company will insert redemption certificates for the more valuable cards, like the 1952 Mantle, the 1953 Willy Mays worth $1,600, the 1954 Ted Williams worth $2,800 and the 1955 Roberto Clemente worth $1,050. Even a common player card from 1967 is worth up to $16. Topps will also give away one complete set from 1952. Spokesman Ken Liss said the company approached collectors for some of the giveaway cards, but found quite a few collecting dust around its Brooklyn, N.Y., headquarters. ``I think it's a great promotion,'' said Richard O. Rieger, an analyst with Ladenburg, Thalmann & Co. Inc. ``It's like they found old cards in a warehouse and held an auction.'' In addition to special promotions, Topps is using television advertising to hype its cards, as is Upper Deck. Upper Deck also is leasing space on the boards at three NHL arenas and using players like Wayne Gretzky to hawk its upscale cards, which cost twice as much as Topps' and are printed with an anti-counterfeiting hologram. ``We have our niche in the marketplace,'' said Jay McCracken, Upper Deck vice president of sales. ``We've seen a lot of the competition come at us this year with new ideas, and that means we'll just have to work that much harder.'' That may be the companies' key to success. Sports cards are cheap enough to make the industry more or less recession-proof - a pack of 15 Topps cards costs 50 cents - and the number of hobbyists is growing. But analysts still question whether there's room for all the products. ``We do hear stories the product isn't selling through as fast as a year ago - not necessarily our stuff, but the product in general. And there's a tremendous proliferation of (card) shows these days. I think yesterday we had four within 20 miles in this area.,'' McCracken said from Upper Deck headquarters in Yorba Linda, Calif. ``When you spread yourself so thin, obviously not everyone is going to do well. There are so many products and so many dealers. But we are still seeing a lot of people come into the hobby,'' he said.
