DOC.HEAD: From Ice Cream To Smoked Quail, Mail-Order Food Market Revs Up For Holidays
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: 'Tis the season for mail-order giving, and more of the gifts criss-crossing the nation make for a transportable feast. Fruit in the mail is nothing new, but how about six pints of assorted gelato packed in dry ice? It's yours if someone doesn't mind paying $10 a pint to get it to you. And forget the mundane fruitcake. Select instead a bouquet of porcini mushrooms, a pair of smoked quail or a basket of prickly pears. The 3,600 companies that tempt the palate with mail-order edibles are competing for $1.2 billion that Americans are expected to spend on food orders this year, according to a recent study by the New York market research firm FINDSVP. Growing at an annual rate of about 10 percent, mail-order foods are likely to account for more than $3 billion in sales by the year 2000, FINDSVP said. Business whips into a frenzy during the final quarter, with some mail-order companies doing virtually all of their shipping between September and January. Entire 747 jets have been stuffed with nothing but thousands of pounds of holiday pears from Harry and David. Based in Medford, Ore., Harry and David has sales in excess of $120 million, making it perhaps the largest mail-order food company in the nation. According to FINDSVP, the top 10 food-by-mail companies control 45 percent of the market; about 3,000 companies are characterized as ``mom-and-pop'' operations, each with sales of less than $50,000 a year. Though the vast majority of food moves by ground transportation, most of the industry's growth is in overnight and two-day delivery services, which can guarantee a delicate or perishable item arrives intact. Clambake Celebrations of Cape Cod, Mass., for example, can promise a customer in Albuquerque, N.M., that she will have lobster, mussels, a few ears of corn - all packed in authentic seaweed - steaming on the stove less than 48 hours after phoning in the order. The cost: $119.95 for two. San Francisco's Gelato Classico Italian Ice Cream is just begining to offer its products by mail. Six pints - which comprise a minimum order at $59.95 - are packaged in dry ice in a foam container much like a picnic cooler. Consultant Jay Walker, who heads Ridgefield, Conn.-based Catalog Media Corp., said that though food-by-mail has been big business for a long time, ``overnight delivery ... allowed a freshness perception for millions of people who didn't believe they could get (food) fresh in the mail. And it made sure food can be given as a gift reliably.'' If you ask Federal Express, spokesman Brandon Davis will tell you his company has been a major boost to the food industry. ``Our business ... allows them to extend their business season right up to Dec. 21,'' he said. ``If you do 80 percent of your business in one or two months of the year and can extend that selling season by just two weeks, it's a tremendous boost.'' Companies with very narrow product lines can stay in business because they cater to a national - rather than local - clientele. Franklin Foods of North Franklin, Conn., for example, sells only exotic mushrooms like Polish cepes, shiitakes and porcinis. Smithfield, Va.-based Fin 'N Feather will put a smoked pheasant buffet on your table. Mr. Spear Inc. of Stockton, Calif., has cultivated a list of 25,000 fans of its colossal asparagus, its sole product. ``It's an alternative to flowers,'' said president Chip Arnett. His super-premium asparagus, which has been served at the White House, simply is ``not in sufficient enough quantities to make it available from a retail standpoint,'' he said. Consultant Walker believes the food-by-mail business is ``countercyclical'' to the economy - that is, as the recession deepens, business is likely to increase. Consumers who feel pinched for cash typically ``trade down'' when it comes to buying gifts, and food is a popular alternative because it has ``no comparative market price,'' Walker said. ``You don't know if a dozen apples from an orchard in Oregon is a $20 gift or a $40 gift,'' he said. Perusing catalogs in the coziness of one's own home and ordering with the mere push of telephone buttons has become a recreational pasttime of sorts for many Americans. ``People are sitting home and they're bored and so they pick up the phone and buy on a credit card,'' said Debbie Cohen, a national saleswoman for Melissa's World Variety Produce Inc., a Los Angeles company that specializes in shipping in exotic produce like purple potatoes, elephant garlic and prickly pears. Though consumers who buy foods through the mail make up less than 2 percent of the population, they are an affluent lot willing to pay more for convenience and a guarantee of quality. A pint of Gelato Classico costs just $3.95 in one of the company's 32 shops, but the minimum 6-pint mail order commands a $36 shipping charge. Too extravagant to buy for yourself, perhaps, but an exquisite gift to give. The mail-order business does have its limitations. Identifying customers can be costly, and it is difficult to adapt quickly to changes in consumer taste. A company that must put together its Christmas catalog by August can't suddenly decide to replace its pecan pie if cranberries become the rage. In addition, the threat of higher postal rates always looms large. Third-class postage, the rate for most catalogs, has increased more than 350 percent since 1970, and the U.S. Postal Service is planning another rate hike for February. Mail-order companies are being pressed to collect sales taxes on a higher proportion of their sales, forcing them to compete harder against local retailers. Finally, since the food business is seasonal, some companies actually are forced to shut down during spring and summer. Others try to round out their offerings with other products. Harry and David, for example, has a sister company called Jackson and Perkins, a gardening and flower concern, which helps smooth out sales throughout the year. To further entice customers, many companies have a ``thing-of-the-month'' plan. For $219.95, Harry and David will send a box of fruit once a month; for $720, Gelato will send six pints of its super-premium ice cream 12 times a year, and you get to choose among flavors like fresh ginger, double espresso and Coppa Mista, with swirls of chocolate, vanilla, pistachio and almond ice creams. Among other ``special'' services companies provide, Baskets of Elegance, a California fashioner of gourmet food baskets, sends customers a color photograph of their orders before they're shipped.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Sunday, Nov. 25

DOC.HEAD: Dayton Hudson Reports Lower Earnings In Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Dayton Hudson Corp. reported Tuesday its earnings fell 9.4 percent in the third quarter, partly because of costs associated with its acquisition of Marshall Field & Co. The retailer said its earnings in the quarter ended Nov. 3 declined to $58 million, or 70 cents per share, compared with $64 million, or 83 cents per share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 16 percent to $3.62 billion from $3.24 billion. The company said its earnings were affected by costs resulting from its employee stock ownerhip plan and the $1.04 billion acquisition of Marshall Field from BAT Industries PLC. Dayton Hudson said its operating profit, which does not take into account one-time transactions like the ESOP or acquisitions, was up 12 percent. The company fared somewhat better than other retailers whose profits were down because of sluggish consumer spending. However, profits at its department store division rose only because of an accounting change connected with the Marshall Field transaction. Department stores have been among those hit the hardest as consumers cut back their spending in response to the faltering economy and the Middle East crisis. Besides Marshall Field and Dayton's and Hudson's department stores, the company owns Mervyn's stores and Target discount stores. For the first nine months of its fiscal year, Dayton Hudson said it earned $181 million, or $2.28 per share, up from $160 million, or $2.06 per share, in the same period a year earlier. Revenue increased to $9.87 billion from $9.16 billion. Dayton Hudson also announced its capital spending for 1991 is expected to total about $1 billion. The firm plans to open 46 Target stores, 15 to 20 Mervyn's stores and two department stores. Dayton Hudson operates 708 stores in 33 states.

DOC.HEAD: U S West Pulls Out of Cable Consortium
DOC.TEXT: U S West Inc. has pulled out of a consortium set up to supply Hong Kong with cable television after a competitor won the right to build a satellite broadcast system in that city, officials said. The pullout, announced Monday, will not have a significant financial impact on the regional telephone company, U S West spokesman Ed Mattix said from the company's headquarters in this Denver suburb. U S West had a 25 percent interest in what was billed at the world's largest cable TV franchise, which also included Hong Kong-based Wharf Holdings and other partners. It would have cost about $700 million to build the system, U S West said. Last summer, a group led by billionaire Hong Kong entrepreneur Li Ka-shing won the right to construct a satellite broadcast system that would link Hong Kong's apartment buildings and bypass any cable system. The cable venture was one of several international moves by U S West in recent years. It has won a contract to build the Soviet Union's first cellular telephone system and has joined with Bell Atlantic Corp. to build a cellular system in Czechoslovakia.

DOC.HEAD: Grains, Beans Slip
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices retreated Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade as speculators expressed their disappointment in the lack of any export agreement between this country and the Soviet Union. Prices recovered somewhat before the close, but at their lows soybeans were down 13 cents a bushel from Monday's settlement and wheat was off 8 cents. Traders had bid prices up the previous two session on the belief that the Soviets were working out a big grain deal with the United States. ``It was very, very much expected'' that an announcement would come out of the meeting Monday between President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev, said John Frazier, agricultural director in Chicago for Gerald Inc. At the close, wheat was 6 cents to 8{ cents lower with the contract for December at $2.45 a bushel; corn was 3 cents to 6 cents lower with December at 42.21{ a bushel; oats were 2 cents to 3{ cents lower with December at $1.08 a bushel; and soybeans were 6{ cents to 13} cents lower with November at $5.57 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Gasoline Prices Fall 2.6 Cents, AAA Reports
DOC.TEXT: Retail gasoline prices fell 2.6 cents a gallon for the week ending Tuesday, according to a regular survey by the American Automobile Association. The average nationwide price for a gallon of self-serve regular unleaded was $1.359, still 28.4 cents higher than the price on Aug. 1, the day before Iraq invaded Kuwait, AAA said. The AAA survey found that pump prices were down across the United States except for the Mid-Atlantic region, where they rose slightly. The survey is compiled through a spot check of gasoline prices at stations across the nation.

DOC.HEAD: WPP Shares Drop More Than 70 Percent After Gloomy Earnings Forecast
DOC.TEXT: Shares in the world's biggest advertising and marketing conglomerate, WPP Group PLC, tumbled again on Tuesday, stretching their losses over two days to more than 70 percent in the wake of a glum earnings forecast. The owner of the J. Walter Thompson and Ogilvy & Mather ad agencies announced on Monday that its 1990 profit wouldn't match analysts' expectations. The announcement raised concerns about the company's ability to meet its debt payments next year, analysts said Tuesday. WPP's shares closed Tuesday at 115 pence, or $2.27, a share on London's Stock Exchange, down 164 pence, or 59 percent, from Monday's close. The shares dropped 113 pence, or $2.23, a share on Monday. They traded as high as 715 pence, or $14.09, a share in the past year. London-based WPP had no comment on the slide in its stock price, said a company spokeswoman, who declined to be identified. The speed of the fall indicated that ``people are worried that it's going to go bust,'' said David Grimbley, an advertising agency analyst with the London investment firm Hoare Govett Ltd. Analysts said the market was shaken partly because WPP Chief Executive Martin Sorrell, who has a reputation for being an adept financial officer, had appeared to have created a company invulnerable to the recession that has gripped the advertising industries in the United States and Britain. Sorrell was the top financial officer in the British advertising company Saatchi & Saatchi PLC, which grew to become the world's largest ad and marketing services company in the mid-1980s through acquisitions. He was credited for perfecting the buyout technique that enabled the buyers to keep existing management on the job by making a partial payment initially and tying addititional payments to earnings performance over several years. Sorrell left the Saatchis and shook up Madison Avenue with the first hostile takeover of an ad agency with his acquisition of J. Walter Thompson's parent company in 1987. He acquired Ogilvy & Mather two years later. The Saatchis meanwhile stumbled because of their iversification into the consulting business, and have forced to put them up for sale. With $16.1 billion in worldwide billings in 1989, WPP surpassed Saatchi and Saatchi PLC as the biggest advertising company, according to the trade publication Advertising Age. Saatchi's billings of $15.7 billion ranked it second, the publication said. WPP announced Monday that its pre-tax profit for the year wouldn't match the analysts' forecast of 110 million pounds, or $217 million, because of a ``general economic downturn,'' although results for the normally strong final two months of the year weren't in yet. The extent of the downturn in its businesses ``has only become apparent this month,'' it said. The company posted a 77 percent increase in pre-tax profit in the first six months of this year, and said at that time that its spread of business interests should insulate it from the worldwide economic downturn. WPP said in its statement that it continues to attract new business, and expects to operate ``successfully at significant levels of profitability.'' Mark Shepperd, an analyst with UBS Phillips and Drew, said Sorrell ``has been saying that `we won't be affected by the downturn.' That now has proved not to be the case.'' The London market in recent months has been nervous about stocks of heavily indebted companies, which has made trading unusually volatile. Analysts say WPP's debt amounts to some 320 million pounds, or $630 million. Grimbley said, ``There are extreme worries that the company next year might break its banking covenant.'' WPP's agreement with lenders stipulates that the company's operating profit should be 2{ times the level of interest it must pay the banks, Grimbley said. ``Profit forecasts imply that that won't be the case,'' Grimbley said. The company is unlikely to generate enough cash to pay off about 34 million pounds of long-term debt, as scheduled next year, partly because it is required to pay dividends to its preferred shareholders, Grimbley said. That means WPP might need short-term loans to pay off long-term debt, and ``in current conditions banks are not that willing to extend credit lines,'' Grimbley said. WPP's pre-tax profit, the preferred indicator of profit performance in Britain, came to 75 million pounds in 1989. It had after-tax profit of 40.5 million pounds on revenues of 4.4 billion pounds last year.

The stock market was down in lackluster trading this afternoon, halting a rally that had begun last week. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was off 26.24 points at 2,539.11 as of 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Decliners outnumbered gainers by about 2 to 1, with 503 up, 1,001 down and 456 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 134.32 million shares with one hour left to trade. Analysts were puzzled to see the stock market falling at the same time oil prices were moving down and bonds were higher. Some traders might be taking things easy with two days to go until Thanksgiving, while others might be selling stocks for end-of-the-year tax purposes, analysts said. ``I think it's kind of consolidating its recent gains,'' said Michael Metz, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Co. ``It has no new strong stimulus here. I think people are going to make this a long holiday.'' Financial stocks took a hit today, with American Express down 1 at 20|, Federal National Mortgage down ~ at 31}, Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. down 1| at 38[ and Citicorp down | at 12~. Among actively traded issues, Boeing Co. was down 4] at 42~, after being downgraded by Goldman Sachs. In other aircraft stocks, McDonnell Douglas Corp. fell 1\ to 50\, United Technologies was down ~ at 44}, Lockheed was down } at 30[ and Northrup was down [ at 16{. Grumman Corp. was up [ at 18. Among other active issues, Eli Lilley was down 1] at 67 following a report on its market share that analysts viewed as disappointing. General Electric was down 1[ at 54\. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 1.49 to 172.85. On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .52 at 295.95.

DOC.HEAD: U.A.E.'s Long-Standing Oil Minister Replaced
DOC.TEXT: Mana Saeed Otaiba, one of the longest serving oil ministers in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, was replaced Tuesday in a cabinet reshuffle in the United Arab Emirates. Otaiba was replaced as minister of petroleum and mineral wealth with the little known Yousef bin Omeir bin Yousef. Other changes among the 24-member cabinet involve a new deputy premier and new ministers in charge of foreign affairs, the interior, the economy and commerce, labor and social affairs, information, education and justice. Otaiba was the longest serving OPEC minister after Ahmed Zaki Yamani of Saudi Arabia, who served for a quarter of a century before he was removed in 1986. Otaiba, a poet born in 1946, first attended OPEC meetings as representative of the Abu Dhabi emirate from 1969 to 1971. In 1971, Abu Dhabi, Dubai and five other emirates united in the U.A.E. and Otaiba was selected as the first federal oil minister. The oil minister's poetry expressed an outspoken stand on the politics of the oil market through verse. Otaiba repeatedly walked out of OPEC meetings in protest against what he usually described as unfair stands against his oil-rich country. Sources said his replacement is an American-educated national who is a senior official at the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, ADIA, and a board member in the Abu Dhabi Insurance Co. Yousef is the son of a leading U.A.E. businessman, said the sources, who refused to be named. Abu Dhabi is the leading oil producer in the U.A.E., which now produces 2.3 million barrels per day.

DOC.HEAD: Veterans Win $14 Million Judgment Against Insurance Company
DOC.TEXT: A Superior Court jury, finding fraud and bad faith, ordered an Ohio life insurance company to pay $14.38 million to 1,800 servicemen and veterans. The class-action suit was brought against Nationwide Life Insurance Co. of Columbus, Ohio, and its San Diego-based agent, the non-profit Armed Forces Benefit & Aid Association. Policyholders from nearly every state sued when the life insurance provider arbitrarily reduced benefits and eliminated coverage at age 60. In returning the verdict Monday, the jury ordered Nationwide and its San Diego branch to pay $11.78 million in general damages and $2.6 million in punitive damages. Lou Fabro, a Nationwide spokesman, said Tuesday that company officers had no immediate comment on the verdict. ``We will be having a meeting next week to consider the verdict and our options,'' he said. ``It's very probable that we will file an appeal.'' Jurors found the company violated its contract with servicemen and veterans when it abruptly decided in 1975 to eliminate coverage when policyholders reached their 60th birthday. Only upon turning 60, however, did the policyholders learn of the change, said David Patterson, a Pittsburgh-based attorney who representedseveral of the plaintiffs. Many had been paying $9.90 a month in premiums for years, expecting lifelong coverage, he said. Instead, they were left late in life with no benefits and had to face the difficult task of trying to obtain new policies at affordable rates, Patterson said. Nationwide also in 1975 decided to reduce the benefits it paid on the policy from $10,000 to as low as $2,000. Again, there was no notification of the change to policyholders, Patterson said. In addition, the suit alleged that Nationwide's San Diego branch falsely promoted itself as an armed services affiliated vendor, persuading many who purchased a policy beginning in the 1960s that the contract was backed by the government when it was not, Patterson said. The suit was filed in 1988 in San Diego, where a sizable number of the policies were sold. The jury deliberated just over two days before finding the insurance company had violated laws against fraudulent misrepresentation, fraudulent concealment of facts, bad-faith insurance practices and conspiracy.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Smoking Adviser Seeking $1 Million Tobacco Company Grant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with six grafs to UPDATE with Philip Morris denying any offer made; further comment from researcher, picks up 5th graf pvs, Woods said; deletes now extraneous 11th graf pvs, A telephone. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: An engineer serving on an Environmental Protection Agency panel on smoking said Tuesday he is near agreement with the Philip Morris tobacco company on a $1 million research grant. James E. Woods Jr., of the Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University in Blacksburg, Va., is a member of an EPA panel reviewing an agency report that concludes that second-hand cigarette smoke causes lung cancer. The panel will meet in Washington, D.C., in December to consider the merits of the report. Woods, a mechanical engineer, said negotiations on the grant began six or eight months ago and that he submitted a proposal for the money about one month ago. He earlier had said Philip Morris had offered him the $1 million a month ago. Steven Parrish, a Philip Morris spokesman, said no offer had been made. Told of Parrish's comment, Woods then said he was wrong about the offer. The grant provides for construction of an office-like test chamber to investigate ventilation effectiveness, Woods said. Woods said he expects to reach final agreement with Philip Morris on the grant in about two months. Robert Flaak, an administrator with EPA's scientific advisory board, said the grant would not conflict with Woods' advisory role at the EPA. ``As long as it's in public knowledge, it does not constitute a conflict of interest,'' Flaak said. The existence of the grant has not been officially disclosed. Flaak said it will be disclosed at the EPA panel's December meeting. ``There's always a chance for perceived conflict of interest,'' Flaak said. ``But is this a conflict with regard to the panel? No, I don't think so. Is Dr. Woods going to represent himself fairly on the panel? Sure, he will.'' An anti-smoking group was sharply critical of the arrangement. ``It means that while he's sitting on the scientific advisory board reviewing what the EPA has come up with, he's got this carrot dangling in front of him which could affect his judgment,'' said Julia Carol, associate director of Americans for Nonsmokers' Rights, based in Berkeley, Calif. Woods said he was trying to set up the grant in such a way that it would not affect his objectivity on the smoking issue. ``For 15 years, I've been on record saying that the best way to control smoking in public buildings is to eliminate the smoker,'' he said. ``But there are situations where that can't happen.'' He said the project would be conducted in the open, a university committee would review the findings for scientific objectivity, and the results would be publicly available. ``We feel at the university we can do open research on this even though it's been funded by Philip Morris,'' Woods said. Flaak said Woods had expressed some concern about the grant. ``When I spoke with him at first about this, he was uncomfortable about the situation,'' Flaak said. ``He's unhappy that he's going to be getting research funds and having this looked at as a conflict, which it isn't. I said I didn't think it was a problem.'' Woods said his university is now considering whether to accept the grant. ``We're working with the university right now to see whether that's consistent with university policy,'' he said. Robert Axelrad, head of the EPA's indoor air division, which prepared the passive-smoking report on lung cancer, gave Woods a ringing endorsement. ``I'm not concerned about Jim Woods's objectivity. He's one of the leaders in indoor air pollution and we know him to be an honest and credible researcher,'' Axelrad said. Woods said the comments he intends to make on the EPA report will demonstrate that he is not biased toward tobacco companies. ``Wait and see what I say at the hearing,'' he said, referring to the panel's December meeting. The EPA passive-smoking panel has come under attack by anti-smoking groups who have charged that it is biased toward the tobacco industry. Six of its 16 members have ties to the Center for Indoor Air Research, which is largely financed and run by the tobacco industry. EPA officials said their lawyers have assured them that panel members' ties with the tobacco-industry research center do not constitute a conflict of interest. The executive director of the center, Max Eisenberg, agreed. ``Their association with the center isn't relevant,'' he said. ``What's important is they're the best people we can find.'' Eisenberg said researchers from the EPA and the Centers for Disease Control are also affiliated with the center.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Appoints AFL-CIO Lawyer To Review Overhaul Plan
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Tuesday appointed the AFL-CIO's top lawyer to review a plan to overhaul the Manville trust designed to speed compensation to workers poisoned by asbestos. U.S. District Judge Jack. B. Weinstein also called for establishing a panel of labor, management and others to recommend ways to devise a single, national fund to distribute all asbestos settlements. In a letter to AFL-CIO President Lane Kirkland, Weinstein said there was a need ``to stop the hemorrhaging of available assets and to substitute a structured compensation system designed to benefit claimants and companies alike.'' Weinstein appointed Washington lawyer Laurence Gold, general counsel of the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations, to review the plan. Gold, 53, has been with the AFL-CIO since 1975. Weinstein asked Kirkland to recommend an independent adviser who was ``uninfluenced by the hope of high legal fees for participation.'' In his letter, dated Monday, Weinstein said organized labor should help solve the asbestos crisis because delays in providing compensation ``undercut the ability of thousands of American workers to secure needed financial assistance.'' The judge also called on labor to help find a way to consolidate the billions of dollars available from dozens of financially ailing companies in bankruptcy court and other courts to compensate asbestos victims. Weinstein has led an effort to reform asbestos litigation, which clogs federal and state court dockets. According to some estimates, up to 70 percent of money intended for victims has gone to lawyers and others. Cases can take years to resolve. Tens of thousands of workers suffer from lung cancer and other respiratory diseases caused by breathing asbestos fibers on the job. More than 90,000 lawsuits are pending nationwide and several companies have been forced into bankruptcy court by their asbestos liability. The Manville trust faces about 130,000 claims. Weinstein ordered its restructuring earlier this year after the trust ran out of cash and offered IOUs to many victims that would not have been paid for decades. The reorganization plan calls for Manville Corp. to inject up to $520 million into the trust and allows the trust to sell $1.8 billion in Manville bonds to raise new cash. Claimants would receive sharply reduced payments, but faster. Victims with cancer and other serious disease would get some money in the plan's first two years. Those with other diseases would begin getting paid in the third year. Payments would be 45 percent of settlement values. The plan is expected to face legal challenges, and hearings are planned in New York, New Orleans, Chicago and San Francisco. Weinstein favors creating a single fund to make payments based on a proportion of available assets, eliminating long and costly litigation. Kirkland agreed to help, saying ``recent events demonstrate that the current system for compensating the working people who have been injured by exposure to asbestos is seriously flawed.'' Asbestos and products containing the mineral were used widely in many industries for decades, with heavy use at shipyards around the country during World War II and the Korean War. Asbestos, which has natural heat resistance and insulation properties, later was found to cause lung cancer and other serious dieases. Thousands of victims have died before receiving compensation.

DOC.HEAD: Hercules Taps Gossage as New CEO
DOC.TEXT: The president of a Hercules Inc. subsidiary has been named chairman and chief executive officer of the parent company, officials announced Tuesday. Thomas L. Gossage, 56, president of Aqualon Co., takes over at the Wilmington-based chemical company Jan. 1. He succeeds David S. Hollingsworth, who had announced plans to retire. Gossage, who worked for Monsanto for 26 years, joined Hercules in 1988 as president of Hercules Specialty Chemicals Co. In 1989, he was named president and chief executive officer of Aqualon, a Hercules wholly-owned subsidiary based in Wilmington that makes water-soluble polymers. Gossage also joined Hercules' board of directors that year and was made a senior vice president. ``Mr. Gossage has broad knowledge and experience in the chemical industry, both internationally and in the U.S. In selecting him, the board recognizes that during his career, Tom Gossage has demonstrated the management and leadership skills needed to lead a diverse, worldwide company like Hercules through the 1990s,'' Hollingsworth said.

DOC.HEAD: Plans 20 Percent Cut in Payments to TV Network Affiliates
DOC.TEXT: CBS Inc. announced a 20 percent slash in payments to television network affiliates next year for carrying its programs, the media giant's latest move to cushion the financial shock of heavy spending on sports programming and an industrywide advertising slump. CBS spent $153 million on payments to its 208 station affiliates this year, so the cut on Jan. 1 should save the media company about $30 million in 1991. But CBS also risks alienating or driving away affiliates. Some rely heavily on the network compensation payment as a source of revenue. ``We know this is not a popular decision,'' said CBS spokesman George Schweitzer. ``But we are doing this to maintain the financial support of the network business so they can benefit.'' He said CBS has been spending more than either NBC or ABC on payments to affiliates. NBC spent $132 million this year and ABC spent $110 million. The CBS announcement comes a day after the company said it expects to post a loss in the fourth quarter and lower earnings next year. It cited the deteriorating national advertising climate and the costs of entertainment and sports programs for its financial forecast. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, CBS lost $3.75 to $156 a share after dropping $4 a share on Monday. CBS executives met privately Monday with representatives of its network affiliates. Phil Jones, a former head of the CBS Affiliate Advisory Board and an executive at Meredith Corp.'s broadcasting group in Des Moines, Iowa, said, ``People were really disappointed'' by the CBS decision. ``Its is a tough environment and some of them already feel somewhat battered. But their argument about their losses are pretty compelling,'' he said. CBS told the affiliate representatives that they were making efforts to control costs in every phase of the company's operation in drafting the 1991 budget. The company said it was compelled to address affiliate payments also. In some ways, the affiliate payment system is outdated. It was started as a way to ensure that the networks have a wide circulation for their programs so they could charge advertisers for delivering a national audience. But the development of cable television has taken a different approach. Cable networks charge system operators for the right to carry their services. Nonetheless, broadcast TV affiliates have in recent years mounted strong resistance to efforts to reduce comnpensation. CBS feels it is in a better position this year to make the cuts, however. Schweitzer noted that CBS is the ratings leader in daytime and Saturday morning television and has shown improvement in prime time. CBS has spent a lot to get better programs, he said. The network has also spent heavily on obtaining sports rights over the past year, including major league baseball, professional football and the Winter Olympics. NBC has not yet announced plans on affilate compensation for next year, a spokesman said. The ABC network plans no across the board cuts but is reviwing compensation on a station-by-staion basis as it has since 1988, a spokeswoman said. CBS is planning to help cushion the blow of the compensation cut for its affiliates, Schweitzer said. CBS will give the local stations more commercial time in news and sports programming to sell to local advertisers. In addition, CBS said it would increase local commercial time on broadcasts of the 1992 Winter Olympics. chweitzer said the extra ad time, which would be taken from the time the network uses for station identifications and other non-revenue producing activities, could mean up to $12 million in extra revenue for affiliates. ``We have mutual stake in each other's financial health and viability,'' said Tony Malara, president of CBS Affliate Relations. ``Given our improved programming performance, we need to insure that our financial picture will be sufficient to continue to support it.''

DOC.HEAD: Low Prices Close Mills Until Market Improves
DOC.TEXT: Roseurg Forest Products is closing three mills and laying off 700 people for at least a month in hopes that the market for lumber and plywood will rebound, the company said Tuesday. Layoffs at lumber and plywood mills have been common in the Northwest as housing construction has slumped nationwide at the same time log prices have risen regionally. Timber supplies have shrunk amid efforts to preserve habitat for the northern spotted owl and public demands for less logging. Roseburg personnel director Bob Wilson notified the Western Council of Industrial Workers Monday that plants in Dillard and Dixonville, employing 400 people, would be closed from Nov. 27 to after Jan. 1. A notice at a third plant in Anderson, Calif., said it would shut down Nov. 30 though the first of the year, said Lou Vess, secretary at the International Woodworkers of America Local 3-433. The mill employs 300. Earlier this fall, the company had shut down two mills in Northern California, laid off 120 workers at another plant and eliminated a relief shift at its Dillard complex. Roseburg, the nation's largest privately held wood products company, has 14 mills and employs about 4,500 in southern Oregon and Northern California. ``This is our first real cutback,'' said Roger Bissonnette, assistant business agent for Western Council Local 2949. ``Most of the others in the area have had their cutbacks.'' Bissonnette said workers had expected bad news because of market conditions and reduced timber harvests on federal lands. ``It's real tough coming right before the holidays,'' said Ted Rabern, business agent for the union. ``But I honestly don't think this was an easy decision to make for the company.''

DOC.HEAD: Marathon Dissolves Marathon Petroleum Subsidiary
DOC.TEXT: Marathon Oil Co. announced Tuesday it was dissolving Marathon Petroleum Co., one of its wholly owned subsidiaries. Marathon Oil, whose parent is Pittsburgh-based USX Corp., said the realignment consolidates operations by shifting all of the assets and business activities of Marathon Petroleum and merging them into Marathon Oil Co. J. Louis Frank, who is now Marathon Petroleum's president, was named executive vice presidcent of Marathon Oil, with continuing responsibilities for refining, marketing and transportation activities. Carl P. Giardini was named executive vice president of Marathon Oil, responsible for oil exploration and production operations. Both Frank and Giardini were also named to the USX corporate policy committee, filling two energy-related vacancies on the panel.

DOC.HEAD: Lack of Trade Pact Sends Grain, Soybean Futures Skidding
DOC.TEXT: Grain traders sent prices into a skid at the Chicago Board of Trade Tuesday, expressing their disappointment over the lack of any food aid plan for the Soviet Union. Wheat lost 7 to 8 cents a bushel and hit contract lows across the board. On other markets, livestock, meat, petroleum and precious metals futures were all losers. During the two previous sessions at the Board of Trade, traders had run grain and soybean prices up on rumors that a huge grain deal was in the works. ``There are some pretty dire stories coming out of Russia about the lack of vegetable oil, flour, potatoes, the lack of bread, even the lack of salt,'' said John Frazier, agricultural director in Chicago for Gerald Inc. ``It was very, very much expected'' that an announcement would come out of the meeting Monday between President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev, he said. There may be an agreement yet, Frazier said, but the disappointment was too great for the traders who had bought on the rumors. Wheat settled 6 cents to 8{ cents lower with the December contract at $2.45\ a bushel; corn was 3 cents to 5} cents lower with December at $2.21} a bushel; oats were 2 cents to 3\ cents lower with December at $1.08\ a bushel; and soybeans were 6{ cents to 12 cents lower with November at $5.57 a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were down across the board at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The government's seven-state cattle-on-feed report released after the close on Monday showed an increase in the number of cattle placed in feedlots during October. This pressured prices for the more distant cattle futures contracts when the October placements would be coming to market, said Paul Hare, an analyst in Chicago with Linnco Futures Inc. Pork prices broke sharply, with bellies losing the daily trading limit of 2 cents a pound. Live hog futures were confronted with a weaker cash trade, went into a decline and triggered sell stops on the way down, Hare said. The market also was expecting lower cash hog prices again on Wednesday as packers, faced with thinner profits, resist paying more for the animals. Traders said the pork complex also suffered from the absence of any trade deal with the Soviets. Live cattle settled .05 cent to .72 cent lower with the December contract at 79.12 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .30 cent lower to .05 cent higher with January at 87.60 cents a pound; live hogs were .50 cent to 1.15 cents lower with December at 53.10 cents a pound; and frozen pork bellies fell the 2 cent limit with February at 70.20 cents a pound. Precious metals futures declined on the Commodity Exchange in New York, owing their weakness only partially to lower oil prices. ``People expect the metals to follow oil tick for tick, but they haven't and they're not going to,'' said William O'Neill, an analyst in New York with Merrill Lynch Futures. He also attributed the decline to selling in Europe, options-related selling at the Comex and the nation's general economic malaise. Gold settled $3.80 to $3.90 lower with December at $378.50 a troy ounce; silver was 2.8 cents to 3.3 cents lower with December at $4.11 a troy ounce. Petroleum futures declined sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange as traders awaited the release of weekly industry production and stocks data, which were interpreted as bullish when they came out after the close. There was little fresh news from the Persian Gulf. Light sweet crude oil was off 52 cents to $1.81 with the January contract settling at $28.91 a barrel; heating oil was 1.30 cents to 2.85 cents lower with December at 84.45 cents a gallon; and unleaded gasoline was 2.25 cents to 2.89 cents lower with December at 77.47 cents a gallon.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Higher as Sterling Slumps; Gold Falls
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against most major currencies Tuesday, climbing most steeply against the British pound after Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was forced into a second-round vote to retain her post. Gold prices fell. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold settled at $377.60 a troy ounce, off $3.80 from Monday. Republic National Bank also quoted a late bid of $377.60, down $3.80. The pound slumped against the dollar as well as other currencies after the results of the vote for British Conservative Party leadership were disclosed, traders said. Mrs. Thatcher failed by only two votes to gain a victory over former Defense Minister Michael Heseltine, forcing a second vote next week. But ``there was information at least that she was supported by a couple of her cabinet officers, so sterling is closing well off the lows,'' said John McCarthy, chief currency dealer at Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank in New York. In London, the pound fell to $1.9695 from $1.9745 late Monday. In New York, one pound cost $1.9660, cheaper than $1.9750 late Monday. The dollar ended marginally higher against the Japanese yen and the German mark, but trading was too sparse ahead of the Thanksgiving holiday to read much into these movements, McCarthy said. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 128.93 Japanese yen from 128.95 yen at Monday's close. Later, in London, it was quoted at 128.65 yen. In New York, one dollar bought 128.85 yen at late afternoon, up from 128.75 yen late Monday. In Europe, the dollar traded at 1.4760 German marks, up from 1.4745 Monday. In New York, one dollar bought 1.4740 marks, compared with 1.4717 marks the day before. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.2450 Swiss francs, unchanged; 4.9760 French francs, up from 4.9645; 1,109 Italian lire, up from 1,108; 1.1593 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1634. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday, included: 1.2470 Swiss francs, up from 1.2465; 4.9780 French francs, up from 4.9745; 1.6650 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6628; 1,110.50 Italian lire, up from 1,110.25; and 1.1598 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1628. Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $377.75 a troy ounce, down from $379.60 late Monday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $377.50, down from $378.75 late Monday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $2.75 an ounce to close at $380.30. Silver prices fell. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.11 a troy ounce, down three cents from late Monday. In London, silver fell to a late bid of $4.10 a troy ounce, from $4.15 late Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Joint Venture To Supply Soviet Telephone Switch Market
DOC.TEXT: Italtel SpA, an Italian telecommunications equipment maker 20 percent owned by AT&T, signed a joint venture accord Tuesday with a Soviet company to produce digital phone exchanges. Telezaria, as the joint venture is named, is 60 percent owned by the Soviet company Krasnaja Zarja and 40 percet by the Italian partner. Once it runs at full capacity, Telezaria expects to supply 25 percent of the Soviet telecommunications market, which plans to have 100 million telephone lines installed by the year 2000, according to a statement released in Milan. A spokeswoman for Italtel said her company will supply the technology and equipment, while Krasnaja Zarja will contribute the factory space and some of the production equipment for the new company. She said the venture would start production in 1992 and reach capacity of 1.5 million lines a year in about 5 years. Italtel is 80 percent owned by Stet Societa Finanziaria Telefonica PA, the Italian state holding company for the telecommunications industry, and 20 percent by American Telephone & Telegraph Co. Leningrad-based Krasnaja Zarja is the Soviet Union's largest manufacturer in the telecommunications industry. Under the accord, the Soviet Union is committed to buy 85 percent of the joint venture's output. The remaining 15 percent will be sold to countries with ``favorable trade agreements'' with the Soviet Union, the companies said.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Decline On Middle East Developments
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices fell sharply Tuesday as events surrounding the Middle East convinced traders that a military confrontation with Iraq was unlikely anytime soon. The January contract for light sweet crude, the benchmark blend of U.S. oil, fell $1.81 to $28.91 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, erasing a $1.72 gain from the previous session. Prices continued to bounce up and down in response to developments in the Middle East. On Monday, prices shot up after Iraqi President Saddam Hussein announced a military buildup. But Tuesday, ``(President) Bush's failure to secure an agreement with Gorbachev on the U.N. resolution to authorize military action was viewed as bearish by the market,'' said Andrew Lebow, an analyst with E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc. The Soviets on Monday and Tuesday rebuffed Bush's efforts to win support for the resolution authorizing military force against Iraq, and oil traders believed this made a confrontation - and a cutoff of oil supplies from the Persian Gulf - less likely. Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev met on Monday, and Secretary of State James A. Baker and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze met Tuesday. Peter Beutel, an analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc. said the oil market also took a second look at Iraqi plans to move another 250,000 troops into Kuwait and decided Monday's announcement by the Baghdad government did not really exacerbate the Persian Gulf crisis. ``The troops have not yet been moved,'' Beutel said. ``Indications are they are not high-quality troops.'' Analysts also said the political troubles of British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher also had a dampening effect on prices. Mrs. Thatcher fell two votes short of defeating a challenge to her leadership of the Conservative Party, and faces another vote next week. The market believed that the British political turmoil makes Mrs. Thatcher less likely to enter into a military conflict in the Middle East, analysts said. Lebow said oil prices were also pulled lower by technical forces in the market. ``The break below $30 was also viwed as bearish,'' he said. Prices for refined products traded on the mercantile exchange also slipped. The December contract for home heating oil fell 2.31 cents to 84.45 cents a gallon, while wholesale unleaded gasoline for December delivery tumbled 2.89 cents to 77.47 cents a gallon. After the close of trading, the American Petroleum Institute announced that crude oil inventories fell slightly in the week ended Friday, and gasoline and heating oil stocks also declined. The figures could move prices higher on Wednesday, although the market is still focused primarily on the Middle East. In natural gas trading, the December contract rose to $2.380 per 1,000 cubic feet from $2.350 on Monday.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS closing Dow Jones average in 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: The stock market fell Tuesday as traders ignored the potential economic benefit of sharply lower oil prices and ended a rally that began last week. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 35.15 points to 2,530.20. Declining issues outnumbered gainers by about 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 511 up, 1,043 down and 450 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 161.17 million shares, up from 140.95 million on Monday. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 195.60 million shares. Analysts were puzzled to see the stock market falling at the same time oil prices were plunging and bonds were rising. ``The last few days, when oil was higher and bonds were cheaper, it did better,'' said Danny Williams at Dillon Read & Co. Inc. ``Today, you've got oil lower and bonds higher and it's going down.'' Some traders might have been taking things easy with two days to go until Thanksgiving, while others were selling stocks for end-of-the-year tax purposes, analysts said. ``It's really being led down by the financial stocks,'' said Michael Metz, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Co. ``It's as much concern about the market rally failing as anything else.'' The Dow Jones industrial average had posted an overall gain of 61.64 points last week, followed by a gain of 15.10 points on Monday, before Tuesday's turn to the downside. As the financial issues took a hit, American Express was down 1[ at 20{, Federal National Mortgage dropped 1 to 31|, Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. was down 2 at 37}, Manufacturers Hanover fell 1[ to 18{ and Citicorp fell } to 12}. Among actively traded issues, Boeing Co. was down 4| at 42|, after being downgraded by Goldman Sachs. In other aircraft stocks, McDonnell Douglas Corp. fell 1| to 49~, United Technologies was down 1 at 44|, Lockheed was down 1[ at 29} and Northrup was down [ at 16{. Grumman Corp. was down \ at 17|. Among other active issues, Eli Lilley was down 2] at 66 following a report on its market share that analysts viewed as disappointing. General Electric was down 2[ at 53\. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market dropped $31.139 billion, or 1.04 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 1.86 to 172.48. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 4.65 to 369.66, and S&P's 500-stock composite index dropped 4.03 to 315.31. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market fell 4.44 to 348.29. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 296.01, down .46.

DOC.HEAD: GM Recalls 520,000 Cars for Potential Brake Light Malfunctions
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. said Tuesday it was recalling 520,000 1989-90 model cars for potentially defective brake lights. The No. 1 automaker is recalling certain 1989-90 Pontiac Grand Prix, Oldsmobile Cutlass Supremes, Buick Regals and 1990 Chevrolet Lumina cars, spokesman David Sloan said. The passenger cars may have a faulty electrical switch that could result in the stoplamps not lighting when brakes are applied, or staying on all the time, he said. Also, the company said, if the cruise-control function is engaged, the cruise may go to the ``resume'' mode when brakes are released. When that occurs, the cruise control can be disconnected by moving the cruise switch to the off position or by reapplying the brakes, GM said in a statement. The normal brakes are not impaired by any of the conditions, GM said. Since 1989, GM has learned of 10 accidents, including four minor injuries, in which the defect allegedly was present, Sloan added. None of the accidents involved fatalities. GM sent notices to affected owners this week. GM dealers will perform inspections and replace the stoplamp switch at no charge, Sloan said.

DOC.HEAD: Lotus Opens Another Copyright Suit Against Competitor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS in 8th graf, Mosaic officials, that unidentified person spoke to Mosaic, sted Bezjian.
DOC.TEXT: In its latest courtroom fight over copyright protection, Lotus Development Corp. went to trial Tuesday against a small software firm accused of imitating Lotus' popular 1-2-3 business spreadsheet program. The case marked an extension of a trial Lotus won earlier this year. Lotus, based in Cambridge, filed suit in 1987 against two firms, Paperback Software International of Berkeley, Calif., and Mosaic Software of Cambridge. It argued that the keyboard commands and on-screen images, the so-called ``user interface,'' were an expression of an idea and thus were protected by copyright laws. The company claimed the defendants virtually duplicated the user interface of 1-2-3. Lotus won its case over Paperback Software in June, but Mosaic had to drop out of that trial because an attorney for the company became ill. Michael Collora, an attorney representing Mosaic, said on Tuesday his client was bound by the decision against Paperback Software in the proceedings that began Tuesday against Mosaic. But Mosaic officials insisted they received permission from Lotus to develop a program that would be similar to 1-2-3. According to Mosaic's defense, Mosaic president Richard Bezjian displayed a software program at a 1983 computer show, after the unveiling of 1-2-3. Mosaic officials said Lotus founder Mitchell Kapor saw the program and threatened to sue, but then an unidentified Lotus employee later assured Mosaic that Lotus would not sue. Lotus argued that Mosaic has never been able to produce this person. Mosaic continued work on the program and unveiled a different version two years later, calling it ``Twin Classic'' and praising the similarities with 1-2-3. Mosaic also argued that Lotus had the opportunity to sue earlier but waited until other competitors came out with 1-2-3 clones. Since its victory over Paperback Software, Lotus has filed copyright infringement suits against two other competitors, Santa Cruz Operation Inc. and Borland International Inc.

The government said home building plunged 6 percent in October, extending the longest construction slide on record and sinking housing starts to their lowest level since the 1981-82 recession. Industry observers pointed to shrinking consumer confidence and the growing inability of builders to obtain credit as causes of the nine-month decline reported Tuesday by the Commerce Department. Many believe the slide will continue into mid-1991. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Four years after he was linked to a government probe of insider trading in the takeover-crazed stock market, Michael Milken finally faces his day of reckoning. Milken's saga ends Wednesday in a Manhattan federal courtroom, where the former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. executive faces up to 28 years in prison for violating securities, tax and conspiracy statutes in the most celebrated case of high-finance crime. He's expected to get at least 3 years. --- NEW YORK - CBS Inc. announced a 20 percent slash in payments to television network affiliates next year for carrying its programs, the media giant's latest move to cushion the financial shock of heavy spending on sports programming and an industrywide advertising slump. CBS spent $153 million on payments to its 208 station affiliates this year, so the cut on Jan. 1 announced Tueslday should save the media company about $30 million in 1991. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Bumper crops elsewhere in the world have lowered prospects for U.S. grain exports in the coming year, an Agriculture Department report said. But the monthly report released Tuesday by the department's Economic Research Service also showed that the net cash income of farmers this year is still expected to be a record, probably in the range of $59 billion to $63 billion. --- WASHINGTON - The wife of Genentech Inc.'s president settled insider trading charges that she tipped her brother to merger talks the biotechnology concern was holding with Roche Holding Ltd. Without admitting or denying wrongdoing, Mollie E. Raab, agreed Tuesday to pay $162,400 in penalties to settle a civil action filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission at federal court in San Francisco. Neither Genentech, nor her husband, G. Kirk Raab, chief executive officer of the San Francisco-based pharmaceutical and biotechnology company, were accused of any wrongdoing. --- NEW YORK (AP) - A federal judge appointed the AFL-CIO's top lawyer to review a plan to overhaul the Manville trust designed to speed compensation to workers poisoned by asbestos. U.S. District Judge Jack. B. Weinstein also called Tuesday for establishing a panel of labor, management and others to recommend ways to devise a single, national fund to distribute all asbestos settlements. --- MOSCOW (AP) - The weakening ruble would become the only legal currency in the Soviet Union under legislation tentatively approved by one chamber of the national legislature. The official Tass news agency said Tuesday the proposed law was aimed at halting ``dollarization'' of the Soviet economy - the rapidly growing use of U.S. dollars in both the official and underground economies. --- PHILADELPHIA (AP) - The collapse of Laventhol & Horwath, the country's seventh largest accounting firm, has forced large-scale layoffs and left clients searching for help with their year-end audits. The Philadelphia-based firm Tuesday announced it would file a Chapter 11 bankruptcy petition on Wednesday. The announcement came after two days of speculation the accounting firm would fold under the weight of several lawsuits. --- LONDON (AP) - Shares in the world's biggest advertising and marketing conglomerate, WPP Group PLC, tumbled for the second straight day, stretching losses to more than 70 percent in the aftermath of a glum earnings forecast. The owner of the J. Walter Thompson and Ogilvy & Mather ad agencies announced on Monday that its 1990 profit wouldn't match analysts' expectations, which began a wave of stock selling. The selloff resumed Tuesday when analysts said the earnings forecast cast doubt on WPP's ability to pay debts next year. ---

The stock market fell Tuesday as traders ignored the potential economic benefit of sharply lower oil prices. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 35.15 points to 2,530.20. The dollar was mostly higher while gold prices declined. Commodities prices slumped, with a variety of bearish developments affecting the grain, oil, livestock and precious metal markets. Bond prices closed higher, rallying on the drop in commodities.

DOC.HEAD: Charges 9 People, R.I. Firm in Penny Stock Fraud
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Enn in penultimate graf is correct
DOC.HEAD: With AM-SEC-Genentech, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Federal securities regulators accused nine people and a Rhode Island brokerage firm Tuesday of a massive manipulation of seven penny stocks over a two-year period. Among those named in the civil complaint filed at federal court in New York were three people convicted of stock manipulation-related charges in the Haas Securities scandal. Those three were Eugene K. Laff and Stanley Aslanian Jr., former principals of Haas, and Henry W. Lorin, a stock promoter and director of three companies in which stock was manipulated. Lorin and Aslanian, who pleaded guilty to conspiracy charges and cooperated with prosecutors, both testified at Laff's 1989 trial, which ended with his conviction on five counts of conspiracy, securities fraud, mail fraud and obstruction of justice. Lorin was later sentenced to three years in prison, Aslanian to one and Laff to five years. The case against Laff stemmed from the government's first fraud investigation after the 1987 stock market crash. Haas Securities, a brokerage house, collapsed nine days after the crash. Prosecutors maintained that the firm's scheme to artificially raise the prices of penny stocks - low-cost, high-risk securities traded over the counter - couldn't be maintained after the market dropped and the share prices fell. Laff, Haas' chairman, was convicted of being part of a scheme to artificially inflate the penny stock prices by creating a false demand for the shares and then selling out his firm's own stake before the prices collapsed. The SEC complaint alleged that from October 1985 throught October 1987, the defendants schemed to defraud the investors by manipulating the over-the-counter market for seven penny stocks: Big O Tires Inc.; Cliff Engle Ltd.; Digital Metcom Inc.; Flores de New Mexico Inc.; Fountain Powerboat Industries Inc.; TS Industries Inc. and Tunex International Inc. The scheme included planting negative news articles about the companies, taking trading positions that would profit from a decline in the stocks' prices and significant selling of manipulated stocks by corporate insiders, the SEC charged. The complaint alleged that the manipulation scheme collapsed after Haas ceased operations, causing the total market value for the shares still held by investors to plunge more than $644 million. Also named in the civil complaint were Capital Shares Inc., the North Providence, R.I. brokerage, and its owner, Lawrence Caito; Toni Vallen, a New York investment adviser; Rosario Ruggiero, and Edward J. Barter, both former Haas employees; Enn Kunnapas, an employee of Lorin's, and Paul L. Miano, a head trader at J.T. Moran & Co. Inc., a brokerage that went out of business in January. The SEC is seeking court orders barring the defendants from future alleged securities law violations as well as repayment of alleged illegal profits by Capital Shares, Ruggiero, Laff and Vallen.

DOC.HEAD: Digital Announces Plant Closing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Jeffry in 4th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: Digital Equipment Corp. announced Tuesday it would close a plant in Phoenix and eliminate more than 400 jobs, which might require the first layoffs in company history. Digital, which has been slashing its payroll for months to cope with a slump in computer sales, said it would try to find other slots in the company for some workers. Also, Digital plans to offer a financial package similar to a severance program the company has used to encourage workers to voluntarily leave their jobs. ``We hope to do this without a layoff and preserve choice, but it's possible we may not be able to do that,'' Digital spokesman Jeffry Gibson said. Digital President Kenneth Olsen has said repeatedly the computer company hopes to avoid layoffs, but he could not offer any guarantees. The Phoenix facility employs 476 people, down from a payroll of 1,800 workers several years ago, Gibson said. No timetable has been set for the actual closing or for shifting businesses away from the site. The Phoenix site has several operations, including a low-volume manufacturing plant for printers and a distribution center. Digital, which recorded its first-ever quarterly loss earlier this year, cut its payroll by 3,000 positions in its last fiscal year. This year, the company plans further cuts of 5,000l news wires for Sunday Nov. 25. LaserPhoto.
DOC.BYLINE: OUT OF THE FRYING PAN: Cook Becomes Boss of Restaurant Chain
DOC.TEXT: NASHVILLE, Tenn. - When James W. Arnett flunked out of college and went to work as a Shoney's Restaurant cook, he had no plans to one day run the company. Fear of failure sent Arnett, 41, to work to repay $1,400 in tuition money spent by his father, a retired Marine. Today that same fear drives him as president and chief operating officer of Shoney's Inc., a company of family restaurants and hotels in 30 states. Slug BC-Personal File-Arnett. By Business Writer Phil West. Moving Wednesday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday Nov. 25. LaserPhoto planned.
DOC.BYLINE: OIL'S WELL THAT ENDS WELL: Alaska Luring Back Tourists Following Spill
DOC.TEXT: ANCHORAGE, Alaska - To try to lure back tourists lost after the Exxon Valdez oil spill, the Alaska Visitors Association put out an ad featuring a close-up of Marilyn Monroe's face. The famous beauty mark on Marilyn's face was missing. The ad explained that she was beautiful even without her mole, just as oil spilled in one part of Alaska did not diminish all of the state's natural wonders. Whether that ad deserves the credit or not, tourism officials say business is on the upswing again, after a sharp drop following the oil spill in March 1989. Slug BC-Alaska Tourism. By Mark Baumgartner. Moved Monday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Nov. 25. Also moving on general news wires. Mailed print subscribers get 4 b&w photos. ColorFoto subscribers get 4 35mm slides.
DOC.BYLINE: BASEBALL CARD PITCH: Topps Hoping '91 Campaign Is A Big Hit
DOC.TEXT: NEW YORK - Did your mother throw away all your baseball cards? Would you like to get some back? You may get the chance next year. Topps Chewing Gum Inc. is celebrating the 40th anniversary of its first card by inserting 300,000 vintage cards - including the 1952 Mickey Mantle worth $8,000 - into its regular 1991 packs that sell for 50 cents. The promotion is a marketing coup for the leader in the sports card business, at a time when the competition has never been so hot. Slug BC-Sports Cards. By Business Writer Jill Arabas. Moving Tuesday on FFF-level news wires for Monday, Nov. 26. With Graphic. . m
DOC.BYLINE: FISHY BUSINESS: Puerto Rico's Once-Thriving Tuna Industry Floundering
DOC.TEXT: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico - Puerto Rico's tuna fish industry, which accounts for more than half U.S. cannery production, is struggling to stay afloat in a sea of Far East competition and efforts to save dolphins. This year, two of the island's five tuna canneries closed and one has reduced operations, putting about 2,000 people out of work. Slug BC-Tuna Woes. By Jaime Pieras. Moving Wednesday on FFF-level news wires for Monday, Nov. 26.
DOC.BYLINE: DER COKE VS. DER PEPSI: Germany New Battleground For Soft-Drink Giants
DOC.TEXT: ATLANTA - A flashpoint of the Cold War is now a focus of the cola war. U.S. soft drink makers Coca-Cola and Pepsi-Cola have been pouring millions of dollars into establishing a presence in what formerly was East Germany, gearing up to win the battle for taste buds in a region that for almost half a century was closed to such Western products. DOC.HEAD: Bankruptcy Judge Reviewing Reorganization Plan
DOC.TEXT: A federal bankruptcy judge Tuesday reviewed a $300 million reorganization plan for Sharon Steel Corp., but did not sign proposed orders. Judge Warren Bentz wanted to consider the matter further, according to his law clerk, Ronald Cook. Bentz has said previously that creditors for the nation's 18th-largest steelmaker apparently favored the plan 9-to-1. Bernhard Schaffler, special counsel to the bankruptcy trustee, has said that the plan was expected to gain approval. The plan could be enacted by mid-December.
